summary: Chinese geneticist He Jiankui revealed at a summit that he has successfully genetically edited babies using the CRISPR-Cas9 technology, claiming the goal is to protect them from HIV infection. He said another volunteer is pregnant as part of the research, despite concerns from scientists and the Chinese government that the work was conducted in secrecy and is unethical. He Jiankui expressed pride in his work, stating it could be used to help millions with inherited diseases, but critics argue that safety issues have not been addressed.

site_title: The challenges facing key players at the G-20 summit
summary: Global leaders will gather for the G-20 summit in Buenos Aires, dominated by tensions over trade between China and the US. US President Donald Trump will meet with Chinese President Xi Jinping to discuss trade disputes, while Trump's first substantive talks with Russian President Vladimir Putin will also take place. Other key players, including British Prime Minister Theresa May, Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, and Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, will also attend. The summit comes as global economies face challenges, including an economic crisis in Argentina and ongoing tensions between Russia and Ukraine.

site_title: Amazon unveils server chip, challenging Intel on price
summary: Amazon has unveiled its own server chip, the Graviton, to challenge Intel's dominance in the market. The Graviton chips will support new versions of Amazon's EC2 cloud-computing service, offering a "significantly lower cost" compared to Intel processors. Estimated to be up to 45% cheaper, the new service aims to differentiate Amazon from its competitors and meet specific use cases for customers. This move marks Amazon's second attempt to challenge Intel's server chip business, following a similar effort with AMD processors in November.

site_title: US: Stocks jump on 'dovish' speech by Fed chief, Dow +2.5%
summary: US stocks surged on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average jumping 2.5% to 25,366.43, its best session since March. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also rose, with gains of 2.3% and 3.0%, respectively. The Federal Reserve chairman's "dovish" speech was seen as a sign that interest rates may not rise further, boosting investor confidence. The strong market performance came after a week of mixed signals on US-EU trade talks and tariff threats.

site_title: UK GDP will suffer 10.7% hit in worst case no-deal Brexit: report
summary: A UK government report predicts a 10.7% hit to GDP if the country crashes out of the EU with no new trade arrangements, making it the worst-case scenario. This would lead to a 15-year decline in GDP, with the UK being poorer under all exit options modeled in the study. The report's findings highlight the potential economic consequences of a no-deal Brexit.

site_title: All the winners and losers of Black Friday this year
summary: Amazon recorded its biggest shopping day in history on Cyber Monday, with over 18 million toys and 13 million fashion items sold. Other winners include Target, Walmart, and Best Buy, which benefited from online shopping and the absence of Toys "R" Us. However, physical stores saw a 6.6% decline in sales during the Black Friday period, with brick-and-mortar retailers such as Sears Holdings Corp struggling. FedEx plans to hire 55,000 temporary workers to meet holiday demand, while UPS increased delivery days to six to handle the surge.

images.alt_text: Big-box retailers still know how to pull off a dynamite Black Friday.

Amazon customers ordered more than 18 million toys and 13 million fashion items on Black Friday and Cyber Monday combined.The holiday rush is also a boon for parcel delivery services such as FedEx Corp.

site_title: Why a US-China tariff ceasefire is coming soon
summary: A US-China tariff ceasefire is expected, despite no agreement being reached at the G20 summit. Four reasons support this prediction: (1) China's willingness to soften economic austerity policies to avoid further slowdown, (2) Trump's calculation to secure a "big win" ahead of the 2020 election, (3) Trump's history of negotiating a tactical retreat after escalating rhetoric, and (4) the fact that a draw or ceasefire would be acceptable for both parties, allowing Trump to secure personal kudos and China to avoid losing the early phase of the conflict.

site_title: US, China and the tech war: Implications for Asia
summary: The US has proposed sweeping export controls on emerging and foundational technologies, including artificial intelligence, robotics, and biotechnology, in response to concerns about China's alleged intellectual property theft. The move aims to balance the bilateral military balance and impact on the global economy. The US Bureau of Industry and Security invited industries and the public to offer comments on the proposal, which is expected to affect major economies leveraging the Fourth Industrial Revolution. The proposed controls are seen as a significant escalation in the tech war between the US and China.

site_title: More LNG traders prefer to keep their fuel inside vessels
summary: LNG traders are opting to keep their multimillion-dollar cargoes inside vessels due to uncertain demand and rising prices. With recent advancements in technology, LNG can now be stored at minus 162 degrees Celsius for longer periods, reducing the need for immediate delivery. This decision is driven by the hope that prices will rise, making the cargo more valuable. The trend is unusual in the established oil market, where stationary cargoes are not common, and highlights the evolving nature of the LNG market.

images.alt_text: There are about 30 vessels currently flagged as floating storage globally, two-thirds of which are in Asia, the biggest LNG consuming region, according to cargo-tracking company Kpler SAS.

site_title: China's WuXi AppTec launches U$1b HK listing
summary: WuXi AppTec, a Shanghai-listed Chinese medical tech platform, has launched a Hong Kong listing of up to $1.06 billion, despite weak markets and a string of poorly performing IPOs. The company, which provides pharmaceutical research and development services, aims to raise funds to expand globally and invest in seven China projects. Goldman Sachs, Huatai Financial, and Morgan Stanley are sponsoring the IPO, which is expected to be priced on December 6 and list on December 13.

site_title: Dollar holds near recent highs ahead of Powell speech
summary: The US dollar rose for a fourth consecutive day on November 28, 2018, as investors sought the safe-haven currency amid rising trade tensions. Despite expectations of a potential interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve, a speech by Chairman Jerome Powell may curb gains. The dollar reached its highest level in two weeks, but later fell back as the euro and British pound made gains. Investors are also watching the G-20 summit and the escalating trade tensions between the US and China, with the dollar strengthening as a safe-haven currency.

site_title: Complaints against banks and insurers climb: FIDReC
summary: The Financial Industry Disputes Resolutions Centre (FIDReC) in Singapore received 1,266 complaints for the year ended June 30, 2018, a 33% increase from the previous year. 45% of complaints were against banks and finance companies, primarily related to inappropriate advice, misrepresentation, or disclosure issues. 53% of life insurer complaints pertained to contractual matters, while 82% of general insurer complaints were due to disputes on liability. The centre resolved 945 complaints, with 96% resolved within six months, and 99% within nine months.

site_title: Hospitality counters OUEHT, CDLHT to ride recovery wave in 2019
summary: Hospitality counters OUEHT and CDLHT are expected to benefit from the recovery in the industry in 2019, driven by easing hotel room supply growth and rising visitor arrivals. Hotel room supply is projected to grow at 2.9% and 0.9% for 2019 and 2020, respectively, while arrivals are on track to beat the record high of 17.4 million visitors. Industry-wide revenue per available room (RevPAR) is expected to expand by 3-7% in 2019, with OUEHT and CDLHT poised to receive a leg up from the rebound.

site_title: Smart technologies a growth area for Daikin in Singapore
summary: Daikin, a Singapore-based air conditioning specialist, is expanding its use of smart technologies to build on its footprint in the city-state. The company has introduced energy-saving and resource-efficient offerings, including a Remote Monitoring System for commercial properties and a D'SmartHome app for residential properties. These systems enable remote monitoring and control of air-conditioning systems, allowing for up to 80% of malfunctions to be predicted and up to 20% of energy costs to be saved. Daikin aims to harness big data from air-conditioning consumption to optimize energy use, with plans to expand its capabilities to Southeast Asia and Japan.

site_title: Chan to Singaporeans: Deepen understanding of region
summary: Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing emphasized the need for Singaporeans to develop a deeper understanding of the South-east Asian region, enabling the country to add value as a springboard for regional partnerships. He stressed the importance of balancing internal focus with global awareness, noting that technological advancements can allow less developed nations to "leapfrog" ahead of more developed ones. Chan called for a new social compact to address social mobility and social mixing, and urged individuals and groups to take collective responsibility for helping those in need.

site_title: TTJ Holdings unit acquires industrial building and machinery for wood pellet business
summary: TTJ Holdings' subsidiary, TTJ Greenfuel, has acquired an industrial property in Singapore and machinery for S$16.18 million to build a wood pellet manufacturing business. The property, valued at S$15.5 million, will be used to convert wood waste into wood chips, with plans to upgrade and enhance production for wood pellet production. The acquisition aims to capitalize on increasing demand from Japan and South Korea, driven by new biomass-consuming power plants scheduled to become operational by 2020.

site_title: Pakistan says it can afford to wait for IMF bailout
summary: Pakistan's Finance Minister Asad Umar stated that the government can afford a two-month delay in stalled IMF bailout negotiations, citing sufficient foreign exchange reserves. The nation is seeking a $12 billion bailout to address its balance of payments crisis. Talks with the IMF will continue on Thursday, with Pakistan's request expected to be submitted to the executive board by January. The country has received $1 billion from Saudi Arabia in a direct support deposit, but its financial gap remains significant.

site_title: CRYPTIC CROSSWORD
summary: A cryptic crossword puzzle was published on November 28, 2018, with 28 clues across and 25 clues down. The solution to the puzzle was published in a separate document, revealing answers such as "Besides" for clue 1, "Obscene" for clue 5, and "Crybaby" for clue 27. The crossword appears to be a form of entertainment, with no specific connection to news or events.

site_title: Singapore's real estate investment market is No 2 in Asia-Pac: report
summary: Singapore's real estate investment market has been ranked second in the Asia Pacific region, according to a report by the Urban Land Institute (ULI) and PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC). The market's growth is driven by major office deals, with domestic investors as the biggest buyers. Office rents have risen due to a lack of supply and revived tenant demand. The report also highlights trends such as investors' interest in value-add plays, logistics facilities, and co-living, with capital flows remaining strong and robust outflows expected in 2019.

site_title: Where do you live? A S$5.50 fee can tell all
summary: Singapore's IPO prospectuses now no longer disclose directors' home addresses, a shift from 15 years ago when CEOs' residential addresses were widely disclosed. This change, made in 2016, allows directors to list alternate addresses instead. However, directors must still provide their home addresses to the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra), which can be listed in public records. The move is seen as a response to growing privacy concerns and the increasing threat of online harassment.

site_title: Ascendas Hospitality Trust to buy Ibis Ambassador Seoul for 77.5 billion won
summary: Ascendas Hospitality Trust has agreed to acquire Ibis Ambassador Seoul for 77.5 billion won (S$94.5 million), acquiring 98.8% of the hotel's owner. The trust will fund the purchase with debt and expects the deal to be completed by the end of December 2018. The hotel is strategically located near a major business district and leisure destinations, with inbound visitors to South Korea showing a 12.1% year-on-year increase.

site_title: GRP unit no longer assured of winning project in China
summary: GRP Ltd, an industrial product supplier, no longer has assurance of winning a mixed-development project in China's Tangshan city. The company's indirect wholly-owned subsidiary, Tangshan GRP Trading, acquired a 165 mu plot of land in 2016, but the local government is repossessing it for 63.8 million yuan. The plot will be rezoned for mixed development and put up for tender, with no guarantee of GRP's success. The repossession agreement has no material impact on GRP's financials, but the company is recovering a disbursed advance from the Kaiping government.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: IHH Healthcare's first nine months net profit fell 86% to RM118 million due to higher exchange translation losses. However, management expects to raise its stake in Acibadem to 90% and capitalise subordinated loans by year-end. Thai Beverage's sales volumes were down 11% due to weaker rural income and rising prices, but the company expects improved farm income and potential relief to boost sales. ThaiBev's earnings growth is expected to increase outside of Thailand, particularly in Myanmar and Vietnam.

site_title: Asia stocks get mild mid-week boost
summary: Asian markets experienced moderate gains on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index in Singapore rising 4.08 points, or 0.1%, to 3,094.48. Gains were seen in Hong Kong, China, Japan, and South Korea, while Australia declined marginally. The positive turn in the Trump-Xi trade talks and a possible US Federal Reserve rate hike boost investor sentiment, with investors awaiting the G-20 meeting and Fed chair Jerome Powell's speech for further direction.

site_title: The Emirates, where art is blooming
summary: The Emirates, particularly Abu Dhabi, Dubai, and Sharjah, are emerging as global arts hubs. The Louvre Abu Dhabi museum has attracted over a million visitors since its opening, while Dubai and Sharjah have hosted various art fairs and design events. Alserkal Avenue in Dubai features top galleries showcasing regional and international works, and the Jameel Arts Centre is the country's first non-government art museum. The region's growing arts scene is also highlighted through features on fashion, home design, and festive ideas.

site_title: Argentine polo turns to genetics to produce champions
summary: Scientists in Argentina are mapping the genome of the Argentine polo horse to create the perfect specimen. The project, starting in December, will analyze 80,000 horses to identify the ideal genetic balance for polo. Researchers aim to replicate the breed's unique speed, durability, and explosiveness. Cloning has already been used to reproduce elite mounts, but the project seeks to optimize physical and temperamental characteristics through genetic selection. The goal is to produce champions within three years, but experts acknowledge that science cannot overcome every challenge, such as establishing a unique connection between horse and rider.

images.alt_text: Researchers of the Genetics Veterinary Institute making tests to a polo horse at La Plata University in La Plata, Argentina.
Researchers of the Genetics Veterinary Institute making tests to a polo horse at La Plata University in La Plata, Argentina.

site_title: Completed condo, private apartment prices fall 0.6% in Oct
summary: Singapore's completed private apartments and condominiums saw a 0.6% decline in October, accelerating from a 0.2% drop in September. This decline was driven by a 0.9% drop in non-central region apartments and a 0.3% fall in central region apartments. However, small units (506 sqft or less) rose 0.3% in October. Year-to-date, prices have climbed 3.6% overall, with 6.2% increases in central region apartments and 5.7% in non-central locations.

site_title: HK finance sector M&A deals fall on China controls
summary: Hong Kong's finance sector saw a significant decline in mergers and acquisitions (M&A) deals in 2018, with insurance sector deals particularly affected, due to China's capital controls and crackdown on corporate debt. Chinese buyers, who once dominated Hong Kong deals, have largely disappeared, with only a quarter of the total volume this year. The decline is attributed to Beijing's efforts to stem the yuan's weakness and limit offshore funding, leaving sellers with fewer options. This shift is expected to open up the market for non-Chinese firms.

site_title: Iran leader calls for boosting of naval forces
summary: Iran's supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei called for boosting the country's naval forces to deter enemies and protect the nation. He emphasized Iran's readiness to defend itself, despite stating no intention of launching a war against anyone. The deployment of new ships, including a destroyer and two submarines, was seen as a sign of progress. Iran considers itself the guardian of the Gulf and regularly condemns US deployment of naval forces in the region.

site_title: Editing babies? We need to learn a lot more first
summary: A Chinese scientist, He Jiankui, has claimed to have edited the genes of two human embryos, resulting in the birth of genetically altered twin girls. This experiment, which involved editing the CCR5 gene to prevent HIV infection, is widely considered unethical due to the potential risks and unknowns of gene editing. The technique, known as Crispr, is still in its early stages and has not been proven safe or effective in humans. The experiment raises concerns about the manipulation of human embryos and the potential consequences for future generations.

site_title: Leadership succession in Singapore: Keeping it predictable
summary: Singapore's People's Action Party (PAP) has chosen Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat as its first assistant secretary-general, paving the way for him to become the country's fourth prime minister. With Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong set to hand over power by 2022, the PAP has a relatively long lead time to assess its choice. Heng is seen as a safe and familiar face to the business community and foreign partners, and the PAP's predictable leadership succession is a hallmark of Singapore's stable politics.

site_title: ECB policymakers leaning towards open reinvestment horizon
summary: European Central Bank policymakers are leaning towards making nuanced changes to how the bank reinvests cash from maturing bonds, potentially keeping the purchases open-ended. The bank's 2.6 trillion euro bond purchase scheme is set to end next month, and policymakers are considering two to three options regarding the duration of reinvestments. A decision is expected at the Dec 13 meeting, with market expectations suggesting purchases will continue for two to three years. The ECB aims to maintain flexibility and avoid commitment, and the discussion is ongoing.

site_title: EY's audits on Noble unit under review
summary: EY's audits of Noble Resources International Pte Ltd, a coal trading unit of commodity trader Noble Group, are under review in a criminal probe. The Commercial Affairs Department and Monetary Authority of Singapore have directed EY to produce documents related to the audits for financial years 2012-2016. The review is based on substantial write-downs announced by Noble in 2017 and other information, amid allegations of accounting practices. An investigation is ongoing, with no conclusion on charges yet, and the restructuring of Noble is delayed due to the probe.

images.alt_text: THE audits conducted by accountants from the Singapore arm of EY on a subsidiary of commodity trader Noble Group for five financial years from 2012 to 2016 have come under review in a criminal probe.

site_title: Murphy Oil in talks to sell Malaysian oil and gas assets, say sources
summary: US-based Murphy Oil Corporation is in talks to sell its Malaysian oil and gas assets, potentially worth between $2 billion and $3 billion, according to sources. The company has tapped banks for the sale of its majority interests in eight offshore production sharing contracts. Negotiations are underway, with potential buyers including Spanish oil major Repsol and other global majors. The sale could fund Murphy's global expansion plans, following its recent joint venture with Brazilian state-controlled oil company Petrobras.

site_title: A choreographer's love letter to Alvin Ailey
summary: Choreographer Ronald K. Brown is set to premiere "The Call," a dance piece paying tribute to Alvin Ailey, at the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater's 60th-anniversary season. The 20-year-old collaboration marks Brown's seventh work for the troupe, combining West African movement with urban drive. The dance is set to a harmonious mix of Bach, jazz, and Malian music, featuring a canon and call-and-response sequences. Brown's choreography is known for its formal quality and simplicity, and he aims to evoke Ailey's clarity of vision and sensibility in the piece.

site_title: Pod Structures launches modular made-in-Singapore homes for multiple markets
summary: Pod Structures, a Singapore-based modular home builder, has launched its MOVIT brand of bespoke homes in multiple markets. The company, led by CEO Samuel Vedanaigam, has seen a 20% increase in clients compared to five years ago. Its patented Tubelar technology allows for the setup of a MOVIT home in 7-10 days, using aluminum instead of steel, making it lightweight and flexible. The company plans to expand into new markets, including Australia and New Zealand, with investors supporting its globalization efforts.

site_title: Beauty World Plaza owners launch redevelopment site for tender
summary: Beauty World Plaza owners are putting the redevelopment site up for tender with a reserve price of S$165 million. The 2,305.6 sqm site, zoned for commercial and residential use, is close to a MRT station and amenities. Knight Frank also announced a tender for 409-419 Upper East Coast Road, a landed development with a reserve price of S$18 million. Despite recent cooling measures, interest in landed homes remains strong, with the new development expected to yield interest from homebuyers.

site_title: Relatives of missing from Malaysia plane say they may have found pieces of debris
summary: Relatives of Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 say they've found new pieces of debris, which they plan to present to the Malaysian government. The plane vanished in 2014 with 239 people on board, and despite 27 collected pieces, only three confirmed wing fragments were found. The next of kin will meet Malaysia's transport minister to hand over five pieces of debris found off Madagascar. The discovery comes after a 495-page report suggested the plane's controls were manipulated off course, but the responsible party remains unknown.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: China Everbright Water secured a 230 million yuan (S$45.55 million) project in Jiangsu province, investing in a water treatment plant and pipeline. Boustead Projects faces a lawsuit from YCH Holdings over a development project, while T T J Holdings acquired a property and machinery for S$16.18 million to build a wood pellet manufacturing business.

site_title: US new home sales plunge in October, lowest since March 2016
summary: US new home sales plummeted in October, reaching the lowest level since March 2016. The decline was widespread, with double-digit drops in the Northeast and Midwest, and a significant drop in the hurricane-affected South. Sales fell 9% compared to September, reaching an annual rate of 544,000, seasonally adjusted. The decline marks the first time sales have fallen in the past 11 months.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on trade truce hopes; Powell speech eyed
summary: US stocks opened higher on November 28, 2018, amid hopes for a trade truce between the US and China at the G20 Summit. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.34%, the S&P 500 gained 0.35%, and the Nasdaq Composite increased 0.74% at the opening bell. Investors looked forward to Fed Chairman Jerome Powell's speech for clues on interest rate hikes.

site_title: NZ rejects Huawei's first 5G bid, cites national security risk
summary: New Zealand's Government Communications Security Bureau has rejected Huawei's bid to provide 5G equipment, citing national security risks. The decision follows similar concerns raised by Western nations, including Australia, which banned Huawei from supplying 5G equipment earlier this year. Huawei has repeatedly denied Chinese government involvement, and the company will "actively address any concerns" to find a way forward. The decision may impact Spark New Zealand's 5G plans and has sparked concerns about competition in the telecom industry.

site_title: Insurer AXA raises profit targets after buying XL
summary: AXA, Europe's second-largest insurer, raised its profit targets after acquiring XL for $15 billion. The company expects adjusted return on equity to increase 14-16% and underlying earnings per share to increase 3-7% over the next two years. The acquisition is expected to boost profitability and synergies to 500 million euros. As a result, AXA increased its dividend payout range to 50-60% from 45-55%. The company's shares rose 1.7% in early trading.

site_title: EY's audits on Noble's coal unit under scrutiny: authorities
summary: EY's audits of Noble Resources International Pte Ltd, a coal trading unit of commodity trader Noble Group, are under scrutiny in a criminal probe. The Singapore authorities, including the Commercial Affairs Department and the Monetary Authority of Singapore, have directed EY to produce documents related to the audits for financial years 2012-2016. The investigation is based on allegations of substantial write-downs and potential breaches of Singapore law. The probe comes as Noble is wrapping up a debt revamp exercise, with control of its business set to be handed to creditors.

site_title: Ghosn's deferred pay 'ballooned after shift in rules'
summary: Carlos Ghosn's deferred income at Nissan Motor Co. increased by 2.5 billion yen ($96.8 million) last year, exceeding a record high, as he sought to downplay his compensation in front of shareholders. The practice, which was a focus of the investigation leading to Ghosn's arrest, was made public in 2009 after Japan required executive pay to be disclosed. Prosecutors are investigating whether Ghosn fixed the annual amount of deferred pay, despite Nissan's internal investigation suggesting only a small group of people were aware of the arrangement.

images.alt_text: On Wednesday, Mr Ghosn through his lawyer denied a separate accusation reported by Japanese media that he passed on personal trading losses to the carmaker.

site_title: Ascendas Hospitality Trust to acquire Ibis Ambassador Seoul for 77.5b won
summary: Ascendas Hospitality Trust has agreed to acquire Ibis Ambassador Seoul for 77.5 billion won (S$94.5 million), marking its maiden entry into South Korea. The acquisition, expected to be completed by the end of December 2018, will be fully funded by debt and translates to a 4.6% pro forma net property income yield. Strategically located near a major business district and leisure destinations, the acquisition is seen as a positive move for the hotel market in Seoul, which has benefited from strong inbound arrivals.

site_title: Far from leaving China anytime soon, GM has committed to going big there
summary: General Motors has reaffirmed its commitment to operating in China, despite falling sales and production issues. The company expects to book $2 billion in equity income in China this year, with margins of 9-10%. Despite President Trump's threats to strip GM of US government subsidies, GM plans to launch at least 10 models in China by the end of the year, including the Cadillac XT4 luxury SUV. GM's CEO Mary Barra has stated that China is a key part of the company's strategy, with a focus on electrification, autonomous vehicles, and ride-sharing.

site_title: Israel unveils rare and ancient mask
summary: Israel's Israel Antiquities Authority unveiled a 9,000-year-old stone mask, discovered in the West Bank, which is linked to the beginnings of agricultural society. The mask, made of pink and yellow sandstone, is rare and naturalistic, featuring cheekbones and a nose. It is believed to be part of ancestor worship rituals during the Neolithic culture's transition to agriculture. The discovery sheds light on the cultural practices of the time, providing insights into the social structure and ritual-religious activities of the people.

images.alt_text: Israeli archeologist Ronit Lupu of the IAA Antiquities Theft Prevention Unit holds a rare stone mask dating to the Neolithic (new stone age) period which was found at the Pnei Hever region of southern Hebron mount, on November 28, 2018 at the Rockefeller archeological museum in Jerusalem.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.58 points to 1,686.55. The index saw 1.7 billion lots traded worth RM2.1 billion, with 405 losers narrowly outnumbering 401 gainers.

site_title: Imran Khan says Pakistan army wants to mend ties with India
summary: Pakistan's Prime Minister Imran Khan stated that his government and the country's powerful military are on the same page regarding mending ties with India. Khan reiterated his pledge to improve relations, saying Pakistan will take two steps forward for every step India takes. Pakistan's Army Chief, General Qamar Javed Bajwa, also expressed support for the idea of peace, but tensions remain due to the disputed region of Kashmir.

site_title: IMF's Lagarde warns of worse trade hit to global economy
summary: IMF chief Christine Lagarde warns that escalating trade tensions have worsened global economic growth concerns, citing a potential 3/4% cut to global GDP if US auto tariffs are imposed. Emerging markets, particularly China and the euro area, are already experiencing economic slowdowns, while a "no-deal Brexit" could further erode confidence. The IMF emphasizes the need for countries to avoid new trade barriers and reverse recent tariffs to avoid self-defeating consequences for all involved.

site_title: China Everbright Water secures 230m yuan waste water treatment project
summary: China Everbright Water has secured a 230 million yuan (S$45.59 million) waste water treatment project in Jiangsu province. The project involves constructing a plant with 40,000 cubic meters of daily treatment capacity and a pipeline network, with services to be provided over a 30-year concession period. The company will invest, construct, and operate the Jiangyin Binjiang Plant 2 and pipeline project on a build-operate-transfer basis.

site_title: India's telecom lobby group seek to halt release of movie showing cellphones as villains
summary: India's telecom lobby group, the Cellular Operators Association of India (COAI), has asked the country's censor board and government to revoke a certificate issued for the movie "2.0", which depicts cellphones as villains in a post-apocalyptic world. The film, starring Rajinikanth, is scheduled to be released in cinemas on Thursday, but the COAI claims it is defamatory and promotes unscientific attitudes against mobile phones. The group is requesting a preview of the movie to ensure it does not incite law and order problems or tower shutdowns.

site_title: Fed stability report: Banks, households strong, but asset values "elevated"
summary: The US Federal Reserve released its first-ever financial stability report, highlighting signs of resilience in the financial system, including strong bank capital positions and tempered household borrowing. However, the report also noted elevated asset prices, growing commercial real estate values, and deteriorating credit standards, which could be particularly vulnerable to shocks such as a trade war or crisis in emerging markets. The Fed aims to review risks to financial stability twice a year, aiming to avoid past mistakes that led to the 2007 financial crisis.

images.alt_text: The US Federal Reserve building in Washington. Tensions over trade, the turbulent Brexit discussions, and trouble in China and emerging markets could rock a US financial system where asset prices are "elevated" and business credit quality may be "deteriorating," the US Federal Reserve said in a first-ever report devoted to financial stability.

site_title: No-deal Brexit could cost UK economy 9.3% of GDP over 15 years - govt
summary: The UK government has warned that a no-deal Brexit could lead to an economy 9.3% smaller in 15 years, or 3.9% in the worst-case scenario, compared to remaining in the EU. A cross-departmental analysis found that even with new trade deals, the economy would still be poorer. The report models two possible deals, with the most optimistic scenario shrinking the economy by 0.6%, and the worst-case by 3.9%. The government's hopes for a frictionless trade and zero net migration were not met in the analysis.

site_title: Singapore least confident in Asean when it comes to opportunities to get ahead: LinkedIn study
summary: Singaporeans are the least confident in Asean countries about gaining access to desired opportunities, according to a LinkedIn study. The top-ranked countries were Indonesia, the Philippines, and Malaysia, while Singapore ranked 6th. Key findings include a desire for rewarding jobs, career advancement, and learning opportunities, but barriers such as a difficult job market, finances, and lack of networks. 40% of respondents across Asia Pacific value work-life balance, with 48% in Singapore, and only 24% in Singapore want to start their own businesses, contrasting with Indonesia and the Philippines.

site_title: YCH sues Boustead Projects
summary: Boustead Projects is being sued by YCH Holdings over alleged breach of contractual obligations for the Supply Chain City development project from 2012 to 2014. YCH seeks S$2.335 million in damages. Boustead Projects intends to vigorously defend the claims and advised shareholders to exercise caution. The lawsuit is expected to be resolved after the financial year ending March 31, 2019.

site_title: Europe: Shares in tentative rebound as trade angst eases
summary: European shares rebounded 0.4% at the open on Wednesday as trade war fears eased ahead of a US-China G20 meeting. The STOXX 600 benchmark rose despite caution on the automotive sector, which fell 1% due to potential new US tariffs on imported cars. Milan's steel firms were a notable exception, with Tenaris shares dropping 9%. The rebound was largely driven by mining and healthcare stocks.

site_title: Two Koreas study possible rail link as ties get back on track
summary: South and North Korea are launching a 2,600-km train trip to inspect potential rail links between the two countries, a step towards re-establishing ties. The 18-day study, led by 30 officials from each side, aims to reconnect rail and road links severed since the 1950-53 Korean conflict. The move comes after the UN Security Council granted sanctions exemptions following consultations between South Korea and the US. The survey is a key step towards a project to reconnect rail links, pending progress on North Korea's denuclearization.

site_title: Go-Jek said to enter Singapore this week in challenge to Grab
summary: Indonesia's ride-hailing company Go-Jek plans to launch a preliminary version of its app in Singapore this week, entering the market in a challenge to Grab, the city-state's dominant player. Go-Jek's beta app will be available to a limited number of consumers before expanding to a wider population. The move is seen as a response to Grab's acquisition of Uber's Southeast Asian business, which has led to complaints from users and drivers about higher prices and reduced income. Go-Jek's CEO, Nadiem Makarim, aims to bring a more consumer- and driver-friendly approach to the market.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's top jobs in demand for 2019 include analytics and data-driven roles, such as data scientists and product management. The country's condo and private apartment prices fell 0.6% in October, driven by a decline in non-central region prices. Singapore's top stocks rose 0.1% on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index at 3,094.48. Globally, Vietnam was surprised by the US tariff announcement, while Malaysia's agency plans to seize RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, and the UK economy shrank for the second month.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks tick up ahead of key events; won inches up
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 0.42% on Wednesday ahead of key events, including a speech by Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell. The won inched up, and bond yields rose. Investors took a cautious stance, expecting the Bank of Korea to raise its base rate to calm the property market. A Reuters poll predicted solid export growth but warned of risks from softening computer memory prices and the US-China trade dispute. The KOSPI was up 8.79 points at 2,108.21.

site_title: Dutch telecoms group KPN to cut costs, expand high-speed fibre network
summary: KPN, the largest Dutch telecoms company, plans to cut operating costs by 350 million euros and expand its high-speed fibre network to 1 million households by 2021. The company aims to save on costs and grow its adjusted core profit, with revenue expected to steady over the period. Analysts praise the company's ambitious targets, which exceed expectations. The move is seen as a strategic move to improve its competitive position in the evolving telecoms landscape.

site_title: State Courts plugs electronic loophole that allowed access to case files
summary: The Singapore State Courts identified and fixed a vulnerability in its electronic case management system, allowing unauthorized access to over 200 e-case files. The loophole, discovered on November 1, enabled accused persons to view court documents in other e-case files. The integrity of ongoing proceedings was not affected, and no files were tampered with. The State Courts reported the incident to the police and implemented additional security measures, sending letters to affected parties and setting up a dedicated email and hotline for queries.

site_title: Commodities giant Cargill unveils two-year Philippine growth plan with US$235 million investment
summary: Commodities giant Cargill has unveiled a two-year growth plan for the Philippines, investing US$235 million in its businesses. The investment will focus on expanding animal feed and nutrition, and agricultural supply chain businesses. Cargill has 2,200 workers in the Philippines and aims to meet growing demand for chicken and pork. The company also announced a US$130,000 investment in an Inclusive Business Capacity Building Fund to support local farmers. Cargill's CEO, Dave MacLennan, said the investments will help the company grow alongside the Filipino people and the local economy.

site_title: Car market collapse outruns GM moves to keep up
summary: General Motors plans to close three North American car assembly plants and slash its workforce, but this move won't fully address the industry's capacity and demand gap for sedans. Sales of traditional passenger cars have been declining for six years, with GM's US car plants operating at less than 50% capacity. Detroit rivals Ford and Fiat Chrysler will have one car plant each in North America after 2019, further reducing capacity. The move is part of GM's efforts to adapt to the decline of the traditional car market.

images.alt_text: A Chevrolet Bolt EV vehicle on the assembly line at General Motors Orion Assembly in Lake Orion, Michigan. General Motors Co's monumental announcement on Monday that it will close three car assembly plants in North America and slash its workforce will only partially close the gap between capacity and demand for the automaker's sedans, according to a Reuters analysis of industry production and capacity data.

site_title: Can artificial intelligence eliminate your bad hair days?
summary: A startup called Prose is using artificial intelligence to create customized hair care products, with a quiz and algorithms determining the ideal ingredients for each customer's hair type. The company has shipped 110,000 bottles and plans to reach $1 million in monthly sales by its first birthday. Another startup, Function of Beauty, uses a similar approach, with one million bottles sold. While some experts, like dermatologist Maryanne Senna, are skeptical about the effectiveness of customized products, others, like cosmetic chemist Perry Romanowski, see potential benefits.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares rally ahead of trade talks
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose over 1% on Wednesday ahead of trade talks between Donald Trump and Xi Jinping, with the Hang Seng Index increasing 1.33% to 26,682.56. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose, driven by hopes for a successful trade deal. The rally followed a broader advance across Asia, with US stocks also edging closer to records despite tariff concerns.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks rallied more than one per cent on Wednesday, in line with a broad advance across Asia, on hopes for a successful conclusion to crucial trade talks between Donald Trump and Xi Jinping at the weekend.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon at 3,095.43, up 0.16%
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Wednesday with the Straits Times Index up 0.16% at 3,095.43, driven by gains in local banks and a surge in EZion shares. DBS, UOB, and OCBC Bank rose 0.34%, 0.12%, and 0.54% respectively. The market saw 174 gainers and 119 losers, with 965.5 million shares changing hands.

site_title: Australia shares tick down on Sino-U.S. trade angst; NZ rises
summary: Australian shares fell 0.06% on Wednesday due to Sino-US trade uncertainty and a decline in commodity prices. The benchmark S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,725.10. Investors were wary of buying into riskier assets amid conflicting comments from US President Donald Trump and White House economic adviser Larry Kudlow on the Sino-US trade dispute. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.46% driven by consumer and utilities stocks.

site_title: Singapore completed condo, private apartment prices fall 0.6% in October from September: NUS index
summary: Singapore's completed private apartment and condominium prices fell 0.6% in October from September, according to the National University of Singapore's (NUS) flash estimates. The decline was driven by a 0.9% drop in non-central region apartments, while small units rose 0.3%. Year-on-year, overall prices rose 5.9%, with 6.2% increases for central region apartments and shoebox units.

site_title: Row of apartments along Phoenix Road to be put up for collective sale for S$42m
summary: A row of 36 apartments and 12 commercial shops along Phoenix Road in Bukit Panjang, Singapore, will be put up for collective sale via public tender on January 17, 2019, for S$42 million. The site has a 99-year leasehold tenure and a gross plot ratio of 1.4, allowing for 84 residential units. Owners are expected to receive an estimated S$1 million to S$1.5 million upon sale. The site is zoned residential and near key transport nodes, appealing to diverse buyers.

images.alt_text: Each owner will stand to receive an estimated gross sale proceed of S$1.0 million to S$1.5 million upon the successful sale of the property.

site_title: US Q3 growth still strong at 3.5% despite slower spending
summary: The US economy maintained a strong growth rate in the third quarter, with GDP expanding at a 3.5% annualized rate, matching the median forecast. Household spending grew 3.6%, despite weaker durable goods purchases, while business investment showed the largest increase. This growth was cushioned by a larger boost from inventories, offsetting the worst trade drag since 1984. The results suggest the economy remains resilient despite trade tensions.

images.alt_text: The US economy remained on a solid footing in the third quarter, matching previously reported results, as stronger business investment and a bigger boost from inventories cushioned the worst trade drag since 1984.

site_title: Singapore's top jobs in demand for 2019 to be analytics, data-driven: Robert Walters
summary: Singapore's job market is expected to see stable growth in 2019, with analytical and data-driven roles in demand, including data scientists, product management, and UX designers. Cybersecurity remains a major focus. Job movers can expect 5-15% pay increments, with larger hikes for IT, digital, and financial services specialists. Employers will seek HR professionals with experience in HR technologies and talent acquisition professionals for the technology sector. Competition will intensify for specialists with international experience and niche skill sets, particularly in product management, technology law, and blockchain.

site_title: Beauty World Plaza owners launch redevelopment tender with S$165m reserve price
summary: The owners of Beauty World Plaza in Singapore are putting the redevelopment site up for tender with a reserve price of S$165 million. The 2,305.6 square meter site is zoned for commercial and residential use with a gross plot ratio of 3.0. An outline application for changing the residential component to serviced apartments has been submitted to the Urban Redevelopment Authority. The site is strategically located near major roads and transport infrastructure, with the Beauty World MRT station nearby. The tender closes on January 30, 2019.

site_title: Mobile commerce app use surges in South-east Asia: Report
summary: Mobile commerce app use in South-east Asia has surged by 240% over the past year, outpacing the average 28% growth in app use. Health, fitness, business, and finance apps saw significant growth, with increases of 170%, 102%, and 51% respectively. This trend indicates a shift towards digital commerce in the region, with m-commerce becoming the most popular category.

site_title: Pakistan says it can afford to wait for an IMF bailout
summary: Pakistan's Finance Minister Asad Umar stated that the government can afford a two-month delay in stalled bailout negotiations with the International Monetary Fund (IMF), despite a financial gap of at least $12 billion. The IMF's proposed changes to Pakistan's currency and tax policy are the main points of contention. Pakistan has received $1 billion from Saudi Arabia, but has been unable to secure similar financial assistance from other countries, including China and the UAE. Umar expressed confidence that the request will be submitted in time for a January IMF executive board meeting.

site_title: Singapore needs new social compact to help 'the slow keep pace with the fast': Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore needs a new social compact to address social mobility and mixing challenges, Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing said. The government policy alone cannot keep pace with changes, and individuals and groups must develop a sense of collective responsibility. A new social compact would require Singaporeans to consider the needs of others, rather than just focusing on their own entitlements. Chan emphasized the importance of a political leadership that prioritizes Singapore's interests and a sense of higher purpose among those in power.

site_title: UK government, BoE to spell out no-deal Brexit risks for economy
summary: The UK government and Bank of England are set to release assessments of the economic risks of a no-deal Brexit, warning of a 1-2% smaller economy in 15 years if the UK leaves the EU without a transition period, compared to a 7.6% smaller economy if there is no deal. The warnings aim to persuade lawmakers to back Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit plan, which includes a transition period. Finance minister Philip Hammond and BoE Governor Mark Carney have previously stressed the importance of a transition period to ease the UK out of the EU, but some Brexit supporters have dismissed the warnings as "Project Fear."

site_title: Trump advisor refuses to listen to Khashoggi murder tape
summary: White House national security advisor John Bolton refused to listen to a tape recording of Jamal Khashoggi's murder, citing his inability to understand Arabic. The tape, a key piece of evidence in the murder allegedly ordered by Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, was distributed by Turkey. Bolton stated he could read a transcript instead, echoing President Donald Trump's stance that US-Saudi relations and oil market stability were too important to rock over the scandal. The CIA had pointed fingers at Prince Mohammed, but Trump denied any knowledge.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open slightly higher on Wednesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly higher on Wednesday, following a positive lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.28% to 26,406.68, while the Shanghai Composite Index inched up 0.77 points to 2,575.45. The Shenzhen Composite Index remained flat.

site_title: Asean's hiring outlook to remain positive in 2019: Robert Walters
summary: Southeast Asia's hiring outlook for 2019 is expected to remain positive, driven by digitalisation and industrial growth. Professions in high demand include IT specialists and those with industrial experience. Robust growth in economies like Indonesia, Philippines, Thailand, and Vietnam is forecasted, while Singapore and Malaysia will experience stable and modest hiring. Multinational companies and foreign direct investment are driving competition for skilled and experienced talent.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as Trump-Xi takes centre stage
summary: Asian markets are mixed ahead of the high-stakes meeting between US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping, with investors awaiting a possible trade deal. Despite positive comments from White House economic advisor Larry Kudlow, dealers remain cautious due to the threat of an escalation in the trade war. The Federal Reserve's Jerome Powell is also set to speak, with traders watching for signs of an easing in interest rate hikes. Markets have seen mixed results, with Hong Kong and Shanghai rising, while Sydney and Singapore fell.

site_title: Goldman Sachs could wind up paying twice for 1MDB
summary: Goldman Sachs may face damages exceeding $5.4 billion for its role in the 1MDB scandal, as Abu Dhabi's sovereign fund sues the US investment bank in New York. The lawsuit alleges Goldman conspired to bribe officials and manipulate bonds, with damages sought exceeding the bank's average annual net profit over three years. The case comes amid growing expectations of a hefty settlement with the US Department of Justice, which could include a fine of up to $1.2 billion and return of $600 million in fees.

site_title: Australia: Material stocks weigh on shares; New Zealand inches up
summary: Australian shares fell 0.2% due to losses in the materials sector, weighed down by concerns over a slowdown in Chinese demand. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 10.5 points to 5717.8. Investors remained cautious after White House economic adviser Larry Kudlow's comments on the Sino-U.S. trade row. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.5% as the utilities sector gained support.

site_title: China transport ministry fines Didi executives in crackdown on illegal practices
summary: China's transport ministry fined Didi Chuxing executives as part of a crackdown on illegal practices, following the deaths of two female passengers earlier this year. The fine is part of an investigation into Didi's car pool service, which the ministry deemed a serious safety hazard. Didi must continue to suspend its car pool service. This move is part of a broader effort to regulate the ride-hailing industry in China.

site_title: Broker's take: Exotix Capital initiates coverage on Wilmar with 'sell'
summary: Exotix Capital has initiated coverage on Wilmar International with a "sell" call, citing a 36% premium to the sector average and poor earnings growth. The broker expects a 27% share downside and -24% total return. Wilmar's poor performance in stress tests and excess supply in palm oil and soybean could lead to inventory writedowns and reduced earnings. A narrowing US dollar to Chinese yuan carry trade could also impact earnings. Exotix recommends a target price of S$2.29, 14 times enterprise value to Ebitda.

site_title: Deutsche Bank mulling shake-up amid regulatory frustrations: source
summary: Deutsche Bank is considering replacing senior executives who oversee its relationships with regulators amid regulatory frustrations. Management board member Sylvie Matherat and operations head Tom Patrick are among those who might leave. The bank is trying to improve compliance systems after repeated failures in preventing misconduct. Germany's markets regulator has ordered Deutsche Bank to improve anti-money laundering controls and appointed a monitor to oversee the efforts. The bank's stock has hit record lows due to concerns over a potential money laundering scandal at Danske Bank.

site_title: 'Palace coup' at Nissan was Japan Inc striking back, says fund
summary: A US hedge fund manager, Jamie Rosenwald, claims Nissan's ousting of former chairman Carlos Ghosn is a "palace coup" by Japan Inc to block Renault's full control of the company. Rosenwald accuses Nissan of ignoring shareholders' interests, contrasting with Ghosn's actions in 1999-2000 that saved them. The US investor urges the French government to intervene to protect shareholders' rights, saying Japan Inc wants Nissan to buy out Renault to go separate ways. Rosenwald has clashed with vested interests in Japan before, including in a failed bid to take a Japanese company private.

site_title: Hong Kong online lending startup Oriente raises US$105m in initial funding round
summary: Oriente, a Hong Kong-based fintech startup, has raised US$105 million in its initial funding round, with investments from family offices and founders. This is one of the largest initial funding rounds by a startup in Asia and for a fintech company worldwide. The funding will be used to accelerate technology and product development, scale operations, and expand into new markets. Oriente uses AI, machine learning, and data science to provide real-time credit scoring and digital lending services, aiming to deliver fast and convenient access to affordable credit for underserved individuals and micro-entrepreneurs.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Hi-P, DBS, Keong Hong, IHH Healthcare, Pine Capital
summary: Hi-P International shares rose 3.77% on Tuesday after rumors of a possible share deal, despite the company denying any approach. DBS Group Holdings plans to expand in the Middle East, aiming to double its private bankers in Dubai to 40 over the next five years.

site_title: New Zealand intelligence bans China's Huawei from 5G rollout
summary: New Zealand's intelligence agency has barred China's Huawei from its 5G rollout due to "significant national security risks." The decision was made by GCSB chief Andrew Hampton after Spark, the country's largest telecoms carrier, proposed using Huawei equipment. The move follows US warnings to exclude Huawei from 5G rollouts over cybersecurity concerns. Huawei has denied any links to Beijing authorities, but New Zealand's decision reflects growing concerns about China's influence in the Pacific. The country still plans to complete its 5G network by July 2020.

images.alt_text: New Zealand's largest telecoms carrier Spark said on Wednesday that the country's intelligence agency had barred it from using equipment provided by China's Huawei in its 5G network as it posed "significant national security risks".

site_title: Malaysia shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Wednesday, rising 0.83 points to 1,685.80. Volume reached 17.93 million lots worth RM13.32 million, with gainers beating losers 100 to 53.

site_title: Former employee says Facebook failing black people
summary: A former Facebook employee, Mark Luckie, claims the company is failing to include black people in its workforce and on the social network, stating that Facebook has a "black people problem." Luckie, who is black, shared a memo with employees worldwide, citing that black employees are underrepresented, with only 4% of the workforce, despite being among the most engaged demographics. He also alleged that black employees face hostility and marginalization, with some reporting being called aggressive or accosted by security.

site_title: Faulty Lion Air sensor wasn't fixed before crash, preliminary report finds
summary: A preliminary report by Indonesia's National Transportation Safety Committee found that a faulty angle-of-attack sensor on the Lion Air Boeing 737 Max 8 caused the October 29 crash, which killed 189 people. The sensor, which measures the plane's nose angle, had malfunctioned on a previous flight and prompted a stall warning, but the pilots didn't follow an emergency procedure to shut off the motor. The investigation also found that the pilots had difficulty understanding basic information such as speed and altitude, and the crash occurred due to a cascade of failures.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher with focus on US-China talks
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.02% to 22,177.02 on Wednesday, driven by gains on Wall Street and a cheaper yen. Investors await US-China summit talks, with speculation about a possible trade deal growing. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index and Topix index also rose 0.58% and 0.58% respectively, respectively.

site_title: Flight control problems reported before Lion Air crash: investigators
summary: Indonesian investigators report that a pilot of the Lion Air jet, which crashed on October 29, 2018, told air traffic control about a "flight control problem" shortly before the crash. The pilots were experiencing issues with the Maneuvering Characteristics Augmentation System (MCAS), an automated modification on the Boeing 737 MAX. The system activated, causing the plane to nose down, and pilots had to use switches to shut it off. The investigation is ongoing and has recommended that Lion Air improve its safety culture, with no clear cause for the crash yet.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index rising 0.51% to 22,064.06, driven by gains on Wall Street and a cheaper yen. Investors await US-China summit talks amid speculation about a possible trade deal. The broader Topix index also rose 0.34%.

site_title: Indonesian investigators meet victim's families before release of first Lion Air crash report
summary: Indonesian investigators met with victim's families of the Lion Air crash, hours before releasing a preliminary report. The report, according to Bloomberg, suggests the pilots were fighting an anti-stall system as they attempted to diagnose multiple failures. The report, released on Wednesday, stopped short of concluding what caused the crash but provided new data on the jet's maintenance and efforts to recover the wreckage. The Lion Air crash, which killed 189 people, is the world's first involving the 737 MAX jet, a fuel-efficient version of Boeing's workhorse narrowbody.

site_title: Trump faces China trade showdown, Russia, Saudi tensions at G-20
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to hold a high-stakes trade meeting with Chinese leader Xi Jinping at the G-20 summit, amid ongoing tensions over punitive tariffs and intellectual property theft. Trump is also navigating diplomatic challenges with Russia's Vladimir Putin, with a potential meeting on the table despite strained US-Russia relations. Meanwhile, Trump's visit to Argentina will also include meetings with leaders of other major economies, including Saudi Arabia, but a meeting with Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman is unlikely due to concerns over his involvement in Jamal Khashoggi's murder.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Wednesday's open; STI up 0.23% to 3,097.64
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.23% to 3,097.64 on Wednesday, driven by gains in US markets following hopes of successful US-China trade talks. Pine Capital Group's share price doubled, while AusGroup Limited increased 5.6%. DBS Group Holdings and ComfortDelGro Corp also saw gains, with DBS up 0.6% and ComfortDelGro flat. The Straits Times Index gained 7.24 points.

site_title: Trump says he's 'not even a little bit happy' with Federal Reserve's Powell
summary: US President Donald Trump expressed dissatisfaction with Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell, stating he's "not even a little bit happy" with his selection. Trump criticized the Fed's interest-rate increases, blaming them for recent stock market declines and economic downturns, including GM's factory closures. The Fed is expected to raise rates in December, which Trump sees as a mistake. Trump's criticism marks a departure from the White House's long-standing respect for Fed independence, sparking concerns about the central bank's independence and monetary policy.

site_title: Blast kills 22 near north China chemical plant: official
summary: An explosion and fire near a chemical factory in Zhangjiakou, northern China, killed at least 22 people and injured 22 others on November 28, 2018. The blast occurred at 12:41am and also damaged 50 trucks. On-site search and rescue work and investigation of the cause of the accident are still underway.

images.alt_text: An explosion and fire near a chemical factory left at least 22 people dead and 22 others injured in northern China on Wednesday, authorities said.

site_title: Google workers demand end to censored Chinese search project
summary: Google workers demand an end to the development of a censored search engine for Chinese users, known as Project Dragonfly. Over 200 engineers and managers signed an open letter expressing concerns about the project's potential to aid the Chinese government in suppressing dissidents and restricting truth. The letter, published on Medium, cites a lack of progress in addressing these issues and questions Google's commitment to its values. The move escalates earlier protests against the project, which Google has described as an experiment not close to launching.

site_title: Kimly voluntarily suspends trading amid disclosure gaps
summary: Kimly Limited, Singapore's largest traditional coffee shop operator, has voluntarily suspended trading amid disclosure gaps. The company cited pending matters to be communicated to shareholders, including regulatory orders, updates on a recent acquisition, and unaudited full-year results. Market watchers suspect the disclosure gaps are related to the company's directors' disclosure in the purchase of Asian Story Corporation, a maker of Asian-flavored drinks, with some speculating an earn-out payment to the seller. The move comes after Kimly completed the acquisition of ASC in July for S$16 million.

site_title: Hong Kong finance sector M&A deals fall prey to China crackdown
summary: Hong Kong's finance sector has seen a significant decline in mergers and acquisitions (M&A) deals this year, with insurance sector deals particularly affected. Chinese buyers have largely disappeared due to Beijing's capital controls, which have tightened since 2015, limiting access to offshore funding. As a result, M&A deals worth US$1.15 billion have been made so far this year, down from US$5.1 billion in 2017. The trend is expected to continue, with non-Chinese firms potentially benefiting from the shift.

images.alt_text: Mergers and acquisitions targeting Hong Kong financial firms have slumped this year, with insurance sector deals particularly hard hit, as China's moves to tighten capital controls and crack down on corporate debt have driven mainland buyers away.

site_title: Amazon's arrival helps Queens waterfront condo secure record price
summary: Amazon's announcement of its arrival in Queens' Long Island City neighborhood has led to a surge in property sales, with one waterfront condo unit at The View selling for a record-breaking $2.077 per square foot. The two-bedroom unit, originally listed for $3.298 million, went into contract after six months on the market and received a 9.1% price cut. This sale, along with 10 others in the neighborhood, marks a shift from a buyers' market to one favoring sellers, with developers now holding out for higher prices.

site_title: Russian hackers bilked firms out of tens of millions of dollars
summary: Eight people, mostly Russian nationals, have been indicted for bilking US firms out of tens of millions of dollars through complex fake advertising schemes. The schemes, dubbed "Methbot" and another, used botnets to falsify ad views, causing companies to pay for ads not seen by human users. The schemes cost businesses over $36 million. The accused, including Aleksandr Zhukov and Sergey Ovsyannikov, were indicted on charges of wire fraud, computer intrusion, and money laundering. Six of the accused are at large, while two were arrested abroad.

site_title: Europe: Shares dip as Trump reignites trade war fears
summary: European shares fell 0.2% on Tuesday, reversing a one-week high, as US President Donald Trump threatened to impose more tariffs on Chinese products and sparked fears of a trade war with Europe. A report in Germany also raised concerns about potential new US taxes on imported cars. Analysts attributed the decline to Trump's comments, which dampened optimism over Brexit and a possible Italian budget compromise.

site_title: Netflix to adapt Roald Dahl classics to small screen
summary: Netflix has partnered with The Roald Dahl Story Company to adapt 16 of Roald Dahl's classic children's books into animated series. The series will include popular titles such as "The BFG", "Matilda", and "Willy Wonka", and aims to bring the unique magic and positive message of Dahl's stories to a global audience. Production is set to begin in 2019, with the goal of reimagining beloved characters in fresh, contemporary ways with high-quality animation and production values. The partnership is seen as a significant move to make Dahl's stories accessible to more children worldwide.

site_title: Oil prices edge lower ahead of G-20, Opec meetings
summary: Oil prices dropped on Tuesday, falling 27 cents to $60.21 a barrel for Brent crude and 7 cents to $51.56 a barrel for US West Texas Intermediate. The decline was attributed to uncertainty over the US-China trade war and increased global crude production. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) will meet on December 6 to discuss output policy, with expectations that crude exporters will agree to cut production. US President Donald Trump is set to meet with Chinese leader Xi Jinping, potentially paving the way for a trade deal.

site_title: Indonesia due to release preliminary Lion Air crash report
summary: Indonesian investigators are set to release a preliminary report on the Lion Air plane crash that killed 189 people in October. The Boeing 737 MAX had issues with its airspeed indicator and angle of attack sensors, prompting Boeing to issue a special bulletin. Investigators have retrieved the flight data recorder and found airspeed indicator issues on multiple earlier flights. Concerns have been raised about the airline's decision to put the plane back into service despite failing to fix the problem. The report is expected to shed more light on the cause of the accident but may not pinpoint a definitive cause.

site_title: China calling - and Singapore lawyers heed with ni hao!
summary: Singaporean lawyers are taking Chinese lessons to better communicate with Chinese clients and gain an edge in the market as China's economic influence grows. Several law firms, including Clifford Chance Asia and Linklaters, are sponsoring the classes, which focus on legal jargon, reading, and conversation. Lawyers say learning Chinese helps build rapport with clients and facilitates smoother communication. The move is seen as a strategic response to China's increasing global presence, with some firms already seeing benefits from the new skills, such as increased confidence in working with Mandarin-speaking clients.

images.alt_text: Li Ying (left) is a Legal Mandarin tutor. Seah Wang Ting (second from left), Keith Han and Tan Tian Yi are lawyers from Clifford Chance Asia attending Chinese lessons to tap the burgeoning China market.

site_title: GSK in exclusive discussions with Unilever about Indian Horlicks unit: FT
summary: GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) is in exclusive talks with Unilever to sell its Indian Horlicks nutrition business, reportedly worth over $4 billion. GSK beat a rival bid from Nestle, which was also seeking to expand its portfolio in the powdered hot beverages category. The sale comes after sources previously mentioned Nestle, Unilever, and Coca-Cola as potential bidders. GSK and Unilever did not comment on the talks outside of regular business hours.

site_title: China Gaoxian unit leases out Chinese properties for 4.9m yuan
summary: China Gaoxian Fibre Fabric Holdings has leased out 111 hostel units and 25,140 square meters of production space in Zhejiang Province for 4.9 million yuan annually. The lease agreements range from two years to nearly five years, with annual rental fees paid in advance. The company plans to use the annual income to cover operating expenses, considering options to revive the business. This move aims to generate additional revenue and reduce the company's financial burden.

site_title: Airbnb hires Amazon veteran as CFO ahead of IPO plans
summary: Airbnb has hired Amazon veteran Dave Stephenson as its new CFO, replacing Laurence Tosi, ahead of a planned initial public offering. Stephenson, with 17 years of experience at Amazon, will start in January. The move follows the departure of Jason Warnick, who is joining online brokerage Robinhood. Airbnb, valued at $31 billion, has been expanding its services to fuel growth, adding luxury vacation homes and hotels to its platform.

site_title: GRP unit no longer assured of winning China mixed-development project
summary: GRP Limited no longer has assurance of winning a mixed-development project in China's Tangshan city due to changes in land right policies. A 165 mu plot of land, acquired in 2016, is being repossessed by the local government and will be rezoned for mixed development. The plot's value is 63.8 million yuan, with payment due by Dec 31, 2020. GRP has disbursed 28.7 million yuan of an advance given for the first right of refusal and will negotiate to recover the amount. The repossession has no expected material impact on GRP's financial year ending June 30, 2019.

site_title: Dawn raids: how corporates can stay awake
summary: A recent report by Baker McKenzie found that 60% of Singapore businesses have no dawn raid guidelines or have not conducted any dawn raid training. Dawn raids, unannounced search and seizure operations, are becoming increasingly frequent and can lead to significant stress and reputational damage for companies. To prepare for dawn raids, businesses should have the right procedures and policies in place, including mock raids and training for staff on how to cooperate with search officers while protecting privileged information.

site_title: Hi-P rides hype of possible share deal
summary: Hi-P International's shares rose 3.77% on Tuesday as speculation about a possible share deal drove trading, despite the company denying any approaches. The shares reached S$1.17 but closed at S$1.10. Hi-P's single controlling shareholder, Executive Chairman and CEO Yao Hsiao Tung, is over 70 and has a 84.22% stake. Speculation has been fueled by Hi-P's high cash balance and lack of a concrete succession plan, with some analysts predicting the company could be an attractive target for global companies looking to build a base in Asia.

site_title: Regular exercise may keep you biologically 30 years younger
summary: A study of 28 active septuagenarians found that their muscles resemble those of healthy 25-year-olds, with similar capillaries and enzyme levels, and higher aerobic capacities than their age-matched non-exercising peers. The study's authors conclude that regular exercise may keep individuals biologically 30 years younger than their chronological age, suggesting that physical activity may alter the aging process.

site_title: UK car sector warns on Brexit no-deal 'catastrophe'
summary: The UK car sector has warned of a "catastrophe" if the country leaves the EU without a deal, citing potential plant closures, job losses, and damage to businesses. Industry body SMMT reported that nearly three-quarters of its member companies believe a no-deal Brexit would harm their business and threaten their future viability. The sector also warned of ongoing Brexit uncertainty affecting investment, with some companies postponing or cancelling UK investment decisions. The industry employs around 800,000 people and 80% of its cars are exported to Europe.

site_title: EU consumer groups want regulators to act against Google for tracking users
summary: Consumer groups in EU countries including the Netherlands, Poland, and others have asked regulators to take action against Google for allegedly tracking users' movements without consent, violating the EU's General Data Protection Regulation. The groups claim Google uses methods to encourage users to enable location history and web activity settings, which are not compliant with GDPR. Google has responded by stating that location history is turned off by default and users can control it, but the groups argue that users' consent is not freely given. The EU's GDPR allows for fines of up to 4% of global revenues for companies that break the rules.

site_title: Financial literacy firm raises US$3m in PE funding
summary: The Praxis Company, a financial literacy firm, has secured a US$3 million investment from Triple P Capital, a private equity impact investing fund. The investment will fuel development in Southeast Asia and expansion into new markets. The firm partners with schools, companies, and financial services firms to provide financial literacy education through its gameplay experiences. Six of the top 10 life insurers in the Philippines and two of the top four life insurers in Thailand already incorporate Praxis into their businesses.

site_title: France plans to triple wind power capacity by 2030
summary: France plans to triple its onshore wind power capacity to 15 Gigawatts by 2030 and multiply its solar power generation by five, aiming to boost renewable energy to 40% of its energy mix. The government will increase spending on renewables to 71 billion euros annually, up from 5 billion euros. French President Emmanuel Macron also announced plans to keep power prices from renewables low for consumers and develop more power interconnectors with European neighbors. This move aims to address France's lagging behind other European nations in renewable energy.

site_title: Gold subdued ahead of Fed chair's speech and G-20 summit
summary: Gold prices dropped 0.1% to $1,220.97 per ounce, as investors awaited the Federal Reserve chairman's speech and the G-20 summit, where US-China trade tensions are expected to escalate. US gold futures fell 0.2% to $1,220.2 an ounce. Investors are cautious due to rising interest rates and a potential slowdown in global growth, which may prompt the Fed to halt interest rate hikes sooner. Gold prices have lost over 10% from their April peak.

site_title: US: Stocks edge up ahead of trade talks
summary: US stocks closed modestly higher on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 0.4% to 24,748.73, as investors weighed the odds for progress on the US-China trade fight. Despite President Trump's dismissal of a deal on Monday, White House economic advisor Larry Kudlow expressed optimism for an agreement, citing certain conditions that must be met. US consumer confidence remained near a historically high level, but stocks were weighed down by declines in United Technologies and General Motors due to the companies' recent announcements.

site_title: ARA Asset Mgt disposes Beijing shopping mall for 2.56b yuan
summary: ARA Asset Management sold the Beijing Jingtong Roosevelt Plaza shopping mall in Beijing to Link Reit for 2.56 billion yuan (S$506.7 million). The mall, located in a mixed-use development, had 96.2% occupancy and opened in 2014. ARA acquired the property under construction and sold it according to its investment plan. Link Reit plans to hold the property as a long-term investment, aiming to enhance product and service offerings to serve the district's expanding customer base. The sale was completed on January 23, 2019.

site_title: Jokowi doubtful US, China can patch up
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo expressed skepticism that the US and China can resolve their trade dispute during the G-20 summit in Argentina, citing hostile meetings between the two leaders at the Apec gathering. Despite US President Donald Trump's threat to raise tariffs on $200 billion in Chinese imports to 25%, Widodo believes the trade war will persist, with Indonesia's financial markets already suffering from investor risk aversion. The Indonesian president urged CEOs to explore export opportunities amid global headwinds.

site_title: The Great Recession vs the Great Depression
summary: Economist J. Bradford DeLong argues that the 2007-09 Great Recession was more damaging than the Great Depression of the 1930s due to a prolonged psychological hangover from the crisis, which has led to cautious consumer and business behavior. Despite the Federal Reserve's and Congress's rapid response to the crisis, income per worker has risen only 7.5% since 2007, compared to 10.5% 11 years after the 1929 stock-market crash. DeLong blames "bad policy" for the sluggish recovery, contrasting it unfavorably with the policymakers of the 1930s, who responded to the Great Depression with a collective policy response.

site_title: China's Xi arrives in Spain for business-driven visit
summary: China's President Xi Jinping arrived in Spain on November 27, 2018, for a three-day business-focused state visit. During his visit, Xi met with King Felipe VI and Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez, and signed at least 18 business and cooperation deals, including one that opens up the Chinese market to Spanish products like "jamon" cured ham.
