The visit aims to strengthen ties with Europe as China seeks to counter the US trade war. Spain, China's largest trading partner outside the EU, hopes to expand its exports to the Chinese market.

images.alt_text: China's President Xi Jinping arrived in Spain on Tuesday for a business-focused state visit as Beijing, currently engaged in a trade war with the United States, seeks to strengthen ties with Europe.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Keong Hong Holdings sold 24 cranes and two luffing jibs for S$12.5 million, using the proceeds to fund working capital needs and pay down bank loans. The company's Q4 net profit fell 86.9% to S$6.8 million due to lower revenue. Sincap Group acquired a 48.97% stake in Orion Energy Resources for S$12 million, increasing its equity stake to 99.97%.

site_title: Facebook was warned of alleged Russian meddling back in 2014
summary: Facebook acknowledged it had warned its engineers of alleged Russian meddling as early as 2014, but did not confirm evidence of a coordinated campaign. This revelation came during British Parliament hearings on how social media companies, including Facebook, were used to manipulate election results. Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg refused to attend the meeting, prompting lawmakers to pull up an empty chair for him. The warnings were made in 2014, but the company did not publicly disclose the information until now.

images.alt_text: Facebook acknowledged on Tuesday that its engineers had flagged suspicious Russian activity as early as 2014 - long before it became public - but did not confirm evidence of a coordinated campaign.

site_title: Aramco wants to buy up chemicals companies using US$100b purse
summary: Saudi Aramco plans to acquire chemicals companies worth around $100 billion over the next decade to expand its refining and petrochemicals business. The move will delay the company's initial public offering (IPO) until 2020 or 2021. Aramco aims to double its refining capacity and transform 3 million barrels of crude into chemicals, driven by growing demand in the petrochemical industry. The company will invest $500 billion in oil, natural gas, chemicals, and refining projects over the next 10 years.

site_title: Trade tensions hoist US dollar to near 2-week highs
summary: The US dollar rose to near 2-week highs against major rivals after President Donald Trump announced plans to push ahead with tariffs on Chinese goods, fuelling concerns over world trade tensions. The dollar index rose 0.2% to 97.28, while sterling fell across the board after Trump's comments on the UK's departure from the EU. The threat of a trade conflict between the US and China is a major concern, with economists predicting a slowdown in the global economy and a potential devaluation of the Chinese yuan.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokers maintain buy recommendations for Thai Beverage (ThaiBev) and Fu Yu Corp, with revised target prices of S$0.87 and S$0.27, respectively. Despite weak FY2018 results, analysts expect the groups to return to growth in FY2019, driven by improved demand, market share gains, and monetization of assets. Fu Yu Corp is also seen as a potential takeover target due to its attractive valuation and diversified customer base. Analysts trimmed earnings forecasts for ThaiBev but still project 10% and 15% growth for FY2019 and FY2020, respectively.

site_title: Local cloud company Deskera raises over US$60m, crosses S$100m in revenue in FY17
summary: Deskera, a Singapore-based cloud company, raised over US$60 million in funding, crossing S$100 million in revenue in FY17. The platform provides cloud-based services to small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in the region. The funding will be used for research and development and integration with Singapore's new digital trade platform. Deskera also launched a B2B commerce platform, Desk, which allows SMEs to buy, sell, and transact online. The company's revenue has grown eight-fold in the last three years, with Tembusu Partners, one of its largest shareholders, expressing confidence in its potential to become a tech unicorn.

images.alt_text: Shashank Dixit, CEO of cloud tech company Deskera.

site_title: Carlos Ghosn's arrest threatens Renault-Nissan alliance with paralysis
summary: Renault and Nissan's auto alliance is threatened with disarray as executives meet to discuss a leadership vacuum following Carlos Ghosn's arrest in Japan. Ghosn, chairman of the alliance, remains in custody on allegations of understating income and misusing assets. Nissan wants to split the top job between the three companies, while Renault's French government insists the chairman should lead the alliance. The alliance, which produces more vehicles than Volkswagen, needs to sort out its differences to avoid falling behind rivals, with analysts warning of the consequences of paralysis.

site_title: IHH Healthcare sinks into the red for Q3 on unit's forex losses
summary: IHH Healthcare, a Malaysia-incorporated healthcare group, posted a net loss of RM104.1 million (S$34.2 million) in Q3, reversing from a profit of RM82.1 million in the same period last year. The loss was primarily due to foreign exchange losses on borrowings of RM752.5 million by its Turkish unit. Revenue was up 1% year-on-year, and the group expects to more than double its Q3 net profit excluding exceptional items. IHH managing director Tan See Leng attributed the loss to forex volatility in Turkey and expressed optimism about the group's operational resilience.

site_title: Google spends US$1b on property next to California HQ
summary: Google has spent $1 billion on a 21ha business park next to its California headquarters, expanding its real estate portfolio. The deal surpasses the largest real estate purchase in Silicon Valley this year, amid fierce competition for offices among tech firms. Google has recently acquired office space in Sunnyvale and is facing a legal backlash over plans to build a massive development in San Jose. The purchase marks the company's latest expansion, following a $2.4 billion purchase of Chelsea Market in New York.

site_title: India pushing its central bank to lift lending curbs on some banks: sources
summary: India's government is set to push the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) to ease lending restrictions for some weak banks, with the goal of removing them from a list of lenders subject to prompt corrective action. The proposal aims to address concerns about the financial health of 11 state-run lenders. A board meeting on December 14 is expected to discuss the plan, amid ongoing disputes between the Finance Ministry and RBI over issues such as lending rules, liquidity, and bad loan management.

site_title: Change is the mantra for future law practice in Singapore
summary: Singapore law firms must adapt to changing client demands and technological disruption to survive. Clients now expect lawyers to provide more than just legal services, driving innovation and competition in the market. Law firms need to re-engineer their business models, develop additional non-legal services, and leverage technology to improve efficiency and client intimacy. The concept of "RightLaw" firms, which combine law with other services, is gaining traction, and Singapore firms must follow suit to stay ahead. Change is inevitable, and law firms must be willing to adapt to evolve and thrive in this new landscape.

site_title: Genting Malaysia falls 19% after it files US$1b suit
summary: Genting Malaysia, a Malaysian casino operator, has filed a $1 billion lawsuit against The Walt Disney Co. and 21st Century Fox, alleging they failed to honor a 2013 deal to license intellectual property for a theme park project in the country. The suit claims Disney and Fox were seeking to terminate the contract due to the park's proximity to a casino, which would harm their "family-friendly" image. Genting Malaysia is seeking damages in excess of $1 billion and vows to fully enforce its rights under the deal.

site_title: Vietnam ranks top in total funds raised via IPOs across S-E Asia
summary: Vietnam has emerged as the top performer in South-east Asia's initial public offerings (IPOs) in 2018, raising a total of $6.2 billion, accounting for 52% of the region's total funds raised. Thailand came in second, with $3.2 billion, and Vinhomes Joint Stock Company's listing as the top blockbuster IPO in Vietnam. The government's privatisation drive and market reforms have contributed to the surge in IPO activity, with prominent foreign investors such as GIC and Fidelity investing in Vietnamese companies.

site_title: Local stocks snap gaining streak on back of US tariff threats
summary: Singapore stocks snapped a four-day winning streak on Tuesday, falling 2.98 points, or 0.1%, to 3,090.4, due to US President Donald Trump's threats to widen tariffs on Chinese imports. The Straits Times Index was down 0.1% with losers beating gainers 192 to 185. Most Asian markets, however, showed resilience, with Japan's Topix rising 0.7% and Australia's ASX 200 up 1%. The US-China trade tensions and potential for further tariffs weighed on the market.

site_title: Semiconductor firm SSMC opens S$300m facility
summary: SSMC, a Singapore-based semiconductor firm, opened a S$300 million facility, Annex 10, with a 34% increase in space for automotive and specialty chip manufacturing. The new clean room will enable SSMC to raise its production of automotive wafers from 26% to 40% by 2023, supporting its strategic direction in the automotive and high-performance mixed signal segments. The facility features Industry 4.0 technologies and will be used for chip sets for car infotainment, in-vehicle networks, and secure car access.

site_title: Maritime industry setting sights on cybersecurity tools
summary: The maritime industry is increasingly focusing on cybersecurity tools to protect against data breaches and cyber threats. Major companies such as ABS and Hyundai Heavy Industries have collaborated to develop cybersecurity requirements for marine assets, with ABS issuing the first-of-its-kind CS-Ready Notation to a large-scale commercial vessel. Other companies, including Inmarsat and Wärtsilä, are also developing cybersecurity solutions and training programs for seafarers. The industry is taking steps to address the human element of cybersecurity, such as crew education, and is promoting innovation and collaboration to strengthen maritime cybersecurity.

site_title: Trump stays adamant, may raise China tariffs
summary: US President Donald Trump said he is "highly unlikely" to accept China's request to hold off on increasing tariffs on $200 billion in Chinese imports to 25% from 10%. Trump plans to impose the tariffs, which are set to take effect on January 1, unless China agrees to "open up their country to competition from the United States." If negotiations fail, Trump will also impose tariffs on the remaining $67 billion in Chinese imports. China's leaders hope to set guidelines for future talks and settle the trade war, but Trump remains resolute in his stance.

site_title: Domestic demand takes centre stage
summary: Domestic demand is expected to drive Asia's economic growth in 2019, as external funding pressures ease and global growth moderates. The US economy is expected to slow down, leading to a decrease in US dollar strength, which will benefit economies with current account deficits like India and Indonesia. Global growth is forecasted to moderate to 3.6% year-on-year, with a focus on autonomous domestic demand to drive growth. Elections in key countries such as India, Indonesia, and the Philippines are also expected to impact growth trajectories, with some countries benefiting from increased government spending and others facing tighter policy to manage macro stability risks.

site_title: DBS to expand in Middle East, will double number of private bankers
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest bank, plans to expand its presence in the Middle East, positioning its Dubai office as a strategic hub for clients seeking to access the Asian market. The bank aims to double its number of private bankers in Dubai to over 40 and triple its revenue over the next five years. This expansion follows rival Bank of Singapore's plans to capture the Middle East's wealthy Indian diaspora. DBS will offer bespoke investment portfolios and structured products, leveraging its Asian network and digital capabilities to support Middle East clients in accessing Asia's growth opportunities.

site_title: Slowing capex in US indicates that growth driver is faltering
summary: US business investment, known as capex, is slowing due to uncertainty from the trade war with China, political gridlock, and rising borrowing costs. Companies are using tax savings for buybacks and dividends rather than investment, raising questions about the outlook for US growth. The Federal Reserve's ability to raise interest rates and the value of the US dollar also depend on capex. Experts warn that a slowdown in capex could lead to reduced forecasts, tighter financial conditions, and lower productivity, which could impact wage gains and the economy's long-term speed limit.

site_title: China's cash crunch brings a dead funding tool back to life
summary: China's cash crunch has led two firms to plan public placements, a share sale method unused since 2014 due to tightened financing rules. The firms aim to raise funds for robotics and car parts projects. Policymakers must balance controlling new share supply with ensuring companies access funding, particularly after a contraction in China's shadow banking industry. Regulators may approve the public placements, which could help companies grow and reduce debt burdens, but critics say more rule simplifications are needed to make the process easier.

site_title: Why emerging markets face a brighter 2019 after a rotten 2018
summary: Emerging markets are expected to experience a brighter 2019 after a tumultuous 2018, with key trends including China policy easing, a potential Federal Reserve pause, and a possible halt in the US-China trade war. Morgan Stanley strategists predict a "triple trend reversal" that would benefit emerging market equities, with the MSCI Emerging Market Index potentially climbing to 1,100 by year-end. Reduced trade tensions and valuations approaching "crisis levels" are seen as long-term buying opportunities, with some strategists projecting a 13% advance for the index in 2019.

site_title: The time is right to move the fintech sector towards maturity
summary: The fintech sector is facing a downturn, with a US$600 billion loss in value and numerous fraudulent initial coin offerings. Regulatory challenges have hindered the industry's progress, but Singapore is positioning itself as a regulatory haven. The Monetary Authority of Singapore has introduced a framework for digital tokens and a Payment Services Bill to strengthen consumer protection. Industry self-regulation is also gaining traction, with organizations such as the Financial Industry Regulatory Association and the Virtual Commodity Association emerging. As the industry faces introspection and innovation, it is time for major players to collaborate on enforceable best practices to protect investors and ensure market fairness.

site_title: JMO to pump millions in Pine Capital for major equity stake
summary: Pine Capital Group is raising S$2.15 million through a share placement to private-owned management consultancy firm JMO Pte Ltd, receiving 799 million shares at a 170% premium. JMO will also lend Pine Capital S$2.7 million, convertible into 1 billion shares. The funds will be used for general working capital and business opportunities, with fees to be paid to Empire Elites Venture, a British Virgin Islands-incorporated entity. Pine Capital's board has been granted a mandate to issue the shares, but will seek shareholder approval if the loan is converted to equity.

site_title: US firm sets up US$1.4m photonics innovation centre in Singapore
summary: A US-based firm, Palomar Technologies, has established a US$1.4m photonics innovation centre in Singapore, offering SMEs and startups advanced assembly services for prototypes. The centre provides automated component packaging systems and contract assembly solutions, with applications including fibre-optic cables and LED bulbs. This move is expected to support businesses in leveraging photonics technology, a field that has vast potential for innovation and growth.

site_title: Removing Indonesia palm oil levy will not help prices, says refiner group
summary: Indonesia's government plans to lower export levies on crude palm oil to zero, aiming to boost competitiveness, but a refiner group says this won't help prices. The levies, currently between US$20 to US$50 per tonne, finance biodiesel and replanting programs. Removing the levy for CPO is unlikely to relieve stock build-up or drop prices, according to the Indonesian Vegetable Oil Industry Association. The move is expected to improve Indonesian palm export competitiveness, but will remove incentives for local refiners.

site_title: GM CEO is starting to look cold-blooded
summary: General Motors CEO Mary Barra is making significant changes to the company, including closing five plants and slashing 14,000 jobs in North America. The move is part of a strategy to focus on electric and self-driving vehicles, with investments in new technologies such as autonomous electric models. Barra's gamble on self-driving taxis is seen as a huge risk by industry analyst Maryann Keller, who questions the technology's readiness and profitability. The company's decision comes amid a slowdown in the Chinese market, where GM faces increased competition and declining sales.

images.alt_text: Ms Barra is taking the savings from cutting jobs and ploughing it into new technologies, betting that GM's future growth will come from selling rides in self-driving electric models.

site_title: First Ship Lease Trust plans 3-for-2 rights issue to raise S$43m
summary: FIRST Ship Lease Trust plans a 3-for-2 rights issue to raise up to S$43.03 million, with up to 956 million new units to be issued at a discounted price of S$0.045 per unit. The offering aims to strengthen the trust's financial position and enhance its fleet renewal, with at least half of the proceeds going towards acquiring new vessels. Unitholders will benefit from the increased market capitalization and potentially improved trading liquidity.

site_title: More than 100 China scientists denounce baby gene-editing as 'crazy'
summary: More than 100 Chinese scientists have denounced the use of CRISPR-Cas9 technology to edit human genes as "crazy" and unethical. The scientists, most of whom are in China, wrote an open letter criticizing the practice of altering human genes after a geneticist, He Jiankui, claimed to have done so to protect twin girls from HIV infection. China's National Health Commission has launched an investigation into the matter, and the government's medical ethics committee has also been informed. The scientists warn that the practice harms the reputation and development of the biomedical community in China.

images.alt_text: A DNA research laboratory for gene sequencing in Nanjing. Chinese scientists say gene editing is risky and unjustified.

site_title: 'Buy Singapore last'? Roundtable shrugs off fear of a hawkish Malaysia
summary: Singapore's economy is unlikely to be significantly impacted by Malaysia's election of Mahathir Mohamad, despite concerns over his hawkish stance. Experts at the 30th Singapore Economic Roundtable noted investment opportunities in infrastructure, but cautioned that political succession remains a wild card. The relationship between the two countries is expected to remain relatively stable.

site_title: Learning Chinese transcends just speaking the language
summary: Learning Chinese is not just about speaking the language, but also acquiring soft skills and cultural sensitivity. Trainer June Gu's Chinese workshops cover cultural-sensitivity training, vocabulary, and soft skills, tailored to specific fields such as law. The Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce & Industry's Business Mandarin courses have over 12,000 graduates, including lawyers, and its China-ready programme provides a deeper understanding of the Chinese economy, market, and socio-cultural norms. This comprehensive approach prepares participants for increasing trade-growth opportunities with China.

images.alt_text: Apart from Legal Mandarin tutor Li Ying (left), other coaches stress acquiring soft skills and being culturally sensitive to China clients.

site_title: Top fund buys Tencent and China stocks, sells US tech giants
summary: A top-performing global equity fund, Nomura Global Equity Fund, has increased its exposure to China, buying shares in Tencent Holdings Ltd and doubling down on China investments, citing government stimulus boosting shares. The fund has reduced its exposure to US tech giants, including Microsoft and Amazon, amid concerns about high valuations. China stocks, which have slumped 22% this year, are expected to rebound, with valuations considered relatively cheap, particularly in technology, consumption, and healthcare sectors.

site_title: Shell positions itself to gain from rising demand for EVs
summary: Royal Dutch Shell plc is positioning itself to gain from the growing demand for electric vehicles (EVs), despite higher oil prices. Istvan Kapitany, head of Shell's global retail business, notes that consumers' emotional connection to EVs, such as the "joy of driving" experience, is driving adoption. Shell plans to expand its EV-charging stations in Europe, increasing them to 100 by the end of 2019, and is revamping its convenience stores to offer more services, such as battery-charging and car-sharing. The company estimates 1.2-1.5 million EVs will be added this year, with EV sales expected to rise to 55% of new cars sold globally by 2040.

site_title: Will Xi-Trump meeting result in a thaw or deep freeze?
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping and US President Donald Trump will meet at the G20 Summit in Argentina, where they will address the ongoing trade war between the two countries. Analysts predict a tense meeting, with neither leader willing to back down publicly, but both suffering economically. The US is under pressure from agricultural and manufacturing sectors, while China faces economic pressure due to declining equity markets and a depreciated yuan. Despite this, both leaders are transaction-oriented and understand the benefits of finding a solution, leading to cautious optimism that meaningful progress will be made during the meeting.

site_title: Trump move on Medicare drugs draws flak
summary: The Trump administration proposed a plan to cut costs for Medicare by reducing the number of prescription drugs that must be made available to people with certain conditions, such as cancer, AIDS, and depression. Under the proposal, health insurance plans that provide drug coverage to Medicare beneficiaries would no longer have to cover all the drugs in six "protected classes." The change would lead to lower out-of-pocket costs for Medicare beneficiaries, but critics argue that it could limit access to essential medicines and harm people with these conditions. The proposal would take effect in 2020 and is part of the administration's efforts to "bring soaring drug prices back down to earth."

site_title: May appeals to voters to pressure MPs to accept Brexit agreement
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May is launching a nationwide campaign to persuade MPs to support her Brexit agreement with the EU, which requires 320 votes to pass. May warned that a no vote could lead to a potential economic crisis. The deal includes a £39 billion payment to the EU and guarantees rights for EU citizens in the UK and vice versa. May appealed to MPs to put aside differences and consider the national interest, and faces opposition from Labour MPs demanding another referendum.

site_title: PM Lee to attend G-20 summit
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong will attend the G-20 Leaders' Summit in Buenos Aires from Wednesday to Saturday, focusing on strengthening economic cooperation with Argentina. He will be hosted to breakfast by President Mauricio Macri and meet with local officials. This marks Lee's first working visit to Argentina.

site_title: Knowledge, ignorance and climate change
summary: Philosophers' insights on skepticism can shed light on public discourse about climate change. Despite overwhelming scientific evidence, some individuals, like US President Donald Trump, express doubt about human-caused global warming, citing ignorance. However, a philosophical perspective suggests that this "ignorance" may be a result of "sceptical pressure" cases, where individuals focus on the possibility of error, leading to doubt despite abundant evidence. To counter scepticism, switching to a probability-based perspective can make claims less persuasive, as people are often willing to accept objective probabilities.

site_title: Analyst who nailed 2018 has same S&P 500 forecast for 2019
summary: Morgan Stanley's chief US equity strategist, Mike Wilson, has forecast that the S&P 500 will end 2019 at 2,750, matching his 2018 prediction. This is about 3% above the current level. Wilson expects a "material" deceleration in corporate profits due to weakening global growth and rising interest rates, but notes the Federal Reserve's potential pause in interest-rate hikes will help offset this. He predicts a range of 2,400 to 3,000 for the S&P 500 in 2019, with stocks likely to swing wildly as expectations are reset.

site_title: Fed official upbeat on economy, but rate hikes to be gradual
summary: US economy faces fewer risks, poised for expansion, but Federal Reserve officials will move gradually to raise interest rates, watching for signs of inflation and labor market developments. Fed Vice Chairman Richard Clarida stated that risks are "less skewed to the downside" and US economic fundamentals are robust, indicating a likely record-long expansion. The central bank will aim to keep inflation below 2% while supporting full employment, with policymakers considering a cautious approach to rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Fed Vice Chairman Richard Clarida stressed that officials will be watching for signs of inflation and developments in labour markets before making any decision to raise the benchmark lending rate.

site_title: China to designate more financial institutions as 'too big to fail'
summary: China's financial regulators plan to designate more financial institutions as "systemically important" (SIFIs) due to the country's swelling debt burden and financial risks. Policymakers will evaluate institutions based on assets, business complexity, and interconnectedness. Designated firms will face extra capital requirements and additional rules on leverage, risk exposure, and information disclosure. This move aims to strengthen oversight of China's $40 trillion financial system and address concerns raised by the International Monetary Fund. The goal is to prevent a crisis similar to the 2008 global financial crisis.

site_title: Spain rejects China's Silk Road plan
summary: Spain has rejected China's "One Belt, One Road" initiative, a multi-billion-dollar project aimed at linking Asia and Europe through a network of ports, railways, and industrial parks. The decision was made ahead of President Xi Jinping's visit to Spain, citing the European Union's own connectivity initiative as a reason. This move follows similar rejections by countries such as Poland and Greece, which have expressed concerns over Beijing's influence. The decision is seen as a blow to China's efforts to expand its project, with China valuing memoranda of understanding signed by 70 countries as a significant signal of interest.

site_title: ESG factors in play; companies must take sustainability metrics seriously
summary: Singapore-listed companies have shown improvement in publishing sustainability reports, with 48.2% of companies reporting their sustainability practices before May 2018. However, the average quality of sustainability disclosures did not improve. Top-performing companies, such as City Developments and DBS Group Holdings, dominated the list of companies with the highest level of sustainability disclosures. ESG reporting is gaining attention from investors, with BlackRock's CEO predicting that all investors will use ESG metrics in the future. Companies must take sustainability metrics seriously to avoid falling off investors' radar, with regional pension funds such as Japan's GPIF and South Korea's NPS already integrating ESG principles into their investment processes.

site_title: Bahrain central bank considers new guidance for Islamic banks
summary: Bahrain's central bank is considering new guidance for Islamic banks, covering Islamic windows, investment accounts, and benchmark rates. The regulator aims to ensure fair treatment of depositors and develop regulations for Islamic retail banks. The existing governance rules for fully-fledged Islamic banks will be extended to cover Islamic windows, while a performance benchmark rate will be introduced to replace the current interbank rate. The move aims to promote the Islamic banking sector, which is closely followed by other jurisdictions.

site_title: Climate change deniers are blocking progress, UN report suggests
summary: The UN's annual climate change assessment report suggests climate change deniers are blocking progress, with global emissions rising and no sign of peaking. For the first time, the report singles out political ideology as a major obstacle, citing "solution aversion" and cost aversion as barriers to implementing climate policies. To meet the 1.5°C goal, national targets must be made five times more ambitious, and behavioral change is critical to building support for climate policies.

site_title: Keppel-KBS US Reit buys second Florida asset for US$48.5m
summary: Keppel-KBS US Reit acquired Maitland Promenade I, an Orlando, Florida office property, for US$48.5 million. The 230,371 square foot property has a 98.1% occupancy rate and will be the Reit's second Florida asset. The acquisition is part of the Reit's strategy to grow its portfolio in "first choice submarkets" with positive macroeconomic and office fundamentals, and is expected to improve committed portfolio occupancy from 90.1% to 91.9%. The deal brings total assets under management to US$1.04 billion.

images.alt_text: Mr Snyder: "Maitland Promenade I extends Keppel-KBS US Reit's foothold in the strong Maitland office submarket."

site_title: Sincap acquires more equity in Orion Energy for S$12m
summary: Sincap Group has acquired 48.97% of Orion Energy Resources Pte Ltd for S$12 million, increasing its equity stake to 99.97%. A three-year non-listed, non-tradable convertible bond with a 5% annual interest will be issued to Magnigrow Capital, the sole shareholder of Orion Energy. Sincap views Orion Energy as a financially strong and profitable entity, with a net asset value of over US$18.69 million as of 2017.

site_title: Kim Heng to sell equipment for S$12.5m
summary: Kim Heng Offshore & Marine Holdings agreed to sell two dozen cranes and two luffing jibs to Hup Hin Heavy Equipment for S$12.5 million. The sale will lower net gearing ratio and fund working capital, business expansion, and loan repayment. Hup Hin will pay S$625,000 upfront and S$11.88 million upon completion. The deal is conditional on obtaining loan approval from a financial institution.

site_title: Amazon is adding more India retailers to its shopping cart
summary: Amazon is expanding its presence in India by acquiring stakes in several brick-and-mortar retailers, including Shoppers Stop and More. The move aims to gain access to smaller cities and offline consumers, where online shopping is less prevalent. Amazon's long-term strategy in India, known as "omni-channel," involves integrating online and offline retail to better understand shopping trends and customer behavior. The company's aggressive expansion in India comes after it lost a deal to Walmart in the country's leading e-commerce company, Flipkart.

site_title: Trump may impose tariffs on imported cars from next week - report
summary: US President Donald Trump may impose tariffs on imported cars from next week, according to a German magazine report. The proposed 25% customs duty on car imports from all countries except Canada and Mexico is based on a US Department of Commerce investigation report. This news led to European auto stocks extending losses, with VW, BMW, and Daimler shares falling as much as 2.8%, 1.6%, and 2.2%, respectively. The move comes amid fears of tariffs and slowing car sales growth, which have driven investors away from the sector, with autos stocks down 20% year-to-date.

site_title: Painstakingly, putting it together, bit by remarkable bit
summary: Lin-Manuel Miranda and the creative team behind the hit musical Hamilton reflect on the song "Satisfied," which cemented the show's legacy. The song, sung by Angelica Schuyler, was a pivotal moment in the show's development, as it introduced a new character and emotional core. The team, comprising Miranda, Thomas Kail, Alex Lacamoire, and Andy Blankenbuehler, credit their trust and collaboration as key to the song's success. "Satisfied" showcases the team's ability to blend cultural references, wit, and emotional depth, making it a standout number in the show.

site_title: Uber fined £385,000 by UK regulator over 2016 cyber attack
summary: Uber Technologies Inc was fined £385,000 by the UK's Information Commissioner's Office for a 2016 cyber attack that compromised the data of 2.7 million UK customers and 82,000 drivers. The breach, which included personal details such as email addresses and phone numbers, was not reported for over a year. Uber paid hackers $100,000 to destroy the data, and the company's failure to inform affected individuals left them vulnerable. The fine is part of a series of regulatory issues Uber is facing, including battles with London drivers over employment status and a new 15-month probationary license.

site_title: HSBC warms up to India ahead of general polls
summary: HSBC upgraded Indian equities to "neutral" from "underweight" ahead of the 2019 general polls, citing reasonable valuations, low investor holdings, and strong earnings growth. The market is expected to gain, driven by pro-growth policies implemented before elections. MSCI India EPS growth consensus is 18.8% in 2018 and 24% in 2019. However, currency weakness and volatile oil prices remain key risks. Morgan Stanley also expects India's growth recovery to continue, with a GDP forecast of 7.7% and 7.6% in 2018 and 2019, respectively.

site_title: DBS expands in the Middle East, will double the number of private bankers over 5 years
summary: DBS, South-east Asia's largest bank, has announced expansion plans in the Middle East, aiming to double its number of private bankers in Dubai over the next five years. The bank will utilize its Dubai office as a strategic hub for the Middle East, focusing on ultra-high net worth and high net worth individuals seeking access to the Asian market. DBS plans to triple its revenue in the region by increasing client diversity, spread, and penetration. The bank's expansion is driven by the growing wealth segment in the Middle East, with the number of UHNW clients projected to increase by 28% to approximately 500 by 2022.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end with a loss
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed lower on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index shedding 0.17% due to investor uncertainty over US-China trade talks. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index declined 1.13 points, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.43%. The decline follows US President Donald Trump's warning that he could escalate his trade war if talks with Chinese President Xi Jinping do not reach a deal.

site_title: Lawmakers criticise Facebook's Zuckerberg for UK parliament no-show
summary: Lawmakers in the UK have criticized Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg for not attending a parliamentary hearing on the company's handling of user data, particularly in relation to the Cambridge Analytica scandal. Facebook is being investigated for its practices and possible interference in elections, with concerns over data analytics and political adverts. Zuckerberg's absence was seen as a significant oversight, with lawmakers accusing the company of undermining democratic institutions. Facebook has admitted to mistakes and accepted the need to comply with data rules, but has not provided examples of individuals or apps banned for data misuse.

site_title: UK banks extend credit ahead of Brexit
summary: UK banks are extending credit to businesses ahead of a potential Brexit, aiming to mitigate risks of a cash crunch. Banks such as Royal Bank of Scotland and CYBG are offering credit, insurance, and loans to protect against delays in cross-border shipments and payments, as well as volatility in sterling. The move is part of efforts to prepare businesses for a potential Brexit, with some banks identifying nearly 2,000 at-risk companies across various sectors.

site_title: Semiconductor firm SSMC opens new S$300m facility
summary: SSMC, a semiconductor firm, has opened a new S$300 million facility in Singapore, expanding its footprint in the country. The 4,400 sq m facility will increase automotive chip manufacturing space by 34% and boost production capacity to 40% by 2023. The facility features Industry 4.0 technologies, including robots, IoT, and big data analytics, supporting SSMC's move into the automotive and High Performance Mixed Signal segments. The expansion reflects the company's long-term commitment to high-value manufacturing in Singapore.

site_title: EU to take next step in disciplinary action against Italy this week
summary: The European Union is set to take disciplinary action against Italy this week over its excessive debt, with European Commission's disciplinary move expected to be backed by EU governments' delegates. Italy's debt is not compliant with EU regulations, requiring a reduction in excessive debt. The decision on formally starting disciplinary proceedings could be delayed until February, offering a conciliatory note for Rome. The EU's Economic and Financial Committee has concluded that Italy's debt criterion should be considered not complied with, warranting the Excessive Deficit Procedure.

site_title: Keong Hong posts 87% fall in Q4 net profit in absence of one-time gain
summary: Keong Hong Holdings reported a 86.9% decline in Q4 net profit to S$6.8 million due to lower revenue and the absence of an exceptional gain. Full-year net profit fell 64.8% to S$22.08 million. The company's construction order book stands at S$376.1 million, and it declared an interim dividend per share of 0.5 Singapore cents. Despite the challenging construction industry, Keong Hong is optimistic about a pick-up in the private residential sector and plans to launch two property developments in 2024.

site_title: Snapchat selfie sparks terror scare on Indian flight
summary: A 21-year-old Indian passenger, Yogvedant Poddar, was detained for almost 10 hours after posting a Snapchat photo with the word "terrorist" on a Jet Airways flight from Kolkata to Mumbai. The photo showed half of his face covered with a handkerchief. After questioning, authorities found no terror link and the passenger was let go without charge. The incident occurred amidst a surge in passenger numbers in India's aviation market, with many first-time flyers taking advantage of cheap fares. The airline stated that the passenger was removed for security reasons and the flight departed with a revised timing.

site_title: Singapore, Malaysia and Indonesia listcos less exposed to cyber threats than global peers: Survey
summary: Singapore, Malaysia, and Indonesia-listed companies are less exposed to cyber threats, with 29% of Singapore's companies, 30% of Indonesia's, and 40% of Malaysia's having some exposure. The global average is 55%. Indonesia had the lowest score (9.56), followed by Hong Kong (13.0) and Singapore (37.7). The industrials industry is the most exposed in Singapore and Malaysia, while Indonesia's energy sector is most at risk. Cyber exposure can lead to sabotage and damage, making it crucial for companies to assess their exposure.

site_title: Spare cash? Last chance to bid for Jho Low's US$250m yacht
summary: The Equanimity yacht, once owned by fugitive businessman Jho Low and used to host high-profile parties, is up for auction in Malaysia with a starting price of US$250 million. The 300-foot vessel, seized in March as part of global efforts to recoup assets allegedly lost through the 1MDB scandal, is expected to sell to a buyer who will receive a globally recognized ownership title. The sale aims to recover funds believed to be missing from 1MDB, with Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad seeking to recover US$4.5 billion.

site_title: Dubai's Emaar picks Standard Chartered to advise on sale of hotel assets
summary: Standard Chartered has been appointed as financial adviser by Dubai's Emaar Properties to sell its hotel assets in Dubai to Abu Dhabi National Hotels. The deal is expected to close by the start of next year and aims to achieve strategic priorities and unlock shareholder value for both companies.

site_title: Jack Ma, China's richest man, is a Communist Party member
summary: Jack Ma, China's richest man and founder of Alibaba, has been revealed as a member of the Communist Party of China, according to the People's Daily. Ma's membership was previously unknown, despite his business rival Pony Ma and Baidu's Robin Li not being affiliated with the party. The move comes as President Xi Jinping pushes to expand the party's influence in private business, with the party now requiring companies with over three party members to set up a party cell. Ma's membership highlights the growing relationship between the party and business in China, where joining the party can be beneficial for private businessmen and women navigating the country's complex business environment.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Regulators in Singapore are seeking documents from coffee shop operator Kimly amid a stock suspension, pending updates on a recent acquisition and unaudited full-year results. The Singapore services sector experienced an 8% revenue growth in Q3, surpassing the second quarter's 7.7% growth. A major shareholder of contract manufacturer Hi-P International is considering a deal, potentially leading to a takeover. Keppel-KBS US Reit acquired an office property in Florida for $48.5 million. Singapore shares ended lower, with the Straits Times Index dropping 0.1%.

images.alt_text: Local coffee shop operator Kimly Limited has received regulatory orders to provide certain information and documents, and is suspending the trading of its stock pending updates, according to a filing to the Singapore Exchange on Tuesday morning.

site_title: IHH in the red for Q3 after forex loss
summary: IHH Healthcare, a Malaysia-incorporated healthcare group, posted a net loss of RM104.1 million (S$34.2 million) for the third quarter, reversing from a profit of RM82.1 million the previous year. Foreign exchange losses on borrowings of a business unit, particularly in Turkey, contributed to the loss. Revenue was RM2.8 billion, up 1% year-on-year, and excluding exceptional items, the group would have more than doubled its Q3 net profit to RM309 million.

site_title: Europe: Shares dip as focus turns to Sino-US trade dispute
summary: European shares fell 0.3% on Tuesday as the Sino-US trade dispute gained focus, with US President Donald Trump threatening to raise tariffs on $200 billion in Chinese imports to 25%. The pan-European STOXX 600 benchmark also fell after Thomas Cook cut its profit forecast and suspended its dividend, dragging down shares in peer companies like TUI. Copper prices slid, pressured by Trump's comments, while travel stocks were under pressure due to the hot British summer.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 17.02 points lower to 1,684.97 on Tuesday, with volume reaching 2.2 billion lots worth RM2.6 billion. Losers outpaced gainers 686 to 199.

site_title: Italy consumer, business confidence drops
summary: Italy's consumer and business confidence dropped in November, with the business confidence index falling to 101.1 points and consumer confidence dropping to 114.8 points. The populist government's draft budget deficit may be limited to 2.2% of GDP, boosting hopes for easing a stand-off with the European Union. However, analysts warn that key electoral measures remain unaddressed, and stress that the impact of Italy's big-spending budget could spread to other European countries. The European Central Bank's Mario Draghi also warned of the risks of unsustainable economic policies in the eurozone.

site_title: Wishful thinking that EU will reopen Brexit talks if Parliament rejects deal - UK minister
summary: UK Minister David Lidington says it's "wishful thinking" that the EU will reopen Brexit negotiations if the British parliament rejects Prime Minister Theresa May's deal. Lidington stated that the EU is "very clear" they won't revisit the package if it's voted down. The UK faces an uphill struggle to get the deal approved by parliament on December 11, with politicians from both parties opposing it. Parliament must decide between accepting the deal or voting it down, with no alternative plan from the EU.

site_title: Indonesia's new 'heresy app' draws fire
summary: Indonesia's new "Smart Pakem" app, launched by the Jakarta Prosecutor's Office, allows users to report suspected cases of religious heresy, sparking concerns from rights groups that it could aggravate persecution of minorities. The app, available for free, lets users report groups practicing unrecognised faiths or unorthodox interpretations of the country's six officially recognised religions. Critics warn it could be misused by hardline Islamic groups to discriminate against religious minorities, who already face harassment and limited access to public services.

site_title: Malaysia's Petronas to hike govt payout as Q3 profit jumps 43 per cent
summary: Malaysia's state-owned energy firm Petronas has announced a 43% increase in its third-quarter net profit to 14.3 billion ringgit, driven by higher revenue and oil prices. The company will also hike its dividend payout to the government by 2 billion ringgit, exceeding its previously committed 24 billion ringgit. The move is seen as a boost to the government's revenue, which is facing a shortfall due to the scrapping of a consumption tax. Petronas's production volume rose to 2.313 million barrels of oil equivalent per day, but LNG sales volume dropped by 1.12 million tonnes.

site_title: Saudi Aramco plans gas investments of US$150b over next decade - CEO
summary: Saudi Aramco plans to invest US$150 billion in its gas program over the next decade, with production expected to grow to 23 billion standard cubic feet per day from the current 14 billion. CEO Amin Nasser also announced plans to invest US$100 billion in chemicals globally over the next 10 years, including potential acquisitions.

site_title: Singapore shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Singapore stocks dropped 2.98 points, or 0.1%, to 3,090.4, with 185 gainers to 192 losers. The most actively traded counter was Spackman, rising 11.54%. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC Bank ended the day with gains. Other notable movers included offshore and oil-linked stocks, with some losing ground. The market was influenced by global economic concerns, including US-EU trade talks and new Trump threats.

site_title: Just say no: Adios cocaine as cocoa becomes hot in the Amazon
summary: Farmers in the Amazon are shifting away from growing coca for cocaine and instead cultivating cocoa, driven by government anti-drug trafficking efforts. Peruvian cocoa production is expected to surge to a record 155,800 metric tons in 2018-19, with over 25,000 farms abandoning coca production. This increase in high-quality cocoa production has boosted Peru's exports 10-fold since 2008 and improved the country's international reputation. However, a new EU regulation may limit Peru's cocoa exports due to high levels of cadmium in the region's growing regions.

site_title: Hot stock: Hi-P shares up 7.6% after news of major shareholder mulling deal
summary: Hi-P International shares rose 7.6% to S$1.14 on the Singapore bourse, driven by news that a controlling shareholder is considering a deal. The company's stock surged 30.9% on Monday, its highest volume in over five years. Analysts Lai Gene Lih and Ling Lee Keng maintained "hold" calls, citing a weak demand environment due to the trade war. However, they noted potential risks to estimates, including an escalation of the trade war or worsening demand outlook.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks tick up as carmakers shares rise; won edges down
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 0.79% to 2,099.42, driven by gains in carmakers' shares, including Hyundai Motor's 6.2% increase. The won edged down 0.04% to 1,129.4 per dollar. Despite US President Donald Trump's fresh remarks on the US-China trade spat, investors remained cautious. Consumer sentiment in South Korea fell to a near two-year low, while inflation expectations decreased to their lowest since August 2016.

site_title: Euro bond traders, platforms trigger "Plan B" for no-deal Brexit
summary: Euro bond traders and investment banks are accelerating plans to move business to the EU due to a potential no-deal Brexit, fearing they'll lose access to continental clients. The London Stock Exchange will shift a fifth of its trading volume to Milan, while rival platforms are moving business to Amsterdam. Trading in British government bonds will remain in London. This "Plan B" move is expected to significantly impact the European bond market, with potential implications for the UK economy and financial markets.

site_title: Islamic finance sees mixed growth, buoyed by capital market - study
summary: The Islamic finance industry experienced mixed growth in 2017, with a 11% year-on-year increase, driven by capital market products and fintech adoption. The industry now spans 56 countries, with 1,389 sharia-compliant firms and $2.4 trillion in assets. Islamic banks, accounting for 71% of total assets, grew at 5%, while capital market products, such as sukuk and investment funds, posted 9% and 16% growth, respectively. The industry is poised for further change with fintech products, including digital-only Islamic banks and robo-advisors.

site_title: Lawsuit against Disney, Fox hits Malaysian casino operator's shares
summary: Malaysian casino operator Genting filed a $1 billion lawsuit against Disney and 21st Century Fox for allegedly abandoning a theme park project in the country. The suit claims Fox sought to terminate the contract and Disney executives wanted to distance themselves from the project due to its adjacency to a casino. Genting vows to enforce its rights and claim damages, which could impact the park's delayed opening date and new proposed opening in the first half of 2019.

site_title: Japan's Line jumps 17 per cent after Nikkei reports Tencent tie-up
summary: Line Corp shares jumped 17% after Nikkei reported a tie-up with Tencent Holdings Ltd to offer mobile payment services to Japanese restaurants and stores targeting Chinese tourists. The deal aims to expand Line's services in payments and Bitcoin, providing relief to the company's flagging stock price. The collaboration is part of Japan's growing attractiveness to China's tech titans, following recent announcements from Alibaba and Didi Chuxing.

site_title: Tesla China sales plunge 70 per cent in October - auto industry body
summary: Tesla's vehicle sales in China plummeted 70% in October to 211 cars, according to the China Passenger Car Association. The decline is attributed to the Sino-US trade war, which has led to higher tariffs on imported US autos. Despite a slowdown in wider auto sales, new-energy vehicle sales in China continue to rise. Tesla has cut the price of its Model X and Model S cars in China to make them more affordable and absorb the impact of higher tariffs. The company is also building a factory in Shanghai to avoid tariffs.

site_title: Venture capital firm Cocoon Capital eyes enterprise-tech startups with US$20m fund
summary: Singapore-based venture capital firm Cocoon Capital has launched a US$20 million fund targeting enterprise-tech startups in South-east Asia, focusing on deep tech, fintech, and medtech verticals. The firm aims to fill the funding gap for seed-stage companies, with plans to invest in Vietnam, Indonesia, and the Philippines. Cocoon Capital's partners, including Steve Diggle and Oliver Tonby, will take an active role in supporting early-stage companies, providing a more hands-on approach compared to traditional VCs.

site_title: Cyber Monday on track for US online shopping record
summary: Cyber Monday is on track to break a US online shopping record, with estimated sales reaching $10.8 billion, according to Adobe Analytics. The day saw a surge in mobile orders, with sales up 20% from last year, and retailers such as Target and Amazon offering free delivery and deep discounts. The event drew an estimated 75 million shoppers, with toys expected to have the biggest discounts, and some industry observers warning of potential store closures if brick-and-mortar players discounted items too heavily.

site_title: Germany pushes back against more ambitious CO2 limits for trucks
summary: Germany is pushing back against proposed EU limits on CO2 emissions from trucks, citing a 15% reduction by 2025 and 30% by 2030 as the maximum. This stance contradicts EU member states such as the Netherlands, which wants a 20% reduction by 2025 and 30% by 2030. The European Parliament has backed a 20% reduction by 2025 and 35% by 2030, sparking concerns that more needs to be done quickly to combat climate change. Negotiations on final targets will start early next year if a common EU position is reached in December.

site_title: Banks, commodities lead Australian shares higher; NZ also rises
summary: Australian shares rose 1% on Tuesday, driven by financial stocks and commodities. The S&P/ASX 200 index climbed 56.7 points to 5,728.30 after the banking regulator extended the deadline for implementing new capital rules on loans to January 1, 2022. Financial stocks rose 1.5%, while metals and mining stocks were boosted by BHP Group's discovery of new mineral deposits. New Zealand's benchmark index also rose 0.13%, driven by gains in consumer and healthcare stocks.
