site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon at 3,100.7, up 0.22%
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index rising 0.22% to 3,100.7. Gainers outpaced losers 146-134, with actively traded counters including local banks such as DBS, UOB, and OCBC Bank. Ezion and Thai Beverage were notable losers, down 2.33% and 5.97% respectively. The rally follows a 5-day streak, with investors awaiting GDP data.

site_title: Builder of US$200 million Turkish chateaux project goes bankrupt
summary: Turkish builder Sarot Group has been ordered into bankruptcy due to a US$27 million debt, affecting the US$200 million Burj Al Babas complex in Bolu province. The project, which was to feature 732 chateau-style villas, was sold to Gulf investors at a cost of US$370,000 to US$530,000. The company blames deadbeat clients for the debt, but the court has ruled for bankruptcy, forcing the group to stop construction immediately. Sarot Group's chairman, Mehmet Emin Yerdelen, plans to appeal the ruling and hopes to partially inaugurate the project in 2019.

site_title: AccorHotels sticks to goals for future earnings growth
summary: AccorHotels, Europe's largest hotel company, reaffirmed its financial targets for future earnings growth, sticking to its goal of doubling earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortization (EBITDA) to 1.2 billion euros by 2022. The company attributes its bullish outlook to recent acquisitions, cost controls, and a general pick-up in the French tourism sector. This contrasts with US rivals Marriott and Hilton, which have cut their forecasts due to weak demand. Accor also announced plans to buy full control of Polish hotels company Orbis.

images.alt_text: The logo of France's AccorHotels on a flag at a business district near Paris. AccorHotels, Europe's largest hotels company, on Tuesday reaffirmed its financial targets for future earnings growth helped by acquisitions and cost controls.

site_title: Only Romaine from Central and Northern California is unsafe, FDA says
summary: The FDA has lifted its warning against eating romaine lettuce from California's north and central coast, citing the end of the growing season. The agency had previously linked the outbreak of 65 E. coli cases to "end of summer" romaine lettuce from this region. However, romaine lettuce grown hydroponically, in greenhouses, or from the winter desert regions can be safely consumed, as long as it is labeled with harvest date and region. The industry has committed to labeling products with this information.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher for third straight session
summary: Tokyo stocks rose for the third consecutive session, with the Nikkei 225 index gaining 0.64% to close at 21,952.40. The improvement in investor sentiment followed Wall Street rallies, fueling expectations for a year-end shopping spree. The broader Topix index also rose 0.73% to 1,644.16.

site_title: Swedish central bank urged to delay rate hike by powerful unions
summary: Sweden's powerful Swedish Trade Union Confederation is urging the Riksbank to delay its planned interest-rate hike due to concerns about the labor market and economic growth. The union group cites Sweden's political gridlock and slowing economic growth as key factors. The Riksbank had planned a 25 basis point rate hike in December or February, but the union's economists argue that this timing could harm the labor market and miss the inflation target. They recommend caution regarding rate increases due to the uncertainty surrounding fiscal policy.

images.alt_text: The headquarters of Sweden's central bank, the Sveriges Riksbank in Stockholm. The central bank has said it plans to raise the main rate by 25 basis points, either in December or February, from its current level of minus 0.5 per cent.

site_title: Facebook secrets in bikini app flap stir international intrigue
summary: A leaked internal Facebook document from a 2014 app, Pikini, that aimed to locate photos of users in swimsuits, is fueling a bitter dispute between Facebook and app developer Six4Three. The leaked documents, which were sealed in a California court case, reveal Facebook's handling of user data and its decision to restrict developer access to friends' data. Facebook is seeking to have Six4Three held in contempt for breaching the court order, while the UK parliamentary committee is set to question a Facebook executive about the documents, raising concerns about Facebook's data sharing practices.

site_title: From superstar to suspect: Carlos Ghosn's crazy week
summary: Carlos Ghosn, former CEO of Nissan, was arrested on November 19, 2018, after landing in Tokyo on his private jet. He was accused of under-reporting his income by approximately $44 million over five years. Ghosn was held in a detention center, where he received consular visits, and was later sacked as Nissan chairman by an unanimous vote of the board. The allegations against him sparked widespread media attention and trading room pandemonium, marking a stunning turn of events for the once-glittering career of the Brazil-born French businessman.

site_title: Airbnb hires Amazon veteran as CFO ahead of potential IPO
summary: Airbnb has hired Dave Stephenson, an Amazon veteran, as its new CFO ahead of a potential initial public offering (IPO) next year. Stephenson, who has worked at Amazon for 17 years, will replace Laurence Tosi in early January. The move comes as Airbnb expands its services and offerings, including luxury vacation homes and hotels. This appointment follows the departure of another Amazon veteran, Jason Warnick, who is joining Robinhood as CFO. Airbnb's valuation is currently estimated at $31 billion.

site_title: Asean supply chains in good stead for US-China trade war, says economist
summary: A US-China trade war may benefit Asean supply chains, particularly Singapore, Malaysia, South Korea, Taiwan, and Vietnam, which could sell 20% more to the US. However, this assumes the region can find alternative customers if the US is not buying from China. The economist notes that supply chain losers, such as China, could sell to other competitors in the region. In the long run, the US-China trade deal may accelerate the shift of foreign direct investment (FDI) to Asean countries, driven by country risk and natural disaster risk.

site_title: Alibaba market value tops Facebook after latest public relations crisis: Chart
summary: Facebook's latest public relations crisis has led to a 37% decline in shares and a nearly $240 billion loss in value, surpassing its market capitalization. This is the second time this year Alibaba Group Holding Ltd has overtaken Facebook, following a March event triggered by the Cambridge Analytica scandal. As a result, Alibaba's market value has surpassed Facebook's, with the Chinese internet giant now holding the top spot.

site_title: OECD paper calls for alternative economic measures
summary: Prominent economists have called for an alternative measure of economic well-being, arguing that the current focus on gross domestic product (GDP) is insufficient. The OECD-backed paper proposes a "dashboard of indicators" to display conditions faced by ordinary people, including environmental, social, and security conditions. The authors believe this approach would have led to stronger GDP growth during the "Great Recession" a decade ago. They also advocate for indicators to be broken down by social status and demographic groups to describe group differences in well-being outcomes.

site_title: Stage set for fresh Australia election in May
summary: Australia is set for a May election following Prime Minister Scott Morrison's announcement of a new national spending plan on April 2, promising a fiscal surplus and a booming economy. The Liberal Party, weakened by another defection, now faces an uphill struggle to keep its job. Julia Banks, a former Liberal MP, quit the party to become an independent, citing party bullying and the removal of Malcolm Turnbull as the catalyst. The election will likely take place in early to mid-May, with Morrison's government in the minority and his party riven by divisions.

site_title: Singapore services sector revenue up by 8% in Q3
summary: Singapore's services sector saw revenue growth of 8% in Q3, up from 7.7% in the second quarter. This marks a reversal from the earlier figure of 7.8% in the second quarter. The growth in services is attributed to a broad increase across various industries, with no specific sectors mentioned. The news comes as part of the overall economic growth in Singapore, with no direct correlation to other global economic trends.

site_title: Regular exercise may keep your body 30 years 'younger'
summary: A study published in the Journal of Applied Physiology found that older adults who have exercised for decades have muscles and cardiovascular systems similar to those of healthy 25-year-olds, making them biologically about 30 years younger than their chronological ages. The study, which included 28 active men and women in their 70s, found that their aerobic capacities were about 40% higher than those of sedentary elderly individuals, and their cardiovascular health was comparable to that of people 30 years younger. The findings suggest that physical activity may alter how we age and that exercise could help build a reserve of good health to slow or evade physical frailty later in life.

site_title: Ex-Trump aide Manafort violated plea agreement by lying: prosecutors
summary: Paul Manafort, former Trump campaign chairman, has violated his plea agreement by lying to investigators, prosecutors said in a court filing. Manafort agreed to cooperate with special counsel Robert Mueller's investigation as part of a plea deal in September, but allegedly committed federal crimes by lying to the FBI and Mueller's office. Manafort pleaded guilty to conspiracy and obstruction of justice charges unrelated to the campaign, stemming from his work for former Ukrainian president Viktor Yanukovych between 2005 and 2014.

site_title: GM's Mary Barra is starting to look downright cold-blooded
summary: General Motors CEO Mary Barra is taking drastic measures to cut costs and invest in new technologies, including electric and autonomous vehicles. The company is closing five plants and slashing 14,000 jobs in North America, with plans to invest $1 billion annually in its Cruise LLC unit for self-driving technology. Analysts question the viability of this strategy, citing the lack of proof that the technology will be ready and profitable within 24 months. Barra's previous moves, including exiting Russia, Indonesia, and India, demonstrate her willingness to cut costs and focus on high-return investments.

site_title: China's industrial profits cool again in October
summary: China's industrial profits cooled again in October, marking the sixth straight month of decline, as demand continued to cool amid the US-China trade war. Industrial profits rose 3.6% from a year earlier, slowing from September's 4.1% gain. The slowdown was largely due to cooling factory-gate inflation and a high-base effect. China's environment ministry has vowed to curb air pollution despite increasing economic pressure, while policymakers have introduced credit-easing measures to boost the slowing economy.

site_title: JTC launches Tuas, Tampines sites under Industrial Government Land Sales programme
summary: Government agency JTC has launched two sites under the 2018 Industrial Government Land Sales (IGLS) programme. The Tuas South Link 3 site (Plot 20) is available for tender and will close on Jan 22, 2019, while the Tampines North Drive 5 site (Plot 9) is available for application. Both sites are zoned for Business-2 use and have a 20-year tenure. The launch is part of 13 sites covering 12.59 hectares, which were announced in June for the second half of 2018.

images.alt_text: The site at Tuas South Link 3 (Plot 20), which is available for tender, is the fifth out of six confirmed list sites for the second half of the 2018 IGLS programme.
The other site at Tampines North Drive 5 (Plot 9) is available for application, and is the fifth out of seven reserve list sites for the second half of the 2018 IGLS programme.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as Trump threatens to ramp up trade war
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Tuesday as US President Donald Trump threatened to ramp up the US trade war with China, warning he would double duties on $250 billion of Chinese imports if no breakthrough is reached. Trump said China must open up its country to US competition. Markets moved cautiously, with Tokyo and Shanghai rising, while Hong Kong and Singapore slipped. Investors are also watching speeches from top Federal Reserve officials, which could signal a softer pace of interest rate hikes, amid concerns about global growth and rising oil prices.

site_title: Last chance to bid for Jho Low's S$344m yacht, allegedly bought with 1MDB funds
summary: The 91-metre Equanimity yacht, allegedly bought with 1MDB funds, is up for auction in Kuala Lumpur. The vessel, owned by fugitive Malaysian businessman Jho Low, features a Turkish bath, swimming pool, and helicopter landing pad. It was seized in March as part of global efforts to recoup assets lost through the state investment company. The last chance to bid on the yacht is on Wednesday. The sale comes after the yacht was put up for sale last month, with proceeds expected to be used to recover assets lost through 1MDB.

site_title: Norway eyes offshore wind to power Nyhamna gas processing plant
summary: Norway's gas system operator Gassco and Canadian energy firm Enbridge are reviving a 350 MW offshore wind project, Havsul 1, to boost power supply security at Norway's Nyhamna gas processing plant. The project was initially licensed in 2009 but abandoned due to profitability concerns. With increasing demand and grid line fragility, Gassco is undertaking a technical study to evaluate a tie-in of Havsul 1 to Nyhamna, expected to be completed by spring 2019. The project could secure power supply for the plant and region for years, with an estimated cost of up to 7 billion crowns.

site_title: Argentina says it is close to inking a beef deal with US
summary: Argentina is close to signing a deal with the US to allow two-way trade of fresh beef for the first time in nearly two decades. The agreement, expected to be signed within days, will simultaneously open beef imports to both countries. Argentina will have a 20,000-tonne limit on its exports to the US, while there will be no limit on US beef going to Argentina, following the elimination of foot-and-mouth disease concerns. The deal is seen as a boost to Argentina's beef sales abroad and a new market for the US cattle sector.

site_title: Africa LNG set to surge as floating projects cut time to market
summary: Africa is poised for a liquefied natural gas boom, driven by accelerating global demand and fast-track methods of getting the fuel to market. The Kosmos Energy Ltd.'s project in Mauritania and Senegal, utilizing a floating vessel, is set to get the go-ahead next month, targeting first gas from Tortue by 2022. This project, combined with others, is expected to nearly double Africa's total LNG output capacity by 2030, with the continent's strategic location between the Atlantic and Pacific basins making it an increasingly important player in the global market.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at Tuesday's open; STI down 0.1% to 3,090.39
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index falling 0.1% to 3,090.39, following US President Donald Trump's indication to continue raising tariffs on Chinese imports. The market saw 68 losers compared to 59 gainers, with ComfortDelGro and Ezion Holdings remaining stable. Active index stocks included DBS Group Holdings and Genting Singapore.

site_title: Australian leader promises first budget surplus in a decade
summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison announced that his government will deliver a budget surplus for the first time in a decade, with the budget proposal to be released on April 2. The move comes ahead of a federal election scheduled for May, and marks a significant shift in the country's fiscal policy. The budget year begins on July 1.

site_title: Google drops US$1b on property near its headquarters
summary: Google has purchased a 51.8-acre business park near its Mountain View, California, headquarters for US$1 billion, expanding its existing campus. The acquisition, the largest in Silicon Valley this year, adds to the company's real estate expansion plans in California and New York City. Google has recently purchased Chelsea Market in Manhattan for US$2.4 billion and is facing a legal backlash over a proposed US$67 million land purchase in San Jose. The deal is part of Google's growing presence in the tech industry.

site_title: Keppel-KBS US Reit acquires second office property in Florida for US$48.5m
summary: Keppel-KBS US Reit has acquired Maitland Promenade I, an office property in Orlando, Florida, for US$48.5 million. The 230,371 sq ft property has a 98.1% occupancy rate and is adjacent to another property owned by the Reit. The acquisition is part of the Reit's strategy to grow its portfolio in quality income-producing properties. The deal is expected to improve committed portfolio occupancy from 90.1% to 91.9% and bring total assets under management to US$1.04 billion.

site_title: Cloud company Deskera raises over US$60m, crosses S$100m in revenue in FY17
summary: Deskera, a cloud-based platform for small and medium enterprises, has raised over US$60 million in funding, crossing S$100 million in revenue in FY17. The company, founded in Singapore in 2008, aims to expand its services into the US, Indonesia, Australia, and the Philippines. Deskera's platform helps SMEs manage their businesses, track finances, and hire employees. The funding will be used for research and development, integrating its ERP system with Singapore's Networked Trade Platform. The company also launched a B2B commerce platform, Desk, to facilitate online transactions for SMEs.

site_title: New Zealand's Fonterra COO of consumer and food service business quits
summary: Fonterra, New Zealand's largest dairy exporter, announced that its COO of consumer and food service business, Lukas Paravicini, has resigned, effective January 2019. The move comes as the company faces a tough period, posting its first annual loss in the year ended July, due to higher milk prices and one-off charges. Fonterra has been shifting from milk powder shipments to selling value-added consumer products, but the strategy backfired due to increased input costs. Paravicini and his family plan to return to Europe after his departure.

site_title: Clean power sees first win over fossil fuels in emerging markets
summary: Developing countries have surpassed wealthier nations in adding clean power capacity, with wind and solar generation accounting for over half of new power capacity in emerging markets last year. According to Bloomberg NEF, 186 gigawatts of new clean power capacity were added, compared to 63 gigawatts in developed economies. This marks the first time clean power has outpaced fossil fuels in emerging markets, driven by lower equipment costs and abundant natural resources. The findings highlight a turnaround from a decade ago when wealthier nations dominated renewable investment and deployment activities.

site_title: Alibaba co-founder Jack Ma confirmed as Communist Party member
summary: Jack Ma, co-founder of Alibaba Group Holding Ltd, has been confirmed as a member of the Communist Party of China's Central Committee. He was recognized as part of a celebration marking 40 years since China's economic reform and opening up. This move comes as the Communist Party plays a leading role in all aspects of society, creating tensions between private business interests and the state. Ma's membership is seen as a nod to the party's legitimacy, but does not necessarily denote high-level political activity.

site_title: Tencent, Line to tie up in Japan mobile payment services: Nikkei
summary: Tencent Holdings and Line Corp, a Japanese chat app operator, are set to tie up to offer mobile payment services in Japan, targeting small retailers to attract Chinese tourists. Line will start using Tencent's WeChat Pay terminals at small to mid-sized restaurants and stores starting next year. The partnership is expected to help Line's shares, which jumped 7.7% following the announcement. The move aims to increase business opportunities for Japanese retailers by catering to the growing number of Chinese tourists visiting Japan.

site_title: Regulators seek documents from coffee shop operator Kimly; stock suspended
summary: Kimly Limited, a Singapore-based coffee shop operator, has received regulatory orders to provide documents and is suspending its stock trading pending updates on a recent acquisition and unaudited full-year results. The company's shares were trading at S$0.28 before the halt. Kimly's stock suspension follows a request for documents from regulators, with the company citing the need for updates on a recent acquisition and its unaudited full-year results.

site_title: Southeast Asia one of the most vulnerable regions to climate change: Eco-Business report
summary: Southeast Asia is highly vulnerable to climate change, with rising sea levels threatening coastlines and densely populated low-lying areas. A report by Eco-Business found that the region is transitioning to a low-carbon economy through clean energy sources, policies to reduce emissions, and re-evaluation of climate-exposed businesses. Key sectors in need of investment are renewable energy and storage, clean energy public transport, and energy-efficient technologies. The report also highlights the importance of business leadership, local government initiatives, and consumer pressure in driving the transition, while insufficient policy and funding are major barriers.

site_title: Trump says he expects to raise China tariffs, suggests 10% tariffs may be placed on iPhones, laptops
summary: US President Donald Trump announced plans to raise tariffs on $200 billion in Chinese imports to 25% from 10%, potentially including iPhones and laptops, ahead of a meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping. Trump stated it's "highly unlikely" he'll accept China's request to delay the increase, which is set to take effect on January 1. If negotiations fail, Trump may impose tariffs on the remaining $267 billion in Chinese imports, with rates of 10% or 25%.

site_title: Australia: Shares inch up as US-China tensions weigh; New Zealand edges up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% to 5,683.2, driven by cautious optimism over US-China trade tensions, despite US President Donald Trump's threat to raise tariffs on $200 billion in Chinese imports to 25%. Heavyweight BHP contributed to the gains after announcing new mineral deposits in South Australia.

site_title: Trump says doesn't believe own government's climate warning
summary: US President Donald Trump expressed skepticism about his government's climate change warning, stating he doesn't believe the report's central warning of massive economic losses by the end of the century. Trump said the US won't take measures to cut emissions unless other countries do the same. He also downplayed the report, calling it "fine" after reading "some" of it. Trump's stance on climate change has been a long-standing issue, with him pulling the US out of the Paris Agreement and tearing up environmental protection laws.

site_title: Malaysia shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Tuesday, down 7.07 points to 1,694.92, amid a global market downturn. The FTSE Bursa Malaysia Index saw a trading volume of 98.36 million lots worth RM95.16 million. Losers outpaced gainers 99 to 95. The global market decline was attributed to bank and healthcare sector drag, with US-EU tariffs in focus.

site_title: APTT refinances debts, lowers distributions to cut costs
summary: ASIAN Pay Television Trust (APTT) successfully refinanced its existing borrowing facilities, extending offshore borrowing to 2021 and lowering interest rates to 1.6%. The refinancing aims to reduce annual interest costs by S$9 million. As part of its debt management program, APTT will pay lower distributions to unitholders, with expected distributions of 1.2 Singapore cents per unit for 2019 and 2020, resulting in annual cash savings of over S$76 million.

site_title: Medtech firm Ark launched with US$40m Series A funding
summary: Singapore-based medtech firm Ark has been formed through the merger of Venturecraft and Mirxes, backed by a $40 million Series A investment led by Venturecraft shareholders and Gaorong Capital. Ark aims to eliminate late-stage cancer-related deaths within 30 years with an industry-first blood test using micro ribonucleic acid (miRNA) as cancer markers. The company plans to launch its first product, a stomach cancer blood test, and has set a goal to enroll 50,000 participants in an Asia's largest clinical study.

site_title: Emerging markets face a brighter outlook after a rotten 2018
summary: Emerging markets are poised for a brighter outlook in 2019, with Morgan Stanley strategists predicting a "triple trend reversal" driven by China policy easing, a Federal Reserve pause, and a halt in the US-China trade war. This could lead to a 13% advance in the MSCI Emerging Market Index by year-end, with analysts favoring countries like Russia, Indonesia, Brazil, and Chile. Despite concerns about a deterioration in the Sino-American relationship, the market sees a "low expectations" atmosphere surrounding the Xi-Trump meeting, leading to a potential long-term buying opportunity for emerging-market equities.

site_title: Currency traders place cheap bet that Trump and Xi could reach a truce
summary: US President Donald Trump and Chinese leader Xi Jinping's meeting at the Group of 20 summit may deliver a trade truce, with currency traders positioning for a stronger Chinese yuan. One-week dollar-yuan risk reversals hit a low since June, signaling a possible truce. Jefferies LLC's head of foreign-exchange, Brad Bechtel, views the yuan as a "relatively cheap bet" due to low implied volatility, and a positive sign from the meeting could benefit the Australian dollar, which has seen elevated volatility. The meeting comes ahead of US tariffs on $200 billion worth of Chinese goods.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Hi-P, Keppel-KBS US Reit, First Ship Lease Trust, Asian Pay Television Trust, Thai Bev
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Stocks to watch on Tuesday include Hi-P International, Keppel-KBS US Reit, First Ship Lease Trust, Asian Pay Television Trust, and Thai Beverage. Hi-P International's controlling shareholder is considering a deal that may lead to a play for the rest of the stock. Keppel-KBS US Reit acquired an office property in Orlando, Florida, for $48.5 million. First Ship Lease Trust proposed a non-renounceable preferential offering to raise up to $43.03 million. Asian Pay Television Trust refinanced its borrowing facilities, and Thai Beverage posted a net profit of $77 million for 2018, down 46% from last year.

site_title: Genting sues Disney, Fox for US$1b over Malaysia theme park
summary: Genting Malaysia Bhd has sued Walt Disney Co and Twenty-First Century Fox Inc for over US$1 billion, alleging they abandoned a contract for a Fox-branded theme park in Malaysia due to "seller's remorse." The lawsuit claims Disney and Fox breached the 2013 contract, which Genting had invested over US$750 million in. Genting is seeking damages, punitive damages, and compensation for the losses incurred. The dispute arises as Disney prepares to complete its US$71.3 billion purchase of Fox assets.

site_title: Federal Reserve's Quarles to chair Financial Stability Board
summary: US Federal Reserve Governor Randal Quarles has been appointed chair of the Financial Stability Board, replacing Bank of England Governor Mark Carney. Quarles, appointed by US President Donald Trump, aims to steer a moderate course, refining post-crisis regulations. He is joined by Dutch central bank president Klaas Knot as vice-chair. The FSB, which coordinates new banking rules for the G-20, is seen as a key international regulatory body. Quarles' appointment aims to keep Washington engaged in FSB while giving Europe an influential role, amid a slowdown in rulemaking following the financial crisis.

site_title: General Motors shuttering plants, cutting 15% of workforce
summary: General Motors announced a restructuring plan to cut 15% of its workforce, equivalent to 27,000 jobs, to save $6 billion. The move includes shuttering seven plants worldwide, primarily in North America, to focus on popular trucks and SUVs and electric models. The closures drew criticism from US and Canadian labor unions, who accused the company of shifting production overseas, while US President Donald Trump expressed dismay and urged GM to "get back in there soon."

site_title: The rise of the "mass affluent" in Asean will transform consumer economy: BCG report
summary: A new report by The Boston Consulting Group (BCG) predicts the rise of the "mass affluent" in Southeast Asia will transform the consumer economy by 2030. The mass affluent, comprising 10% of the population, controls 40% of the region's household income and is projected to grow to 137 million by then. This income group is digitally savvy, seeking exclusivity in brands and products, and already drives significant spending in categories like leisure travel and luxury goods. The BCG report notes that the mass affluent's behavior evolves as they become more accustomed to their wealth, shifting from famous brands to quality and value-driven products.

site_title: Hi-P major shareholder mulls deal, raising possibility of deal for rest of manufacturer's shares
summary: A controlling shareholder of Hi-P International, the company's chairman and CEO Yao Hsiao Tung, is considering a deal that could lead to a play for the rest of the manufacturer's shares. The news follows a 30.9% stock surge on Monday after 19.5 million shares changed hands. Yao Hsiao Tung holds an 84.2% stake in the company, and a deal could significantly impact the company's ownership. The exact nature of the deal is unclear, but it may involve the purchase of the remaining shares.

site_title: Europe: Telecoms, banks lift shares in post-Thanksgiving rally
summary: European shares rose 1.2% on Monday, with the Stoxx 600 leading the way, as optimism over Italy's budget negotiations lifted shares in Milan and telecoms stocks. Italian banks gained 2.9% and 4.8% respectively, driven by hopes of a compromise from the government. Telecoms shares rallied 3.3% after a report suggested the European Commission would clear a merger. Energy shares also rose 2.2% following a rebound in oil prices.

site_title: China orders probe into scientist claims of first gene-edited babies
summary: China orders an investigation into claims by scientist He Jiankui that he created the world's first gene-edited babies using CRISPR technology to prevent them from contracting HIV. The twin girls, born a few weeks ago, were allegedly created through regular IVF using a specially modified egg. The investigation comes amid widespread criticism from the scientific community, with many deeming the claim a "modern form of eugenics" and questioning the ethics of gene editing in humans.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher as sentiment improves
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.69% and the Topix index up 0.68%. Investor sentiment improved after rallies on Wall Street, with expectations for a year-end shopping spree driving gains.

site_title: Trump warns Brexit may harm UK-US trade
summary: President Donald Trump warned that the UK's exit from the EU may harm trade between the two countries, stating that the deal could "hamper trade" and lead to a "very big negative" for the agreement. Trump expressed hope that Prime Minister Theresa May can address this issue, as she faces a difficult task securing parliamentary approval for the deal. The UK had closed Brexit talks with the EU on Sunday, but the outcome remains uncertain.

site_title: ThaiBev full year net profit down 46% at 18.53b baht
summary: Thai Beverage's full-year net profit fell 46% to 18.53 billion baht due to a slow economy and increased product prices, including higher excise tax rates and an elderly fund tax. Revenue rose 21% to 229.7 billion baht, with spirits sales declining 3.1% and beer sales dropping 10.4%. The company's non-alcoholic beverages business reported a net loss, while its food business saw significant growth. ThaiBev declared an annual dividend of 0.39 baht per share, down from 0.67 baht in 2017.

site_title: May begins tour of Britain to sell Brexit deal benefits
summary: Theresa May embarks on a UK tour to promote her Brexit deal, which secured agreement with the EU on continued close trade ties. Despite the deal's limitations, including a potential border in Northern Ireland, May aims to build support ahead of a parliamentary vote on December 11. The visit includes meetings with Northern Irish and Welsh leaders, as well as business and community groups, in an effort to strengthen support for the deal and counter opposition from the Democratic Unionist Party.

site_title: Oil breaks above US$60/bbl, but doubts about growth curb gains
summary: Oil prices rose nearly 3% on Monday, rebounding from last week's steep losses, but gains were limited by concerns over global economic growth and increasing supply. Brent crude futures rose to $60.48 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude gained to $51.63 a barrel. Despite a moderate stock market rally, demand concerns and record Saudi production capped the rebound, with Saudi output reaching an all-time high of 11.1-11.3 million barrels per day in November.

site_title: FSLT plans preferential 3-for-2 rights offering to raise up to S$43.03m
summary: FIRST Ship Lease Trust (FSLT) plans a non-renounceable preferential offering of three rights units for every two existing units at S$0.045 per new unit, aiming to raise up to S$43.03 million. The offering will issue up to 956 million new units, strengthening FSLT's financial position and capital base. The proceeds will primarily fund fleet renewal, with at least half going towards acquiring new vessels. Sponsor FSL Holdings has committed to subscribing for its total pro rata allotment of new units.

site_title: Boom or bust? Brexit makes London property outlook hard to read
summary: London's biggest office landlords are uncertain about the impact of Brexit on their real estate market, with some developers pausing large-scale developments and others focusing on squeezing more out of existing projects. Land Securities Group Plc, British Land Co, and Great Portland Estates Plc are grappling with debt and risk management amid the uncertainty. The UK's departure from the EU has disrupted the typical boom-and-bust cycle, and companies that don't have a pipeline of properties in the works risk missing out on years of profitable growth.

site_title: US: Stocks rally ahead of G-20 talks
summary: US stocks rallied ahead of a G-20 meeting between US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 1.5% to 24,640.24, the S&P 500 advancing 1.6% to 2,673.45, and the Nasdaq Composite Index jumping 2.1% to 7,081.85. Analysts attributed the gains to investors seeking a potential trade deal and cautious signals on interest rates from Federal Reserve officials. Retail shares surged, with Adobe Analytics predicting a record-breaking "Cyber Monday" with $7.8 billion in sales.

site_title: Early US data show big jump in online holiday shopping
summary: US online holiday shopping showed a strong start, with $531 million in sales on Cyber Monday and $6.2 billion on Black Friday, up 18.3% and 23.6% from last year, respectively. Analysts project a 4-5% growth in retail sales for 2018, but warned that deeper discounts, increased e-commerce costs, and higher inventory levels could be concerns. The longer-than-usual holiday shopping season due to an early Thanksgiving also means there's still time for improvement in underlying profitability to boost shares.

site_title: ECB must end bond buying despite risks: board member
summary: The European Central Bank should end its bond buying program despite economic risks, according to a board member, Sabine Lautenschlaeger. Extending the program would not bring significant benefits but increase negative effects. Lautenschlaeger expects the ECB to normalize monetary policy, with possible interest rate hikes in mid-2019, and believes the reinvested bond proceeds will act as a sufficient stimulus. She advocates for quantitative easing to be a tool of last resort, used only in cases of deflation.

site_title: NY architect builds his family a haiku of a home
summary: New York architect Kyle Page designed a minimalist, 1,080 sqft home in rural Sullivan County, NY, as a weekend retreat for his family. The $450,000 home, built in 2017, features a weathering steel and cedar-clad structure that blends into its surroundings. Page prioritized simplicity and efficiency, using a hyper-efficient envelope, spray-foam insulation, and reclaimed wood for furniture. The home includes a living area, kitchen, bedrooms, and a sleeping loft, with a focus on functionality over luxury.

site_title: Retiree village in California fire disaster is the hardest hit
summary: The Camp Fire, the deadliest and most destructive wildfire in California history, was finally brought under control after 17 days of raging. The hardest-hit community, Paradise, California, was a retiree village with over 25% of its residents 65 or older, many of whom lost everything and must start over from scratch. The disaster has left thousands of seniors without medical supplies, medications, and support, exacerbating health challenges. The air quality in evacuation shelters is also a concern, with many unable to wear masks due to pre-existing health conditions.

site_title: Microsoft briefly tops Apple as most valuable company
summary: Microsoft briefly surpassed Apple as the world's most valuable company by market capitalization, reaching $812.9 billion, before Apple regained the top spot with a market value of $822.9 billion. The brief takeover was due to a late-afternoon surge in Apple's stock price. This brief reversal came amid a decline in the Nasdaq, with tech names experiencing significant drops since the end of September, particularly Apple, which has fallen 23% since the third quarter, while Microsoft has lost 6.7% over the same period.

site_title: Top official calls for more women in ECB leadership roles
summary: European Central Bank official Sabine Lautenschlaeger calls for more women in leadership roles, citing improved gender balance as a benefit. The ECB should bring more women into management positions, following the selection of Andrea Enria over Sharon Donnery in the banking supervision chief position. The ECB has pledged to hire more female staff, but still lags behind its goal of one in four high-level management posts held by women, with a current ratio of 17%. Lautenschlaeger hopes to increase the ratio of women in central banking and banking supervision.

site_title: Govt seeks to modernise wholesale industry with digital roadmap
summary: Singapore's government has launched the Wholesale Trade Industry Digital Plan (IDP) to modernize the country's wholesale industry through digitalization. The plan provides a three-stage digital roadmap for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to adopt digital solutions, including enterprise resource planning systems, B2B e-marketplaces, and blockchain technology. The plan aims to help SMEs in the wholesale trade industry, which contributes 16% of Singapore's GDP, to improve their processes and tap into new markets, with the goal of transforming the industry by 2025.

site_title: Successful digitalisation of global supply chain depends on people-related factors
summary: A successful digitalization of the global supply chain relies heavily on people-related factors, including the ability to collaborate, adapt to new technologies, and possess the right mindset. As Industry 4.0 technologies automate processes, new job profiles and skillsets emerge, such as digital platform managers and data scientists. Companies must invest in employee development, training, and a supportive corporate culture to empower their workforce. Seamless collaboration with business partners, suppliers, and startups is also crucial for achieving an optimized global supply chain.

site_title: Euro heads towards 2-week high as risk appetite picks up
summary: The euro advanced towards a two-week high on Monday due to increased risk appetite and firmer oil prices. Italy may cut its budget deficit target to 2% to placate the European Union, and news of a Brexit deal between Britain and the EU boosted the single currency. European stock markets rallied, while the gap between Italian and German government bond yields narrowed. The euro gained almost a third of a percent to US$1.1368 and was up 0.5% at 128.65 yen, hitting a two-week high of US$1.1472.

site_title: Bitcoin's deepening crash now rivals its worst bear markets
summary: Bitcoin's value has plummeted to $3,475, rivaling its worst bear markets, including a 93% drop in 2011 and an 84% decline from 2013-2015. The cryptocurrency has lost over $700 billion in value since its peak, with rival coins like Ether and XRP also affected. Institutional investors are being cautious due to concerns over exchange security, market manipulation, and regulatory risk, leaving bulls hopeful that a rally could be sparked by demand from institutional investors.

site_title: Wage growth slows to worst rate since 2008 crisis: UN
summary: The International Labour Organization reported that global wage growth in 2017 was the lowest since the 2008 financial crisis, despite solid economic growth and falling unemployment. Women worldwide continue to be paid 20% less than men.

site_title: Tech stocks propel Singapore market
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 40.89 points, or 1.34%, to 3,093.38, driven by tech counters and offshore-and-marine stocks. Gainers outnumbered losers 210 to 154, with shares of Venture Corp, Hi-P International, and Creative Technology advancing. The gains may be attributed to expectations of higher-than-expected Cyber Monday sales and a rebound in Singapore's October manufacturing data.

site_title: Keppel units to build, operate data centre in Johor
summary: Keppel Corp's units have agreed to develop and operate a data centre in Johor, Malaysia, with a targeted 2020 completion date. Alpha Data Centre Fund secured a contract to build a high-availability data centre for a technology customer, with Keppel Data Centres Holding undertaking initial development and facilities management. The agreement includes a put option for Alpha DC Fund to require Keppel Data Centres to buy shares in the project company, allowing Keppel T&T to increase its stake to 70% by 2020.

site_title: Hong Kong's hottest IPOs bring worst returns to investors
summary: Hong Kong's hottest initial public offerings have produced the worst returns for investors this year, with Ping An Healthcare and Technology Co falling 37% since its May trading debut. In contrast, the least popular deals have seen better performance.

site_title: Global economy heads into final stretch with diminished momentum
summary: The global economy entered the final stretch of 2018 in weakened shape due to a slowdown and volatile markets. Key data from Japan and Germany showed a manufacturing gauge at its lowest since 2016 and business confidence falling for a third month. The European Central Bank's meeting in December will confirm the end of net asset purchases, while the US Federal Reserve is set to raise interest rates again. Economists expect the Fed to pause in 2019 due to a deceleration in economic growth. The global trade war and protectionism have significant implications for monetary policy worldwide.

site_title: Financial inclusion must be done right
summary: Financial inclusion in Southeast Asia is crucial to unlock long-term socio-economic impacts, but current solutions are often unviable or short-sighted. Fintech firms must adopt a purpose-driven mission and promote responsible financial behavior to foster greater inclusion for underserved populations. A collaborative approach between the public and private sectors, utilizing technology to assess risks and provide access to basic financial services, is essential. Governments and institutions must prioritize financial literacy and education to maximize the benefits of access to new tools, and companies must take responsibility for their role in promoting responsible lending practices.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Coffee with Claressa: Data analytics changing the fashion industry
summary: Omnilytics, the first fashion analytics company in Southeast Asia, is revolutionizing the fashion industry by providing data analytics solutions to fashion houses. Founder Kendrick Wong discussed the company's impact on product preparation, planning, and sales on the Money FM podcast "Coffee with Claressa". The company's innovative approach is set to transform the fashion industry's use of data, making it more efficient and effective.

site_title: China building US$9b rival to American-run GPS
summary: China is developing a US$9 billion rival navigation system, Beidou, to counter the US's GPS, amid heightened tensions between the two countries. The system, expected to be accessible worldwide by 2020, will provide positioning accuracies of one meter or less and is part of China's ambitious campaign to displace Western dominance in aerospace. The development is seen as a strategic move to reduce dependence on US-controlled GPS and increase China's global influence in next-generation technologies.

site_title: More Reits can be enticed to list here, says SMU don
summary: A Singaporean professor suggests that better and extended tax concessions and relaxing impediments to listing could attract more real-estate investment trusts (Reits) to list on the Singapore Exchange. Prof Francis Koh proposes a permanent statement on tax concessions and relaxing the leverage ceiling of 45% for Reits with robust credit standing. He also recommends diversifying Reits, incorporating environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors, and taking advantage of the Asean Collective Investment Scheme (CIS) Fund Passport to attract more investors.

site_title: Breaking cycles that keep women out of tech
summary: Women are underrepresented in STEM fields, with only 25% of graduates in information and communications technology and 24% in engineering in developed countries. A digital gender divide persists globally, with 3.9 billion people offline, mostly women. Experts say giving women the skills to master technology is a social, moral, and economic necessity. Encouraging girls to develop an interest in math and sciences between ages 11 and 15 is crucial, with girls wanting more role models and hands-on experience. Addressing stereotypes and promoting shared responsibilities at home are also key to increasing women's participation in STEM.

site_title: 50-to-1 odds in rental lottery reveal Toronto's housing crisis
summary: Toronto's housing crisis worsens as 3,800 people compete for 75 rental units in a lottery, with 50-to-1 odds of winning. The city's unaffordability is driven by a meager supply of 11,620 new rental units, despite creating 17,000 renter households annually. Prices have skyrocketed, with condo rents up 7.6% and newly available units 17% higher. The city's population growth and influx of newcomers, including refugees and immigrants, are putting pressure on the housing market, leading to homelessness and stress for those struggling to find affordable housing.

site_title: Chinese university to launch investigation after don says he had edited twins' genes
summary: A Chinese university, the Southern University of Science and Technology, will launch an investigation after Associate Professor He Jiankui claimed to have edited the genes of twin girls using CRISPR-Cas9 technology, citing "lifetime protection" against HIV. The university stated that He's work is a "serious violation of academic ethics and standards" and that he was on unpaid leave since February. An independent committee of experts will be formed to investigate, and the university emphasized the need for research to conform to national laws and regulations.

site_title: At G20 summit, an urgency to address trade dispute and climate change
summary: The G20 summit in Buenos Aires, hosted by Argentina, is expected to be uncertain as world leaders struggle to address trade disputes and climate change. US President Donald Trump's presence will be crucial, with his skepticism on climate change and protectionist trade policies likely to hinder negotiations. A bilateral meeting between Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping may help ease tensions, but a trade war between the two largest economies continues to threaten global economic growth. The G20's failure to address climate change is also a concern, with fossil fuels accounting for 82% of the group's energy supply.

site_title: Noble probe: Timing matters less than thoroughness
summary: Singapore's top securities and accounting watchdogs, along with white-collar crime buster, launched a joint investigation into commodity trader Noble Group, amid allegations of breaches of securities rules and company law. The probe's timing has been criticized as "too little, too late," but regulators say thoroughness of the investigation matters more than timing. The investigation's impact on Noble's prospects remains uncertain, with observers suggesting the company's bleak outlook due to thinning margins and high finance costs. The restructuring and debt rescue plan still have a fair chance of success, with creditors backing the deal and a key waiver from Singapore's Securities Industry Council.

site_title: Singapore becoming too reliant on a murky data economy
summary: Singapore's growing reliance on a data economy, which powers innovations like Smart City initiatives, poses concerns about data accuracy and authenticity. The data economy's opaque supply chain, where data is often sourced from middlemen without transparency, increases the risk of faked or inaccurate data. This can have hidden costs, such as failed businesses and slower economic growth. To address this, technology like data authentication using blockchain can provide a solution, enabling accountability and tracing back to the source of poor-quality data, as seen in the Facebook video viewership metrics controversy.

site_title: Court extends Hyflux debt moratorium to end of April 2019
summary: A Singapore High Court has extended Hyflux's debt moratorium by four-and-a-half months to April 30, 2019, despite arguments from bank creditors that the insolvent firm should be kept on a tighter leash. The extension allows Hyflux to continue negotiations with creditors and plan a scheme of arrangement to restructure its debt. The firm must obtain approval from at least 75% of creditors in value and 50% in number to proceed with the restructuring.

site_title: Integrating smart solutions into the workforce
summary: V3 Smart Technologies, a Singapore-based mobility solutions provider, has developed award-winning solutions to boost the efficiency of Singapore's workforce. Its Workforce Assignment & Mobility (WAM) solution optimizes job planning, scheduling, and monitoring, increasing transparency and automation. WAM has been adapted for various industries and has helped bridge the gap in homecare services for elderly patients. The company is now working on integrating mixed reality technology into its WAM service to enhance visualizations and monitoring of work status.

summary: There is no article to summarize, the provided text appears to be a collection of news headlines from various dates.

site_title: Singapore's industrial output up a surprise 4.3% in October
summary: Singapore's manufacturing output grew 4.3% in October, exceeding economists' expectations of 2.6% growth, according to preliminary estimates. Excluding the biomedical manufacturing sector, output rose 3%. Despite this, economists remain cautious on the manufacturing outlook, citing a global tech cycle fade and US-China trade war disruptions. The electronics sector fell 2.7% year on year, while transport engineering remained the top-performing cluster. Economists predict a slowdown in manufacturing for the remainder of 2018, with some expecting a contraction in 2019.

images.alt_text: Singapore's manufacturing output grew 4.3 per cent year on year in October, more than rebounding from September's marginal 0.1 per cent fall, according to preliminary estimates from the Economic Development Board on Monday.

site_title: China property billionaire transfers US$7b stake to her daughter's trust
summary: China property billionaire Wu Yajun is transferring a $7.2 billion stake in her company Longfor Group Holding to a trust linked to her daughter, Cai Xinyi, for "family wealth and succession planning". The stake, held by a discretionary trust, will be distributed to the daughter's trust. Wu Yajun remains the chairman and executive director of the company. The transaction is seen as a move for succession planning, but details about the daughter's involvement in the company are scarce.

site_title: France enters world of whisky-making
summary: France, known for its wine and cognac, has entered the world of whisky-making, with 33 fully-operational distilleries and 30-odd more in production. Sales have quadrupled to 850,000 bottles last year, with the country drinking the most whisky per capita, 2.15 liters per person in 2014. French whiskies offer a unique "terroir" experience, with many distilleries using used wine barrels and exploiting the country's skilled distillation and ageing techniques. Despite growth, the industry remains limited, with only a few distilleries capable of large-scale production, and faces high profit margin requirements.

site_title: Paychex to buy outsourcing firm Oasis for US$1.2b
summary: Paychex Inc. announced plans to buy outsourcing firm Oasis Outsourcing Acquisition Corp for $1.2 billion in cash to expand its human resources outsourcing services and enter new markets. Oasis, serving over 8,400 clients, will increase Paychex's market reach and PEO sales organization. The deal, funded by a combination of cash and debt, is expected to have minimal impact on Paychex's fiscal year 2019 earnings per share.

site_title: EU proposes way forward for WTO's appellate body
summary: The European Union has proposed a way forward to unblock the World Trade Organization's (WTO) appellate body, which has been paralyzed due to the US blocking appointments. The proposal, backed by 11 countries, aims to create new rules for outgoing appellate body members and ensure appeal proceedings are completed within the 90-day timeframe set by the WTO. The EU also suggests reinforcing the appellate body's independence and impartiality by adding two new members and providing additional support. The proposal will be presented at the WTO's General Council on December 12.

site_title: With all this innovation, why are payments still so fragmented?
summary: The payments landscape in Singapore remains fragmented despite recent innovations, with multiple mobile wallets and partnerships emerging. The proliferation of QR wallets and partnerships has led to consumer confusion, with small businesses struggling to manage multiple payment solutions. However, experts believe that the real innovation opportunity lies in interoperability and openness, with softPOS technology offering a seamless customer experience through contactless card payments on smartphones. Singapore can lead in mobile-first, inter-operable payments acceptance, making life easier for consumers and businesses alike.

site_title: Singapore malls add more on-site to combat online threat
summary: Singapore malls are introducing non-shopping activities such as yoga studios, boxing gyms, and climbing walls to combat the threat of online shopping. Despite falling rents and rising vacancies, visitor numbers have risen 3.1% at VivoCity and shopper traffic at CapitaLand Mall Trust has climbed 0.5%. However, actual shopping has fallen slightly, and mall rents are expected to remain subdued until in-store purchases increase. The government's new tax on imported digital services may also contribute to the strategy's effectiveness.

images.alt_text: Futuristic machines and a revamped bumper car arena at Timezone's newly renovated flagship store at VivoCity. The mall's visitor numbers rose 3.1% in the 6 months to Sept 30 from a year earlier.

site_title: Steering MDIS beyond the Red Dot
summary: MDIS, a Singapore-based private education institution, aims to expand its global presence despite the saturated education sector. The institution has achieved numerous awards, including the Enterprise 50 award, and has established partnerships with universities worldwide. MDIS has also expanded overseas, opening a campus in Uzbekistan and plans to establish more campuses in Myanmar, Indonesia, and the Philippines. Its focus is on providing future-ready skills to students and mid-career professionals, and the institution plans to introduce new vocational programs and Singapore Workforce Skills Qualification certifications.

site_title: Mitsubishi Motors board ousts Ghosn as chairman
summary: Mitsubishi Motors Corp removed Carlos Ghosn as chairman in a unanimous board vote, following his ouster from Nissan Motor Co. due to alleged financial misconduct. Ghosn's dismissal marks the end of his chairmanship, just two years after he led Mitsubishi Motors out of a cheating scandal. CEO Osamu Masuko will become temporary chairman, amid a power struggle between Nissan and Renault, a French partner in the 19-year Franco-Japanese alliance. The move comes as the alliance faces challenges from Volkswagen and Toyota, and as Ghosn pushes for a deeper tie-up between Renault and Nissan.

site_title: ChildAid's through train down memory lane raises over S$2 million
summary: The 14th edition of ChildAid, a charity concert, was held at Resorts World Sentosa, raising S$2,057,237 for arts training and school support funds. The event, organized by The Business Times and The Straits Times, featured a 60-year pop music journey through performances by various artists, including Dick Lee, Madonna, George Michael, and Pharrell Williams. The concert, which included young performers and older audience favorites, was attended by President Halimah Yacob and raised funds for disadvantaged children.

site_title: Banksy the rebel on show in Milan
summary: A new exhibition in Milan, Italy, explores the works of British street artist Banksy, examining his art as a form of protest and social commentary. The solo show, curated by Gianni Mercurio, features 80 works, including paintings, sculptures, and prints, and runs until April 2019. The exhibition delves into Banksy's influences, including the Situationism movement and the 1968 Paris uprising, and showcases his subversive style, which critiques consumerism, imperialism, and war. By exploring Banksy's art beyond his anonymity, the show aims to understand the artist's significance and message.

images.alt_text: A Visual Protest showcases 80 works including paintings, sculptures, prints and record and CD covers.

site_title: Upset Pines members demand city club membership or compensation
summary: Approximately 90 upset members of The Pines club in Singapore have demanded city club membership or compensation from owner Peter Kwee, alleging he misrepresented redevelopment plans. Members claim the club owner sold a land parcel to Oxley Holdings in 2013, contradicting his promise to build new facilities. They are seeking "fair compensation" of S$44,000 to S$147,000, or alternative options such as equivalent membership in nearby clubs or a new hotel. Kwee maintains he did not misrepresent the plans and offered alternative membership options.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Cityneon Holdings has received a "fair and reasonable" cash offer of S$1.30 per share from independent financial adviser Novus Corporate Finance, advising shareholders to accept unless they can secure a higher price on the open market. The offer, launched by executive chairman Ron Tan and Hong Kong entrepreneur Johnson Ko, aims to delist and take the company private.

site_title: It will take a decade to fix profiteering culture, says Aussie bank chairman
summary: National Australia Bank (NAB) chairman Ken Henry says it will take a decade to fix the profiteering culture that has damaged the lender's reputation. The culture includes bribery, fraud, and charging fees for no service, with customers' trust "pretty well eroded to zero." NAB has reviewed its culture and found "insufficient intensity of focus on getting it right all the time." The bank has admitted to charging dead client accounts and has determined it did not respond fast enough to regulators. Henry did not specify why it would take 10 years to overhaul the culture.

site_title: Oil gets caught in a perfect storm
summary: Oil prices have plummeted by nearly one-third in less than two months to $50, driven by uncertainty in demand, high production, and skepticism about OPEC's ability to curb output. The recent price retreat has been amplified by US sanctions on Iran, despite further restrictions. A perfect storm of factors, including US President Trump's Twitter campaign and Saudi Arabia's reluctance to take action, has led to a difficult short-term outlook for oil prices. Market participants are advised to draw insights from the "cobweb theorem" to better understand the dynamics.

site_title: Golden Wall Centre sold for S$276.2m on second collective sale attempt
summary: Golden Wall Centre, a 2,251.9 sq m freehold commercial property in Singapore, was sold en bloc for S$276.2 million to City View Holdings, exceeding the reserve price of S$260 million. The property is zoned for commercial use and benefits from its location near Rochor MRT station and the Beach Road/Ophir-Rochor Corridor. ET&Co handled the collective sale, citing the property's strategic location and proximity to arts and cultural districts as ideal for a hotel development.

site_title: Asia manager who called China tech peak is ready to dive back in
summary: Asia manager Jian Shi Cortesi is ready to re-enter the Chinese tech sector, citing a near-record discount between Asian and US stocks. She's looking at three areas: China Internet, China autos, and Korean cosmetics, seeing opportunities to buy shares that have been impacted by policy headwinds and sentiment shifts. Cortesi expects the MSCI Asia index to rally 20% next year, driven by valuation recovery and potential trade tensions easing.

site_title: Car market growth engine sputters in China's hinterland
summary: China's car market, the world's largest, is on the brink of its first sales contraction in almost three decades due to a slowdown aggravated by the protracted trade war with the US. In smaller, provincial cities like Pingdingshan, consumers are being squeezed tight, with many facing reduced incomes and increased debt. As a result, car sales have dropped sharply, with Henan province seeing a 18% decline in October, outstripping a 12% nationwide decline. Local car dealers have responded by cutting prices, but sales remain sluggish, with some dealers reporting declines of 40-60% compared to last year.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: SIA Engineering Company's share price has corrected by 15% since a downgrade on Nov 9, 2018, due to reduced work volume and competition. The company's operating margins and dividends may be pressured in the future. Analysts have reduced their fair value estimate to S$2.64, citing a dim outlook with limited catalysts for growth. The competition from Chinese maintenance providers and a possible privatisation of SIA may remain a challenge in the longer term.

site_title: Competition for funds driving up fixed deposit rates
summary: Competing for fixed deposit funds, banks in Singapore are offering higher rates to attract investors. Key players, including DBS, CIMB Bank Singapore, and Hong Leong Finance, are promoting fresh funds placed in fixed deposits, with rates reaching up to 1.85% for two-year terms. As interest rates rise, alternative instruments like Singapore Savings Bonds and short-term papers are gaining popularity. Banks aim to retain their share of funds amid competition, while investors seek higher yields in a rising interest rate environment.

site_title: This year's G20 may be the most crucial since 2009
summary: World leaders are gathering for the G20 summit in Argentina, where US-China trade tensions are expected to come to a head. The meeting, attended by 19 nations accounting for 90% of global GDP, is seen as the most crucial since 2009. Last year's Hamburg summit highlighted divisions on trade, migration, and climate change, with US President Donald Trump being isolated over his rejection of the Paris Agreement. This year's meeting may address these issues, with the US and China's trade tensions potentially reaching a boiling point.

site_title: Singapore bonds face contagion fears from Lippo probe
summary: Singapore dollar-denominated bonds issued by First Real Estate Investment Trust (First Reit) and OUE Ltd have dropped amid a liquidity crunch and concerns of contagion from an investigation into Indonesian property developer PT Lippo Karawaci, controlled by the Riady family. Lippo Karawaci is under probe due to a bribery inquiry, and its weakening credit profile is negatively impacting First Reit and Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust. The entities' bonds have sold off as they use other entities to shore up finances, raising concerns about a potential liquidity crunch.

site_title: Oil bulls flee as Riyadh shows no sign of slowing production
summary: Hedge funds have become extremely bearish on global oil prices, with net-long wagers on Brent crude falling 15% in the week ending Nov 20, their lowest level since 2016. Saudi Arabia's continued record production and US shale producers' high volumes amid low demand are driving the pessimistic sentiment. Analysts predict sustained oversupply in 2019, undoing Opec's success in draining global inventories, unless a new deal is reached to constrain output in Vienna next month.

site_title: First batch of diesel-electric hybrid buses to hit the road in December
summary: Singapore will introduce its first 10 diesel-electric hybrid buses, part of a national effort to make public buses more environmentally friendly, in December. The buses, supplied by Volvo East Asia, will run on electricity at speeds of up to 17 km/h and switch to diesel engines at higher speeds. The hybrid buses feature advanced driver-assistance systems and an enhanced information display system with LCD and LED screens. The Land Transport Authority plans to progressively deploy the buses on different services to better understand operational challenges and maintain the vehicles.

site_title: General Atlantic invests in Mideast's Property Finder
summary: General Atlantic led a $120 million investment round in Property Finder, a Middle East real estate classifieds website, acquiring a minority stake. The investment will be used to enhance product and technology, and expand the brand in existing markets. Property Finder's CEO Michael Lahyani stated the company will add approximately 200 staff to its workforce by the end of 2019, valuing the company at nearly $500 million. This investment follows a 2016 valuation of $200 million.

site_title: WTO's quarterly indicator suggests trade growth slowing further in Q4
summary: The World Trade Organization's quarterly indicator suggests global merchandise trade growth is slowing further in Q4, with a reading of 98.6, the lowest since October 2016. This marks a decline in momentum since August, with all seven drivers of trade showing declines. A reading below 100 signals below-trend growth in trade, indicating a loss of momentum.

site_title: Cancer diagnostics firm Biolidics lodges prospectus for Catalist IPO
summary: Biolidics Limited, a cancer diagnostics firm, has lodged a preliminary prospectus for a planned initial public offering (IPO) on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board. The company, formerly known as Clearbridge Biomedics, specializes in developing cell enrichment systems for cancer diagnosis and has installed 80 systems globally. Its main product, ClearCell FX1 System, is used for liquid biopsies and is being developed into end-to-end diagnostics solutions. The IPO proceeds will be used to expand its product pipeline and clinical services, with no pricing, amount, or timing details announced yet.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as retail, tech stocks gain
summary: US stocks opened higher on Monday, driven by optimism for a robust holiday season, as retailers and technology stocks rebounded from last week's sell-off. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.32%, the S&P 500 gained 0.66%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 1.26%. The gains followed a brutal sell-off last week, but investors are focusing on the potential for a strong holiday season.

site_title: Ralph Breaks the Internet pulls in US$55.7m, dominates US box office
summary: Disney's animated film Ralph Breaks the Internet dominated the US box office, earning an estimated $55.7 million over the Thanksgiving holiday weekend. The film, a sequel to Wreck It Ralph, has a production budget of $175 million. It took the second-best debut for the holiday weekend, behind Disney's Frozen. Creed II and The Grinch rounded out the top three spots, with Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald and Bohemian Rhapsody following.

images.alt_text: Ralph (voiced by John Reilly) and fellow misfit Vanellope von Schweetz (Sarah Silverman) venture into the expansive world of the Internet, where they meet eBay Elayne (Rebecca Wisocky), as well as encounter some un-Disney-like behaviour.

site_title: Italy may cut deficit target in bid to appease EU, markets
summary: Italy's governing coalition may lower its next year's budget deficit target to 2% of gross domestic product to appease the European Union and avoid disciplinary action. The move comes after the European Commission called for a reduction in the structural deficit. The decision could lead to a breakthrough in the standoff with Brussels, which has roiled financial markets. The Italian benchmark bond-yield spread fell to its tightest level in over a month, and the stock market rose over 2%. A meeting between Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte and European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker on Saturday appeared to open the way to a softening of Italy's position.

site_title: Drones to the rescue of crumbling Great Wall
summary: Chinese authorities are using Intel's Falcon 8+ drones to map and measure sections of the crumbling Great Wall, collecting precise data to rehabilitate the ancient structure. The drones capture 3D images of badly weathered ramparts, such as the Jiankou section, allowing workers to build support structures for vulnerable sections. The effort is complex, requiring the study of arrow holes, battlements, and floor designs, according to a Great Wall architect. This innovative approach aims to preserve the wall, a 2,000-year-old feat of engineering, and protect it from natural erosion.

site_title: GIC, Australian Reit Dexus form A$2b JV to invest in logistics
summary: Singapore sovereign wealth fund GIC and Australian Reit Dexus have formed a $2 billion joint venture, Dexus Australian Logistics Trust, to invest in logistics properties in Australia. GIC will be the foundation investor, taking a 25% stake, and will also hold 49% interest in a $1.4 billion seed development portfolio. The JV will focus on core logistics facilities in strong performing precincts with good access to major roads, rails, and ports, primarily in Sydney and Melbourne, with a weighted average lease expiry of 5.3 years and 98% occupancy.

site_title: A slippery trade: oil slump proves bears right
summary: Oil prices have fallen to a one-year low, reversing the trend from a four-year high in early 2018, as global trade war worries and rising US shale oil production took hold. The collapse has proved some investors right in their skepticism about energy stocks, with big banks advising investors to avoid the sector. Energy stocks are still sensitive to oil price volatility, and companies are seeking stability in prices to make investment decisions. Despite this, energy companies are better positioned to withstand lower oil prices, with top companies generating profits at around $50 a barrel.

site_title: America has chance to repair its image abroad
summary: US President Donald Trump's presidency has been marked by unconventional actions, including picking fights with allies and devaluing human rights. As Democrats take control of the House, they should assert themselves on national security, reaffirming alliances and democratic values. They should also challenge Trump's approach to the "forever war" and end US support for the Saudi-led war in Yemen. Democrats should scrutinize administration plans, including nuclear modernization and space force, and investigate potential corruption, particularly in dealings with countries like Saudi Arabia and Russia. By taking these steps, Democrats can signal a shift in priorities and help restore America's international standing.

site_title: Leaving the EU to cost UK US$128b, anti-Brexit group says
summary: A study commissioned by the People's Vote group found that the UK's decision to leave the EU will cost the country $128 billion annually by 2030, with the economy expected to shrink by 3.9% compared to staying in the EU. The study warns of a "catastrophic reduction in trade and investment" and a decline in foreign direct investment and tax revenue. This comes as Prime Minister Theresa May begins selling her Brexit agreement to UK politicians, with the Bank of England set to present its own analysis on Thursday.

site_title: LTC Corp to convene adjourned EGM, vote on proposed delisting
summary: LTC Corp, a Singapore-based steel trading and property company, will convene an adjourned extraordinary general meeting (EGM) on Dec 11 to vote on its proposed delisting. The company has confirmed with the Singapore Exchange (SGX) that its delisting will be subject to existing voluntary delisting rules, despite recent proposed changes by SGX Regco. The offeror, Mountbatten Resources Pte Ltd, holds 88.44% of LTC's shares and can vote, making it difficult for minority shareholders to oppose the delisting resolution.

site_title: Where to park your funds? Well, it depends
summary: Singaporeans should consider diversifying their investment portfolio as interest rates rise, rather than putting all savings in fixed deposits. Alfred Chia, CEO at SingCapital, advises monitoring inflation rates and ensuring deposit rates exceed them to avoid erosion. Fixed deposits are suitable for risk-averse investors, while high-quality bonds like Singapore Savings Bonds and Temasek retail bonds may be suitable for those with balanced risk profiles. Ultimately, investors should choose an instrument based on their individual risk profile, investment objective, and time horizon.

site_title: Qatar Airways announces more flights to Iran weeks after US sanctions reimposed on Tehran
summary: Qatar Airways announced it will add two weekly flights to its Doha-Tehran route and three weekly flights to its Shiraz service in January, following the US reimposition of sanctions on Iran. The airline's CEO, Akbar al-Baker, stated that the new flights demonstrate Qatar Airways' commitment to the Iranian market. This move comes after European carriers and Etihad Airways suspended flights to Iran due to US sanctions targeting Iran's economy and nuclear program. The sanctions were re-imposed just weeks after the US pulled out of a nuclear deal with Iran.

site_title: Goldman predicts commodities will soar in 2019
summary: Goldman Sachs predicts commodities will soar in 2019, citing unsustainable market conditions and a potential turning point at the upcoming G-20 meeting in Buenos Aires. Analysts forecast 17% returns for oil, gold, and base metals, with OPEC supply cuts and improved US-China relations driving the rebound. The bank also recommends long positions on short-dated Brent, selling US$50 December 2019 WTI put options, and going long Chicago soybeans and shorting corn.

site_title: Goodluck Garden gets court's nod for sale despite missteps by committee, advisers
summary: The High Court of Singapore granted a sale order to Goodluck Garden, a condominium on Toh Tuck Road, after finding "no bad faith" despite missteps by the collective sale committee, marketing agent, and lawyers. The sale price, S$610 million, was 12.6% higher than an independent valuation by Colliers International. The court criticized the committee for not disclosing the development charge (DC) accurately and not informing owners of the potential DC increase. The sale was finalized before the cooling measures were implemented, making the sale price more favorable for owners.

images.alt_text: The high Court granted a sale order to Goodluck Garden on Monday, making it the latest property to have its collective sale resolved by the courts, though the court also found several missteps in the sale process.

site_title: Chinese university to investigate after academic claims to have edited twins' genes
summary: A Chinese university has announced an investigation into an associate professor's claim to have edited the genes of twin girls born earlier this month using the CRISPR-Cas9 technology. Prof He Jiankui, who is on unpaid leave, released videos on YouTube defending his work and claiming the editing process "worked safely as intended". The university described the work as a "serious violation of academic ethics and standards". The investigation will be led by an independent committee of experts, and the university has stated that it strictly requires scientific research to conform to national laws and regulations and respect international academic ethics.

site_title: Glaxo considers developing Gonorrhea vaccine as threat rises
summary: GlaxoSmithKline is considering developing a vaccine against gonorrhea, a sexually-transmitted infection threatening to become unstoppable due to antibiotic resistance. The company is exploring expanding its Bexsero vaccine to include gonorrhea, as well as developing a targeted vaccine. US infections have risen 19% in a year, and the US CDC has listed drug-resistant gonorrhea as a major public health threat. Glaxo would need to weigh the effort against other options, with a goal of achieving 90% efficacy, currently at 30%.

site_title: Saudi Arabia pumps record amount of oil as Trump piles on pressure
