summary: Saudi Arabia has raised oil production to an all-time high of 11.1-11.3 million barrels per day in November, as US President Donald Trump pressures the kingdom to refrain from production cuts at an Opec meeting next week. This move comes after Saudi Arabia agreed to raise supply in June to cool oil prices and address a supply shortage after Washington imposed sanctions on Iran. Analysts at Goldman Sachs expect the G20 meeting to lead to a recovery in oil prices, while Saudi energy minister Khalid al Falih said global oil supply could exceed demand by over 1 million bpd next year.

site_title: GM confirms plans to slash jobs and production, cancel some car models
summary: General Motors (GM) plans to cut car production, stop building several slow-selling models, and slash its North American workforce, its largest restructuring in North America since bankruptcy. The company will halt production at three assembly plants and stop building models like the Chevrolet Cruze, Cadillac CT6, and Buick LaCrosse. GM will shift investment to electric and autonomous vehicles, citing increased cost pressures due to auto industry changes and tariffs on imported steel. The company employs about 2,500 union staff in Oshawa, Canada, which will be affected by the cuts.

images.alt_text: GM's assembly plant in Oshawa, Ontario, one of the three plants it will be shutting down.

site_title: TA Corp subsidiary bags residential development contracts totalling S$149.9m
summary: TA Corporation's subsidiary Tiong Aik Construction secured two residential development contracts totaling S$149.9 million from Allgreen Properties for projects at Fourth Avenue and Ewe Boon Road. The contracts are expected to have no impact on the group's earnings per share and net tangible assets for the current financial year. TA Corporation's shares closed unchanged at S$0.22 following the announcement.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's manufacturing output grew 4.3% year on year in October, exceeding economists' expectations. The High Court granted a sale order to Goodluck Garden's S$610 million collective sale. Golden Wall Centre was sold en bloc for S$276.2m to Hotel 81 owner. DBS Bank's PayLah! e-wallet can now be used at UnionPay QR code merchants in 24 countries. Singapore shares closed higher on Monday, with the Straits Times Index rising 40.89 points, or 1.34%.

images.alt_text: Employees working at the wafer production line at REC Solar ASA manufacturing facility in Tuas. Singapore's manufacturing output grew 4.3 per cent year on year in October, more than rebounding from September's marginal 0.1 per cent fall and exceeding economists' expectations of 2.6 per cent growth.

site_title: Wage growth slows to worst rate since 2008 crisis: UN
summary: The International Labour Organization reported that global wage growth slowed to 1.8% in 2017, its lowest rate since the 2008 financial crisis. Women worldwide continue to earn 20% less than men, and the gap persists despite economic growth and falling unemployment. The report highlights significant differences between high-income and developing countries, with wages tripling in emerging economies but remaining stagnant in advanced nations. The ILO director-general called the persistent gender pay gap a "manifestation of social injustice" and urged countries to accelerate progress towards gender equality.

images.alt_text: Guy Ryder, General Director of the International Labour Organisation (ILO) has called the persistent gender pay gaps "one of today's greatest manifestations of social injustice."

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly up as eyes turn to Trump-Xi talks
summary: Asian markets rose on Monday as investors awaited a meeting between US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping, expected to signal a softening in the China-US trade war. Despite energy firms falling due to oil price collapse, the markets were boosted by gains in Hong Kong, Shanghai, Tokyo, Singapore, and Seoul. However, Wellington and Sydney declined. The meeting, set for the weekend, is seen as a key event, but expectations for a deal are low, with perceptions on both sides being crucial.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher on Monday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 40.89 points, or 1.34%, to 3,093.38 on Monday, driven by gains in offshore and marine stocks. About 1.6 billion shares worth S$853.8 million changed hands. Ezion Holdings and Rex International saw significant gains, while Vallianz fell. The gains followed a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: 'Last Tango In Paris' director Bertolucci dies: reports
summary: Italian film director Bernardo Bertolucci, known for "Last Tango In Paris" and "1900", has died in Rome at 77. He was the only Italian to win the Oscar for best film in 1988 for "The Last Emperor," a biographical masterpiece that won nine Oscars. Bertolucci was wheelchair-bound for several years and received an honorary Palme d'Or at the 2011 Cannes Film Festival. His films often dealt with politics and workers' struggles, but he faced controversy over the depiction of a sex scene in "Last Tango In Paris."

site_title: Singapore High Court extends Hyflux debt moratorium to end of April 2019
summary: The Singapore High Court has extended Hyflux's debt moratorium to April 30, 2019, despite arguments from some bank creditors that the insolvent firm should be kept on a tighter leash. Justice Aedit Abdullah granted the extension after hearing lawyers for Hyflux and its unsecured working group. The decision allows Hyflux more time to negotiate with creditors, with its next case conference set for January 21, 2019.

site_title: EU sends WTO reform proposals to break US deadlock
summary: The European Union has submitted proposals for WTO reform to break the US deadlock, after agreeing with China, India, and other countries. The EU aims to address US concerns about the Appellate Body's authority and rules, and has identified five US concerns in its proposals. The proposals will be presented at the WTO's General Council on December 12, but the US has not officially responded. The WTO is facing a crisis after President Trump blocked appointments and threatened a US withdrawal, bringing the world's top trade court to the brink of collapse.

site_title: Cyber Monday deals to test limits of retailers' websites
summary: Cyber Monday online shopping sales are expected to reach $7.8 billion, with 75 million shoppers participating. Retailers, including Amazon and Target, are offering discounts and free shipping to test their e-commerce operations. Technical difficulties were reported on Black Friday and are expected to be a challenge, with toys and clothing being the biggest discounts. Online sales have already seen a significant jump, with Black Friday sales reaching $6 billion and Thanksgiving sales surpassing $3.7 billion.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open week with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.73% on Monday, driven by bargain-buying following recent losses, as dealers await a key meeting between Donald Trump and Xi Jinping at the end of the week. The Hang Seng Index reached 26,376.18, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index declined 0.14% and 0.32%, respectively. The gains were despite US-EU trade tensions and a slump in European stocks.

site_title: Europe: Stocks up as EU approves May's Brexit plan
summary: European stocks rose 0.8-0.9% on positive political developments, led by banking and oil shares. The EU approved Theresa May's Brexit plan, with investors watching closely how it fares in the UK Parliament. Italy's FTSE MIB jumped 2.4% as Deputy Prime Minister Matteo Salvini's economic adviser indicated possible fine-tuning of the budget. Oil shares, including BP, Total, and Shell, rose as Brent oil recovered from declines.

site_title: Global economy heads into final stretch with diminished momentum
summary: The global economy is heading into its final stretch of 2018 with diminished momentum, sparking concerns about central banks' ability to tighten monetary policy next year. Manufacturing gauges in Japan and Germany dropped to their lowest levels since early 2016 and 2017, respectively. Business confidence in Germany fell for a third month, and the European Central Bank is set to confirm the end of net asset purchases in December. The US Federal Reserve may raise interest rates again in December but may be more cautious in 2019 due to a slowdown in economic growth.

site_title: Thai Bev full year net profit down 46%
summary: Thai Beverage reported a 46% decline in full-year net profit to 18.53 billion baht (S$77 million) for 2018, due to lower profits across its spirits, beer, and non-alcoholic beverage businesses. The company attributed the decline to a slow economy, increased product prices, and reduced consumer purchasing power. The spirits business saw a 13.2% year-on-year decrease in net profit, while beer sales declined 10.4%. However, the food business reported a 96.8% increase in sales revenue and a 529% surge in net profit. ThaiBev declared annual dividends of 0.39 baht per share.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed higher on Monday, up 6.11 points to 1,701.99. The index saw 1.7 billion lots traded worth RM1.4 billion, with 452 losers outweighing 354 gainers.

site_title: Greek Eurobank to buy property firm in 780m euro deal
summary: Greek Eurobank agrees to acquire property firm Grivalia Properties in an all-share deal valued at 780 million euros. The acquisition aims to strengthen Eurobank's capital base and reduce bad loans, with the merged entity targeting strong sustainable earnings per share and a 10% return on tangible equity in 2020. Fairfax Financial Holdings, which holds significant stakes in both companies, will become the largest shareholder in the merged entity. The deal is expected to cut Eurobank's non-performing loans to single digits by 2021.

site_title: Asia manager who called China Tech peak is ready to dive back in
summary: Asia manager Jian Shi Cortesi is looking to buy into China Internet, China Autos, and Korea Cosmetics due to oversold valuations. Cortesi believes the Chinese government's regulations on the internet sector will introduce order and prevent a complete collapse, making it an attractive investment opportunity. She expects the MSCI Asia index to rally 20% in 2019, driven by a recovery in valuations, particularly if trade tensions with the US ease. Cortesi's firm, GAM Investments, oversees $146 billion in assets globally.

site_title: Five London penthouses, now 20 per cent off or more
summary: London penthouse prices have dropped by at least 20% as buyers negotiate discounts amid market uncertainty. Five penthouses have had their prices reduced, including a 5-bedroom Aykon London One penthouse now priced at £11 million (S$19.2 million), a Camden duplex at £1 million (down from £1.28 million), and a Chelsea Creek property at £1 million (down from £1.38 million). The discounts come as fears of a market crash weigh on demand, with buyers seeking reductions of 15% or more.

site_title: Golden Wall Centre sold en bloc for S$276.2m to Hotel 81 owner
summary: Golden Wall Centre, a freehold commercial property in Singapore, has been sold en bloc for S$276.2 million to City View Holdings, a subsidiary of Worldwide Hotels. The sale price exceeded the reserve price of S$260 million, and the property will be redeveloped into a hotel. Located near the Rochor MRT station and in the Beach Road/Ophir-Rochor Corridor, the property benefits from its strategic city fringe location and proximity to cultural districts. The sale was handled by ET&Co, and the property's land area is approximately 2,251.9 square meters.

site_title: DBS PayLah! can soon be used at UnionPay QR code merchants in 24 countries
summary: DBS PayLah! users can soon use their mobile wallet at over 10 million UnionPay QR code merchants in 24 countries, including Australia and the US. The partnership between DBS Bank and UnionPay International enables cross-border QR code payments, following a similar tie-up with Nets in September. This expansion aims to provide a universal mobile wallet for consumers worldwide, with DBS recording 1.2 million QR code transactions in Singapore each month.

site_title: Oil, metal woes hurt Australian shares; NZ also down
summary: Australian shares declined 0.78% on Monday, led by heavy losses in the mining and energy sectors due to a plunge in oil prices. Global miners BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto fell 3.6% each, while metals and mining stocks plummeted 3% to their lowest level in over seven months. Oil prices, which dropped 8% last week, steadied slightly in Asian markets but failed to offset the losses. New Zealand's benchmark index also fell 0.45%.

site_title: Tencent Music to sound out global IPO market
summary: Tencent Music, China's answer to Spotify, plans to list its music streaming service in New York, with a potential $2 billion IPO in December. The move is seen as a test for the global IPO market, which has been subdued due to a global stock selloff and large investors' preference for avoiding chunky deals during the festive period. Tencent has already pared back its plans, and shares are expected to start trading on December 12. The company is already profitable and has $1.9 billion in cash, raising questions about the need for fresh funds.

site_title: Singapore manufacturing surprises on the upside with 4.3% growth in October
summary: Singapore's manufacturing output grew 4.3% year-over-year in October, exceeding economists' expectations, according to preliminary estimates. Excluding biomedical manufacturing, output grew 3%. Electronics output declined 2.7% year-over-year, while transport engineering, marine, and offshore engineering sectors saw significant growth. Biomedical manufacturing output grew 11.5%, driven by pharmaceuticals and medical technology segments.

site_title: GM to make major announcement about global operations Monday -Canada union
summary: General Motors is set to make a major announcement on Monday affecting its global operations, including auto production at an Ontario plant in Canada. The Oshawa plant, which employs 2,500 union staff and 300 salaried employees, will no longer receive allocated products after December 2019, according to Unifor. This move comes as GM cuts jobs to address plunging car sales in North America and has been internally debating how to address shrinking demand. The company has been offering buyouts to North American salaried workers and has said it could lay off staff if cost-cutting targets are not met.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rise on gains in chemicals, airlines; won inches up
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 25.55 points, or 1.24%, to 2,083.03, its biggest daily gain since November 2, driven by gains in chemical and airline stocks due to an oil price slump. The won edged up, while bond yields remained nearly unchanged. Railway-related firms soared after the South Korean government secured an exception for an inter-Korean railway survey. Investors took a wait-and-see attitude ahead of the Fed monetary policy decision and the US-China summit.

site_title: Flash: Singapore High Court grants sale order of Goodluck Garden on Monday morning
summary: The Singapore High Court granted a sale order for the Goodluck Garden property on Monday morning. The court's decision comes after a long-standing dispute over the property. The sale order will likely pave the way for the property to be sold, but the exact terms and conditions remain unclear. The outcome is a significant development in the ongoing saga surrounding the property.

site_title: Chasen Holdings secures two contracts worth 34m yuan with repeat customer
summary: Chasen Holdings secured two contracts worth 34 million yuan with a repeat customer in China. The contracts involve providing relocation services for a state-of-the-art flat-panel display production plant and a semiconductor fabrication facility. The projects are expected to have a positive impact on Chasen's results for the next financial year, driven by growing demand for electronic and smart devices in China.

site_title: Russia plans stiffer fines for tech firms that break rules - sources
summary: Russia plans to impose stiffer fines on technology firms that fail to comply with Russian laws, with fines equal to 1% of their annual revenue in Russia. The proposal, contained in a consultation document, aims to increase enforcement of internet laws requiring search engines to delete search results, messaging services to share encryption keys, and social networks to store user data on Russian servers. The move targets global tech giants like Facebook and Google, which have faced criticism for failing to comply with Russian laws.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks gain on World Expo cheer
summary: Tokyo stocks rose on Monday, driven by gains in the construction sector and companies related to Japan's hosting of the World Expo 2025. The Nikkei 225 index increased 0.76% to 21,812.00, while the Topix index rose 0.20% to 1,632.20. Investors monitored US-China trade talks, but the benchmark indices closed higher.

site_title: Singapore High Court grants sale order to Goodluck Garden en bloc
summary: The Singapore High Court has granted a sale order to Goodluck Garden's S$610 million collective sale after a lengthy dispute. Justice Woo Bih Li criticized marketing agent Knight Frank, the collective sale committee, and their lawyers for handling the sale. The court found no bad faith in the collective sale process, but criticized the committee for not extending the tender period and for not seeking owners' approval for the apportionment of sale proceeds. The sale order allows the buyer, Qingjian, to acquire the 210-unit freehold residential development.

site_title: LNG import boom seen as no relief for Australian gas prices
summary: Australia's plans to import liquefied natural gas (LNG) to ease supply shortages and lower prices are unlikely to be effective, according to industry experts. Despite having abundant gas in the west, supply constraints in the east have led to rising prices, with wholesale gas increasing by 20% between 2015 and 2017. Importing LNG would not significantly reduce prices, as it would be sold at the same netback price as domestic producers, averaging around A$12.20 per gigajoule.

site_title: Boom or bust? Brexit makes London property outlook hard to read
summary: London's office landlords face uncertainty due to Brexit, which could disrupt the real estate market. Developers such as Land Securities Group Plc, British Land Co., and Great Portland Estates Plc are adjusting their strategies by focusing on existing projects, reducing debt, and squeezing more out of their portfolios. The risk of a no-deal Brexit remains, but some developers, like British Land, are taking a more bullish approach by pursuing new leases and refurbishments. The outlook for the London property market remains challenging, with most landlords trading at wide discounts to asset value due to Brexit risk.

site_title: New Zealand pressured to defend rights of China researcher
summary: New Zealand researchers have called on Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern to defend academic freedoms following the alleged intimidation of University of Canterbury professor Anne-Marie Brady, who investigated China's foreign policy. Brady's home and office were burgled, and her car was tampered with, sparking concerns that she was targeted due to her research. The 29 researchers, including Amnesty International New Zealand, urged transparency in the police investigation and warned that intimidation of one academic could impact all others.

site_title: A wee dram, s'il vous plait: France enters world of whisky-making
summary: France has entered the world of whisky-making, with 33 fully-operational distilleries and 30-odd more in development. This shift comes after Japan's success in disrupting the traditional whisky market, and France aims to establish itself as a major player in the industry. The French Whisky Federation oversees the production of these unique, Gallic-styled spirits, which will mature in barrels for at least three years before being released.

site_title: Australian PM holds emergency meeting as election rout looms
summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison held an emergency meeting with his embattled Liberal party as his minority government faces a heavy election defeat. A Newspoll showed the government on course to lose 21 seats, with support at 35%. Liberal and conservative elements clashed over policy, with some calling for a shift away from fossil fuels. Morrison faces a hostile parliament and Labor may seek a parliamentary vote to refer Home Affairs Minister Peter Dutton to the High Court over his eligibility.

site_title: Pro-China party's big win in Taiwan puts Tsai future in doubt
summary: Taiwan's pro-independence leader, Tsai Ing-wen, faces a significant challenge after her Democratic Progressive Party suffered a resounding loss in local elections, losing seven cities and counties. The Kuomintang, a China-friendly party, made a comeback, winning 48.8% of the vote. Tsai now has 14 months to regain public support before the presidential election in January 2020. Analysts suggest she should take a tougher stance on China and emphasize her party's liberal and progressive values to win back support.

site_title: Second needle incident in strawberries in New Zealand
summary: A needle has been found in a strawberry punnet sold in New Zealand's Geraldine town, the second incident in the country since a contamination crisis in Australia. The supermarket owner has removed strawberries from shelves as a precaution. A 50-year-old woman has been arrested in Australia and charged with contaminating goods in a related incident. The New Zealand Ministry for Primary Industries has not found any reason to believe this is more widespread. The person who found the needle was not harmed.

site_title: PNG upholds deal with Huawei to lay internet cable, derides counter-offer
summary: PNG upholds agreement with Huawei to build internet infrastructure, despite counter-offers from Australia, Japan, and the US. Papua New Guinea's minister for public enterprise and state investment, William Duma, stated that the country will honor its existing deal with Huawei, citing "honour and integrity". Huawei had won a tender to build a network in PNG two years ago, but Western countries expressed concerns over the company's ties to China's government, which they claim could be used for espionage.

site_title: Australia regulators watching non-banks for financial stability risks: RBA
summary: Australian regulators are monitoring non-bank lenders for potential financial stability risks, particularly in interest-only loans, which are considered high-risk by policymakers. According to Assistant Governor Christopher Kent, non-banks have been lending to borrowers who may not have obtained credit from banks without regulatory measures. This has raised concerns about the potential risks to financial stability.

site_title: Taiwan leader's 'separatist stance' cost election: Chinese media
summary: Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen's Democratic Progressive Party suffered a massive loss in the recent city and county seats vote, with the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) making gains. Chinese state-run media blamed Tsai's "separatist stance" on the party's defeat, calling for her to make an "about-face" on ties with the mainland. The Chinese government has increased pressure on Taiwan, considering it part of its territory to be reunified. The election outcome is seen as a setback for Tsai and her pro-independence policies, which have been criticized by Beijing as "secessionist" and "misguided".

site_title: Tencent-backed online travel agent jumps on Hong Kong debut
summary: Tongcheng-Elong Holdings Ltd, a Chinese online travel agent backed by Tencent Holdings, made its Hong Kong debut, with shares rising 10% above the IPO price, reaching HK$10.78 apiece. The company raised HK$1.25 billion to enhance product offerings and expand its user base. Tencent, the largest shareholder, saw its shares rise 1.6%. The Hong Kong Hang Seng index also climbed 1.3% following the broader market's rebound.

images.alt_text: Shares of Tongcheng-Elong Holdings Ltd, a Chinese online travel agent backed by tech giant Tencent Holdings, jump as much as 10 per cent above IPO (initial public offering) price on their trading debut, riding the broader market's rebound.

site_title: Elite Partners Capital buys 97 freehold UK offices for £282.15m
summary: Elite Partners Capital has acquired a portfolio of 97 freehold UK offices for £282.15m, marking the firm's first significant transaction in the UK real estate market. The Hayhill Portfolio, covering 2.6 million sq ft, is currently let to the UK government on 10-year leases with built-in rent uplifts. The acquisition offers low-risk, sustainable long-term yield with potential for capital gains through asset enhancements and conversion for alternate uses, according to the firm's CEO, Victor Song.

site_title: A long time ago in drawings far far away ...
summary: John Mollo, a British military illustrator and cinematic wardrobe consultant, won an Academy Award for Best Costume Design for George Lucas' "Star Wars" in 1978. Mollo's original sketchbooks for "Star Wars" and "The Empire Strikes Back" will be auctioned by Bonhams on Dec. 11, with estimated prices of $130,000 to $190,000 and $100,000 to $160,000, respectively. Mollo's designs for iconic characters, including Obi-Wan Kenobi, Han Solo, and Darth Vader, showcased his attention to detail and commitment to creating realistic costumes, despite Lucas' desire for them to be understated.

site_title: Campbell Soup nears deal with Third Point to end board challenge-sources
summary: Campbell Soup is nearing a deal with activist investor Third Point to end a bitter proxy contest. The hedge fund, led by Daniel Loeb, will add two of its nominees to the company's board, including a say in selecting the next CEO. In exchange, Third Point will refrain from running another proxy contest for a year and will have a seat on the board. The deal also includes Campbell Soup naming two of Third Point's nominees to the board, expanding the board to 15 members.

site_title: GM to close Canadian factory, putting 3000 jobs at risk: report
summary: General Motors is expected to announce the closure of a factory in Oshawa, Canada, putting approximately 3,000 jobs at risk. The decision is linked to the company's global restructuring plans, which also affect 50,000 employees across the US, Canada, and Mexico. The Oshawa plant, built in 1953, currently employs 2,800 people and assembles various GM models. The closure is not confirmed yet, but GM has previously announced plans to reduce its workforce across North America.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday afternoon at 3,077.55, up 0.8%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Straits Times Index up 25.06 points, or 0.8%, to 3,077.55. Gainers outnumbered losers 166 to 135, with 947 million shares worth S$376.6 million traded. Venture was the top gainer, up 4.89%, followed by Vallianz, which declined 10%. The rally came ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Malaysia to fully implement new biodiesel programme from February 2019
summary: Malaysia plans to implement a higher biodiesel mandate from February 2019, requiring 10% bio-content in biodiesel for the transportation sector. The new B10 biodiesel programme, starting with a phase-in from December, aims to bolster the palm oil industry. Petroleum companies have two months to transition from the current 7% bio-content. The move is part of efforts to reduce dependence on fossil fuels and promote sustainable energy sources.

site_title: 5.6-magnitude quake hits off western Taiwan
summary: A 5.6-magnitude earthquake struck off the western coast of Taiwan, approximately 100km off Pinghu island, at a depth of 13km. The quake was felt hundreds of kilometers away in Hong Kong. There were no immediate reports of casualties or damage, but local media reported people running outside in the city of Magong after feeling tremors. Taiwan lies near a tectonic plate junction, increasing its earthquake risk.

site_title: Ghosn faces Mitsubishi sack as more allegations surface
summary: Carlos Ghosn, chairman of Mitsubishi Motors, is set to be sacked over alleged financial misconduct, following Nissan's decision to oust him as chairman. Ghosn denies allegations of under-reporting his salary by $44 million over several years. Fellow executive Greg Kelly also denies the allegations. The board of Nissan made the decision based on evidence of misconduct, amid concerns Ghosn was working on a merger with Renault. Renault has decided to stick by Ghosn, but Nissan's CEO has expressed "great resentment and dismay" at the allegations.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks edge up at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.66% on Monday, edging up after two days of losses, driven by gains in energy firms despite another drop in oil prices. The Hang Seng Index reached 26,099.35, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.05%. Energy firms continued to suffer losses, while the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.18%.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index climbing 0.44% to 21,741.48, and the Topix index rising 0.07%. Investors looked beyond negative news such as declining oil prices and the US-led trade war, seeking fresh trading clues. The moves came despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions and tariff threats.

site_title: Singapore SMEs get a leg-up going digital with wholesale trade industry digital plan
summary: Singapore has launched a wholesale trade industry digital plan (IDP) to help small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) assess their digital readiness and opportunities to go digital. The plan, part of the SMEs Go Digital Programme, comprises a three-stage digital roadmap and training programs to enhance employees' digital skill sets. The goal is to help SMEs compete effectively in the global trading ecosystem, particularly in the seafood industry, where a new B2B e-marketplace is being established to streamline processes and improve operational efficiency.

site_title: Malaysia shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 2.84 points to 1,693.04 at 9am on Monday, opening lower. The index had 71 losers compared to 69 gainers. Volume reached 35.61 million lots worth RM14.63 million.

site_title: Oil prices edge up after nearly 8% 'Black Friday' plunge
summary: Oil prices rose 0.7% to US$59.20 per barrel, rebounding from a 8% drop on Friday, dubbed 'Black Friday'. The gains were limited by weak fundamentals, including a surge in supply and slowing demand growth. The US dollar's surge also weighed on oil prices. Analysts warn that the market is still under pressure, citing a downturn in wider financial markets and risks from the US-China trade conflict, with potential tariffs on Chinese imports by Q1 2019.

site_title: Singapore bonds face contagion fears from Lippo probe
summary: Singapore dollar-denominated bonds issued by First Real Estate Investment Trust (First Reit) and OUE Ltd have dropped amid concerns of a liquidity crunch and contagion from an investigation into troubled Indonesian property developer PT Lippo Karawaci, controlled by billionaire Riady family. The entities' bonds have sold off due to weakening credit profiles and concerns that various Lippo entities are making acquisitions to help out Lippo Karawaci. Lippo Karawaci has been under pressure due to a bribery inquiry and a cut by Fitch Ratings to CCC+ from BB-.

site_title: New Zealand retail sales flat in Q3, sparking sell-off in the local currency
summary: New Zealand's quarterly retail sales were flat in Q3, falling short of market expectations and pushing the local currency to a 12-day low. Retail sales volumes rose 2.7% annually but remained unchanged on the quarter. The New Zealand dollar fell to its lowest since mid-November. The result suggests a "lull" in consumer spending, with consumers holding off on buying food and motor vehicles, according to Statistics New Zealand. This may impact the country's central bank's growth outlook, which has been cautious despite recent strong economic data.

site_title: Storm strands US holiday travellers, more than 1,240 flights cancelled
summary: A blizzard in the Midwest, stretching from northeast Kansas to Chicago, stranded holiday travelers in the US, canceling over 1,240 flights. The storm brought winds of 48-56kmh and 15-30cm of snowfall, with "high impact" conditions expected in Kansas and Chicago. Chicago O'Hare and Midway airports saw 900 flights canceled, while Kansas City International Airport had nearly 200 flights canceled. The cancellations affected flights to and from the US, causing disruptions to holiday travel.

site_title: Cancer diagnostics firm Biolidics lodges prospectus for Catalist IPO
summary: Biolidics Limited, a cancer diagnostic solutions developer, lodged a preliminary prospectus for an initial public offering (IPO) on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board. The company, formerly known as Clearbridge Biomedics, specializes in developing cell enrichment systems for cancer diagnosis and has installed 80 systems globally. The IPO proceeds will be used to develop clinical applications and expand its product pipeline, with the remaining funds allocated for general corporate and working capital purposes. Details of the pricing, amount, and timing of the offering have not been announced.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Cityneon, LTC Corp
summary: Cityneon Holdings received a "fair and reasonable" cash offer of S$1.30 per share from independent financial adviser Novus Corporate Finance, with independent directors advised to recommend shareholders accept the offer unless a higher price is obtained on the open market. Meanwhile, LTC Corporation will proceed with voting on its proposed delisting after the Singapore Exchange confirmed it would be subject to existing voluntary delisting rules.

site_title: Ukraine accuses Russia of firing on, seizing three of its ships
summary: Ukraine's navy accused Russia of opening fire on and seizing three of its vessels in the Kerch Strait, near Moscow-annexed Crimea, on November 25, 2018. A Russian border guard vessel rammed a Ukrainian tugboat, damaging it, and then fired on one of its ships, injuring two Ukrainian soldiers. Russia claims Ukraine was "illegally entering" its waters and provoking a conflict, while Ukraine denies any wrongdoing and accuses Russia of escalating tensions.

site_title: A whole new ball game for Neo Group
summary: Neo Group's CEO, Neo Kah Kiat, is considering a spin-off for its DoDo fish ball unit and a potential listing for its Thong Siek unit. The company aims to grow its revenue to $1 billion by 2025 and is focusing on business-to-business (B2B) supply and business-to-consumer (B2C) offerings. Neo Group has been investing in new businesses, including acquisitions, with the goal of increasing profitability. The company is also planning to expand its food retail segment and is exploring opportunities for growth overseas.

site_title: May begins intensive campaign to sell Brexit deal at home
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May will convene her cabinet and update parliament on her Brexit deal, aiming to sell it to a skeptical country. The deal, sealed with EU leaders, prepares for Britain's exit on March 29, 2019, and sets out a partnership vision. May faces a battle to win MPs' approval, with opposition from her own party and governing allies, and warns that rejecting the deal would lead to division and uncertainty. She will embark on an intensive nationwide campaign to promote the plan ahead of a vote by lawmakers on or around December 12.

site_title: China heaps pressure on Taiwan president after election defeat
summary: China has intensified pressure on Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen after her pro-independence party suffered heavy defeats in local elections, with Beijing calling for cooperation with newly elected officials. Tsai resigned as DPP chairwoman after losing key battleground cities to the China-friendly Kuomintang, which now controls 15 cities. Beijing has refused to deal with Tsai's administration, considering Taiwan's formal independence a red line. Tsai vowed to maintain the status quo but defend Taiwan's security and democracy, while China's state media welcomed the Kuomintang's victory and urged the DPP to re-evaluate its stance.

site_title: Keppel units to build, operate data centre in Johor
summary: Keppel Corp's data centre units, Keppel Data Centres Holding and Alpha DC Fund Pte Ltd, have agreed to develop and operate a data centre in Johor, Malaysia with a 2020 completion date. The project will be undertaken by a special-purpose vehicle owned by Alpha DC Fund, with Keppel Data Centres holding a 70% stake. A customer has secured a 30-month lease, giving them the option to buy the data centre. The deal marks Keppel T&T's first data centre project with the customer and paves the way for future projects in Asia-Pacific and Europe.

site_title: Malaysia bets on durian as China goes bananas for world's smelliest fruit
summary: Malaysia is betting on durian as a major export, driven by unprecedented demand from China. The Southeast Asian nation is rushing to develop thousands of acres for large-scale durian farming, with the goal of a 50% jump in exports by 2030. Even property tycoons and palm oil companies are investing in the durian business, as the Malaysian government encourages the development of the fruit. The durian, known for its strong smell, is expected to become a significant export for Malaysia.

site_title: Goldman Sachs tightened risk oversight after 1MDB deal: FT
summary: Goldman Sachs was instructed by regulators to tighten its risk oversight and increase reporting on internal debates after completing a $6.5 billion bond financing deal for 1MDB, a Malaysian fund, in 2018. The changes were agreed upon in 2013 but not publicly disclosed. The New York Federal Reserve pressured Goldman to be more transparent, leading to the reforms. Goldman implemented changes to its internal committees, following pressure from the Fed.

site_title: Singapore malls take big gamble to outpace online shopping
summary: Singapore's malls are attempting to outpace online shopping by offering activities like yoga studios and food options, despite falling rents and rising vacancies. With online shopping penetration at 5.7% in 2017, the government is also considering a tax on e-commerce imports. Early signs suggest this strategy is driving up traffic, with some malls reporting 3.1% increase in visitors. However, actual shopping sales have fallen, and mall rents remain under pressure due to the influx of new retail space.

images.alt_text: With some of the nation's biggest mall operators reporting falling rents and rising vacancies, landlords, just like those elsewhere in Asia and the US, are being forced to reposition.

site_title: Australia: Shares down on weaker commodity prices, New Zealand lower
summary: Australian shares declined 0.4% on Monday, falling 22.9 points to 5,693.3, amid weaker commodity prices and global trade concerns. The decline followed a weaker lead from US stocks, which fell on Friday. The benchmark rose slightly on Friday. Weaker commodity prices weighed on heavyweight resource stocks, while a wider aversion to equity markets contributed to the decline.

site_title: IFA finds S$1.30/share cash offer for Cityneon 'fair and reasonable'
summary: Independent financial adviser Novus Corporate Finance has deemed the S$1.30/share cash offer for Cityneon Holdings as "fair and reasonable". The offer, launched by executive chairman and group CEO Ron Tan and Hong Kong entrepreneur Johnson Ko Chun Shun, aims to delist and take Cityneon private. Shareholders have until Dec 12, 2018 to accept the offer, which will be final and unconditional. The offer price is at a premium to the company's highest ever closing price, with the offeror citing greater control and management flexibility as key benefits.

site_title: Home 'most dangerous place' for women, UN study shows
summary: A new UN study reveals that over half of the women murdered worldwide in 2017 were killed by their intimate partners or family members, making home the most dangerous place for women. The study found that 58% of female homicide cases were committed by intimate partners or family members, with 34% of those being committed by intimate partners alone. The global rate of female homicide victims stands at 1.3 per 100,000 female population, with Africa and the Americas being the regions with the highest rates.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Monday; STI up 0.2% to 3,059.45
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Straits Times Index rising 6.96 points to 3,059.45. Venture Corporation led the gains, increasing 1.8% to S$14.99. Gainers outnumbered losers 65 to 62, with commodity and oil gas-related counters among the top traded stocks by volume.

site_title: India marks tenth anniversary of Mumbai terror attacks
summary: India marks the 10th anniversary of the 2008 Mumbai terror attacks, which left 166 people dead and hundreds injured. The attacks, carried out by Pakistan-based Lashkar-e-Taiba, targeted luxury hotels, a railway station, and other locations, including a Jewish center. The police force will hold a ceremony to remember the officers killed, while relatives of victims will lay wreaths at a memorial. The attacks, which lasted three days, were broadcast live on TV news channels worldwide, and Indian commandos ultimately retook control of the Taj Mahal Palace Hotel.

site_title: Concerns about fraud keeping elderly away from digital payments: study
summary: A study by Visa Singapore found that despite many elderly Singaporeans (ages 50-80) using smartphone apps, their usage of digital payments is low. By 2030, one in five residents will be aged 65 and above, raising concerns about digital inclusion in this demographic. The study highlights a need to address fraud concerns and improve digital payment security to encourage elderly individuals to adopt digital payments.

site_title: LTC Corp to convene adjourned EGM, vote on proposed delisting
summary: LTC Corp, a Singapore-based steel trading and property company, will convene an adjourned extraordinary general meeting (EGM) on Dec 11 to vote on its proposed delisting. The company received confirmation from the Singapore Exchange that its proposed delisting would be subject to existing voluntary delisting rules, rather than amended ones. The EGM will be held at 9:30am at the Swissotel Merchant Court. The closing date for the exit offer has been extended to Dec 27.

site_title: You face a stark choice - Britain's May warns lawmakers over Brexit
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May warned lawmakers that they face a choice between backing her Brexit deal, which would see Britain leaving the EU with close trade ties, or rejecting it and risking "more division and more uncertainty." The deal has been met with opposition from both her party and the opposition Labour Party, and May will ask parliament to back the deal to allow Britain to "move on." The EU has expressed little appetite to reopen negotiations if parliament votes it down, and May faces a tough task to win the necessary majority.

site_title: Russia space agency targeted over "stolen" billions
summary: Russia's space agency Roskosmos has been targeted by the country's audit court over financial irregularities, including "stolen" billions. The agency faces 151 irregularities totaling 785.5 billion rubles ($16.4 billion) and has been plagued by procurement issues, high prices, and unfinished projects. Roskosmos head Dmitry Rogozin has called for an anti-corruption plan, following a Soyuz rocket failure in October that forced a US-Russia cosmonaut to make an emergency landing. The agency's reputation has already been damaged by the rocket failure.

site_title: Australian government faces rout after Labor's big state poll win: Newspoll
summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison's Liberal National Coalition has lost support for a third consecutive poll, with a near-record low of 34% primary vote, down from 35% two weeks earlier. Labor has held steady at 40%, indicating a potential loss of 21 seats in the federal election in May. The result mirrors the unexpectedly large swing against the Coalition in Saturday's state election in Victoria, where Labor won a large majority. The Coalition's minority status has raised concerns, with the final two weeks of the year set to begin on Monday.

site_title: US shuts border post as migrants try to cross from Mexico
summary: US officials closed the San Ysidro border crossing in southern California after hundreds of migrants from a Central American caravan attempted to breach a fence from Mexico. The move came after President Donald Trump threatened to close the border if control was lost or people got hurt. Migrants, including women and children, tried to cross the border, with some making it over a first barrier and others turning back as US border officers fired tear gas. The incident occurred amid concerns over the safety of migrants and amid a reported asylum deal between the US and Mexico.

site_title: Hong Kong democrats lose in key vote
summary: Hong Kong's democracy camp suffered a significant setback in a key by-election, losing the Kowloon West seat to a pro-establishment candidate. The result further erodes the democratic movement's representation in the legislature, leaving them with 26 seats out of 70. The loss is seen as a blow to Hong Kong's rights, which are protected by a pre-1997 agreement, as the city's pro-Beijing establishment continues to consolidate its power. The democratic camp had been struggling to regain ground after six lawmakers were disqualified in 2016.

site_title: UK watchdog to probe China state media over role in 'confession'
summary: A British fraud investigator, Peter Humphrey, has asked the UK's media regulator Ofcom to revoke China Central Television's (CCTV) broadcast license for allegedly helping stage his forced confession and jailing in China. Humphrey claims CCTV journalists cooperated with police to extract and broadcast his confession, which he was allegedly drugged and coerced into making. This is the first legal action against Chinese entities involved in his incarceration, with Humphrey stating it will not be the last. Ofcom is assessing the complaint as a priority and may fine or revoke CCTV's license if rules are found to have been broken.

site_title: F1: Renault and Red Bull go their separate ways
summary: Red Bull and Renault, a Formula One partnership that won eight world championships, ended on Sunday in Abu Dhabi. The partnership, marked by a lack of power and reliability, led to verbal sparring between team leaders Cyril Abiteboul and Christian Horner. Red Bull will partner with Honda next season, while Renault will focus on its own factory team and clients, including McLaren. Renault will also take Australian driver Daniel Ricciardo with them. The partnership, which achieved 59 wins and 160 podiums, will be remembered for its outstanding results despite its challenges.

site_title: GIC, Australian Reit set up A$2b JV to invest in logistics properties Down Under
summary: Singapore sovereign wealth fund GIC and Australian Reit Dexus have established a joint venture, Dexus Australian Logistics Trust, to invest in logistics properties Down Under with an initial A$2 billion investment. GIC will hold 25% in the core portfolio and 49% in the seed development portfolio, with the option to acquire an additional 24% by June 2020.

images.alt_text: GIC and Australian Reit Dexus have established a joint venture (JV) known as Dexus Australian Logistics Trust - a new A$2 billion (S$1.99 billion) unlisted trust - to invest in logistics properties Down Under.

site_title: Reaching the unbanked, underbanked, and unhappily banked
summary: Fintech has the potential to improve financial inclusion, but its success depends on collaboration and responsible approach. If not done right, fintech can exclude certain demographics, such as the unbanked, older technology users, and those with limited financial literacy. Fintech companies must prioritize accessibility, education, and ethics to ensure that their solutions are inclusive and beneficial to all users. Governments and financial institutions must also work together to create a supportive infrastructure and provide access to financial services for underserved populations, including women, SMEs, and rural communities.

site_title: S$20m in buybacks; Macquarie acquires 5% of Geo Energy
summary: Macquarie acquired 5% of Geo Energy Resources through a S$20.3 million share subscription, completing the deal on Nov 21. This acquisition marks Macquarie's direct interest in the company. Geo Energy Resources entered into a coal offtake agreement with Macquarie for life of mine coal production from PT Tanah Bumbu Resources. The deal is expected to supply 43.23 million tonnes of coal to Macquarie over six years.

site_title: Newly-minted en bloc millionaires offer rich pickings for banks
summary: Banks in Singapore are targeting newly-minted millionaires from en bloc sales, with 11 UOB bankers visiting a Dunearn Gardens resident to collect cheques from a S$468 million sale. This year's en bloc sales total S$10 billion, with payouts averaging S$3.4 million per unit, compared to S$2.5 million in 2017. Banks are offering preferential interest rates and referral rewards to attract these clients, with UOB offering a 1.75% interest rate and S$1,000 for new customers who keep S$2 million in the bank for four months.

site_title: Dodging traffic, and death, on Manila's railway carts
summary: In Manila, thousands of commuters use makeshift pushcarts to navigate the city's notorious traffic, dodging trains and risking injury or death in the process. The carts, operated by "trolley boys," charge 10 pesos (26 Singapore cents) per trip and allow passengers to bypass hours-long traffic congestion. Despite the dangers, casualties are rare, and commuters praise the service for its convenience and affordability. The carts have become a tolerated, if unofficial, part of Manila's public transportation system, with many users relying on them to get to work or school.

site_title: India wants to discuss governance issues with RBI
summary: India's government plans to discuss changes to the Reserve Bank of India's (RBI) governance structure at a board meeting on December 14, including setting up oversight panels. The administration seeks to plug budget gaps and increase interim dividends from the central bank. Tensions between the finance ministry and RBI are ongoing, with disagreements over issues like surplus funds, bad-loan rules, and shadow-banking sector liquidity. The proposed changes aim to improve banking supervision and financial conditions, but may further strain relations between the two sides.

site_title: Money FM podcast: The Hot Seat: An exclusive interview with DBS CEO Piyush Gupta
summary: DBS CEO Piyush Gupta shares his thoughts on the bank's 50th anniversary and its latest results in an exclusive interview. Gupta highlights DBS' standout achievements and discusses the bank's hopes for the next 50 years. The interview also touches on the bank's strategy and future plans. Gupta's comments come as DBS continues to expand its operations globally.

site_title: US$/S$ extends upward movement
summary: The US dollar (USD) has extended its upward movement against the Singapore dollar (S$) in 2018, despite the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) increasing the slope of the S$ Nominal Effective Exchange Rate (S$NEER) twice to allow for appreciation. The USD/S$ has rallied to a year-high of 1.3870 in October and is expected to continue its upward trend, with technical analysis indicating a potential continuation pattern and strong support levels at 1.3660 and 1.4000.

site_title: All eyes on G-20 this week as Xi, Trump meet
summary: G-20 leaders, including China's Xi Jinping and US President Donald Trump, will meet in Buenos Aires, Argentina from Nov 30 to Dec 1, amid uncertainty over a potential trade deal between the two nations. The Apec summit's lack of a joint communique has raised concerns, but analysts believe the G-20 summit offers an opportunity for China and the US to break a negative spiral in financial markets. Market sentiment is expected to be dominated by the G-20 event, with investors watching for developments in US-China trade talks.

site_title: Brexit limps towards a conclusion
summary: The UK appears to have negotiated a Brexit deal with the EU, settling terms for leaving the union by March 2019. However, the deal's significance is diminished by the Prime Minister's lack of credit and the involvement of unelected aides, raising questions about accountability. The deal includes a proposed customs union for the UK, pending resolution of the Irish border issue, which remains a contentious point. The agreement has been met with criticism, with some accusing the UK of being anti-immigrant and racist, despite its historical openness to people from around the world.

The law, introduced by the British in 1861, had carried jail terms of up to 10 years and was used to harass the gay community. India is now one of over 120 countries to have effectively decriminalized homosexuality, marking a significant step towards social acceptance.

SIA will hold about 70% stake, while Sats and DFASS will hold about 15% each. KrisShop aims to offer inflight and ground-based duty-free and duty-paid goods, as well as mail order and pre-order services. The investment will be completed on November 30, with KrisShop paying S$27.5 million for DFASS's business transfer.

site_title: Reits
summary: US President Trump has imposed a 50% copper import tariff, affecting refined metal. In real estate news, Good Class Bungalow prices are being reevaluated, and the Q3 condo launch wave may test demand for prime projects above S$3,000 psf. US mortgage rates have risen after five weeks of decline, while Manhattan rents reached a record high. Goldman Sachs acquired a large hotel and retail portfolio in Seoul, and UK homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high. New World Group is selling China property assets following a loan deal.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Acromec, a specialist engineering firm, expects to report losses for fiscal 2018 due to additional construction costs for a pharmaceutical plant in Tuas. Keppel Corporation will sell two Thai-based firms for S$6.9 million, expecting a small gain. Aspen Group's unit has terminated an agreement with a buyer in Penang, Malaysia, after non-payment of sale terms.

site_title: Oil falls to lowest since late 2017 on growing glut; Opec expected to cut supply
summary: Oil prices plummeted to their lowest since late 2017 due to a growing supply glut and a weakening global economic outlook. International benchmark Brent crude fell to $61.52 per barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures slid 2.3% to $53.38 a barrel. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) is expected to cut supply in December to counter the oversupply, potentially supporting oil prices in the high-$50s.

site_title: Lies, damn lies and post-truth
summary: US President Donald Trump has told 6,420 lies during his presidency, according to The Washington Post. However, the author argues that this doesn't change the fact that Trump's lies are unique in their strategic purpose, serving a proto-authoritarian ideology rather than just trying to deceive. This "post-truth" approach, defined by the Oxford English Dictionaries as circumstances where objective facts are less influential than emotions and personal belief, is seen as a precursor to fascism and authoritarianism, with Trump's actions aligning with the playbook of leaders like Vladimir Putin and Recep Tayyip Erdogan.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall for second week, growth and trade worries linger
summary: European shares fell for the second week, despite a 0.4% gain for the STOXX 600, as concerns over slowing global growth, weak earnings, and the US-China trade war drove investors away. Italy's FTSE MIB rose 0.6% led by rebounding banks and technology stocks. Data showed weak business activity and Germany's economy contracted in Q3, prompting a scaling back of ECB rate-hike expectations. The European oil and gas index sank 2.9% to April lows, while airlines benefited from the sell-off.

site_title: Chaswood Resources to sell F&B businesses in Malaysia as part of restructuring exercise
summary: Chaswood Resources Holdings is selling its Malaysian food and beverage businesses, TGI Friday's and Teh Tarik Place, to Sino Hua-An International for RM8 million (S$2.6 million). The sale is part of the company's restructuring efforts to repay outstanding loans and creditors. The subsidiaries recorded significant losses, and the sale is expected to result in a loss of RM18.4 million for Chaswood Resources. The proceeds will be used to repay group loans and trade creditors.

site_title: Nasdaq-listed oncology firm launches regional HQ in Singapore
summary: Guardant Health, a Nasdaq-listed oncology firm, has launched its Asia, Middle East and Africa (AMEA) regional headquarters in Singapore. The move expands its distributorships in key markets, including Southeast Asia, Hong Kong, New Zealand, and Israel. Guardant Health offers liquid biopsy tests and big data analytics to help medical professionals determine effective therapies for advanced-stage cancer patients with solid tumors.

site_title: Taking shelter from a potential negative convergence
summary: Investors may consider reducing exposure to US equities amid a potential negative convergence with the rest of the world. A year ago, a "goldilocks" economic growth period was expected, but growth has decelerated and earnings growth has declined. The US economy's tax cuts are expected to expire, leading to a deceleration in earnings growth. With US equities trading at a relatively low price-to-earnings ratio, investors may consider shifting to fixed income, such as US Treasuries or short duration bond funds, to preserve capital and avoid potential losses.

site_title: Crypto losses near US$700b in worst week since January peak
summary: Cryptocurrency markets have experienced their worst week since January, with Bitcoin sinking towards $4,000 and most peers tumbling 23% since November 16. The Bloomberg Galaxy Crypto Index has declined by nearly $700 billion, with many investors losing 70% or more of their value. Despite concerns about regulatory scrutiny, community infighting, and exchange issues, experts see little evidence of a market bottom, with some predicting a potential collapse to $3,000 or lower.

site_title: BRC Asia posts S$12m full-year profit on Lee Metal acquisition
summary: BRC Asia reported a full-year net profit of S$12 million, a significant increase from S$1.81 million in the same period last year, following the completion of its acquisition of Lee Metal in July 2018. Revenue rose 83% to S$567 million, driven by increased steel sales tonnage and higher steel prices. However, the company warned of subdued profit margins due to a "mixed picture" for the reinforcing steel industry, citing government property curbs and a decline in public sector residential supply.

site_title: American millennials' loneliness sets the table for 'Friendsgiving'
summary: American millennials are increasingly turning to "Friendsgiving" as a way to celebrate Thanksgiving without being alone. This trend, which began as a marketing campaign in 2011, has gained popularity as urbanites with childless households and delayed marriage and parenthood seek alternative forms of community and connection. According to a recent survey, Gen Z and millennials report higher rates of loneliness despite being connected online. Friendsgiving has become a way for young people to fill the void left by smaller households and delayed family formation, with many gathering with friends for a potluck-style meal.

images.alt_text: Friendsgiving has its roots in the reality TV show, The Real Housewives of New Jersey (the cast, above). This practice among unattached individuals or childless couples has since seeped into the cultural zeitgeist.

site_title: Fitbit's Versa-tile fitness tracker
summary: The Fitbit Versa, a premium fitness tracker, retains the hallmarks that made the Pebble great, including a simple and sleek design, long battery life, and high readability in sunlight. It offers a wide range of colors and strap options, a high-resolution color screen, and can track various exercises, heart rate, and blood oxygen content. The watch also features a virtual coach and an app store with a limited but useful selection of apps. While it lacks GPS and has a small screen, its strong battery life and focus on workout tracking make it a standout in the market.

site_title: Slump in Singapore vehicle sales to worsen in 2019
summary: Singapore's vehicle sales are expected to contract sharply in 2019 and 2021 due to macro factors weighing on consumer sentiment, including slowing economic growth, rising interest rates, and imported inflation. A report by Fitch Solutions forecasts a 20.1% decline in new vehicle registrations in 2019, followed by a 25.4% annual average contraction over 2020-2021. The market is expected to bottom out at around 46,000 units, less than half of the 2017 peak, as ride-sharing demand slows down following Uber's sale of its South-east Asia business unit to Grab.

site_title: Why Singapore's office sector continues to draw investors
summary: Singapore's office sector continues to attract investors, with Grade A office capital values recovering by over 20% since 2017. Record pricings were set in 2018, with units selling at up to S$2,602 psf. Investors are optimistic due to the sector's promising prospects for steady growth, driven by a low pipeline supply of new developments. While some forecast slower demand, redevelopment activities and the government's land sales program are expected to rebalance supply with demand, paving the way for steady and sustainable growth.

site_title: Laguna National provides boost to SGA's Rookie Pro Programme
summary: The Singapore Golf Association's Rookie Professional Programme has received a boost from Laguna National, a golf course in Singapore. The programme, launched in mid-2020, aims to help elite amateur golfers transition into the professional ranks. With the 2020 Tokyo Olympics in mind, the partnership will provide additional support and resources for the programme's participants. This collaboration is seen as a significant development for the golf association and the country's golfing community.

site_title: Civil servants to get year-end bonus of one month's salary
summary: Singapore civil servants will receive a year-end annual variable component (AVC) bonus of one month's salary, totaling 1.5 months of pay, to be paid in December. Additionally, they will receive a non-pensionable annual allowance of one month. This bonus is part of the government's annual compensation package.

site_title: Financial system stable but global risks increasing: MAS
summary: Singapore's financial stability remains sound, with corporate debt profiles and household borrowing remaining stable. However, rising interest rates and global trade tensions pose risks to global financial stability, potentially weakening the ability of sovereigns, corporates, and households to service debt, particularly those with foreign currency debt. The Monetary Authority of Singapore advised firms to stay cautious of external headwinds and households to monitor their debt servicing abilities amid interest rate hikes.

site_title: Keppel Corp units divest stakes in two Thai property-related firms for S$6.9m
summary: Keppel Corp will sell its 49% stakes in two Thai property firms, KPN-Keppel Alliance and KPN-Keppel Alliance, for S$6.9 million. The divestment is expected to result in a small gain for Keppel Corp. Shares closed at S$6.16 on the day of the announcement.

site_title: Tried & tested
summary: Cobra Golf's F9 driver features a 3% thinner and 10% lighter face, thanks to CNC milling technology. This innovation builds on the company's previous F7 model, which also utilized precision milling. The F9's design aims to enhance performance and reduce weight, allowing for improved distance and control.

site_title: MAS taps unconventional data to monitor crypto market
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is monitoring the cryptocurrency market using non-traditional data sources, such as blockchain ledgers and digital token trading platform APIs, to detect potential risks to financial stability. Despite current low levels of trading activity, MAS is keeping a close eye on potential wealth effects and regulatory implications. The central bank found that the wealth effects from a decline in households' holdings of cryptocurrencies are currently small, with estimated monthly trading volumes of less than 1% of the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Catching a falling knife
summary: Investors may view Asian equities as a "falling knife" due to the perfect storm of a looming trade war, US dollar strength, and rising interest rates. The MSCI Asia ex-Japan index has dropped 16% this year, with China's CSI300 Index falling 17.5%. Economic growth is slowing globally, and US rate hikes threaten to further impact Asian economies. However, Asian economies are also expected to drive dollar asset diversification, and investors may see opportunities for growth in the region. Despite challenges, the outlook is not as bleak as initially feared.

site_title: STI up 0.4% despite thin trading volume
summary: The Straits Times Index rose 11.11 points, or 0.4%, to 3,052.49, despite thin trading volume due to US market closures for Thanksgiving. Gainers outnumbered losers 196 to 175, with Singapore Airlines and Singtel contributing to the gain. Banking stocks also rebounded after a previous day's loss, while Chinese shares led the decline in Asia.

site_title: Hyflux says it hasn't finalised terms of debt revamp after some lenders reject first draft proposal
summary: Hyflux, a Singaporean water project developer, has not finalized terms of its debt revamp plan after some lenders rejected its initial proposal. The company needs up to two months to sound out all stakeholders before presenting a restructuring plan to creditors. The plan, previously discussed with senior unsecured creditors and medium-term note holders, has been rejected due to concerns over the management team's implied equity value of S$20 million. Hyflux will engage in a consultative process to formulate a final proposal, with a court-sanctioned scheme of arrangement aimed for April next year.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Q&M Dental Group's Q3 earnings were slightly below expectations due to a slowdown in local dental demand. The company's core PATMI was in line with estimates, but associates' contribution declined 26.5% y-o-y. Q&M has focused on organic initiatives, such as hiring dentists with scholarships, rather than acquisitions. As a result, the company lowered its FY18-19F EPS and target price to S$0.47, reaffirming its "reduce" call.

site_title: Sime Darby Plantation posts 89% fall in Q1 profit
summary: Sime Darby Plantation Berhad, the world's largest oil palm planter, reported a 89% decline in Q1 profit to RM115 million due to lower palm prices and reduced margins. Revenue declined 14% to RM3.04 billion, primarily affected by a decline in crude palm oil and palm kernel prices. The company expects CPO prices to remain under pressure due to seasonal production rise, higher inventories, and sluggish export demand.

site_title: French wine market to shrink further, but organics surge: report
summary: French wine sales are expected to decline further, with 208 million cases forecast for 2022, down from 241 million in 2012. However, organic wine sales are on the rise, doubling between now and 2022 to 17.3 million cases, with sales of organic wines commanding higher prices. Organic wine revenues are projected to exceed €1 billion annually by 2022, driven by a growing global demand for organic products, with France setting the pace for growth.

site_title: Finding your way through market volatilities
summary: During times of market volatility, investors often overreact and sell off their investments, missing out on potential gains. To successfully navigate these uncertainties, investors should follow key pillars: investing for the long term, avoiding impulsive decisions, diversifying portfolios, and rebalancing regularly. A long-term investment approach can lead to better returns, as historical data shows that equity returns over 10-year periods range from -2% to 18% per annum. Regular rebalancing can also help reduce risk by selling overvalued assets and acquiring undervalued ones, making it essential to adopt a systematic approach to managing investment portfolios.

site_title: Picking through stock exchange dividends
summary: Stock exchanges, rather than individual shares, may be attractive investment options due to their stability and potential for steady returns. Over the last decade, many exchanges have delivered attractive total returns, with some generating profits of nearly 20% per year. Exchanges like the Singapore Exchange, Hong Kong Exchange, and Intercontinental Exchange have achieved high returns, often driven by dividend payouts. While dividend yields vary, most exchanges pay dividends, and those with high yields may be due for a correction. The key factor is not just the yield but also the company's ability to sustainably distribute dividends.

site_title: Ace Achieve suspends trading, says it's unable to assess financial position
summary: Ace Achieve Infocom suspended trading of its shares due to an inability to assess its financial position. The company, which had announced plans to acquire a 36% stake in a blockchain business, will now release its unaudited results for the full year ended April 30, 2018, and resume trading "in due course." The company had also taken a US$500,000 loan to complete its audit and convene its shareholders' meeting. Two independent directors quit in August, citing delays in the audit and lack of information from management.

site_title: AGV Group warns of full-year loss
summary: AGV Group, a galvanised steel and metal repair company, warned of a full-year loss for the 12 months ended Sept 30, 2018, due to increased raw material costs and reduced services tonnage. The company is expected to release its results on Nov 30, 2018.

site_title: UK Black Friday sales down year-on-year, data shows
summary: UK Black Friday sales declined year-on-year, with Barclaycard data showing a 12% drop in spending despite a 15% increase in transaction volume. Consumers opted for smaller, less expensive purchases, with retailers hoping for stronger sales at the start of the Christmas shopping season. The event was marred by concerns over cyber-crime, with the National Cyber Security Centre warning shoppers to be cautious. The decline in sales is a blow to retailers struggling with subdued consumer spending, rising costs, and Brexit uncertainty.

site_title: Ready... Get set... Motivate!
summary: A business owner struggles to motivate their staff, despite paying them well. Research shows that money is not the best motivator, and instead, employees are driven by people, not companies. To motivate employees, one must devote time to nurturing and guarding them, behave as though they are people first, and show kindness. Video calls and regular communication can be effective, even for remote teams. The author suggests using experiential and participative training methods, recognizing employees' individuality, and setting a positive example as a leader.

site_title: Acromec makes loss guidance for FY2018
summary: Acromec, a specialist engineering firm, has released loss guidance for FY2018, citing additional construction costs for a pharmaceutical plant in Tuas as the main reason. The loss is expected during the 12 months ended Sept 30, 2018.

site_title: Foyth steps forward as Spurs unearth latest gem
summary: Tottenham Hotspur is set to face an undefeated Chelsea in a crucial English Premier League (EPL) match, with 20-year-old Argentine defender Juan Foyth potentially starting in place of injured Jan Vertonghen. Foyth's recent breakthrough in the League Cup and his debut for Argentina demonstrate Tottenham manager Mauricio Pochettino's ability to unearth gems. A win against Chelsea could propel Spurs into third place, while Chelsea, led by Eden Hazard, remain a contender despite being unbeaten in 12 games.

images.alt_text: If selected against Chelsea, Foyth will face a stern test against a Blues side who have made a mockery of a so-called two-horse EPL title race between champions Manchester City and Liverpool.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 0.26 points to 1,695.88, closing higher on Friday with 1.6 billion lots traded worth RM1.1 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 597 to 236.

site_title: Impact of frequency and intensity of exercise on health
summary: The US Department of Health and Human Services' 2018 Physical Activity Guidelines recommend at least 150-300 minutes of moderate-intensity exercise or 75-150 minutes of vigorous-intensity aerobic physical activity per week for adults to reduce risks of heart disease, stroke, and Type 2 diabetes. Exceeding these thresholds can confer additional benefits without apparent health risk. Regular exercise also reduces blood pressure, improves cognition, and has a positive impact on brain health, with a 14% reduction in heart artery disease risk and a 40% reduction in stroke and heart attack deaths.

site_title: London home price cuts seep outwards as sellers get real amid Brexit worries
summary: London home prices are declining, with discounts creeping outwards from the city center as sellers become more realistic amid Brexit uncertainty. The percentage of sellers cutting asking prices rose in 32 of 33 boroughs, with Merton topping the list at 46.4%. The largest average price cut was in Kensington and Chelsea, at 8.2%. London home prices have risen 66% in a decade, making it now cost buyers 14.5 times their annual gross salary to purchase a property, the highest level on record. Home sales in the capital have fallen to record lows.

site_title: Trump calls for wall funding after claiming he's closed border
summary: President Donald Trump called on lawmakers to fund his proposed wall along the US-Mexico border, following a claim he'd closed parts of it. Trump tweeted that Republicans and Democrats must work together on a Border Security package, which would include wall funding. This comes after the president said he'd ordered the closure of the US-Mexican border and authorized US troops to use lethal force against migrants. Trump's deployment of troops was criticized as a political stunt before the midterm elections.

site_title: Jason Marine's financial controller leaves
summary: Jason Marine Group announced that its financial controller, Esabelle Saw Hong Gaik, has left to pursue new opportunities. The company will appoint Derrick Chan Kwok Yuan, senior finance manager, as financial controller, effective November 26. Additionally, Ong Bee Choo will be appointed as joint company secretary, also taking effect on November 26.

site_title: UK faces 'more division' if Brexit deal fails: May
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May warned that Britain will face "more division and more uncertainty" if a draft Brexit deal fails, ahead of an EU summit this weekend. May, who voted to stay in the EU in 2016, refused to say whether she would resign if the deal is rejected by parliament, instead focusing on explaining the agreement to the public. She dismissed calls for a second EU referendum and emphasized the need to build a "better future" outside the bloc, while reaffirming British sovereignty over Gibraltar.

site_title: Business groups positive as Heng looks set to be fourth PM
summary: Singapore's Heng Swee Keat, the current Finance Minister, is set to become the country's fourth prime minister after the next general election. Heng, 57, has been elected as the party's first assistant secretary-general and is expected to become deputy prime minister alongside Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing. Heng, who has made a full recovery from a major stroke in 2016, has the backing of a strong team and is seen as responsive to businesses' concerns. Business groups welcomed the news, citing his experience and ability to maintain a stable and prosperous environment for businesses to thrive.

site_title: It's not shopping, it's buying an 'experience'
summary: Malls in Asia are shifting from traditional shopping experiences to immersive aesthetic experiences, prioritizing content over contents. Projects like Shanghai Village, COEX Mall library, T Galleria, and Victoria Dockside in Hong Kong, are creating unique environments that combine shopping with art, culture, and entertainment. Experts believe this approach will become a new standard for global retail, focusing on building brand equity through service and touch, rather than just selling products. This shift is driven by millennial consumers who prefer experiences over material goods, and is seen as a key factor in the rise of the experience economy.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore: Heng Swee Keat, a key figure in the ruling People's Action Party (PAP), was appointed as the party's first assistant secretary-general. This move is seen as a likely stepping stone for him to succeed Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. Meanwhile, Singapore's financial stability is sound, but global risks, including rising interest rates and currency pressure, pose a threat. The country's vehicle sales are expected to worsen, with Fitch predicting a 20.1% contraction in 2019.

site_title: EU steps up preparations for euro clearing in 'no deal' Brexit
summary: The European Union has begun preparations to ensure euro clearing in the event of a "no deal" Brexit. Regulators, including the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA), will temporarily recognize British clearing houses to continue clearing derivatives trades for EU customers. This move aims to minimize disruption to trillions of euros in cross-border transactions. The plans follow a meeting between Britain and the EU to endorse a divorce deal, which includes a transition period until the end of 2020.

site_title: US: Wall Street slips at open as oil prices hit year low
summary: US stocks fell at open on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 128.29 points, or 0.52%, to 24,336.40. Energy stocks took a hit from oil prices sliding to their lowest in over a year. Investors were cautious ahead of US-China trade talks at the G20 summit.
