The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also fell, with the S&P 500 down 16.57 points, or 0.63%, to 2,633.36, and the Nasdaq down 52.74 points, or 0.76%, to 6,919.52.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher on Friday
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.4% to 3,052.49 on Friday, with the Straits Times Index increasing 11.11 points. Gainers outnumbered losers 196 to 175, with shares worth S$530.9 million changing hands. Vallianz led gains, rising 42.9%, followed by United Engineers and OCBC.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell on Friday, following an Asia-wide sell-off due to growing fears over the global economy. The Hang Seng Index dropped 0.35%, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 2.49%. The Shenzhen Composite Index also declined 3.66%. These losses come as investors remain cautious amid concerns over global economic uncertainty.

site_title: Value, cost of target assets in TSH reverse takeover raised to S$19.4m
summary: TSH Corp has raised the consideration for assets in a reverse takeover to S$19.4 million following an independent valuation. The deal involves acquiring Sloshed!, a pub operator, in exchange for TSH shares giving Sloshed!'s owners a majority stake. The consideration was initially set at S$18.8 million and will now issue about 646.7 million new TSH shares to the sellers. The deal also includes waiving shareholder loans totaling S$1.45 million and S$265,492. The acquisition aims to give TSH an operational and income-generating business with growth prospects.

site_title: Raffles Infrastructure special audit hits snag with 'lack of cooperation' from Chinese unit
summary: Raffles Infrastructure's special audit has hit a snag due to a lack of cooperation from its Chinese unit, Sinwa Knitting & Dyeing. The audit, which began on Oct 1, is investigating compensation claims of S$159 million by three customers of China Fibretech, a former S-chip of Raffles Infrastructure. The audit team from KPMG was unable to complete its tasks due to the lack of cooperation, and Raffles Infrastructure is working with professionals to ensure the audit is completed on time. The audit's outcome will impact the resumption of trading of Raffles Infrastructure's shares.

site_title: Britain's opposition Labour Party plots overthrow of capitalism
summary: The British Labour Party, under Jeremy Corbyn's leadership, is plotting to overthrow capitalism and build a socialist society. Finance minister John McDonnell has outlined a radical economic agenda, including sweeping nationalisation, higher public spending, and an overhaul of the banking system. His plans include forcing large companies to hand over a tenth of their equity to their workforce and increasing taxes on businesses and the wealthy. With the Conservative Party's grip on power looking vulnerable, Labour is confident it will win the next election and become the next guardians of the world's fifth-largest economy.

site_title: Porsche has a plan to drive up profit by 6b euros
summary: Porsche AG aims to boost operating profit by 6 billion euros over eight years through cost-cutting and efficiency gains, necessary to maintain Volkswagen's target of a 15% return on sales. The company is investing heavily in electric cars, with over 6 billion euros spent by 2022, and expects half of deliveries to be fully-electric or hybrid by 2025. This push for efficiency is driven by the need to offset lower profits from electric cars and meet the Paris Climate accord's goals, which make combustion engine vehicles economically unviable by 2030.

site_title: Australia shares close higher on banks, energy; NZ flat
summary: Australian shares rose 0.44% on Friday, driven by gains in banks and energy stocks, despite a decline in broader Asian shares. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 5,716.20, with Westpac and Commonwealth Bank adding 1.4% and 1%, respectively. Energy stocks rose 0.5% despite a fall in oil prices, while healthcare stocks fell 0.7%. The Australian dollar eased, and New Zealand's benchmark index was nearly flat.

site_title: Startups in JLL and Lendlease's proptech accelerator in talks to put solutions to use
summary: The Propell Asia proptech accelerator programme has concluded, with its five participating startups now working with industry leaders JLL and Lendlease to implement their products and solutions. GorillaSpace and Talox are in talks to incorporate their products into Lendlease's Paya Lebar Quarter mixed-use development, while the startups are also finalizing seed investments and expanding regionally. The accelerator programme allowed the startups to test their solutions in Singapore malls, with successful trials conducted at 313@Somerset and Jem malls. Future editions of the programme are planned.

images.alt_text: JLL Asia Pacific's chief operating officer Albert Ovidi says: "Future editions of the Propell Asia accelerator programme are currently in the works."

site_title: China confirms first swine fever cases in Beijing
summary: China's agriculture ministry confirmed the first cases of African swine fever in Beijing, with 86 pigs dying on two farms in the Fangshan District. The disease has spread across 20 provinces, with 73 cases reported, and 600,000 pigs culled since its detection in August. The ministry attributed the spread to backward farming methods, hygiene issues, and long-distance pig transportation. The disease has caused a spike in pork prices and raised concerns about its potential impact on the global pork market.

site_title: Europe: Italian stocks lead Europe in recovery driven by banks, technology
summary: European shares rose modestly at the end of a volatile week, driven by gains in Italian banks and technology stocks. Italian banks climbed 2% after a report that EU Affairs Minister Paolo Savona is considering resigning, boosting lenders with large sovereign bond portfolios. Renault shares rose 3.2% after CEO Carlos Ghosn's arrest, and Ericsson shares gained 2.1% following a Wall Street Journal report on Huawei. Despite earnings disappointments, small-cap stocks like Flybe surged 19% after a potential acquisition by Virgin Atlantic.

site_title: Heng Swee Keat is PAP's first assistant secretary-general; most likely to be next PM
summary: Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat, 57, has been appointed as the first assistant secretary-general of the ruling People's Action Party (PAP), making him the most likely candidate to succeed Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. Heng, who made a miraculous recovery from a stroke in 2016, is seen as the front-runner for the top leadership position, with Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing as second assistant secretary-general. The appointments follow a biennial election by the party's Central Executive Committee, which had listed Heng and Chan as top choices for the party leadership.

site_title: Nasdaq-listed oncology firm launches regional HQ in S'pore
summary: Guardant Health, a precision oncology firm, has launched its Asia, Middle East and Africa regional headquarters in Singapore. The move aims to capitalize on the growing market in Asia, where half of the world's cancer incidence and mortality occur. Guardant Health's flagship product, Guardant360, has been ordered over 70,000 times and has been reviewed by 80 peer-reviewed publications. The company is expanding its presence in key markets and is collaborating with local partners to generate data on Asian patient populations.

site_title: Aspen unit ends deal with land buyer on payment default
summary: Aspen Group's unit has ended an agreement with land buyer Pendang Pembangunan (PPSB) in Penang, Malaysia, due to PPSB's failure to make payments. The agreement, signed in 2017, was for a petrol station and drive-through restaurant on a piece of land owned by Aspen. The company has exercised its right to forfeiture, terminating the deal. This follows PPSB's neglect to fully perform payment obligations under the purchase and development agreement.

site_title: India to give 5% subsidy for non-basmati rice exports
summary: India's government will provide a 5% subsidy for non-basmati rice exports for four months to March 25, 2019, to boost flagging overseas sales. This move aims to accelerate exports and keep local prices steady, following a 9.6% decline in non-basmati rice exports to 5.8 million tonnes in the first six months of the financial year. The subsidy is expected to help India's rice exporters, particularly in the face of reduced purchases from top buyer Bangladesh due to a bumper harvest.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks decline tracking Chinese markets; won slips
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index declined 0.60% on Friday, tracking Chinese markets, and fell 1.7% for the week. The won slipped, weakening 0.11% against the US dollar, while bond yields declined. Shares exposed to North Korea surged, with Busan Industrial jumping 17.1%, amid unification talks with the US. The won's decline marked the third consecutive week of losses, with the Kospi down 16.1% this year and 2.80% in the previous 30 days.

site_title: Civil servants to get one-month bonus in Dec; full-year bonus at 1.5 months
summary: Civil servants in Singapore will receive a year-end annual variable component (AVC) bonus, totaling 1.5 months of their salaries. Lower-wage civil servants will receive a minimum AVC of S$1,800, with around 1,380 officers receiving this payment. The government aims to support lower-wage workers, and this bonus signals the government's commitment to helping these workers. The bonus, along with a non-pensionable annual allowance of one month, will be paid in December.

site_title: German exports drag economy to first contraction since 2015
summary: Germany's economy contracted by 0.2% in the third quarter, its first decline since 2015, due to a slump in exports and private consumption. The drop in exports, 0.9%, was the biggest drag on growth, while private consumption fell 0.3%. However, investment and capital growth helped offset the decline, adding 0.9% to GDP. The Bundesbank expects strong growth in the final quarter of the year as car production returns to normal. This data may impact the European Central Bank's decision on ending stimulus at the end of the year.

site_title: Singapore headline inflation flat at 0.7% in October, but core inflation inches higher
summary: Singapore's headline inflation remained flat at 0.7% in October, as private road transport costs continued to decline, but core inflation edged higher to 1.9% due to rising electricity and gas prices. Food and retail prices slowed, while housing costs fell by 2.5%. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) reiterated their inflation forecasts, expecting headline inflation to average 0.5% in 2018 and 1-2% in 2019.

site_title: Singapore Life launches endowment plan with guaranteed interest and no penalty get-out clause
summary: Singapore Life is launching its third endowment plan, guaranteeing 3% interest per annum for up to S$6,000 over three years. For amounts above S$6,001, a 2.2% interest rate applies. The plan has a no-penalty get-out clause, allowing policy owners to partially withdraw for free with certain caveats, such as medical issues, life stage events, or financial distress. The policy owners can withdraw up to 50% of the single premium paid, with a maximum of S$50,000.

site_title: Malaysia's October inflation rate at 0.6% y-o-y, matches forecast
summary: Malaysia's consumer price index rose 0.6% in October, matching a forecast, driven by higher prices in five key sectors, including housing, food, and transport. This marks a reversal from the 0.2% low in August after a tax holiday. Core inflation rose 0.4% and is expected to edge upwards for the rest of the year and into next year. Bank Negara Malaysia forecasts an 4.8% economic expansion this year and 4.9% in 2019.

site_title: Robots are coming to one of South-east Asia's largest malls
summary: Philippines' richest man Henry Sy plans to roll out robots in his massive shopping mall, SM Megamall, starting in 2019. The three androids will provide directions and information on promotions and events, aiming to enhance customer service and make the shopping experience seamless. If successful, the robots will be deployed in other major malls, including SM North Edsa. The AI-powered robots will employ interactive and real-time platforms to cater to the daily foot traffic of 277,000 people in the mall.

site_title: China reports H5N6 bird flu outbreak in Jiangsu province
summary: China's agriculture ministry confirmed an outbreak of highly pathogenic H5N6 bird flu in Yangzhou city, Jiangsu province, on a farm with 11,810 birds. Authorities culled over 31,000 poultry in the area following the case. This is the latest in a series of H5N6 outbreaks in China, with previous incidents reported in Hebei and Sichuan provinces.

site_title: Singapore's financial stability sound but global risks have increased: MAS
summary: Singapore's financial stability remains sound, with low corporate debt and household borrowing rates. However, global risks have increased due to tighter financial conditions and trade tensions. Rising interest rates and currency pressure may weaken debt servicing abilities, particularly for those with foreign currency debt. The Monetary Authority of Singapore advises firms to remain cautious and households to monitor their debt servicing abilities, amid potential external headwinds. Overall, while Singapore's financial picture is stable, global risks pose a threat to the country's financial stability.

site_title: Malaysia to implement B10 biodiesel programme from Dec 1
summary: Malaysia will increase its biodiesel fuel mandate to 10% starting December 1, requiring fuel stations to use B10 biofuel. The move aims to double the use of palm oil locally and is part of a plan to reduce dependence on imported fuel. The B10 biodiesel programme will be implemented in stages, starting with the transport sector and other subsidised sectors in February 2019. The government has obtained agreement from the Federation of Malaysian Manufacturers to implement B7 biofuel in the industrial sector.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon at 3,040.71, down 0.02%
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Friday, down 0.02% at 3,040.71, with losers outpacing gainers 163-130. Rex International was the most actively traded, up 1.5% to 6.8 cents, while United Engineers rose 0.39% to 2.56 cents. Active index stocks included Singtel, up 0.32% to 3.11 cents, and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, down 1.6% to 1.23 cents.

site_title: Asia: Stocks follow Europe down, as fears grow over global economy
summary: Asian stocks declined on Friday, following Europe's losses, amid growing concerns over the global economy. Investors were unfazed by US President Donald Trump's comments on resolving the US-China trade dispute, with a meeting between the two leaders set for the G-20 in Argentina next week. Despite Trump's optimism, the market remains cautious, with US-EU tariffs a key focus.

site_title: Millennials the biggest investors in Indonesian stocks
summary: Millennials in Indonesia aged 21-30 are the largest group of investors in the country's equities, making up 34% of retail investors, according to the Central Securities Depository. This represents a 40% increase in retail investors since November 2017. Despite this, participation of individual investors in Indonesia remains low, with only 1% of the population registered as stock investors. Meanwhile, offshore investors are expected to post a record net outflow of almost US$3.3 billion this year.

site_title: Malaysia shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 0.70 points to 1,696.32 on Friday, with 32.6 million lots traded worth RM14.36 million. Losers outperformed gainers 70 to 67.

site_title: Samsung Electronics apologises for factory cancer cases
summary: Samsung Electronics has apologized to workers who developed cancer after working at its semiconductor factories, acknowledging it failed to properly manage health risks. The company will pay up to 150 million won (S$182,000) per case to 320 workers, including 118 who died, and their families. The apology comes after a decade-long dispute, with relatives of victims expressing mixed emotions, but accepting the compensation.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai : Stocks fall in early trade
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks fell on Friday, tracking a decline in European markets. The Hang Seng Index dropped 0.30% to 25,940.35, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.18% to 2,640.67. The decline was attributed to a focus on US-EU trade talks and weaker bank and healthcare sectors in Europe.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Nelson Peltz founding partner of Trian Fund Management LP. speak at the WSJD Live conference in Laguna Beach, California October 25, 2016. REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo##########unilever25##########

site_title: Australia, New Zealand dollars set for biggest weekly fall since October
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars are on track for their worst weekly performances since October, with the Australian dollar down 1% and the New Zealand dollar down 1% this week. The currencies fell amid a global sell-off in equities and concerns about a slowdown in world growth due to policy tightening in the US and the Sino-US trade war. A meeting between US President Trump and Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping next week is expected to determine whether tensions can be de-escalated, potentially boosting the AUD.

site_title: Slump in Singapore vehicle sales to worsen in 2019, hit rock bottom in 2021: Fitch
summary: Singapore's vehicle sales are expected to worsen in 2019 and hit rock bottom in 2021, with a 20.1% contraction in 2019 and a 25.4% annual average decline from 2020-2021. The market will touch annual new registrations of just under 46,000 units, less than half of the 116,148 new registrations seen in 2017. The decline is due to the cyclical nature of vehicle sales and high vehicle ownership costs, despite an improving consumer outlook and rising ride-sharing demand. US-China trade tensions and rising interest rates also weigh on consumer sentiment.

site_title: Japan prosecutors likely to build new criminal case against Ghosn: Asahi
summary: Japanese prosecutors are likely to build a new case against ousted Nissan chairman Carlos Ghosn for understating his remuneration by 3 billion yen (S$37.0 million) over three years. This would add to the existing case of alleged conspiracy to understate his remuneration by about half the 10 billion yen he earned at Nissan over five years. Combined, Ghosn has understated his remuneration by around 8 billion yen over eight years. The new case would make Ghosn liable for rearrest, potentially affecting his defense against the allegations.

images.alt_text: Japanese prosecutors are likely to build a new criminal case against ousted Nissan Motor chairman Carlos Ghosn for understating his remuneration by 3 billion yen (S$37.0 million) over three years from fiscal 2015, the Asahi newspaper reported on Friday.

site_title: Malaysia's Sime Darby Plantation quarterly profit slumps on weaker palm prices
summary: Sime Darby Plantation, the world's largest oil palm planter, reported a 89% slump in first-quarter profit to RM115 million due to lower palm oil and kernel prices. Revenue declined 14% to RM3.04 billion, primarily affected by a decline in CPO and palm kernel prices. The company expects fresh fruit bunch production to improve in the next six months but notes that the US-China trade war and weaker ringgit could support CPO prices.

site_title: Debt-laden Hyflux clarifies still hammering out terms of scheme of arrangement
summary: Hyflux, a debt-laden water treatment firm, is still working to finalize the terms of a scheme of arrangement involving creditors. The company denies recent media reports on a proposed plan, stating it's engaging with stakeholders to gather feedback and will make an announcement once the proposal is finalized. Hyflux secured a S$400 million equity injection from SM Investments, a consortium led by Salim Group, in exchange for a 60% stake in the company. The company will submit an application to the court for leave to convene creditor meetings once the proposal is ready.

site_title: SIA, Sats, DFASS sign share subscription deal for KrisShop
summary: SIA, Sats, and DFASS sign a share subscription deal for KrisShop, investing over S$35 million. SIA takes a 70% stake for S$24.9 million, with Sats holding 24% and DFASS holding 6%. The three companies will invest in a travel retail joint venture offering inflight and ground-based duty-free goods in Singapore.

site_title: 'Big Four' accountancy giants face UK probe
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority is investigating the "Big Four" accountancy firms - Deloitte, EY, KPMG, and PwC - amid a string of scandals in Britain. The firms, which dominate the sector, engage in a range of activities including auditing, strategy consulting, and taxation. The probe comes nearly two decades after the Enron scandal, highlighting concerns over the firms' influence and accountability. The investigation is expected to focus on the firms' role in advising and monitoring big businesses.

site_title: Startups in JLL and Lendlease's proptech accelerator in talks to put solutions to use
summary: JLL and Lendlease's proptech accelerator, Propell Asia, has concluded with five startups working with industry players to implement their products and solutions. GorillaSpace and Talox are in talks with Lendlease to use their products for a mixed-use development, while GorillaSpace also discusses marketing small office spaces with JLL. The startups will use the 10-week program to trial their solutions and secure seed investment. The accelerator aims to create better places, deliver the best customer experience, and drive efficient processes in the real estate industry.

site_title: Chaswood Resources to divest certain F&B business in Malaysia for RM8m
summary: CHASWOOD Resources Holdings' subsidiary, Chaswood Resources (CRSB), has agreed to sell certain F&B businesses in Malaysia, including TGI Friday's and Teh Tarik Place, to Sino Hua-An International for RM8 million. The sale is part of the group's restructuring efforts, which aim to restore its financial position and provide better value to shareholders. The proposed disposal will result in a loss of RM18.4 million, but the entire net sale proceeds will be used to repay outstanding loans and creditors. The sale is subject to court approval and the group's scheme of arrangement.

site_title: Value and cost of target assets in TSH reverse takeover raised to S$19.4m
summary: TSH Corp has raised the consideration for assets in a reverse takeover to S$19.4 million, following an independent valuation. The deal involves acquiring Sloshed!, a pub operator and liquor distributor, in exchange for new TSH shares. The consideration will be adjusted to match the valuation, resulting in about 646.7 million new TSH shares being issued to the sellers. The sellers have also waived S$1.45 million of shareholder loans to complete the deal.

site_title: Singapore shares open slightly lower on Friday, STI down 0.1% to 3,038.31
summary: Singapore shares slipped 0.1% to 3,038.31 on Friday, with the Straits Times Index down 3.07 points. Losers outnumbered gainers 55 to 40, with 14.4 million shares changing hands. Top traded stocks included Rex International, which rose 4.5%, and Hotel Properties Limited, which fell 2.7%. The market edged lower, with no major conclusions drawn from the trading session.

site_title: China says US-China trade talks should be equal, mutually beneficial
summary: China's Vice Commerce Minister Wang Shouwen stated that US-China trade talks should be equal and mutually beneficial. US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping are set to meet at the G20 summit, amid US demands for improved market access and intellectual property protections. China has rejected US accusations of unfair trade practices and urged Washington to stop making provocations. The US has imposed tariffs on $250 billion of Chinese imports, with plans to increase the rate to 25% on January 1, unless concessions are made.

site_title: China steps up prosecutions for pollution offences
summary: China prosecuted over 3,500 people for pollution-related crimes in the first 10 months of 2018, a 40% increase from last year. The country aims to show "zero tolerance" to environmental crimes, with nearly 8,500 people also prosecuted for "damaging resources." Despite this, environmental violations remain widespread, with 130,000 reported cases and fines totaling $2.1 billion. Beijing encourages courts and police to crack down on polluters, with President Xi Jinping promising to deploy the state's full weight to reverse environmental damage.

site_title: Meituan should carve up an albatross to create a unicorn
summary: Meituan, a Chinese food delivery company, reported improved operating figures after its IPO two months ago, driven by reduced subsidies and improved driver costs. However, its "new and other initiatives" including ride-hailing and bike rentals posted a gross loss, and may not contribute to income anytime soon. To address this, the company should carve out these businesses into a new unit, allowing it to take outside funding and sign up strategic investors, thereby creating a potential unicorn. This move would help Meituan focus on its core competence and capitalize on its strengths.

site_title: Hundreds of migrants push on to US-Mexico border bridge
summary: Hundreds of Central American migrants gathered at the US-Mexico border bridge in Tijuana, Mexico, as President Donald Trump threatened to close the border if they posed a threat. The migrants, mostly men, headed towards the bridge despite US helicopters overhead and local officials' efforts to dissuade them. Authorities in Tijuana set up a job fair to recruit skilled workers, while Mexico offered temporary residency papers. The migrants, fleeing poverty and gang violence in Central America, have been on the move for over a month, covering 4,400km before reaching the border town.

site_title: Ace Achieve suspends trading, says unable to assess financial position
summary: Ace Achieve Infocom suspended trading of its shares due to inability to assess its financial position and inform the market. The company recently announced plans to acquire a 36% stake in a blockchain business and take a S$500,000 loan to fund its audit and annual general meeting. The shares will be resumed "in due course."

site_title: Grab, NUS to test electric scooter sharing service on campus
summary: Grab's innovation arm has partnered with NUS to pilot an electric scooter sharing service, GrabWheels, on the university's Kent Ridge campus for a three-month trial. Eight parking stations are initially available, with plans to expand to 30 locations by the end of the year. Users can pick up and return e-scooters using the GrabWheels app, and they will be recharged daily. This is the first time GrabWheels is being tested in Singapore.

site_title: Tokyo: Markets closed on Friday for public holiday
summary: Japanese financial markets were closed on Friday, Nov 23, 2018, for a public holiday, resuming trading on Monday, Nov 26. In contrast, global markets experienced fluctuations, with US stocks edging down from records amid tariff threats, while European stocks were boosted by mining and healthcare sectors. Asia's stocks continued their rally despite Trump's new threats, with Singapore and Singaporean companies experiencing gains. US-EU trade talks remain a focus for investors.

site_title: ECB chief economist dashes hopes of imminent cash injection for banks
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) chief economist Peter Praet has dashed hopes of an imminent cash injection for struggling banks, citing it's too early to decide on a new multi-year loan program. Praet stated that existing funding will cover banks' needs until the middle of next year. The ECB is sticking to plans to reduce monetary stimulus, despite concerns about the euro zone economy. Praet also emphasized that the economic outlook remains balanced, despite growing "downside risks."

site_title: Europe: Shares wilt again as earnings disappoint, Italian banks drop
summary: European shares declined 0.7% on Thursday, driven by disappointing earnings updates and falling mining stocks. Uncertainty over Italian politics, Brexit, and slowing economic growth discouraged investors. Miners, including Centrica and Rotork, were major losers, while telecoms firm Altice slumped 11.9% due to heavy promotions. Analysts cut their 2018 earnings growth estimate to 4.8% from 10%, but expect 10% growth in 2019. Deutsche Bank upgraded its recommendation on cyclical sectors, predicting they will outperform defensives by 15% by April.

site_title: UK retailers hope for Black Friday tonic after grim year
summary: UK retailers are hoping Black Friday sales will boost spending after a difficult year, with several store closures and business bankruptcies. Despite subdued consumer spending and online competition, GlobalData forecasts 3.1% growth in UK spending during the Black Friday period to £10.4 billion. Footfall on main shopping streets is expected to drop, while online transactions are forecast to rise. Retailers, including Amazon and John Lewis, are stretching promotions to smooth out demand and reduce pressure on supply networks.

images.alt_text: Britain's retailers are hoping Black Friday discounts will get shoppers spending again after a torrid year for much of the sector.

site_title: Facebook to pay 100m euros in Italian fiscal accord
summary: Facebook has agreed to pay 100 million euros to end a fiscal fraud dispute with Italian tax authorities, settling a 7-year investigation. This payment is part of a growing trend of multinationals, including Amazon, Apple, and Google, agreeing to pay millions to settle tax disputes in Italy. The agreement aims to end tax enquiries related to profits booked in countries with lower tax rates. This follows similar agreements from other tech giants, highlighting the EU's efforts to increase tax revenue from multinational corporations.

site_title: Goldman chairman Lloyd Blankfein met privately with Jho Low
summary: Goldman Sachs chairman Lloyd Blankfein met privately with Jho Low, a Malaysian financier with ties to Malaysia's prime minister, in December 2012. Low is now an international fugitive accused of masterminding a multibillion-dollar 1MDB fraud. The meeting is being examined by federal prosecutors as part of a criminal investigation into Goldman, which had supported the 1MDB fund. The face-to-face meeting contradicts Goldman's claim that its problems stem from rogue employees, expanding the scope of the scandal.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Chaswood Resources, Singtel, Singapore Airlines, Ace Achieve Infocom
summary: Chaswood Resources Holdings has agreed to sell certain subsidiaries, including TGI Friday's in Malaysia and Teh Tarik Place businesses, to Sino Hua-An International for RM8 million. Singtel secured broadcast rights for the Premier League for three years at unchanged prices. Singapore Airlines is reorganizing routes as part of a transformation program ahead of a potential merger with SilkAir. Ace Achieve Infocom temporarily suspended trading after announcing a plan to acquire a 36% stake in a blockchain business and seeking funding for its audit.

site_title: British lawmakers launch probe into bank IT failures
summary: British lawmakers have launched an inquiry into computer systems failures at financial services firms, following recent IT outages that left millions of customers unable to access their money. The Treasury Committee will examine how firms prevent IT failures and whether regulators can hold them accountable when customers lose out. Over the past year and a half, several major financial firms, including Barclays and Royal Bank of Scotland, have experienced IT failures. The investigation aims to identify the causes of these failures and ensure greater protection for customers.

site_title: Ex-FBI director Comey to testify before outgoing Congress
summary: Former FBI Director James Comey and former Attorney General Loretta Lynch will testify before Congress on December 3 and 4, respectively, before Republicans relinquish control of the House. Comey has expressed his willingness to answer questions in an open hearing, but has vowed to resist closed-door questioning, citing concerns about bias and selective leaking. The hearings come amid ongoing investigations into alleged bias against the Trump campaign and the 2016 election. Comey and Lynch have been summoned to testify on political bias at the Justice Department.

site_title: Saudi prince lands in UAE on first foreign tour since Khashoggi murder
summary: Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman began a regional tour, his first official trip abroad since Jamal Khashoggi's murder, with a visit to the UAE. Prince Mohammed was welcomed by Abu Dhabi's Crown Prince Mohammed bin Zayed. The trip is at the request of King Salman, and the countries visited will be named later. The tour comes as Saudi Arabia seeks to rebuild its international relationships following the Khashoggi crisis.

site_title: US asks allies to avoid Huawei's equipment: WSJ
summary: The US government has asked allied countries to avoid using telecommunications equipment from China's Huawei Technologies due to cybersecurity concerns. US officials have reached out to governments and telecom executives in countries where Huawei equipment is already in use, citing risks of espionage. The concerns are based on Huawei's alleged ties to the Chinese government and the use of its equipment in countries hosting US military bases. Washington is considering increasing financial aid for telecommunications development in countries that shun Chinese-made equipment.

images.alt_text: The US government is trying to persuade wireless and internet providers in allied countries to avoid telecommunications equipment from China's Huawei Technologies, the Wall Street Journal reported on Thursday.

site_title: Oil falls on rising US inventories, Opec talk of cut limits loss
summary: Oil prices fell on Thursday, with Brent dipping 96 cents to $62.52 a barrel and US WTI falling 78 cents to $53.85, amid rising US inventories and concerns about a global crude glut. However, Opec's talk of potential output cuts limited losses. US crude inventories rose to 446.91 million barrels, their highest since December, while US crude production stayed at a record 11.7 million barrels per day. Opec's meeting on December 6 is expected to discuss production cuts, but Iran's exports have dropped by several hundred thousand barrels per day due to US sanctions.

site_title: Trump says prepared for G-20 meeting with China's Xi
summary: US President Donald Trump expressed confidence in a potential deal with Chinese President Xi Jinping at the G-20 summit in Argentina, saying he was "very prepared" for the meeting. Trump, who has been locked in a trade war with China, suggested that a deal could be reached to end the trade war. He stated that China wants to make a deal and if a deal is reached, the US will make one as well. The meeting is set to take place on the sidelines of the summit, which begins on November 30.

site_title: Honey From Heartache
summary: Dance queen Robyn releases her sixth solo album, "Honey", after an eight-year wait. The album reflects on her romantic breakup and the death of her producer Christian Falk, blending existential melancholy with upbeat synthpop beats. Standout tracks include "Missing U", "Baby Forgive Me", "Ever Again", and the title track "Honey". Robyn's music helps the lost and lonely work through their emotions, making her a modern-day equivalent of Adele. The album is now available on iTunes.

site_title: Temasek will explore AI, blockchain deals
summary: Temasek Holdings, Singapore's state investment firm, is setting up new groups to explore opportunities in artificial intelligence (AI) and blockchain technologies. The firm is creating "experimental pods" to focus on these areas, which it sees as long-term trends impacting multiple industries and geographies. This move comes after Temasek's recent investments in AI startups and blockchain companies, including SenseTime Group Ltd and R3. The firm aims to remain nimble and well-positioned to capture opportunities that deliver sustainable value over the long term.

site_title: EU, Britain agree draft deal on future relations
summary: Britain and the European Union have agreed on a draft text for a close post-Brexit relationship, despite ongoing wrangling over Gibraltar's control. The draft treaty, finalized after a meeting between EU chief executive Jean-Claude Juncker and British Prime Minister Theresa May, aims to establish a comprehensive economic partnership between the two parties. The agreement is expected to be rubber-stamped by EU leaders on Sunday, but Spain's opposition to the deal over Gibraltar remains a major hurdle. The draft text commits the EU to avoiding a "backstop" clause that could limit Britain's need to follow EU trade rules.

site_title: EU and Britain agree to draft on post-Brexit ties
summary: The European Union and Britain have agreed on a 26-page draft declaration outlining plans for post-Brexit relations, described as "ambitious, broad, deep and flexible." The declaration, set to be reviewed by the remaining 27 EU member states, includes agreements on trade, security, the environment, and other issues. The declaration's approval is seen as crucial for the UK's departure from the bloc, with Prime Minister Theresa May hoping it will convince skeptical lawmakers to back her vision. A final Brexit deal is set to be signed by EU leaders on Sunday.

site_title: Venezuela economy shrank 16.6% in 2017, central bank data shows: sources
summary: Venezuela's economy shrank 16.6% in 2017, the country's sharpest decline on record, according to central bank data. The economy has been in free fall since 2014's oil price collapse and socialist system unraveling. The central bank has stopped publishing economic indicators amid an "economic war" led by businesses and political adversaries. The International Monetary Fund is pressuring Venezuela to provide data on economic activity and consumer prices, which may lead to IMF sanctions and expulsion from the institution.

site_title: US government asks allies to drop Huawei equipment, WSJ says
summary: The US government is urging its foreign allies to drop telecommunications equipment from Chinese company Huawei due to cybersecurity concerns, according to a Wall Street Journal report. American officials have briefed telecom executives in Germany, Italy, and Japan about the risks, while considering financial aid for countries that shun Huawei. The US is particularly concerned about Huawei's presence in countries hosting US military bases and fears the rise of Chinese tech giants benefiting authoritarian governments.

site_title: China's capital controls keep outflows from getting worse
summary: China's capital controls have limited capital outflows, despite economic growth slowing and the yuan trading near its weakest level in over a decade. Restrictions on overseas takeovers and purchases of insurance policies in Hong Kong have kept outflows at a trickle in 2018. Net outflows through September totalled about $296 billion, compared to an estimated $1.4 trillion in 2015 and 2016. Chinese measures to curb capital flight, including a ban on domestic cryptocurrency exchanges, have helped moderate outflow pressure, but the yuan's slide remains a concern, particularly if outflows increase in January when China resets its foreign exchange quota.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Mind Your Business - Lawyers with a Heart
summary: TSMP Law Corporation, a Singapore-based law firm, has won the President's Volunteerism and Philanthropy Awards for the Corporate category, becoming the first law firm to receive this prestigious award. Joint managing partner Stefanie Yuen Thio discussed the firm's commitment to giving back and "celebrating" this achievement. The win highlights the importance of corporate social responsibility and the role law firms can play in philanthropy.

site_title: Tiger Woods calls betting integral to golf ahead of US$9m duel with Mickelson
summary: Tiger Woods and Phil Mickelson will compete in a US$9 million golf match with various side bets, or "challenges," that will be wagered out of their own pockets and donated to charity. The event, which will be broadcast live on pay-per-view, will feature live odds on screen and allow fans to bet shot by shot. Woods and Mickelson see betting as an integral part of the game, with Woods stating it's what makes golf "uncomfortable" and encourages players to think about their shots. The event is seen as a potential step forward for golf, which could benefit from increased viewership and the growth of legal gambling.

site_title: Singapore exports not very exposed to trade war: MTI analysts
summary: Singapore's economy is relatively shielded from the US-China trade war, with value added from US-China bilateral exports making up only 1.29% of Singapore's GDP last year. The actual impact of the trade conflict on the Singapore economy is likely to be smaller due to limited exposure and the fact that not all goods exported between the US and China have tariffs slapped on them. However, economists warn that if the global economy experiences a sharp decline, the negative impact on Singapore's exports could be more significant.

site_title: Backlash prompts Amazon to re-open US store to Australians
summary: Amazon has lifted its ban on Australian customers shopping on its US site after a customer backlash, citing a reversal of its decision to block Australians due to Australian tax laws. The move comes after a year of Amazon's Australian platform launch, which led to a decline in online sales growth. Amazon will now allow customers to place orders on its US site, but the exemption only applies to products sold by Amazon and not third-party sales.

site_title: China considers tax cut for plane parts to help home-built aircraft
summary: China is considering a tax cut on plane parts imported for domestically developed commercial aircraft, a move that could benefit suppliers such as General Electric Co and Honeywell International Inc. The Finance Ministry proposal, being reviewed by the State Council, could win approvals in a few weeks. Currently, tariffs on aviation components range from 1.5% to 11%, with the goal of reducing costs for China's aviation industry. The move is seen as a step to support the development of China's home-built commercial aircraft.

site_title: Singapore Exclusive
summary: Auchentoshan has released a rare single malt Scotch, the 1987 30-Year Old Single Cask, exclusively for Singapore. 383 bottles were handpicked by master blender Ron Welsh, featuring notes of honey, molasses, and lychees. The whisky retails at S$1088 and is embellished with a handwritten "Singapore 2018" on each box. Welsh recommends enjoying it neat to savour its nuances. This is the first time Auchentoshan has bottled a single malt specifically for Singapore.

site_title: SPH Radio stations grow audience base further
summary: SPH Radio stations experienced significant growth in listenership, with monthly digital listenership reaching over 800,000 unique users in October 2018, a 23% increase from June. ONE FM 91.3 saw a 80% increase in digital audience numbers, while MONEY FM 89.3's listenership jumped 59% to 89,000. The Chinese audience size also increased, with UFM100.3 leading the growth by 10%. This growth is attributed to changing radio consumption habits and the success of rebranding efforts, according to SPH Radio's general manager.

site_title: Block Party
summary: A one-stop shopping event, #TBLblockparty, will take place at Tan Boon Liat Building on November 24-25. Over 30 showrooms, including Journey East and Foundry, will offer exclusive deals, pop-ups, workshops, and design talks. The event also features a building-wide lucky draw with four winners receiving $250 cash vouchers. The event is a shopping orgy for home furnishing, providing a unique experience for customers.

site_title: How do you make them stay?
summary: Nanyang Technological University produces 2,600 engineering graduates annually, but only about half become engineers. A recent survey explores the reasons behind this trend, citing perceived better prospects in other professions as a major factor. Engineering graduates report a desire for higher pay and a more balanced work-life. The article aims to understand the disconnect between engineering graduates' aspirations and career choices.

site_title: March 1961: Playing with fire
summary: Singapore banned private fireworks displays in the 1970s following a fatal accident during Chinese New Year celebrations. However, fireworks have a long history in the country, dating back hundreds of years and initially used in funerals to ward off evil spirits. While the ban remains in place, aficionados can still enjoy fireworks during specific occasions such as Chinese New Year, Formula 1, and National Day, providing a celebratory atmosphere.

site_title: The Local Life
summary: The Grand Copthorne Waterfront Hotel in Singapore is launching a "Live like a Local" campaign starting December 1, offering free tours and monthly workshops to international and local guests. The campaign aims to show guests how Singaporeans really live, with highlights including a tour of Tiong Bahru, Qi Tian Gong Temple, and cultural festivities activities. The initiative is part of the hotel's efforts to help guests assimilate into local life, with the goal of providing a more authentic experience.

site_title: China's steel sector faces a chill as demand wanes in key industries
summary: China's steel sector is experiencing a decline, with prices falling almost 20% in the past three months due to a slowing economy and trade disputes. The benchmark price, Shanghai steel rebar futures, dropped 18.8% from its highest level this year to 3,586 yuan (S$875) a tonne. Despite still being higher than last year's close, the recent declines are close to erasing the year's gains. The industry faces a bear market, with record production unable to offset the economic slowdown.

site_title: US mortgage rates dip to lows not seen in more than a month
summary: US mortgage rates have dropped to their lowest level in seven weeks, with the 30-year fixed-rate average falling to 4.81% and the 15-year fixed-rate average dropping to 4.24%. The decline is attributed to stock market volatility, causing investors to seek safer assets, such as long-term bonds. Experts predict that rates will remain relatively stable, with some warning of a potential rate increase by the US Federal Reserve in December. Mortgage applications were flat, with refinance activity declining 5% and purchase activity rising 3%.

site_title: UK markets watchdog proposes price cap on rent-to-own goods
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority proposes a price cap on rent-to-own goods, such as televisions and washing machines, to be implemented from April next year. The cap will limit credit charges to the product's cost, and RTO firms will need to benchmark prices against other retailers. This move aims to save consumers up to £22.7 million annually and protect vulnerable individuals who often pay multiples of the product's price. The FCA also introduces a two-day cooling off period for extended warranties on items bought.

site_title: 'Tis The Season
summary: W!ld Rice's pantomime 'A $ingapore Carol' parodies Charles Dickens' A Christmas Carol, starring Sebastian Tan as miserly S.K. Loo. Directed by Hossan Leong and written by Jonathan Lim, the show features Singlish humour, topical references, and a reworked soundtrack. The production runs at Victoria Theatre from Nov 22 to Dec 15.

site_title: Screen Shot
summary: The 29th Singapore International Film Festival will run from November 28 to December 9, featuring 81 screenings over 12 days. Notable films include Ho Wi Ding's "Cities of Last Things" and Stanley Kwan's "First Night Nerves", with Kwan attending the Southeast Asian premiere. The festival also celebrates the 15th anniversary of Royston Tan's directorial debut "15" with an uncut screening.

site_title: UK could slide into recession if it crashes out of the EU: OECD
summary: The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) predicts that if the UK crashes out of the European Union, it will slide into recession, with a decline of over 2% in real GDP over two years. This would lead to an inflationary recession, with inflation forecast to rise from 2.4% to potentially over 4%. In contrast, a deal that ensures the closest possible trading relationship with the EU could support growth, but a weak stagflation economy is also a possible outcome.

site_title: Jane Austen's unfinished novel comes to the stage
summary: A British playwright, Laura Wade, has adapted Jane Austen's unfinished novel "The Watsons" into a stage play after working on it for over a decade. The 17,500-word novel, written in 1804-1805, follows the story of a young woman named Emma Watson as she returns to her family after being raised by a wealthy aunt. Wade's adaptation brings the story to life with a modern twist, imagining what the characters would do if they had the same opportunities as women today. The play opened at the Chichester Festival Theater in southeast England, marking a significant interpretation of Austen's work, which also explores themes of dispossession and character types that appear in later novels.

site_title: CPH to acquire fintech firm oCap in RTO
summary: CPH Ltd, a Singapore-based printed circuit board manufacturer, has signed a conditional sale and purchase agreement to acquire fintech firm oCap Management for S$61.8 million. The deal, which includes a reverse takeover, will give oCap a 80.34% stake in CPH. The acquisition aims to diversify CPH's business, which has faced strong competition from Taiwanese and Chinese factories, and will enable CPH to appeal to a broader base of investors. oCap's profitable business model and scalable services will target cash flow problems faced by small and medium-sized enterprises.

site_title: Firefly suspends all flights to Singapore from Dec 1
summary: Malaysian airline Firefly has suspended all flights to Singapore from December 1, citing regulatory issues related to its transfer of operations from Changi to Seletar Airport. The airline had planned to move its turboprop operations to the new terminal at Seletar Airport but will not resume flights until the authorities clear the necessary matters. Firefly will provide arrangements for affected passengers and plans to resume services once the regulatory issues are resolved.

site_title: US dollar slips for second day in quiet trading
summary: The US dollar slipped 0.1% against a basket of currencies for a second consecutive day, retreating from a near 1½-year high. The euro rose 0.1% amid cautious optimism about the European bond market. Investors are questioning the Federal Reserve's ability to raise interest rates without risking a slowdown in the US economy, with a Reuters poll showing a median forecast for three more rate hikes in 2019. The British pound remained little changed as traders await clarity on a Brexit agreement.

site_title: Global markets will return to normality in 2019: Goldman Sachs
summary: Goldman Sachs predicts global markets will return to normalcy in 2019, but without the "comfort blanket" of quantitative easing, leading to increased volatility. Central banks are shifting from QE to QT, and the European Central Bank will end its 2.5 trillion euro bond-buying program next month. The bank expects the global economy to slow moderately from 3.8% in 2018 to 3.5% in 2019, with potential growth in China above 6-6.5%. Goldman Sachs is maintaining a "strong overweight position" towards emerging markets, including India and Indonesia, and is modestly overweight on oil.

site_title: US existing-home sales rise for first time in seven months
summary: US existing-home sales rose in October for the first time in seven months, with contract closings increasing to an annual rate of 5.22 million, exceeding economists' projections. The median sales price rose 3.8% from a year earlier, while the inventory of available homes expanded 2.8% for the third straight month. Despite the monthly increase, sales remain down 5.1% from a year earlier, and the market remains relatively soft due to high mortgage rates and rising property prices.

site_title: IMDA puts up seed funding to boost blockchain adoption
summary: IMDA, Singapore's Infocomm Media Development Authority, has launched a seed funding initiative to boost blockchain adoption in the country. The program aims to develop an engagement platform that connects industry players, provides guides for enterprises on blockchain adoption, and links to global blockchain communities. This follows concerns that blockchain's nascent state and lack of successful cases have hindered mainstream adoption. IMDA also launched a Blockchain Challenge to invite proposals for innovative solutions using distributed ledger technology, targeting operational efficiency and business model innovation.

site_title: NODX tipped to expand 5.5-6% in 2018
summary: Singapore's total merchandise trade and non-oil domestic exports (NODX) grew 14.7% and 8% year-over-year in the third quarter, respectively, exceeding forecasts. The strong showing was attributed to favorable sector-specific export trends in pharmaceuticals and food, as well as higher oil prices. Enterprise Singapore has raised its full-year growth forecasts to 9-9.5% for total trade and 5.5-6% for NODX, with forecasts easing to 0-2% for 2019.

site_title: Financial services not for the faint-hearted
summary: Financial services companies face significant transformation to remain relevant, driven by constant change and new technologies. Despite relatively stable industries, executives expect radical changes within the next five years, with 74% of bankers and 63% of insurance executives believing their organisations will be transformed. The disruptability index shows banking and insurance jumping to second and fourth place, respectively, indicating a need for decisive action to avoid falling behind.

site_title: Job perks and how to get them
summary: Companies are shifting from viewing staff welfare as a privilege to a right, offering perks such as free flu vaccinations, flexible work hours, and wellness programs to boost employee happiness and productivity. Top employers like Royal Plaza on Scotts, Mercury Live, and DP Architects are setting the standard with innovative benefits, including meditation sessions, fitness programs, and team-building activities. Experts say that happy employees are more productive, engaged, and loyal, and that companies must understand their employees' goals and motivations to develop effective rewards and recognition systems.

site_title: Lithium giant bets big on demand shift with Australia mine deal
summary: Albemarle Corp has agreed to pay $1.15 billion for a 50% stake in Australia's Wodgina hard-rock lithium mine, expanding its output to meet rising demand for lithium hydroxide, a refined form of lithium used in electric-car batteries. The deal is part of Albemarle's strategy to diversify its spodumene assets and strengthen its hydroxide supply chain, following a significant acceleration in demand for the mineral. Total lithium demand is expected to almost triple by 2025 as manufacturers like Tesla ramp up electric vehicle production.

site_title: STI tracks Wall Street to rise 0.1%
summary: The Straits Times Index rose 2.73 points, or 0.1%, to 3,041.38 on Thursday, driven by a rebound in US Wall Street overnight. However, investors in Asia were largely uninspired, with equities struggling to find direction. Market observers caution that the US market's recovery should not be taken as a significant indicator, given light trading ahead of the US Thanksgiving holiday.

site_title: Golfers fear for the future of HK's Fanling
summary: Hong Kong's Hong Kong Golf Club, home to the 170-hectare Fanling golf course, faces an uncertain future as its lease is set to expire in two years. The course, a relic of British colonialism, is under threat from developers seeking to build homes and skyscrapers. The prospect of losing the course is unpalatable to many golfers, who consider it a part of Hong Kong's identity. The club pays a token HK$1 per year in rent, and its members fear that the land will be converted into concrete, threatening the city's golfing heritage.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Jumbo Group's Q4 earnings fell short of expectations, with revenue increasing 4% year-over-year. DBS Group Research maintains a "hold" stance, citing growth prospects largely priced in, and cuts FY19-20F earnings by 20-22%. NetLink NBN Trust is expected to benefit from the retirement of legacy ADSL and HFC networks, with UOB Kay Hian upgrading to "buy" with a target price of S$0.99. The company's distribution per unit is projected to rise 5.2% for the year.

site_title: Soft skills are not as soft as you think
summary: A growing trend in the Asia-Pacific region is the increasing demand for tech jobs requiring a mix of technical and soft skills, particularly in data science roles. LinkedIn's Emerging Jobs report found data science to be a top emerging job across the region, with staggering growth rates. To succeed in these roles, individuals need to possess both technical skills and the ability to communicate and manage effectively, highlighting the importance of soft skills in the tech industry.

site_title: Indonesia plans tax revisions to prop up sluggish property sector
summary: Indonesia plans to revise tax rules to boost the sluggish property sector, including cutting luxury property taxes and introducing lower tax rates on sales. The government aims to attract investment and support economic growth, which has been stuck at around 5% in recent years. Additionally, measures to boost exports and foreign direct investment (FDI) are being considered, including tax incentives and easing of the "Negative Investment List."

site_title: A Minimal Space
summary: The National Gallery Singapore and ArtScience Museum's "Minimalism: Space. Light. Object." exhibition, running for five months, is a broad introduction to the 20th-century art movement. Despite featuring prominent artists like Donald Judd and Mark Rothko, the show's scope is criticized for being too big and superficial, lacking depth. The exhibition aims to be accessible and educational, but may feel perfunctory for those already familiar with art history. It showcases not only Western minimalists but also Asian artists influenced by Zen Buddhism and other Asian belief systems.

site_title: Raft of programmes launched to help ICT SMEs
summary: The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) has launched several initiatives to support small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in the infocomm media sector, aiming to transform the sector into a seamless and end-to-end ecosystem. The GoCloud initiative will help SMEs move to cloud-native systems, while the SG Digital Cloud Community promotes adoption of cloud-native architecture. Other initiatives include a Digital Services Laboratory and programmes to help infocomm media firms break into overseas markets, focusing on market immersion, demo days, and curated professional services.

site_title: China allows foreign firms to join credit monitoring system
summary: China has allowed foreign firms to join its nationwide credit monitoring system, a move expected to increase the credit information coverage from 300 million to around 800 million people. The system, built by the People's Bank of China, assesses the debt payment abilities of businesses and individuals. US credit information servicer Dun & Bradstreet Corp and the Chinese subsidiary of Experian PLC have already registered, while an Italian credit information service company is preparing to do so. This expansion aims to reduce the country's credit information blind spot and increase financial transparency.

site_title: Review sees SIA, SilkAir, Scoot shuffle routes among themselves
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and its regional arm SilkAir are shuffling routes among themselves ahead of a potential merger. Scoot, SIA's budget arm, will take over SilkAir's routes to Luang Prabang, Vientiane, and several destinations in India, China, and Southeast Asia over the next two years. Scoot will also suspend its Honolulu service due to weak demand. Meanwhile, SilkAir will convert its Mandalay route to a seasonal service. The changes are part of SIA's three-year transformation program aimed at strengthening the group for the long term.

site_title: Skai's the limit
summary: Skai restaurant, located 70 floors high in the Swissotel Stamford, has revamped its mod-European cuisine with Japanese influences, aiming to stand out in the dining scene. After a sabbatical, the restaurant has returned with a new outlook and menu, seeking to surpass its previous heights.

site_title: Adan Jimenez & Felicia Low-Jimenez
summary: Adan Jimenez and Felicia Low-Jimenez, a married couple, have co-authored 14 children's books under the pen name A.J. Low. Their series, "Sherlock Sam," follows the adventures of a precocious kid detective in Singapore, with a sidekick named Watson. The couple, who share a love for comic-books, fantasy, and science fiction, conduct writing workshops and draw inspiration from their personal experiences and travels. With a distinctly Singapore identity, the series has gained success in Singapore and overseas, and the authors plan to continue writing for the kids' market, while also exploring other genres.

site_title: Failed job applications a result of skills mismatch
summary: A study by Ministry of Trade and Industry economists in Singapore found that skills mismatches are the most likely reason for unsuccessful job applications. Non-generic skills mismatches, such as knowledge of specific programming languages or tax expertise, had the greatest impact, with a one-unit increase associated with a 4.3 percentage point increase in the probability of an unsuccessful application. Jobseekers are advised to be mindful of skills requirements and acquire these skills to improve their chances of success.

images.alt_text: Released on Thursday as part of the third quarter's Economic Survey of Singapore, the study looked at applications on government jobs portal MyCareersFuture.sg from January till December 2016.

site_title: Trump stuck with Powell despite strains
summary: US President Donald Trump is reportedly considering replacing Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell with Neel Kashkari, despite the latter's criticism of the Fed's interest rate increases. Kashkari, a former regional bank president, has expressed doubts about the Fed's policy, but his regulatory stance would make Senate confirmation difficult. Trump's attempts to pressure the Fed may backfire, as seen in President Nixon's pressure on Fed Chair Arthur Burns in 1972. The Fed's institutional bias towards early and frequent rate increases may also limit Powell's ability to change course without appearing weak.

site_title: No Signboard warns of losses owing to ailing beer business
summary: No Signboard Holdings, a Singaporean F&B group, is expected to record losses for its fiscal fourth quarter and full year due to an impairment charge on its struggling beer business. The impairment charge is attributed to the beer business's poor performance, and the company is rationalizing and restructuring the business. No Signboard acquired a 20% stake in Danish Breweries in June for S$400,000, aiming to capitalize on the beer business's potential, but the latest move indicates a reversal of this strategy. The company's shares fell 2.6% on the news.

site_title: Machines to soup up counting at Singapore's next polls
summary: Singapore's next general election will feature electronic voter registration and the use of counting machines to speed up the voting process. Voters will scan their identity cards at polling stations, reducing waiting times. The counting machines, similar to those used for handling banknotes, will make the counting process three times faster, allowing for faster results. The changes aim to improve the election process and provide a smoother experience for voters, with the aim of reducing processing and counting time by 30-40%. The use of e-registration and counting machines will be tested before the election.

site_title: Salary for Singapore workers to rise 2.6% in 2019: ECA International
summary: Singapore workers can expect a 2.6% real salary increase in 2019, down from 2.9% in 2018, due to higher inflation of 1.4% from 1% in 2018, according to ECA International. This marks a reduction in real pay hikes compared to the previous year.

site_title: The return of Orson Welles
summary: Orson Welles' long-lost film "The Other Side of the Wind" has finally been released on Netflix 33 years after his death. The 1970s film, which was left unfinished due to funding issues, is a surreal and chaotic swansong that pays tribute to and parodies European arthouse cinema. The film, which was condensed from 100 hours of footage, depicts a story-within-a-story that is partly based on Welles' own life, including his tumultuous relationship with his mistress Oja Kodar. The film's completion was made possible with a $5 million investment from Netflix, and it is now available for streaming alongside a companion documentary.

site_title: Chinese thirst for cognac lifts Remy Cointreau's H1 profits
summary: French spirits group Remy Cointreau delivered higher first-half profits, exceeding forecasts, driven by strong demand for premium cognac in China and a tight cost control. The company's current group operating profit for the six months to Sept 30 reached 138 million euros, a 10.1% like-for-like growth. The Remy Martin cognac division saw a 11.3% like-for-like rise in operating profit, supported by strong demand in Greater China, Singapore, Australia, and Japan.

images.alt_text: Remy Cointreau has been focusing on selling spirits priced at US$50 a bottle or more.

site_title: Volkswagen Polo review: VW beats its baby
summary: Volkswagen's new Polo Beats model, priced at S$99,400, offers better equipment than the basic Polo Comfortline at S$90,900. The car's collaboration with Beats audio is expected to attract younger consumers. The Polo Beats boasts improved audio quality and design, drawing attention to its substance beyond its trendy features. VW's strategy may help win over younger car buyers, who have fallen out of love with cars, with the Polo Beats offering a balance of style and substance.

site_title: UK looks to hydrogen as source of green energy
summary: The UK's Committee on Climate Change is urging the government to develop a strategy to remove carbon emissions from heat, with a focus on hydrogen as a green energy source. The committee recommends writing a strategy within the next three years, starting with the roll-out of hybrid heat pumps. Hydrogen has the potential to contribute to near-zero carbon energy emissions if used strategically, and could provide 25% of heat for buildings by 2050. The UK aims to meet 15% of its energy needs with renewables by 2020 and 30% of electricity by the same year.

site_title: Paw-Fect Fit
summary: Moncler has launched a winter wear collection specifically for dogs, in collaboration with Poldo Dog Couture. The collection, part of the Moncler Genius project, features canine-friendly versions of the brand's classic down jackets, waistcoats, and hoodies. The items are made with nylon laque and are designed to keep dogs warm and stylish during the cold weather. The collection is available at Moncler boutiques and moncler.com.

site_title: Sky High Perks
summary: Pan Pacific Singapore's Pacific Club Lounge offers exclusive privileges for business travelers, including access to a 360-degree view of Marina Bay and a range of gourmet food and drink options. Guests can enjoy champagne breakfast, high tea, and evening cocktails, accompanied by canapés. The lounge features floor-to-ceiling windows, a Master Butcher's crafted cold cuts, and a Peranakan Corner serving traditional nonya kueh and curry. The Pacific Club Lounge is designed to blend business and leisure needs, providing a stress-free experience for executives traveling for work.

site_title: Spice Central
summary: The Orchard Cafe, a Singaporean eatery, has reopened after a four-month hiatus with a fresh contemporary look. The cafe serves authentic local fare, including popular dishes such as taukwa pau and braised pork knuckle bee hoon. Executive chef Bryce Li has added modern twists to traditional dishes, like lobster Roti John. The cafe is now open for reservations.

site_title: Focus on succession planning and the board at AGMs
summary: Shareholders attending annual general meetings (AGMs) are increasingly financially literate, but many focus on company finances and dividend payouts, overlooking succession planning. Studies show that boards typically address this issue only when a CEO is retiring or stepping down. In today's rapidly changing world, boards should proactively evaluate the skills and composition of their members to ensure they are equipped to lead the company. This is crucial for long-term success and should be a key area of scrutiny for shareholders at AGMs.

site_title: The Big Cheese
summary: Cheese consumption is growing in Singapore, with more diverse options available in restaurants and shops. Ten years ago, there were limited cheese options, but the trend has gained momentum, with over 20 cheeses on offer at some restaurants. Experts attribute the trend to education and exposure, with many diners now opting for the cheese course in tasting menus. Foreign players have also entered the market, with The Mast' opening its first Asian outpost in Singapore. Chefs recommend considering different types of cheese, including pungent ones, and pairing them with sweet elements to experience new flavors.

site_title: Online fashion thrives for new retailer where women call the shots
summary: British fashion retailer Sosandar has seen a 400% revenue growth in the six months through September, defying the gloom among UK brick-and-mortar retailers. The company, founded by two women who cater to women aged 35-55, has a market value of £40 million and has almost doubled its stock value this year. Sosandar aims to expand online and eventually enter the European and US markets, with a focus on turning profitable as sales grow. The company's founders have a deep understanding of its target demographic, allowing them to connect with customers and drive investor appetite.

site_title: Fixed legal fees off the table for now
summary: Singapore's proposed changes to fix civil litigation costs have been withdrawn, with the Ministry of Law (MinLaw) deciding not to proceed with the consultation on fixing legal costs that lawyers can charge their clients. The recommendation, which aimed to incentivize lawyers to resolve disputes quickly, was met with concerns from lawyers and was deemed not in the public interest. The proposal will be revisited in a few years' time after the litigation process has been streamlined and the Bar has been consulted.

site_title: More SGX-listed firms embark on sustainability reporting
summary: More than 48% of Singapore Exchange-listed companies have started sustainability reporting, with an average level of disclosure of 55.3 percentage points as of May 31. A study by the National University of Singapore Business School and Asean CSR Network found that 327 out of 678 mainboard- and Catalist-listed companies communicated their sustainability practices. However, the study highlighted that improvements are needed in reporting quality and level of disclosures.

site_title: Grab unveils pioneer batch of startups in accelerator programme
summary: Grab has unveiled five startups in its 16-week accelerator programme called Velocity, chosen from over 500 applications. The selected startups include Helpling, Tueetor, BookMyShow, Sejasa, and Minutes, which will integrate their services into the Grab app for users in Singapore and Indonesia. The programme aims to assess the startups' potential for collaboration and investment, with Grab setting aside $250 million to invest in Indonesian startups. The selected startups will report on the integration's outcome in January and pitch for potential collaboration.

site_title: Nissan board sacks chairman Carlos Ghosn, says broadcaster
summary: Nissan's board has ousted chairman Carlos Ghosn, citing his arrest on financial misconduct allegations. Ghosn, who was also chairman of Renault and had been pushing for a deeper alliance, remains in detention in Japan. Renault has refused to fire Ghosn, but Mitsubishi Motors plans to remove him as chairman. The move has created uncertainty for the 19-year alliance between Nissan, Renault, and Mitsubishi, with industry officials expressing concern over the potential breakup of the alliance.

site_title: Indian rice samples fail test for Egypt's rice import tender
summary: Indian rice samples failed a cooking test required for Egypt's 2018 rice import tender, with all Chinese samples accepted and one Vietnamese sample accepted and one rejected. This is a setback for India, which has previously exported rice to Egypt but now faces water shortages, leading to an import shift. The samples were tested by a research centre before approval.

site_title: Russia says G20 draft communique project touches trade, global restrictions, WTO
summary: Russia's Deputy Finance Minister Sergei Storchak stated that a draft G20 communique covers trade and WTO issues, amidst disagreements with the US. The document, set to be discussed at the G20 meeting in Argentina, aims to involve all member countries in its drafting. Argentina is pushing for active involvement, while Russia and the US have major disagreements. The communique's focus on trade and global restrictions reflects the current global economic landscape.

site_title: Tesla cuts China car prices to absorb hit from trade war tariffs
summary: Tesla cuts prices of Model X and Model S cars in China by 12-26% to make them more affordable, taking a hit from trade war tariffs. The move aims to boost sales in the world's top car market, where new-energy vehicles are rising in popularity. The price cuts are a strategic shift by the US firm, led by CEO Elon Musk, amid a biting trade war between China and the US.

images.alt_text: Tesla says it will cut prices of its Model X (pictured) & Model S by 12-26 per cent to make the cars more affordable.

site_title: Dolce & Gabbana draws ire of China netizens
summary: Dolce & Gabbana faced backlash in China after a Shanghai fashion show was cancelled due to accusations of racism against designer Stefano Gabbana. Private messages from Gabbana's account were leaked online, containing crude and insulting comments about Chinese people. The brand claimed its accounts were hacked, but many questioned the authenticity of the statement. The incident has sparked widespread outrage in China, with many calling for a boycott of the brand. The controversy highlights the sensitivity of luxury brands operating in China, where online criticism can quickly spread and have severe consequences.

site_title: Singtel retains Premier League broadcast rights until May 2022
summary: Singtel has secured the broadcast rights for the Premier League until May 2022, with a deal from August 2019 to May 2022. The company will keep prices unchanged for the upcoming season, but this may not apply to all three years. The Premier League matches will be available on Singtel's over-the-top service, Cast, and other football options include the Uefa Champions League and the FA Cup. The deal is expected to contribute to the company's revenue growth in the consumer home services segment.

site_title: India, Pakistan make progress on "corridor" for Sikh pilgrims
summary: India and Pakistan have agreed to build a new border entry point and road, known as the "corridor," to facilitate the visit of Sikh pilgrims to a holy site in Pakistan. The Indian government approved the project, and Pakistan's Prime Minister Imran Khan will lay the foundation stone this month. The move is seen as a step towards improved relations between the two nuclear-armed foes, who have fought over the disputed region of Kashmir for years. Thousands of Sikhs already visit the shrine in Pakistan annually.

site_title: Ramba to raise S$10.2m in fresh placement, kills earlier deal with fund
summary: Ramba Energy plans to sell S$10.2 million worth of shares to Eneco Investment, representing 17.6% of its current share base, through a share placement. The placement price is a 50% premium over the previous day's volume-weighted average price. The funds will be used for general working capital. Ramba also cancelled its share and warrant placement agreement with Judah Value Activist Fund, previously announced in May.

site_title: Capitalist Avenue? 'Nein danke!' say Berlin's Karl Marx Allee tenants
summary: Protesters in Berlin oppose the sale of 700 apartments on Karl Marx Allee to Deutsche Wohnen, a property company, amid rising rents. The apartments, built in the socialist style, were once affordable but have seen rents more than double since 2008. Tenant groups aim to gather 170,000 signatures for a referendum to expropriate Deutsche Wohnen's property. The company plans to keep the apartments, with existing contracts remaining valid. The sale sparks concerns about gentrification and a shortage of affordable housing in the city.

site_title: Give Italy's government a chance
summary: Italy's new ruling coalition, comprising the Five Star Movement and the League party, is facing criticism for its budget proposal, which includes a deficit of 2.4% of GDP. Despite concerns about the coalition's popularity and potential unattractive policy positions, it's too early to judge the government. The proposed "citizenship income" plan to provide a monthly payment to job seekers is a step in the right direction, even if its implementation may be challenging. The European Commission should instead focus on pushing for structural reforms in 2020, rather than risking a crisis by blocking the 2019 budget.

site_title: MTI: Growth to let up in 2019; Q3 GDP underwhelms
summary: Singapore's economic growth is expected to ease from this year's pace, with the Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) projecting a 1.5-3.5% growth rate in 2019. The weaker outlook is due to moderating global demand for electronics and the impact of the ongoing trade war. The third-quarter GDP growth rate was 2.2%, below economists' estimates of 2.4%. The MTI expects the main growth driver to shift from manufacturing to services, with outward-oriented sectors expected to slow down. Risks include a further escalation of the trade conflict and a faster-than-expected tightening of global financial conditions.

site_title: Saudi energy minister Falih says kingdom to respond to weak oil demand
