site_title: Bharti's debt woes won't deter Singtel
summary: Singtel Group, which owns a 39.5% stake in Indian telecom carrier Bharti Airtel, remains committed to its long-term investment in the company despite Bharti's mounting debt. Bharti has agreed to two- and three-year loans totaling over $2 billion from banks, amid concerns over weak cash flow and high leverage. Singtel CEO Arthur Lang expressed confidence in Bharti's potential for growth, citing younger demographics and mobile data growth in India. Analysts also point to Bharti's African and tower businesses as monetizable assets to raise funds.

site_title: Innovation wins at Singtel social programme
summary: Singaporean startups AEvice Health and XCLR8 were selected as winners of the Singtel Group Future Makers 2018 program, receiving a total of $110,000 in funding. AEvice Health developed a smart wearable device to monitor and track children's asthma, while XCLR8 created a tele-medicine solution to tackle the ageing population problem. The program, now in its third year, attracted over 3,000 applicants from five countries and aims to nurture innovators to create greater social impact through technology.

site_title: US carrier visits Hong Kong amid heightened China tensions
summary: An American warship and carrier strike group visited Hong Kong, a conciliatory gesture by China ahead of a meeting between US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping at the G20 summit in Argentina. The USS Ronald Reagan arrived with two destroyers and a guided-missile cruiser, following a similar visit by the US Navy two months ago that was cancelled by China. The visit aims to ease tensions between the two countries amid a trade war and failed APEC summit discussions on global trade rules.

site_title: G20 draft communique avoids explicit anti-protectionist pledge
summary: The Group of 20 nations is drafting a communique for its summit in Buenos Aires that avoids an explicit pledge to fight protectionism, a move aimed at avoiding friction between US President Donald Trump and world leaders. The draft communique calls for countries to keep markets open and preserve multilateral trade, but does not include a commitment to combat protectionism. This is a departure from previous years, where anti-protectionist language was included in the G20's trade pledges since its inception in 2008.

site_title: Banyan Tree unit sells 18.6% stake in JV with China Vanke to JV partner for S$78.6m
summary: Banyan Tree Holdings unit Banyan Tree China (BTC) sold 18.6% stake in its joint venture with China Vanke, Banyan Tree Assets (China) Holdings (BTAC), for S$78.6 million. This sale brings BTC's stake in BTAC to 4.2%. BTC retains the right to sell nearly all of the remaining shareholding in BTAC in eight years. The transaction does not affect Banyan Tree Holdings' shares, which closed unchanged at S$0.51.

site_title: Jumbo Group posts 23.8% fall in FY18 profit
summary: Jumbo Group reported a 23.8% decline in net profit for FY18 to S$11 million, down from S$14.5 million a year ago. Revenue rose 5.5% to S$153 million, but expenses increased at a faster pace. The group plans to open new outlets in the next 12 months, including two Jumbo Seafood restaurants and more Tsui Wah Cha Chaan Teng locations. A dividend of 0.7 Singapore cents per share was declared.

site_title: AIMS Financial Service to buy out partner managing AA Reit
summary: AIMS Financial Service Group, a Sydney-based fund manager, plans to buy out its partner AMP Capital, which owns 50% of AA Reit's management entities. The transaction will give AIMS Financial Group a 17.88% stake in the Reit. The sale is expected to close in December and no acquisition amount was disclosed. AMP Capital will retain its 10.26% stake in AA Reit units.

site_title: Singapore shares end higher on Wednesday
summary: Singapore stocks ended higher on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index rising 11.66 points, or 0.4%, to 3,038.65. Losers outnumbered gainers 219 to 159, with about 1.25 billion shares worth S$789.6 million changing hands. Genting Singapore was the most actively traded counter, rising 1.6% to close at S$0.935.

site_title: SoilBuild buys Sembcorp associated firm for S$12.3m
summary: SoilBuild Construction Group acquired Sembcorp EOSM for S$12.3 million, buying 60% of the stake from Sembcorp Industries and other sellers. The acquisition will enhance shareholders' value and support growth in premium precast building components and pre-finished volumetric construction modular components. The purchase was made using internal funds and bank borrowings, and will benefit the group by adopting leading technologies in the construction industry, including "design for manufacturing and assembly" methodology.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close on positive note
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed with gains on Wednesday, reversing early losses due to bargain buying. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.51%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained 0.21% and 0.54%, respectively. Despite energy firms being beaten down by another oil market rout, the market ended on a positive note.

site_title: COE prices for small cars down to $25,000 in latest round of bidding
summary: Certificate of entitlement (COE) premiums for small cars in Singapore's latest round of bidding fell 11.3% to $25,000, the lowest since 2010. The price drop was attributed to a poor economic outlook, rising interest rates, and the new vehicular emissions scheme, which has reduced demand for cars. Commercial vehicle COE prices also dropped 6.8%, while motorcycle COE prices rose 18.4%. Experts point to the economic and emissions factors as contributing to the downward trend in car COE prices.

site_title: ASL Marine to hold third meeting with bondholders over debt restructure
summary: ASL Marine will hold its third meeting with bondholders on Dec 5 to present a revised proposal for the company's S$150 million notes. The bondholders hold two tranches of notes: one series of S$100 million due 2017 at 4.75% and a second series of S$50 million due 2018 at 5.35%. The company's shares last traded at S$0.079.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 15.34 points to 1,695.37. Volume reached 2 billion lots worth RM1.9 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 494 to 322.

site_title: Jar wars: Italian plot to weaken Nutella
summary: Italy's pasta company Barilla is set to launch a chocolate spread, Crema Pan di Stelle, in 2019, targeting Nutella's perceived weakness: palm oil. The new spread, containing sunflower oil, Italian hazelnuts, and cocoa from sustainable farms, aims to challenge Nutella's 54% global market share. Barilla plans to secure a spot on supermarket shelves in Italy, but faces a tough challenge, with industry specialists estimating the cost of securing a spot could be several million euros.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares slip after Wall Street rout
summary: Tokyo shares declined on November 21, 2018, following a sharp fall in US stocks. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index dropped 0.35% and the Topix index fell 0.60%. Fears over weakness in the technology sector contributed to the market downturn.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rebound at open
summary: European stock markets rebounded at the start of trading on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index gaining 0.2% to 6,958.12 points, Frankfurt's DAX 30 climbing 0.7% to 11,138.25 points, and Paris's CAC 40 winning 0.5% to 4,949.72 points. The rebound follows heavy losses in oil prices. The gains are attributed to a rebound in the mining and healthcare sectors.

site_title: Singapore startup Mogul.sg unveils keyword-based property search portal
summary: Singapore startup Mogul.sg launches a keyword-based property search portal, using a database of over 5,000 custom keywords to filter property listings. The ad-free system utilizes Singapore Land Authority's OneMap geospatial data, simplifying the search process and making it easier for property owners and seekers to match. Mogul.sg charges agents for listing properties, with basic and premium membership tiers offering varying features and fees.

site_title: Cosco-PSA joint venture terminal to add two new berths
summary: Cosco Shipping Ports has signed a memorandum of understanding with PSA Corporation to launch two new berths at their joint venture container terminal. The new berths will increase the terminal's capacity to five million TEUs, up from three million TEUs, and are expected to enhance productivity and service capability. Automated yard technology will support the new berths, allowing for more efficient berthing arrangements and improved service quality. The expansion is part of the Cosco-PSA Terminal's ongoing efforts to increase its efficiency and competitiveness in the container terminal market.

site_title: Trump thanks Saudi Arabia for lower oil prices
summary: US President Donald Trump thanked Saudi Arabia for lower oil prices, stating they've been a "big Tax Cut for America and the World." The remarks came after he pledged to remain a "steadfast partner" of the kingdom despite the murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi. Trump claimed he kept oil prices low by supporting Saudi Arabia, which may be seen as a move to prevent them from lowering output at the December Opec meeting.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump thanked Saudi Arabia Wednesday for lower oil prices - a day after pledging the US would remain a "steadfast partner" of the kingdom despite the murder of a dissident journalist.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: NOBLE Group will proceed with its restructuring plan despite a police probe, citing previously disclosed timelines. Singapore and Kazakhstan signed a bilateral investment treaty to boost investment flows. Hong Kong, Tokyo, and Singapore ranked top finance spots in Asia, according to a Colliers report. Swissco Offshore Pte Ltd received a six-month extension of judicial management. Cosco-PSA Terminal will add two new berths, increasing capacity to 5 million TEUs. Singapore shares rose 0.4% on Wednesday, while global markets were impacted by US tariffs on Vietnam and the Asian garment industry.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher as oil prices, tech stocks recover
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 76.01 points, or 0.31%, to 24,541.65, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite gaining 15.85 and 76.68 points, respectively. The recovery was driven by Apple's bounce-back and steadying oil prices.

images.alt_text: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday after two days of heavy selling as Apple Inc and other major technology stocks bounced back and oil prices steadied.

site_title: Alibaba suffers rare 'down round' investment as Babytree's HK IPO prices low
summary: Alibaba's investment in Babytree Group, a parenting website operator, has resulted in a rare "down round" for the tech firm. Babytree's Hong Kong IPO priced at HK$6.80 (US$1.20) per share, valuing the company at US$1.5 billion, lower than its initial valuation of US$2 billion. This marks a rare instance of a tech-related firm suffering a down round following new investment, with 11.8% of global venture capital deals experiencing the same issue this year.

site_title: China's Pinduoduo gives silent class in short defence
summary: Pinduoduo, a US$26 billion Chinese e-commerce company, has deflected accusations of book-fiddling from activist research outfit Blue Orca Capital. Despite the allegations, Pinduoduo's stock has risen 35% since the report was published, with shares now worth US$23 each, three times more than Blue Orca claims. The company's quarterly earnings call revealed a 697% increase in revenue and a 396% rise in net loss, exceeding analysts' expectations. Pinduoduo's silence on the matter has effectively silenced the negative story, with high-profile investors backing the company's resistance.

site_title: Trump sticks by Saudi Crown Prince
summary: President Donald Trump reaffirmed his support for Saudi Arabia, stating that the murder of Jamal Khashoggi won't jeopardize the US relationship with the world's largest oil supplier. Trump cited the kingdom's strategic importance, saying higher oil prices would result if the US broke ties. The move was met with criticism from lawmakers, who accused Trump of showing subservience to the Saudi monarchy. The Senate is now likely to consider a human rights-related law that could impose sanctions on Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman if the prince is deemed responsible for Khashoggi's death.

site_title: Japan says ready to work for stability of Nissan-Renault alliance
summary: Japan is ready to work for the stability of the Nissan-Renault alliance following the arrest of common chairman Carlos Ghosn, who is accused of years of wrongdoing. Nissan claims Ghosn misused company funds and understated his compensation. Japanese prosecutors are considering bringing a case against the Japanese automaker, citing the mis-statement as also affecting Nissan. The alliance is a symbol of Franco-Japanese industrial success, with Japan's top government spokesman calling for a stable relationship between the three automakers. Ghosn's removal from post is planned for Thursday.

site_title: Australia shares end lower amid global equity sell-off; NZ also falls
summary: Australian shares closed at their lowest level since February 2017, falling 0.51% or 29.00 points to 5,642.800, amid global equity sell-off and a plunge in oil prices. Miners, including BHP and Rio Tinto, dropped 2.9% and 3.3% respectively. Financial stocks recovered late in trade, with Commonwealth Bank gaining 1.2%. New Zealand's benchmark index slipped 0.55% as dairy giant a2 Milk Co fell 3.4%.

site_title: Mumbai port under probe after PSA complaint: sources
summary: India's Competition Commission has launched a probe into alleged anti-competitive practices by Maersk and DP World at the Mumbai port, following a complaint by Singapore's PSA International. The probe centers around inter-terminal transfers, with PSA alleging that Maersk and DP World imposed higher fees on shipping companies that used the PSA terminal, hindering its growth. The regulator has asked its investigations unit to submit a report by January, which will also examine the role of individual company executives.

site_title: Ghosn custody extended as crisis deepens at Nissan
summary: Japanese authorities have extended Nissan Chairman Carlos Ghosn's detention by 10 days amid allegations of financial misconduct. Prosecutors are investigating under-reporting of Ghosn's package by about five billion yen (S$60.8 million). Ghosn, who turned around Nissan's fortunes, faces charges that could also apply to the car giant itself. The crisis has sent shockwaves through the global car sector and corporate Japan, with Renault sticking with Ghosn as CEO despite the scandal. Ghosn's fate appears sealed, with his hand-picked replacement, Hiroto Saikawa, launching a broadside against him.

site_title: Facebook services tripped up by server problem
summary: Facebook services experienced a server problem, causing users to have trouble accessing the social network and its other applications, such as Instagram, for several hours. The issue affected most parts of the world, particularly in North America, Europe, and Asia, and was resolved after a degraded experience for users. The incident occurred just days after Facebook faced criticism over its handling of misinformation campaigns and its hiring of a consultancy to address the issue. Facebook has over 2.2 billion active users worldwide and apologized for the inconvenience caused by the outage.

site_title: Newest bubble in China stocks
summary: Chinese investors are betting on tech park operators as President Xi Jinping plans to set up a Shanghai stock trading board for technology companies. Shares in Shanghai Shibei Hi-Tech Co have more than tripled since Xi's announcement on November 5. Other park developers in Beijing and Tianjin have also seen a rally, with speculation driving the gains. Analysts are cautious, citing a lack of details about the planned board.

site_title: FairPrice and Courts among 41 Top Influential Brands
summary: Forty-one influential brands, including FairPrice and Courts, were recognized for their branding strength and engagement with consumers in Asia. The Asia's "Top Influential Brands" award covers over 100 categories and was based on a survey of over 4,000 consumers, primarily women aged 26-50. Winners were praised for prioritizing consumer needs and adapting to the digital age. The award also honored nine "Top Employer Brands" and six "Top CEOs Of The Year" from Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, and the Philippines.

site_title: Saudi Arabia launches project to boost sustainable tourism-related jobs
summary: Saudi Arabia has launched the Wadi Al Disah Development project, aiming to boost sustainable tourism-related jobs. The project, valued at over 11 billion riyals (S$4 billion), will be developed within the Prince Mohammed bin Salman Natural Reserve. The initiative is part of Saudi King Salman's domestic tour, where he has inaugurated 151 projects in the northern province of Tabuk. The project's focus on sustainable tourism is expected to make a positive impact on the environment, society, and economy.

site_title: Tencent-backed travel site raises US$180m in Hong Kong IPO
summary: Tongcheng-Elong Holdings Ltd, a Chinese travel website backed by Tencent Holdings, raised US$180 million in its Hong Kong IPO after pricing its shares at HK$9.80 apiece. The company's fundraising goal was reduced from US$800 million to US$1 billion due to market conditions, which have seen the New York Stock Exchange's FANG+ index fall 7.5% over three days. This is the latest in a series of Hong Kong IPOs to struggle, with other companies including parenting website Babytree Group also raising funds at the bottom of their marketed ranges.

site_title: Trump tweets 'good first step' in naming historian for headline dinner
summary: President Donald Trump tweeted that the White House Correspondents' Association's decision to feature a historian at its annual dinner is a "good first step" and a departure from the usual comedian. He referenced last year's comedian, Michelle Wolf, who he deemed "bombed badly." This marks the first time in decades that a historian will be featured at the event, which will take place in April next year. Trump also hinted he might attend the event, saying "Maybe I will go?"

site_title: Seoul: Stocks cut losses on institutional buying; won down 0.5%
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index closed 0.29% lower at 2,076.55, erasing earlier losses due to institutional buying. The won weakened 0.5% against the dollar, while bond yields gained. Local institutions bought 294.8 billion won worth of shares, and exports rose 5.7% in annual terms, while imports grew 12.8%. The Kospi is down 15.6% so far this year.

site_title: Hong Kong, Tokyo, Singapore choice spots in Asia for finance: Colliers report
summary: Hong Kong, Tokyo, and Singapore are the top three locations in Asia for finance, according to a report by Colliers International. Hong Kong ranked first with a score of 61%, followed by Tokyo and Singapore with scores of 55% and 55%, respectively. The report highlights the cities' strong socio-economic factors, including employment and wealth, as well as their stable and pro-business environments. Singapore's human factors, such as personal tax and living quality, also contributed to its high ranking.

site_title: MAS unveils Year of the Boar Chinese almanac coins
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has unveiled the 2019 Year of the Boar Chinese almanac coins, the third issue in a 12-year series. The coins feature a boar in a Singaporean park setting and will be available in 10 metallic compositions, ranging from S$2 to S$200. Special premium sets will also be available, with coins to be issued on January 1 and sold until December 16.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at Wednesday's open; STI down 0.54% to 3,010.74
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index retreating 0.54% to 3,010.74. US tech stocks fell overnight, causing the index to decline. Losers outnumbered gainers 86 to 37, with Ezion Holdings and DBS Group Holdings being among the most heavily traded stocks. The decline follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with traders brushing off new Trump threats to extend the rally.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wed trading at 3,039.17, up 0.4% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Wednesday, advancing 12.18 points, or 0.4%, to 3,039.17 at 1pm. Losers outnumbered gainers 173 to 118, with about 835.1 million shares changing hands. Active stocks included Best World (up 8.7%), OCBC (up 1.2%), and Nam Cheong (flat).

site_title: Stocks to watch: China Jinjiang Environment, Sunpower, Keppel Infrastructure Trust, Ace Achieve Infocom
summary: Stocks to watch: China Jinjiang Environment, Sunpower, Keppel Infrastructure Trust, Ace Achieve Infocom. China Jinjiang Environment secured a concession for a waste-to-energy facility, while Sunpower clarified it's not in breach of loan provisions after unauthorized transfers of shares. Keppel Infrastructure Trust's Australian electricity interconnector subsidiary Basslink triggered a technical default due to delayed facility fees. Ace Achieve Infocom's trading remains halted pending an announcement.

site_title: India is about to become the world's biggest sugar producer
summary: India is expected to surpass Brazil as the world's largest sugar producer, with a forecasted 35.9 million metric tons of production, a 5.2% increase from last season. Brazil's output is predicted to decline 21% to 30.6 million tons due to adverse weather and ethanol production. Global production is forecast to fall 4.5% to 185.9 million tons. India's increased production will lead to a rise in global inventory, as the country engages in "massive stock building".

images.alt_text: Sugarcane is harvested at a farm near Biosev SA's Santa Elisa sugar mill in Sertaozinho, Brazil.

site_title: Nasa to review workplace safety culture at SpaceX, Boeing
summary: US space agency NASA plans to review the workplace safety culture at SpaceX and Boeing Co, two companies selected to send astronauts to the International Space Station. The review, set to begin, aims to ensure adherence to safety requirements, including a drug-free environment. The move comes after concerns raised about SpaceX's founder Elon Musk's recent behavior, including drinking whiskey and smoking marijuana during a live podcast. Both Boeing and SpaceX have stated their commitment to safety and quality, with SpaceX already promoting a safe work environment.

site_title: WebEx veteran's streaming business raises US$70m in series C funding: source
summary: Agora.io, a mobile video and audio call service operator, has raised US$70 million in a series C funding round led by Coatue Management. This brings total funding to US$125 million, with existing investors also participating. Founded by Tony Zhao, a former WebEx engineer, Agora processes 10 billion minutes of live communications monthly for customers like Xiaomi and Momo. The deal highlights Coatue's tech-focused investments, including Uber and Snap.

site_title: Where does Noble probe leave US$3.5b restructuring?
summary: Noble Group's $3.5 billion restructuring deal hangs in the balance after Singaporean authorities launched a multi-agency investigation into the Asia-focused commodity trader. The probe, which includes a review by Singapore's white-collar crime squad, may delay the restructuring deal, which is due to be completed by November 27. The deal's completion is crucial for Noble's creditors, including hedge funds and Deutsche Bank, as it would allow them to take control of the company. Noble Group and its creditors will work to persuade the regulators to approve the deal, but a failure could lead to insolvency and wipe out shareholders and perpetual bondholders.

site_title: Dotcom ghosts haunt emerging stocks as tech profits stall
summary: Developing-nation technology stocks are experiencing a bear market, with earnings disappointing and analysts slashing profit estimates. The MSCI emerging-market tech gauge has slumped 29% since January, mirroring the dot-com bubble in the late 1990s. Analysts predict the slump may continue for another year, citing deepening trade tensions and low valuations. Companies like Chinese semiconductors and Alibaba Group Holdings are particularly vulnerable, while others like Tencent Holdings and NetEase Inc are undervalued but may not see a rebound.

site_title: Singapore tech startup Sendhelper raises S$610,000 in seed funding
summary: Singapore-based tech startup Sendhelper raised S$610,000 in seed funding led by Captii Ventures. The mobile e-commerce platform enables users to book and pay for home services. Sendhelper plans to launch Sendjobs, a B2B platform matching employers with jobseekers for non-executive positions, using AI technology. The company has seen significant sales growth, with over S$2 million in sales since its launch, and aims to expand globally, including markets in the US, Canada, Australia, and South America.

site_title: Singapore and Kazakhstan sign bilateral investment treaty
summary: Singapore and Kazakhstan signed a bilateral investment treaty (BIT) to strengthen their economic partnership, promoting greater investment flows and protecting investors' interests. The treaty grants non-discriminatory treatment, fair and equitable treatment, and full protection from illegal expropriation. The agreement complements the existing Avoidance of Double Taxation Agreement and aims to facilitate companies venturing into each other's markets. Total bilateral trade in goods between the two countries was S$133.6 million in 2017, with opportunities for Singapore companies to venture into Kazakhstan's growing urban middle class and key industries such as IT and logistics.

images.alt_text: (From left) Ambassador to the Republic of Singapore, His Excellency Usen Suleimen, His Excellency Bakytzhan Sagintayev, Prime Minister of the Republic of Kazakhstan, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Ambassador to the Republic of Kazakhstan, Zulkifli Baharudin at the Istana, on Nov 21, 2018.

site_title: Swissco judicial managers receive extension of time
summary: The Singapore High Court has granted extensions of time for judicial managers of Swissco Holdings and its subsidiary, Swissco Offshore Pte Ltd, to carry out their tasks. The judicial management period for Swissco Offshore Pte Ltd has been extended by six months to July 31, 2019, from January 31, 2019. The deadline for submitting proposals for offshore support vessel companies has also been extended to March 30, 2019.

site_title: Tokyo stocks open lower after Wall Street rout
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on November 21, 2018, due to a sharp fall in US stocks, with fears of weakness in the technology sector affecting other sectors. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 1.49% and the Topix index fell 1.58%. The declines were attributed to concerns over the technology sector, which led to a broader market downturn.

site_title: Trump calls Fed a 'problem', says he wants lower interest rates
summary: US President Donald Trump criticized the Federal Reserve, calling it a "problem" and urging for lower interest rates. The criticism comes amid a slowing housing market and concerns over global growth and the US-China trade war. The Fed held interest rates steady in its last meeting but is expected to raise rates in December. Trump's comments break a two-decade tradition of respecting the Fed's independence. The Fed aims to keep inflation near 2% and moderate economic growth, which is forecast to slow following the effects of Trump tax cuts and government spending increases.

site_title: US accuses China of continuing IP theft amid trade war
summary: The US has released a 53-page report accusing China of continuing a state-backed campaign of intellectual property and technology theft despite the ongoing trade war. The report, released just days before a meeting between US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping, claims China has not altered its practices and has taken further unreasonable actions. The US accuses China of cyber-attacks on American companies, including a possible "malicious" campaign by China Telecom to hijack internet traffic. China has made only incremental changes to its restrictions on foreign investment, and Chinese foreign-direct investment in the US has become more focused on tech startups.

site_title: US stock market's slide is flashing a warning about the economy
summary: The US stock market has turned negative for the year, with the S&P 500 closing at 2,642, down 1.8% on Tuesday. Despite a strong US economy, with low unemployment and rising wages, the stock market is flashing a warning sign. Retail stocks have been hit due to rising costs and higher wages cutting into profits, while commodities have been pummeled by the prospect of weaker global demand. The sell-off doesn't necessarily mean a recession, but it could portend problems, particularly with the US economy vulnerable to a range of risks, including a slowing global economy.

site_title: Renault and Nissan lurch towards war
summary: Renault and Nissan are embroiled in a dispute after Nissan CEO Hiroto Saikawa announced a police investigation into the group's founder, Carlos Ghosn, and plans to fire him as chairman. Renault has refused to comment on the allegations, with Ghosn remaining chairman and CEO despite being temporarily incapacitated. The dispute raises concerns about the future of the Renault-Nissan-Mitsubishi alliance, with potential implications for the global carmaking industry. The situation has escalated to national levels, with France and Japan taking an interest in protecting their respective interests in the company.

site_title: Developers now have to screen buyers to prevent money laundering under new Bill
summary: Singapore's Parliament has passed a Bill requiring developers to screen buyers for money laundering and terrorism financing. The Developers (Anti-Money Laundering and Terrorism Financing) Bill, which aligns with international standards, mandates developers to conduct due diligence checks, keep records, and report suspicious transactions. The changes will bring Singapore's anti-money laundering regime in line with global standards, with the aim of preventing illicit activities in the real estate sector.

site_title: Noble to stick with restructuring deadline despite launch of police probe
summary: NOBLE Group announced it will continue to work towards its restructuring deadline despite a police probe and investigations by Singapore law enforcement and regulators. The probes are related to suspected false statements and non-compliance with accounting standards. NOBLE has suspended trading of its shares and plans to re-list as a restructured entity by November 27. The company will cooperate with the investigations, which have sought documents and information from 2012 to 2017. NOBLE has previously disclosed its restructuring timeline and will not be deterred by the ongoing investigations.

images.alt_text: NOBLE Group will continue to work towards implementing its proposed restructuring within previously disclosed timelines despite the launch of investigations by Singapore law enforcement and regulators, the commodities trading company announced on Wednesday morning.

site_title: Clamping down on money laundering
summary: Money laundering continues to be a global issue, with the European Union and Asia facing challenges in coordinating efforts to combat it. Recent scandals, such as the Danske Bank scandal and the 1MDB scandal, highlight the need for effective anti-money laundering measures. The rise of cryptocurrencies and cyber threats has further complicated the issue, with regulators struggling to keep pace with emerging technologies. To address these challenges, experts emphasize the importance of having experienced practitioners who can leverage technology to support intelligence and make professional judgments, rather than relying solely on technology.

site_title: Malaysia claim of Goldman cheating is a bit rich
summary: Malaysia is seeking a refund of $600 million in fees and revenue from Goldman Sachs, citing a "cheating" by the investment bank in arranging bonds for the 1MDB fund. The scandal occurred during the administration of former Prime Minister Najib Razak, who gave Jho Low, a young financier, significant influence over the fund. Goldman's global compliance committee overlooked red flags, but the bank claims it was deceived by its own employees. The US Department of Justice has said $4.5 billion was misappropriated from 1MDB, and some fines may be recovered and shared with Malaysia.

site_title: Singapore's Sea reports wider loss on e-commerce investment
summary: Sea Ltd, operator of Southeast Asia's biggest gaming platform, reported a wider third-quarter loss of US$218 million due to rising investments in e-commerce unit Shopee. Total revenue rose to US$204.9 million, with digital entertainment unit Garena increasing revenue by 41% and e-commerce unit Shopee by 29%. The company raised its 2018 forecast for total adjusted revenue to between US$930 million and US$970 million. Group chief strategy officer Alan Hellawell will depart the company, and Sea has promoted Terry Zhao as president of Garena.

site_title: Investors flee oil as stock rout, Opec doubts turn up pressure
summary: Investors fled oil, driving prices down 30% since October, amid a global sell-off in stocks, rising doubts on OPEC's commitment to production cuts, and escalating trade tensions. Crude prices fell 6% in New York and London, with US President Donald Trump's comments on Saudi Arabia's oil production sparking concerns. OPEC allies are waiting to see how the market develops before making decisions on output cuts, and experts predict downward pressure on oil demand due to slowing growth in the US and China.

site_title: Foreign investors find trophy properties in unlikely US cities
summary: Foreign investors are shifting their focus to US cities outside the major metropolitan areas, with Canada, China, and Germany topping the list of foreign buyers of US commercial real estate this year. Cities such as Denver, Phoenix, Philadelphia, and the suburbs of Atlanta have attracted investment, driven by growing economic opportunities and rising yields. The trend is expected to continue, with Philadelphia experiencing a 516% growth in the first three quarters of the year.

site_title: Trump submits written responses to some of Mueller's questions
summary: US President Donald Trump's legal team submitted written responses to some questions from special counsel Robert Mueller's Russia investigation. The answers cover Russia-related topics and whether Trump colluded with Russia and his campaign, but not obstruction of justice. Trump's lawyers claim the questions raised constitutional issues and were beyond the scope of a legitimate inquiry. The written questions stop short of the in-person interview Mueller requested, and it's unclear if Mueller will be satisfied with the written answers. Trump claims he wrote the responses himself and didn't take long to do so.

site_title: Sunpower: No loan provisions breached after 2 substantial shareholders pledged their shares for personal loans
summary: Sunpower Group has clarified that it is not in breach of any loan provisions after two substantial shareholders, Guo Hongxin and Ma Ming, pledged their shares for personal loans. The shareholders had entered into loan agreements with America 2030 Capital, but the company maintains that these are personal borrowings, not group borrowings, and do not affect its ability to continue as a going concern. The shares transferred without authority are below the threshold stipulated in the bond agreements.

site_title: Healthcare firms Walgreens and Humana may regret a half-deal
summary: Healthcare firms Walgreens and Humana are reportedly discussing a deal that would involve taking sizeable stakes in each other, rather than a full merger. This partnership would allow them to share costs and revenue, but may not offer much protection in a rapidly evolving market. Unlike CVS's $69 billion megamerger, the deal would lack a key component: a giant pharmacy benefit manager to keep drug costs down. The partnership also faces challenges, including differing goals and executive approvals. This may render them less nimble and committed than vertically integrated rivals.

site_title: PSA complaint 'leads to antitrust probe at Mumbai port'
summary: India's antitrust regulator, the Competition Commission of India, has ordered a probe into alleged anti-competitive practices by Maersk and DP World at Mumbai's Jawaharlal Nehru Port Trust, following a complaint by Singapore's PSA International. The complaint alleges that Maersk and DP World colluded to prevent PSA's terminal from growing by charging higher fees for handling containers that arrived at the PSA terminal. The probe, which will be completed by January, aims to determine whether Maersk and DP World's actions created entry barriers for PSA and had an anti-competitive effect.

site_title: Abstain from romaine: US, Canada warn on E.coli in lettuce
summary: US and Canadian public health officials warned against eating romaine lettuce due to an E. coli outbreak affecting 50 people, including 13 hospitalized. The outbreak, which occurred between Oct 8 and 31, has no reported deaths. Symptoms include fever, stomach cramps, vomiting, and bloody diarrhea. The source of the tainted lettuce is unknown. Consumers are advised to discard romaine lettuce and sanitize storage areas. The outbreak is unrelated to a previous multi-state E. coli infection linked to romaine lettuce that killed five people.

site_title: Uber to withhold Mexico driver taxes in landmark deal
summary: Uber has agreed to a landmark deal with the Mexican government, where the company will withhold taxes from drivers' earnings in a pilot program starting next week. The program will collect an 8% value-added tax and up to 9% income tax, depending on the number of rides completed each month. The move aims to boost tax collection in Mexico, which has struggled with low tax compliance. Uber's participation is seen as a key step in the country's efforts to crack down on tax evasion, with the program expected to launch early 2019.

images.alt_text: After months of setbacks, Mexico is now on the cusp of rolling out an automatic tax payment system that forms a key part of its effort to crack down on evasion.

site_title: Asia: Stocks slide, oil stymied as growth woes grip global markets
summary: Asian stocks fell 0.55% due to US economic growth concerns, while crude oil struggled after a sharp slide. The US dollar rallied from a two-week low due to heightened risk aversion. In Europe, stocks declined with bank and healthcare sectors weighing down, while US-EU tariffs remained a focus. The US stock market edged down from records despite reaching fresh highs.

site_title: Tech rout putting Silicon Valley on edge
summary: Silicon Valley is experiencing a growing sense of unease as the recent 13% decline in the Nasdaq is expected to worsen, potentially driving down private start-up valuations. Even in the heart of the tech industry, doubts are creeping in, with some entrepreneurs and investors bracing for a correction. Despite the optimism, concerns about the sector's future are fueled by the causes of the downturn, including privacy issues, demand slumps, and the US-China trade war.

site_title: Renault names Thierry Bollore interim leader after Carlos Ghosn's arrest
summary: Renault named Thierry Bollore interim leader after Carlos Ghosn's arrest in Japan, where Ghosn faces allegations of financial impropriety. Bollore, who has been Ghosn's heir apparent, was named interim deputy CEO with the same powers as Ghosn. The board declined to dismiss Ghosn, but requested information from Nissan regarding internal investigations. The move casts doubt over the future of the Renault-Nissan-Mitsubishi Alliance, which was held together by Ghosn's presence.

site_title: Nissan shares slump as Ghosn's arrest rocks global alliance
summary: Nissan shares plummeted 6% after Chairman Carlos Ghosn's arrest, throwing doubt on the company's future and global alliance. An internal investigation revealed Ghosn engaged in personal use of company money and under-reported earnings for years. He will be fired from Nissan's board this week. The arrest sent shockwaves through the business world, affecting Nissan's stock price and future prospects.

site_title: China-bashing agenda will have bipartisan support in Washington
summary: The US midterm election has resulted in a stalemate, with the Democrats regaining control of the House of Representatives but the Republicans maintaining control of the Senate. Despite this, both parties are expected to work together on a bipartisan China-bashing agenda, with President Trump's tough stance on China gaining support from many Democrats who have long called for a more aggressive approach. This unexpected bipartisan support could lead to legislative and policy gridlock, but also presents an opportunity for cooperation on trade policy and the US-China relationship.

site_title: Australia's central bank governor raps banks for misdeeds
summary: Australian Reserve Bank Governor Philip Lowe criticized the country's banks for their misdeeds, saying strong penalties are required to punish wrongdoing but cautioning that over-regulation could harm the economy. Lowe stated that banks must balance risk-taking with good behavior, and that a balance needs to be struck to avoid unintended consequences. He also noted that stagnant real wage growth has hurt living standards, but the economy remains strong, with a record low interest rate and rapid population growth.

site_title: GE shakes up leadership in ailing power business
summary: General Electric (GE) has shaken up its ailing power business, appointing John Rice, a 39-year veteran, as chairman of gas power, and Scott Strazik as CEO of the division, overseeing both equipment sales and services. The changes aim to restore profits at GE Power, which has seen profits plunge due to declining demand for gas turbines. New CEO Larry Culp's efforts to reduce debt and restore profits have led to these changes, but analysts remain cautious about a quick improvement in power's performance.

site_title: Victoria's Secret appoints new CEO to uplift sagging results
summary: Victoria's Secret appoints John Mehas as new lingerie CEO to boost sagging results, replacing Jan Singer who resigned amid criticism for idealizing glamazonian femininity and reluctance to feature larger and transgender models. The new CEO's appointment comes after the company reported a net loss of $42.8 million in the third quarter, down from $86 million last year. Leslie Wexner, L Brands chairman and CEO, expressed confidence that Mehas will lead the brand to deliver products and experiences that resonate with women globally.

site_title: Italian police confiscate Mafia villas in Rome swoop
summary: Italian police confiscated eight luxury villas in Rome in a dawn raid involving 600 officers, targeting the Casamonica Mafia clan. The villas, built in areas of archaeological interest, will be demolished by the end of the year. The operation marks an end to years of illegality and sends a strong statement to the clan. City mayor Virginia Raggi, who oversaw the raid, hailed it as an historic day for Rome, putting an end to the clan's influence in the city. The confiscation follows previous raids in July that arrested 33 members of the group.

site_title: Exporters of AI tech fretting over proposed curbs
summary: The Trump administration proposes new regulations on the export of US artificial intelligence (AI) technology to foreign governments or researchers in certain countries, including China. US companies like Amazon, Apple, and Google may need to obtain licenses before selling their products and services to foreign governments or partnering with researchers in China. The rules aim to protect national security without hindering the US commercial sector's ability to keep pace with international advances. The proposal, made at the request of Congress, reflects growing concerns over China's investment in the AI industry.

site_title: Fishing nations rue the one that got away - saving the bigeye tuna
summary: Fishing nations failed to agree on catch limits for the bigeye tuna, a species threatened by severe overfishing, at the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) meeting in Dubrovnik, Croatia. Despite warnings from scientists that stocks could crash within a decade, countries such as Brazil and Senegal resisted quotas, citing commercial interests. The current catch limit of 65,000 tonnes was extended, and a partial moratorium on fishing devices was maintained, sparking concerns about the species' future recovery.

site_title: Medinex eyes all-placement Catalist IPO
summary: Medinex, a Singapore-based medical support services company, is seeking an initial public offering (IPO) on the Catalist board of the Singapore Exchange to raise funds for expansion and acquisitions. The IPO will feature new shares and vendor shares, with Medinex's controlling shareholders planning to use the funds for business expansion, joint ventures, and marketing. The company may acquire Ark Leadership, a human resources consulting services group, with a right of first refusal. Medinex reported a net profit of S$1.06 million for half-year 2018, with plans to distribute at least 70% of its profit as dividends.

site_title: Singapore investors unfazed by market volatility: poll
summary: Singapore investors remain optimistic despite market volatility, with 40% considering investing more in the face of increased volatility. Only 12% believe global economic growth and geopolitical uncertainty pose a risk to their investments. Despite top concerns over inflation, economic instability, and trade wars, 60% of investors see buying opportunities in the current market environment. The survey, conducted by Legg Mason Global Asset Management, highlights a "home bias" among Singapore investors, with 40% preferring domestic investments over international ones.

site_title: Europe: Sliding banks, tumbling tech drag stocks to three-week low
summary: European stocks fell to a three-week low on Tuesday, with banks weighing heavily on concerns about slowing economic growth, fading earnings momentum, and Italy's budget dispute. The pan-European STOXX 600 dropped 0.7%, with Germany's DAX and Britain's FTSE 100 also declining. European bank stocks index sank 1.8%, with Italian lenders suffering their worst fall in five weeks, while tech stocks fell 2% due to concerns about iPhone growth at Apple. Analysts expect low equity returns across all regions for 2019 due to slow profit growth and deteriorating growth and inflation mix.

site_title: Trumpism and the politics of division in the US
summary: US President Donald Trump's policies have exacerbated economic divisions in the US, particularly between rich metropolitan areas and lagging regions. Amazon's headquarters criteria, which prioritize areas with high-skilled workers, further reinforce this divide. Trump's base in rural areas, which voted for him in 2016, has turned red, while his growing regions have turned blue. The article argues that economic anxiety and racial antagonism are driving this division, and that the regional economic divide is becoming a chasm in US politics, making it challenging to bridge.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokerages maintain their forecasts for mm2 Asia, with Maybank Kim Eng setting a target price of S$0.57 and "buy" recommendation. The company's strong production pipeline, including Netflix work, is expected to contribute to Q4 growth. CDL Hospitality Trust is also recommended, with CGS-CIMB targeting S$1.56 after acquiring a 95% stake in a 4-star hotel in Italy for S$63.6 million. Both companies are expected to be DPU-accretive following the acquisitions.

site_title: Give time to blockchain to make a difference in everyday lives
summary: Blockchain technology, despite its ebbs and flows, has the potential to significantly impact everyday lives, but patience is key to its widespread adoption. The technology, which has been in the early stages of development, has made significant progress, including the launch of Bitcoin in 2009, the first major bitcoin security breach in 2010, and the development of Ethereum's smart contracts in 2014. While the industry has seen numerous failed projects and a decrease in interest, experts believe that blockchain's true potential will be unleashed as production systems solve niche problems and transform various industries, with a potential annual business value of over $3 trillion by 2030.

site_title: Asian equities shaken by US tech tremors
summary: Asian equities fell on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing 1.24% lower due to a US tech slump. Singapore shares were among the worst hit, with financials and technology stocks leading the decline. The tech sector saw heavy losses, with companies like Precision manufacturer UMS Holdings and electronics manufacturing services provider Venture Corp dropping 3.97% and 1.87%, respectively. The US tech rout was sparked by reports of production cuts and controversies over customer data, and there is rising expectation of a détente at the G20 Trump-Xi meeting.

site_title: More scope for Singapore, Jiangsu firms to collaborate
summary: Singapore and Jiangsu province in China signed 13 memoranda of understanding to boost cooperation in areas like trade, logistics, and financial services. Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the Republic's commitment to partnering Jiangsu in supporting China's economic priorities, such as the Belt and Road Initiative. Singapore firms will have more opportunities to collaborate with Jiangsu companies, with a focus on exploring coastal cities and developing industrial parks in South-east Asia. The agreements aim to facilitate investments and partnerships between Singapore and Jiangsu in fintech, innovation, and startup spaces.

site_title: SGX lays out guidelines for listed companies issuing initial coin offerings
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has outlined guidelines for listed companies planning to conduct initial coin offerings (ICOs), requiring them to make clear disclosures about the ICO, accounting treatments, and risks involved. The guidelines cover only the company and not the tokens or their holders, and listed issuers must consult SGX RegCo, provide legal and auditor opinions, and carry out checks to address money laundering and terrorist financing risks. The regulator aims to ensure relevant disclosures are made and that information is clear and complete for investors.

site_title: Key players in Nissan chairman Carlos Ghosn's downfall
summary: Nissan Motor Co has accused longtime leader Carlos Ghosn of understating his compensation in securities filings and using company assets for personal use, sparking a 20-year-old alliance between Nissan and Renault SA to unravel. The allegations have thrown Nissan into chaos, with Ghosn's downfall marking a significant shift in the company's leadership. The exact extent of Ghosn's alleged misconduct remains unclear, but the incident has raised questions about corporate governance and the consequences of such actions. Ghosn's future at Nissan remains uncertain, and the company's future with Renault is now in jeopardy.

images.alt_text: Nissan Motor Co has made shocking allegations against its longtime leader Carlos Ghosn, accusing him of understating his compensation in securities filings and using company assets for personal use.

site_title: IMF sees Australia risks tilt to downside on China and rising trade tensions
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has warned that Australia's economy is at risk of a downturn due to a deteriorating global outlook, particularly with weaker-than-expected growth in China and rising trade tensions. The IMF urges the Reserve Bank of Australia to keep interest rates low, citing a continued expansion of the economy and gradual upward pressure on wages and prices. Despite recent strong growth and declining unemployment, the IMF advises against withdrawing macroeconomic policy support due to remaining slack in the economy.

site_title: Seeking life's lessons in books, podcasts - Wall St elites reflect
summary: Wall Street elites have found solace in self-improvement resources such as books and podcasts, with 80% of Shane Parrish's blog followers being high-net-worth investors. Parrish, a former cybersecurity expert, wrote about the importance of deep learning, wide thinking, and strategic reading to improve decision-making skills. His blog attracted hedge fund titans and mutual fund executives seeking personal growth amidst the 2008 financial crisis. This trend highlights the growing interest in personal development among wealthy investors.

site_title: Incoming Petrobras CEO rules out privatisation
summary: Brazil's incoming Petrobras CEO, Roberto Castello Branco, has ruled out privatizing the state-run oil company, but plans to sell non-core assets and focus on oil exploration and production. Branco, a University of Chicago-trained economist, was appointed by President-elect Jair Bolsonaro, who has a market-friendly approach to governance. Branco aims to cut costs, eliminate downstream operations, and maximize Petrobras' potential in the pre-salt deep-water area. The move is seen as a positive step by investors, who expect the company to continue its deleveraging process and divestment program under Branco's tenure.

site_title: Euro weakens as market sell-off hits sentiment
summary: The euro fell 0.2% to US$1.1430 on Tuesday, reversing its two-week high, due to a sell-off in world stock markets and concerns over Italian banks. The Swiss franc and Japanese yen gained ground, while the dollar index edged higher. Investors' nerves were fueled by worries about the China-US trade conflict, Brexit negotiations, and a potential global slowdown, with US Federal Reserve officials expressing concern about a potential global economic downturn.

site_title: Kazakhstan holds first Singapore forum to attract potential investors
summary: Kazakhstan has hosted its first Singapore forum to attract potential investors, with the event held at the Shangri-La Hotel. The forum, which includes a working visit by Kazakhstan Prime Minister Bakytzhan Sagintayev, aims to showcase the country's investment opportunities and growth as a logistics hub between Asia and Europe. The event is part of the 25th anniversary of diplomatic relations between Kazakhstan and Singapore, and will feature presentations by Kazakh Invest, the national company advocating for foreign direct investment in Kazakhstan.

site_title: DBS makes new appointments to transaction banking team in bid to grow business
summary: DBS Bank has made new appointments to its transaction banking team in an effort to grow the business. Sriram Muthukrishnan joins as group head of global transaction services (GTS) trade product management, while Navinder Duggal takes over as GTS-SME head. Jasmin Ng, who previously managed cash products, now leads the group head of cash product management. The appointments aim to strengthen trade products and services for large corporates and small businesses, with a focus on digital initiatives and expanding market share in the SME segment.

site_title: First Reit falls as concerns swirl over sponsor
summary: Singapore's First Reit plummeted 16% in three days to S$0.975, its lowest close since 2012, amid concerns over its main sponsor, Lippo Karawaci, and its liquidity risks. Fitch Ratings downgraded Lippo Karawaci's rating to CCC+ over concerns about its asset sales, and an alleged bribery linked to the Lippo Group's US$21 billion Meikarta property project. Analysts attribute the sell-off to institutional investors offloading their stakes, rather than retail investors, citing the unusual trading pattern and Lippo Karawaci's recent downgrades.

site_title: Frank and Barbara Sinatra's rare personal items up for auction
summary: Frank Sinatra's rare personal items, including a 20.5-carat diamond engagement ring, Norman Rockwell's portrait, and a set of his golf clubs, are up for auction for the first time. The items, from Frank Sinatra's 22-year marriage to Barbara Sinatra, will be sold at Sotheby's auctions in New York on December 4 and 6. The collection includes fine art, decorative art, furniture, jewelry, and accessories from the couple's lifetime together, offering a unique glimpse into their personal lives. The auctions are expected to draw significant interest from collectors and fans.

site_title: Instagram ousting fake followers, likes and comments from accounts
summary: Instagram is removing fake followers, likes, and comments generated by third-party apps to artificially boost account popularity. The social network is using self-improving software to identify and purge inauthentic activity, notifying users of removed content. Users who unknowingly linked to offending apps can change their passwords to sever connections. The move aims to curb misinformation and manipulation, following a New York Times investigation into Facebook's handling of Russian influence campaigns.

site_title: Coal pollution may rise in UK if Brexit comes without a deal: analysts
summary: UK pollution levels are expected to rise if the country crashes out of the European Union without a deal, according to Bloomberg NEF. Burning coal would increase in the first quarter of 2019, resulting in an additional 6 million tonnes of carbon emissions. This is due to a loophole in the EU's carbon market, which would allow UK polluters to sell off their carbon allowances before Brexit, causing prices to sink and encouraging coal burning. A tax on emissions is planned to replace the EU's carbon market, but analysts warn that a hard Brexit is the only way to prevent this issue.

site_title: Theresa May's Brexit deal has a fatal defect
summary: Theresa May's Brexit deal has been criticized for its fatal defect, a lack of a time limit or exit clause for the backstop arrangement, which could tie the UK to a customs union and level playing field with the EU indefinitely. This commitment could empower the EU to prolong discussions on a long-term trade partnership, potentially stifling Britain's ability to negotiate a more favorable deal. The deal's failure has serious implications for both the UK and the EU, with the EU risking damage to its relationship with Britain and the UK potentially being humiliated as a subordinate.

site_title: More foreign issuers target Singapore-dollar market amid volatility
summary: Foreign issuers are increasingly targeting the Singapore-dollar market amid volatility in the US and Euro markets. In the year to date, there have been 27 deals worth S$3.4 billion, accounting for 15.7% of total volume. Recent deals by UBS and Shangri-La Hotel have attracted orders of over S$1.6 billion and S$825 million respectively, with UBS's S$700 million Tier 1 perpetuals selling at 5.875% interest. Foreign issuers are drawn to the SGD market for its efficiency, accessibility, and cost savings, with some estimating a 50 basis points per annum savings.

images.alt_text: Clifford Lee, DBS Bank's head of fixed income, said the recent SGD bumper deals by foreign issuers show that, while global markets as a whole are volatile, "the SGD market has, more importantly, proven itself efficient and accessible".

site_title: Can we expect a major rebound in oil prices?
summary: Oil prices may experience a rebound after hitting a 20% decline from October's peak. WTI and Brent crude benchmarks regained ground at the end of the week despite a 10-million-barrel increase in US crude oil inventories. Rising prices suggest that oil may have already hit a bottom, and OPEC+ action in early December could lead to a price increase. Hedge fund liquidation and fundamental factors, such as OECD stocks and Iran sanctions, also support a potential price bounce.

site_title: Minbu Villa takes second stab at en bloc sale at S$145.8m, but price may go lower
summary: Minbu Villa, a 10-storey freehold residential development in Novena, Singapore, is up for tender at S$145.8 million, with a lower reserve price of S$129.1 million, after 60% of owners agreed to lower the price. The site has a land area of 38,426 sq ft and a gross plot ratio of 2.8. The tender closes on Dec 18, with owners facing the cooling en bloc market and revised guidelines on development. The sale is handled by Savills Singapore, with no development charge payable.

site_title: India's central bank signals truce with government over reserves
summary: India's central bank, the RBI, has agreed to form a panel to consider transferring funds to the government, a move seen as a compromise with the government over reserves. The RBI will study the funds transfer, but will not ease lending norms for weak banks. Analysts welcome the move, saying it preserves the RBI's autonomy and avoids a direct confrontation. The agreement is seen as key to retaining investor confidence in India, a nation that relies on imported capital to fund investment.

site_title: Asia refinancing risk to 'remain low' in next 5 years: study
summary: A study by S&P Global Fixed Income Research finds that refinancing risk in the Asia-Pacific region will remain low and manageable over the next five years, with 90% of maturing debt in the investment-grade category. About $1.2 trillion of debt is expected to mature from 2018 to 2023, with the majority from Japanese, Australian, and New Zealand corporations. Risks include US Federal Reserve rate hikes, dollar-denominated debt refinancing, and capital market volatility, but the majority of maturing debt is from investment-grade issuers, reducing refinancing risk.

site_title: Xi's Manila visit expected to yield deals worth billions
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping is expected to seal billions of dollars worth of deals during his two-day trip to Manila, marking the first state visit to the Philippines by a Chinese president in 13 years. The trip reflects warmer ties between the two nations, which have been building since Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte shifted his focus from the US to China. Dozens of agreements are expected to be signed on infrastructure, trade, and security, following $24 billion in investment pledges made two years ago.

site_title: New plan launched to help food businesses go digital
summary: The Singapore Government has launched the Food Services Industry Digital Plan to help small and medium-sized food businesses go digital, aiming to increase productivity by 2% a year for the next five years. The plan provides advice, step-by-step guides, and digital tools to help businesses improve operations, customer relationships, and inventory management. With the goal of maintaining Singapore's competitive edge in the food services industry, the plan also aims to encourage innovation and growth through the use of artificial intelligence and other digital technologies.

site_title: Courts Singapore treats kids with special needs to carnival revelry
summary: Courts Asia organized a Mega Carnival at its Tampines store, treating children with special needs from charity AWWA to a day of fun, food, and games. The event, which ran from November 10 to December 2, 2018, raised funds for AWWA, supporting the organization's mission to provide for the special needs and underprivileged across all life stages in Singapore. Group CEO Terry O'Connor and country CEO Ben Tan kicked off the festivities, encouraging customers to participate and purchase additional tickets, with 100% of proceeds going to AWWA.

site_title: Taco Bell brings back Big Ben's chimes to mark outlets' opening
summary: Taco Bell has brought back the sound of Big Ben's chimes to mark the opening of four new restaurants in London, a temporary solution until the famous bell resumes its iconic sound after repairs. The chain enlisted the help of a specialist audio designer and composer to recreate the bell's sound. This move is a unique marketing gesture, allowing the restaurants to offer a distinctive experience for customers.

site_title: EasyJet logs sky-high annual profit
summary: EasyJet reported a 17% increase in annual net profit to £385 million, driven by strong sales and record passenger numbers. Pre-tax profit rose 41.4% to £578 million, with revenues increasing 17% to £5.9 billion. The airline carried a record 88.5 million passengers and is confident that flying rights will be maintained despite Brexit turbulence, with the EU and UK committed to maintaining flights between the two.

site_title: China's opening up could offset US trade frictions
summary: China's central bank adviser, Liu Shijin, says the country's economic opening up will help it cope with US trade frictions. China will continue with reforms, but at its own pace, and cannot go backwards on market reforms. This comes as the US and China impose tariffs on each other's goods, threatening to overshadow China's 40-year economic achievements since reforms began. China will implement high-level market opening, but on its own terms, and not due to external pressure.

site_title: Credit markets set for worst year since 2008 as crashes hit sentiment
summary: Credit markets are expected to have their worst year since the 2008 financial crisis due to investor sentiment shifting towards avoiding losses. High-yield and investment-grade notes are headed for losses in both euros and dollars, with euro high-yield spreads reaching a near-seven-year high. The market's volatility has been exacerbated by events such as the arrest of Carlos Ghosn and the end of European Central Bank stimulus measures. Central banks may provide support if economic news forces policy changes, but investors are focusing on individual company financial health rather than chasing yields.

site_title: Fallout from US-China clash
summary: US President Donald Trump's tariff tactics against China may backfire, eroding US power and influence. A trade war could harm the US economy, particularly if the tariffs are permanent, reducing consumer surplus and increasing costs for domestically produced and imported goods. China may retaliate, further exacerbating the situation. In contrast, emerging markets (EM) could benefit from the trade diversion, with exports shifting to countries like Vietnam, India, and Indonesia. The US strategy may also reduce economic interdependence with China, potentially increasing the risk of military conflict and China's incentive to become more aggressive.

site_title: Twitter CEO trolled for 'hate mongering' against India's Brahmins
summary: Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey faced backlash in India after a photo of him holding a placard with a message critical of the Hindu caste system went viral. The poster, which read "smash Brahminical patriarchy," was given to him by a Dalit activist during a private meeting with women journalists and activists. Several prominent Indians accused Dorsey of "hate mongering" against Brahmins, prompting Twitter's legal and policy lead, Vijaya Gadde, to apologize for the incident, stating the company should have been more thoughtful and respectful.

site_title: One in five Hong Kong residents living in poverty
summary: Hong Kong's poverty rate reached a record 20.1% in 2017, with 1.38 million residents living below the poverty line, earning less than HK$4,000 per month. This represents a 1.85% increase from the previous year. The child poverty rate rose to 23.1%, mainly due to larger households staying with elderly parents. The government's social welfare programs reduced the poverty rate to 14.7% after accounting for cash handouts. Economic growth forecasted to slow to 3.2% in 2018 due to uncertainties from trade wars and a slowing mainland economy.

site_title: Buyers of water produced by Hyflux's Algerian plant seek to terminate deal
summary: Hyflux, a Singapore-based water project developer, says buyers of its Algerian desalination plant are trying to terminate their water purchase agreement. The buyers, Algérienne des Eaux and Sonatrach, have given 8 days' prior written notice, but Hyflux disputes the allegations and plans to seek advice to enforce its rights. The Souk Tleta desalination plant, which has been in operation since 2011, supplies water to the state-owned national water company and national oil company in Algeria.

site_title: Saudi Arabia announces more new projects in royal investment spree
summary: Saudi Arabia's King Salman announced $3 billion in new investment projects during a royal spending spree, as the ruling family seeks to shore up support amid a crisis over journalist Jamal Khashoggi's murder. The 151 projects in Tabuk province are valued at over $4 billion, marking the latest in a series of development projects launched during the king's domestic tour.

site_title: Getting maritime industry shipshape
summary: The Maritime Singapore Connect (MSC) Office aims to attract more Singaporeans to join the maritime industry, which has faced a decline in recruits. The office, set up with a $4 million commitment, held the annual MSC Connexions Forum to discuss employer branding and creating an employee-centric environment. Experts emphasized the importance of adapting to the digital age and investing in human resources to attract and retain talent. They noted that competition for talent is fierce, and companies must focus on their brand and value proposition to engage staff and retain them.

site_title: Opposing collective sale doesn't exempt owners from stamp duty
summary: Singapore residents opposing a collective sale of private homes will still be required to pay seller's stamp duty if the sale occurs within their holding period, according to Second Finance Minister Lawrence Wong. The stamp duty applies regardless of individual owner consent, as stated in Parliament on November 20, 2018.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Oxley Holdings' deputy CEO Low See Ching increased his stake to 29.78% after buying 300,000 shares at S$0.295 each. China Jinjiang Environment secured a concession to build a waste-to-energy facility in Hebei Province for S$65.5 million. Chew's Group suspended trading due to a mandatory general offer exceeding 90% acceptance. US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, while NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed.

site_title: Cash-hungry China property developers face new norm: double-digit bond yields
summary: Chinese property developers are facing a new norm of double-digit bond yields due to rising US interest rates, investor aversion to risk taking, and a cooling property market. Times China Holdings and Evergrande Group, two heavily indebted developers, have seen their bond yields increase to 11% for a two-year bond, a drastic increase from 6.25%. This trend is expected to continue, putting pressure on policymakers as China's GDP growth is forecast to slow, raising concerns about the country's economic stability.

site_title: Sri Lanka risks debt default, warns largest party
summary: Sri Lanka's largest party, the United National Party, warns of a high risk of debt default due to the ongoing political crisis. Moody's downgraded the country's credit rating to B2, citing a lasting impact of the crisis on policy. The nation has been without a government since November 15, and a US$1 billion sovereign bond is set to mature on January 10. International ratings agency Moody's decision reflects external and internal issues exacerbated by the crisis, which could lead to a greater risk of default.

site_title: Twitter CEO kicks up storm in India, offending some Hindus
summary: Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey has sparked controversy in India after a picture of him holding a poster with the phrase "smash Brahminical patriarchy" went viral. The poster, meant to represent a discussion on women's experiences, was gifted to Dorsey by a Dalit activist. Twitter has apologized, stating the views do not reflect the company's or Dorsey's, and has expressed regret over the incident. Several prominent Indians have accused Dorsey of "hate-mongering" against the Hindu caste system.

site_title: Noble probe launched - three years after alarms first raised
summary: Singapore authorities have launched a joint investigation into Noble Group for potential breaches of securities rules and company law, just weeks before the planned listing of a new Noble Group on the Singapore Exchange. The probe follows recent disclosures by the company and an extensive review of its financial statements. The investigation is expected to derail the listing, which was initially set for November 27. Regulators have directed Noble and its subsidiary to produce documents related to the company's financial statements, and the Singapore Exchange has halted trading in Noble's shares.

site_title: Taylor Swift flexes music muscle to seek higher payouts for other artists
summary: Taylor Swift has signed a new record deal with Universal Music Group, gaining greater control over her music and potentially boosting payouts to artists on Spotify. The deal includes an agreement that any Spotify sale would distribute money to artists, non-recoupable. Swift will own her master recordings and has been a long-time advocate for better payments to artists from streaming services. The multi-album, multi-year agreement is effective immediately, with Universal Music CEO Lucian Grainge stating he respects Swift's campaign for better terms.

site_title: EU's Vestager insists on 'level playing field' after Brexit
summary: European Competition Commissioner Margrethe Vestager emphasized the importance of a 'level playing field' for the UK after Brexit, stating that the EU's 27 member states will remain vigilant to ensure Britain adheres to the same rules as Europe on business. Vestager has been working closely with Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier to address this issue, particularly in relation to the Irish border backstop. The EU demands that the UK observe 'level playing field' commitments on competition, state aid, environment standards, and tax to prevent undercutting EU industry in the post-Brexit future.

site_title: Ivanka Trump repeatedly used personal email at White House
summary: Ivanka Trump used a personal email account to conduct government business in 2017, according to a White House review. The email use, which included exchanges with Cabinet secretaries and forwards of schedules, has raised concerns for congressional oversight. The revelation comes as Democrats will control the House majority, and Ivanka's use of a personal email account has drawn comparisons to Hillary Clinton's private email server during her time as secretary of state. Ivanka's allies claim the volume of emails related to government work was relatively small, but current and former White House officials say it blurred the lines between her government work and personal life.

site_title: Italy's boardroom saga - a property rights lesson
summary: Italy's government is pushing to merge Telecom Italia with Open Fiber, a smaller rival, to control the country's phone and broadband network. The move, supported by the ruling Five Star Movement and Elliott Management Corp, a hedge fund controlling Telecom Italia, is opposed by Vivendi, the French media company that owns the largest shareholder stake. The plan's feasibility is questioned, as Italy has little money to pay for the network, which is valued between 10-15 billion euros. The government's decision raises concerns about the respect of property rights in Italy, following recent instances of state intervention in private companies, including the collapse of a bridge in Genoa.

images.alt_text: Luigi Gubitosi, Telecom Italia's CEO, is open to Five Star Movement's draft amendment to a fiscal decree.

site_title: How Amazon marches to the beat of a different drum
summary: Amazon is distinct from other large corporations due to its resource-allocation strategy, particularly its decision to retain profits and reinvest them rather than distributing them to shareholders as dividends and buybacks. This approach has allowed Amazon to prioritize long-term growth over short-term gains, enabling the company to maintain its market power and influence on the economy. As a result, Amazon has become one of the few large American corporations to invest its profits in its business, rather than cutting payrolls and distributing cash to shareholders.

site_title: Norway's wealth fund buys property in Paris for US$473m
summary: Norway's sovereign wealth fund has agreed to purchase a 100% interest in a 20,400 square meter office property in central Paris for $473 million. The seller is a South Korean mutual fund, IGIS Global Private Placement Real Estate Fund Number 37-1. The purchase was made in cash, with no additional details on the property's expected use. This acquisition marks another expansion of Norway's global real estate holdings.

site_title: Cartier reopens its ION flagship boutique
summary: Cartier has reopened its ION flagship boutique in Singapore, featuring a 688 sqm space with a 20m long glass facade inspired by the country's tropical climate. The boutique, which opened to the public on Saturday, showcases iconic Cartier Collection pieces in a two-week exhibition, "Cartier, Icon of Style". The store's design, created by Parisian artist Bruno Moinard, blends French art de vivre with Singaporean culture, featuring the Cartier panther in a bas-relief sculpture. The new space offers an unparalleled client experience with a third floor reserved for discerning clients.

site_title: Pakistan, IMF extend bailout talks after failing to reach agreement
summary: Pakistan has extended talks with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) after failing to agree on a bailout package, with a final deal expected by mid-January. The two sides have made significant progress on policy priorities and reforms, but still need to iron out some issues. Pakistan is seeking a $6 billion bailout to address a current account deficit and is pushing back against IMF demands for structural reforms. The IMF predicts Pakistan's growth will slow to 4% in 2019 and 3% in the medium term.

site_title: India to probe alleged antitrust behaviour by Maersk, DP World at Mumbai port
summary: India's antitrust regulator has ordered a probe into alleged anti-competitive practices by Maersk and DP World at the Mumbai port, following a complaint by Singapore's PSA International. The investigation centers around so-called inter-terminal transfers, where freight trains arriving at the port stop at one terminal, and the alleged imposition of higher fees on shipping companies that use the PSA terminal. The Competition Commission of India (CCI) has asked its investigations unit to submit a report by January, and the probe may also look at the role of individual company executives.

site_title: Shareholders right to have misgivings over Magnus Energy's headlong rush into microalgae farming
