summary: Magnus Energy shareholders expressed concerns over the company's investments in microalgae farming, citing failed projects and lack of return on investment. A US$9.4 million investment in an algae-to-oil project has remained unviable after two years, and a US$7.4 million debt to an Indonesian contractor remains unpaid. Shareholders also criticized the management for not structuring deals with greater care. ExxonMobil's cautious approach to microalgae farming is contrasted with Innopac's failed project, highlighting the risks involved in this emerging industry.

site_title: Judge blocks Trump administration's plan to bar asylum seekers
summary: A federal judge in San Francisco has temporarily blocked the Trump administration's plan to deny asylum to people who enter the US illegally, citing a conflict with the Immigration and Nationality Act of 1965. The order, announced by President Trump, restricted asylum to those entering at official checkpoints, not sneaking across the border. US District Judge Jon Tigar ruled that the rule "irreconcilably conflicts with the INA" and cannot be rewritten by the President. The restraining order remains in effect until the court decides on the case.

site_title: BOE 'quietly confident' UK banks ready for Brexit, Carney says
summary: The Bank of England is "quietly confident" that UK banks are ready for a no-deal Brexit, Deputy Governor Jon Cunliffe said. The EU must deliver legislation within weeks to ensure UK clearinghouses can continue serving clients in the EU in case of a disorderly divorce. The BOE has taken steps to prepare the financial system for a possible no-deal Brexit, with Governor Mark Carney stating that the necessary measures are in place. A report on the impact of the draft withdrawal agreement will be published on November 29.

site_title: Dow dives 2.2%, moves into the red for 2018
summary: US stocks plummeted on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 2.2% to 24,465.64, wiping out its 2018 gains. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also dropped, with the Nasdaq reaching its lowest levels in over seven months. Analysts attribute the weakness to global growth concerns, Federal Reserve interest rate hikes, and the US-China trade dispute. Technology and energy sectors were particularly hard hit, with Apple and Microsoft shedding 4.8% and 2.8% respectively, while petroleum-linked shares plummeted amid low oil prices.

site_title: US: Wall Street tumbles at open on retail gloom, tech concerns
summary: US stocks plummeted at the open on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 398.76 points, or 1.59%, to 24,618.68. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also dropped, with the S&P 500 falling 36.13 points, or 1.34%, and the Nasdaq Composite falling 161.05 points, or 2.29%. The decline was driven by poor holiday quarter forecasts from retailers and concerns about demand for iPhones.

site_title: Bitcoin slump takes pressure off Britain's regulators
summary: Britain's financial regulators face reduced pressure to issue new rules on cryptocurrency due to a recent slump in bitcoin's value. The drop has eased concerns about the sector's growth and potential impact on innovation and consumer protection. Regulators, including the Financial Conduct Authority, are instead focusing on clarifying existing rules and working with international counterparts to establish a unified regulatory framework. A task force has recommended a ban on selling derivatives linked to cryptoassets, but unilateral action may be limited, and collaboration with global regulatory bodies is preferred.

site_title: Australia blocks CK Group's A$13 billion bid for APA pipelines
summary: Australia's Treasurer Josh Frydenberg has officially vetoed CK Group's A$13 billion bid for APA Group, citing concerns over concentrated foreign ownership. The decision blocks a potential acquisition by a single foreign company group controlling Australia's dominant natural gas pipeline operator. The move could open the way for local bidders, and APA Group's existing stakeholders, including UniSuper Ltd, may back a new suitor. The decision is seen as a potential impediment to deeper business ties with China, Australia's largest trading partner.

site_title: Fatality from collapse at LY Corp factory
summary: A fatal collapse occurred on Monday at LY Corporation's factory in Batu Pahat, Johor, Malaysia, resulting in the death of an employee. The company has filed a report and conducted additional safety checks. The chairman and CEO are assisting the deceased's family. Shares of LY Corporation fell slightly following the incident.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's stock market ended 1.2% lower on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index losing 38.08 points to 3,026.99. Noble Group faces joint probe by CAD, MAS, and ACRA over suspected breaches of disclosure requirements and false statements. The probe involves the bank's board and requires further information.

site_title: AO World says UK appliances market declining
summary: AO World, a UK-based online electricals retailer, reported a first-half loss due to lower-than-anticipated sales for large domestic appliances in the UK market. Revenue grew 9.9% to £404.2 million, with UK growth of 5.7% and 35% growth in Europe. The company reiterated its guidance for full-year results, despite Brexit-related supply chain friction. AO aims to make its European operations profitable by 2021, with shares down 29% over the six months.

site_title: Chew Group's controlling shareholder to retain listing, even as free float falls under 10%
summary: Chew Group's controlling shareholder, Goldhill Trust, has completed a mandatory general offer for the remaining shares, gaining 93.4% control of the company. Despite the significant stake, Goldhill intends to retain Chew's listing on the Catalist board, with the goal of restoring the free float, currently below 10%. The offer was made at a 27.3% discount to Chew's last trading price.

site_title: Authorities probing false statements, breaches by Noble
summary: The Commercial Affairs Department, Monetary Authority of Singapore, and Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority are jointly investigating Noble Group for suspected false statements and breaches of disclosure requirements. The investigation involves Noble Resources International and follows an extensive review of NRI's financial statements from 2012 to 2016. The authorities have directed Noble Group and NRI to provide documents related to the preparation of Noble Group's financial statements. The investigation is ongoing, with the ACRA requiring NRI's directors to furnish further information.

images.alt_text: In a joint statement on Tuesday, they said that NRI's board has been notified that ACRA has made findings of suspected breaches of the Companies Act and has required the directors to furnish further information as part of the ongoing investigation.

site_title: France urges Renault to replace Ghosn, defends alliance
summary: France is urging Renault to replace CEO Carlos Ghosn, who was arrested in Japan on financial misconduct allegations, citing his inability to lead the company. The French state owns 15% of Renault, which holds a 43.4% stake in Nissan, and Ghosn's departure could rock the complex alliance. Renault's board will meet to discuss temporarily replacing Ghosn, and French Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire has asked Japanese authorities to investigate Ghosn's affairs, finding no significant issues. The alliance's future and governance are now in question, amid a difficult time for the industry with tighter emissions regulations and declining sales of diesel vehicles.

images.alt_text: France urged Renault on Tuesday to replace CEO Carlos Ghosn a day after his arrest in Japan on financial misconduct allegations, but sought to defend the carmaker's alliance with Nissan, which has been rocked by the scandal.

site_title: How long can people live?
summary: Scientists aim to treat multiple chronic illnesses by targeting aging itself. The oldest person on record, Jeanne Calment, lived to 122. In 2040, the average life span in Spain is projected to reach 86 years, surpassing Japan. Currently, heart disease, cancer, and other conditions increase with age, making old age the most common risk factor for serious disease. Researchers hope to extend human lifespan, but the human body is not built to last forever.

site_title: Oxley Holdings deputy CEO raises his stake to 29.78% as share price keeps falling
summary: Oxley Holdings deputy CEO Low See Ching raised his stake in the property developer to 27.78% after buying 300,000 shares at S$0.295 each. The move comes as the company's share price has fallen to a 12-month low, following a steady stream of purchases by directors and management. Oxley Holdings has been the worst-performing billionaire stock in the year to Nov 13, with a return of negative 40.9%.

site_title: Lian Beng associated firm plans HK listing
summary: Lian Beng Group's associated company United E&P plans to list on the Hong Kong stock exchange, with Lian Beng owning 40% of the firm. This move aims to raise capital for United E&P. Lian Beng's shares closed at S$0.455, down one Singapore cent, on the day of the announcement.

site_title: British PM's N Irish allies up pressure over Brexit
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May faces pressure from Northern Irish allies to approve the Brexit deal, amid fears her government might collapse. The Democratic Unionist Party (DUP), which supports May's government, abstained on key votes and sided with the opposition Labour party, raising concerns about the deal's passage. Without DUP support, the Conservatives lack a majority, and the UK risks leaving the EU on March 29, 2019, with no alternative arrangement in place. The DUP and many Conservatives oppose the "backstop" plan, which would keep Britain in the EU's customs union and Northern Ireland in the single market.

site_title: Waste treatment firm China Jinjiang Environment wins project worth some 330m yuan
summary: China Jinjiang Environment Holding has secured a 330m yuan (S$65.5m) concession to build a waste-to-energy facility in Hebei Province, with a 30-year concession period. The facility will treat 450 tonnes of municipal waste, 100 tonnes of other solid waste, and 60 tonnes of sewage per day. Construction is expected to be completed by the end of 2020. The investment will be funded through bank borrowings and internal resources, with shares closing unchanged at S$0.45.

site_title: TT Int'l secures deadline extension for disclosure reporting
summary: TT International, a Singapore-based electronics retailer, has secured a deadline extension for disclosing its financial statements. The Singapore Exchange granted a six-month extension until May 14, 2019, as the company continues its restructuring. TT International shares have been voluntarily suspended since August 2017. The extensions allow the firm to announce its fiscal 2018 financial statement, among other things, and are part of its ongoing efforts to stabilize its operations.

site_title: ECB steps up checks of banks at high risk of laundering money
summary: The European Central Bank is stepping up checks of banks at high risk of laundering money by launching a dedicated network of watchdogs to share information on the matter. This comes after a string of money-laundering scandals in Denmark, Malta, and Latvia. The Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM) will set up an anti-money laundering office to collect and share information from its supervisors and other authorities. The move is in response to high-profile scandals involving Danske Bank, Pilatus Bank, and ABLV, and is seen as a concrete response to the issue.

site_title: S Korea's Jeju Air in US$4.4b 40-plane Boeing order
summary: South Korean budget carrier Jeju Air ordered 40 Boeing B737-MAX 8 planes worth US$4.4 billion, with deliveries from 2022 to 2026. The order is the largest single model contract by a South Korean carrier and will help Jeju Air replace its existing fleet with next-generation airplanes, cutting costs and maintaining price competitiveness. The new aircraft is more efficient than its current planes, enabling the airline to grow into a leading carrier.

site_title: Boston Scientific boosts tech with US$4.2b BTG deal
summary: Boston Scientific Corp. agreed to buy BTG Corp. for 3.3 billion pounds (S$5.7 billion) to expand its medical device offerings, particularly in treating cancer and other disorders. Boston Scientific will pay 840 pence in cash per share, a 37% premium over BTG's closing price. The acquisition will augment Boston Scientific's capabilities and is expected to add 2-3 cents to its adjusted earnings per share next year. This is Boston Scientific's largest deal since 2005.

site_title: Neuroscience marketing startup NeuroTrend raises US$1.5m in seed funding
summary: NeuroTrend, a neuroscience marketing startup, has raised US$1.5 million in seed funding led by Trive Ventures. Founded in Russia, the firm now operates from Singapore and offers neuromarketing services, analyzing consumer insights through electroencephalography, eye tracking, and facial recognition. This approach provides a more comprehensive understanding of consumer behavior, with 90% accuracy compared to traditional market research methods. The company plans to establish a research and development lab in Singapore to further develop its neuroscience capabilities.

site_title: Financing of KIT's Basslink project goes into technical default due to fee delay
summary: KEPPEL Infrastructure Trust (KIT) reported a technical default on its Basslink project due to a delayed facility fee payment from Hydro Tasmania. The delay, caused by a disagreement over a 2018 service outage, has resulted in a shortfall in fees that triggered a technical default. KIT expects to meet the required debt service coverage ratio by September 2019, once the full facility fees are paid. The company remains current on debt payments and expects no material financial impact on its distribution per unit.

site_title: Singapore shares slide 1.2% on Tuesday
summary: Singapore stocks declined 1.2% on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index falling 38.08 points to 3,026.99. Losers outnumbered gainers 268 to 118, with all three local banks finishing in the red. OCBC dropped 2.53%, UOB fell 1.65%, and DBS declined 1.29%. Genting Singapore was the most actively traded counter, losing 2.13%. Total shares traded were 1.44 billion worth S$925.4 million.

site_title: Australia's central bank raps banks for misdeeds; watching housing downturn
summary: Australia's Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) Governor Philip Lowe criticized the country's scandal-ridden banks for their misdeeds, urging strong penalties to punish wrongdoing. Lowe emphasized the need for a balance between lending and risk management, warning that excessive caution could harm the economy. The RBA has tightened lending standards, exacerbating a housing downturn, but Lowe sees the current economic backdrop as favorable, with a strong world economy and low interest rates. The RBA is cautious about raising interest rates, awaiting a pick-up in inflation.

site_title: Mondelez hires Morgan Stanley to study Tim Tam bid
summary: Mondelez International is working with Morgan Stanley to study a bid for Arnott's Biscuits, the Australian maker of Tim Tams, and Kelsen Group, a Danish butter-cookie producer. Pacific Equity Partners is also considering an offer for Campbell Soup Co. brands, which could fetch up to $3 billion. The assets have drawn interest from other potential bidders, including Kraft Heinz. No final decisions have been made, and there's no certainty the suitors will proceed to submit bids.

site_title: Freehold Minbu Villa up for collective sale again at S$145.8m, but price could go lower
summary: Minbu Villa, a 10-storey freehold residential development in Novena, Singapore, is up for collective sale at S$145.8 million, with the reserve price potentially lowered to S$129.1 million if 80% of owners agree. The site, completed in 1981, has in-principle approval for an adjoining state land and could be developed up to 36 storeys high with an allowable GFA of 107,593 sq ft. The sale is part of the cooling en bloc market, with over 60 sites closing without buyers since the start of the year.

site_title: Cybersecurity, data analytics top tech focus areas in 2019: CIO Academy Asia poll
summary: Cybersecurity and data analytics have emerged as the top tech focus areas in 2019 among tech leaders in South-east Asia, according to a CIO Academy Asia survey. 70 workers polled reported that 66% of their organizations will be spending the most on these areas in the next 1-2 years.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets open lower
summary: European stocks fell at the opening bell on Tuesday, mirroring Asian losses, as a global sell-off continued. The FTSE 100 index was down 0.5% at 6,968.79 points, while the DAX 30 and CAC 40 lost 0.8% and 0.5% respectively. The decline was driven by concerns over Apple's iPhone demand, as well as negative news on Facebook and other tech giants. The sell-off follows a brief period of stability and is part of a broader global market downturn amid US-China trade tensions and flagging growth among tech giants.

site_title: Seoul: Chip, carmaker shares lead losses; won gains
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index fell 0.86% on Tuesday, weighed by losses in tech and auto industries. Leading chipmakers Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix slipped 2.0% and 3.3%, respectively, amid weak iPhone sales and China's antitrust probe. Carmakers Hyundai Motor and Kia Motors also declined, with Hyundai's shares hitting their lowest close since 2009. The won rose 0.25% against the dollar, while bond yields fell. The Kospi is down 14.9% this year and 7.36% in the past 30 days.

site_title: London's stockpile of unsold homes jumps almost 50% to record
summary: London's stockpile of unsold homes has jumped to a record 2,374 units as of September 30, a 48% increase from the end of 2017. Brexit uncertainty and affordability issues have driven the surge, with the average Londoner needing 14.5 times their annual salary to purchase a home, the highest multiple ever. The borough of Wandsworth has the largest stockpile, followed by Croydon, with sales in London and its commuter belt drying up due to high prices and economic uncertainty.

site_title: Us dollar bulls wary after cautious Fed comments, weak homebuilder report
summary: The US dollar hovered near a two-week low against its peers after cautious comments from Federal Reserve officials and weak US homebuilder data raised questions over the pace of interest rate increases. US 10-year treasury yields pulled back slightly, and the dollar index fell nearly half a percent last week, its biggest weekly drop since late September. Despite this, analysts believe the dollar can stage a comeback if global equities continue to correct and volatility rises, citing a possible reversal in dollar weakness.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares tumble in tech sell-off
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 2.02% on Tuesday, following a tech sell-off in Asia and the US. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 25,840.34, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also declined. The tech sector was heavily impacted, with technology firms among the biggest losers. The decline is attributed to heavy selling in the sector on Wall Street.

site_title: Vietnam's Bamboo Airways books maiden flight on Dec 29 - Chairman
summary: Bamboo Airways, Vietnam's fifth carrier, plans to operate its maiden domestic flight on December 29 if it receives its license to fly. The airline, a subsidiary of FLC Group JSC, aims to connect Hanoi with Quy Nhon, a coastal resort city. Bamboo Airways plans to expand its services to domestic destinations not currently reached by existing airlines and will launch international flights to South Korea and Japan in the second quarter. The airline's chairman, Trinh Van Quyet, stated that Bamboo Airways will also operate flights to main cities.

site_title: SGX lays out guidelines for listed companies issuing initial coin offerings
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has issued guidelines for listed companies planning to conduct initial coin offerings (ICOs), requiring them to disclose relevant information to shareholders. The guidelines, outlined by SGX RegCo, include making clear disclosures about the ICO, money laundering and terrorist financing risks, and accounting treatment. Listed issuers must also consult with auditors and obtain their opinion on the ICO's accounting treatment. The SGX will provide a checklist to ensure compliance and expects the issuer to keep shareholders informed of material information.

site_title: GE shakes up power unit leadership, taps retired exec to help
summary: General Electric (GE) has made significant changes to its power business, appointing John Rice, a 39-year veteran, as chairman of gas power and Scott Strazik as CEO of Gas Power. The moves come as part of CEO Larry Culp's effort to reduce debt and restore profits at the conglomerate. The reorganization of GE Power's gas-turbine business from coal- and nuclear-fueled power plants and power grids, announced three weeks ago, aims to position the business for success. Analysts say Rice's experience will help, but a quick improvement in power's performance is uncertain.

site_title: Flagging Victoria's Secret announces new lingerie CEO
summary: Victoria's Secret appoints John Mehas as new lingerie CEO, replacing Jan Singer amid declining sales and criticism over idealized femininity and lack of diverse models. Mehas comes from Tory Burch, where he is currently president, and will focus on improving performance through fresh perspectives on marketing, brand positioning, and cost structure. His appointment aims to boost the brand's ailing fortunes.

site_title: Homeowners who opposed collective sale must still pay stamp duty: Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore homeowners who opposed collective sales must still pay seller's stamp duty if a sale occurs within the holding period, according to Second Minister for Finance Lawrence Wong. The collective sales committee can enter into a sale and purchase agreement on behalf of all owners, making the agreement binding on all owners. Homeowners who do not consent to a collective sale can file objections, but the seller's stamp duty remains applicable. This is part of the government's measures to ensure a stable and sustainable property market. The duty varies according to how long a person has owned the property.

site_title: NYC seeks approval for private management of housing
summary: New York City plans to seek federal approval to transition 62,000 public housing apartments into a $13 billion rent-subsidy program by 2028, eliminating reliance on government block grants. The US Housing and Urban Development's RAD program allows investors to rely on predictable revenue from monthly rent vouchers instead of annual federal budget appropriations. This move aims to address maintenance backlogs and ensure 140,000 residents receive necessary repairs, including heating systems and elevators.

site_title: Offtakers seek to end water purchase contract for Hyflux JV plant in Algeria
summary: Hyflux, the developer of the Souk Tleta desalination plant in Algeria, reported that off-takers are seeking to terminate their water purchase agreement. The plant supplies water to the state-owned national water company Algérienne des Eaux and the national oil company Sonatrach. The off-takers have sent a notice of termination to Hyflux and its 51% shareholder TDIC, citing unspecified reasons.

site_title: Bharti signs for over US$2b loan amid threat of ratings cut
summary: Bharti Airtel Ltd, India's second-largest wireless carrier, has secured over $2 billion in loans from banks amid increased competition and a threat of a junk ratings downgrade. The company has agreed to two- and three-year bilateral loans with 10-12 lenders, following a review of its Baa3 rating by Moody's Investors Service. The loans, which include a 110-120 basis points over London interbank offered rate, are part of efforts to fund capital spending and address low profitability and high debt levels. The move comes after Reliance Jio Infocomm's free services disrupted the market since 2016.

images.alt_text: Bharti Airtel Ltd is raising more than US$2 billion in loans from banks, as India's second-biggest wireless carrier faces increased competition at home and the threat of a ratings downgrade to junk.

site_title: Australia shares close lower on Wall St's tech selloff; NZ also down
summary: Australian shares fell 0.38% on Tuesday, following a Wall Street tech selloff, but pared losses with gains in financials and miners. Global stocks declined after US tech stocks dropped due to worries on slackening demand and the US-China trade dispute. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,671.80, down 21.90 points from Monday's 0.6% decline.

site_title: Xi visits Philippines as China, US wrangle for supremacy
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping visited the Philippines for a two-day state visit, amid a power struggle between Beijing and Washington in the Pacific. The visit aims to secure investment in major infrastructure projects, but protestors opposed closer ties with China. The Philippines has a long-standing bond with the US, but President Rodrigo Duterte has courted trade and investment from China since his 2016 election. Despite China's pledge of $24 billion in loans, only a small portion has been delivered, prompting concerns of a "debt trap."

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon at 3,028.8, down 1.2%
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading Tuesday at 3,028.8, down 1.2% from the previous close. The Straits Times Index lost 36.27 points. Losers outnumbered gainers 216 to 97, with 695.4 million shares changing hands. Local banks OCBC Bank, UOB, and DBS fell 2.44%, 1.53%, and 1.38% respectively. The most actively traded counter, Rich Capital, fell 11.11% to 0.8 Singapore cent.

site_title: PNG police, soldiers storm parliament over unpaid Apec bonuses
summary: Papua New Guinea police and soldiers stormed the parliament in Port Moresby, smashing windows and furniture, to demand unpaid Apec bonuses. The bonuses, totaling 350 kina (S$143), were due just days after the international summit ended. No injuries were reported, and police and soldiers were involved in the incident. The protesters, who are among the poorest members of Apec, had expressed anger over the government's lavish expenses for the summit, which coincided with the country's struggles with a polio outbreak and malaria.

site_title: Sign of things to come? Indian ETF draws first inflow since July
summary: Indian exchange-traded fund (ETF) saw its first inflow since July 19, with US$4.13 million added to VanEck Vectors India Small-Cap Index ETF SCIF, representing 2% of its capitalization. The influx follows a slump in oil, easing India's widening trade deficit. Weaker oil prices have helped the country's currency appreciate and boosted Indian equities, which have rallied for three weeks. This trend is part of a broader trend of inflows in emerging-market ETFs amid fading dollar strength and President Trump's more moderate tone on trade disputes.

site_title: Surge in China theft of Australia company secrets: report
summary: China has escalated cyberattacks on Australian companies, targeting intellectual property, according to a report by Fairfax Media and Channel Nine. The attacks, attributed to China's Ministry of State Security, are part of a "constant, significant effort" to steal sensitive data. The US has also accused Beijing of widespread intellectual property theft, with the alleged attacks taking place despite an agreement between Canberra and Beijing last year. Cyber experts, including CrowdStrike, have noted a significant increase in attacks targeting all sectors, with no doubt the gloves are off.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks tumble at open on Tuesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted over 1% in early trading on Tuesday, following a US sell-off fueled by concerns over iPhone demand. The Hang Seng Index dropped 1.28%, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.71%. The decline was attributed to technology firms taking a hit.

site_title: Maggots, licorice and cobra hearts at Sweden's 'Disgusting Food Museum'
summary: The "Disgusting Food Museum" in Sweden showcases foods from around the world, highlighting the subjective nature of disgust. The exhibit features dishes like maggot-infested cheese, fermented shark, and cobra hearts, which are presented alongside Western delicacies. Museum director Andreas Ahrens notes that disgust is indoctrinated by upbringing, and the exhibit aims to challenge visitors' perceptions. Visitors can sample the dishes, including some that may seem repulsive to Western palates. The exhibit runs until January 27 and plans to tour Europe and the world.

images.alt_text: A visitor reacts as he observes the "Mouse Wine" from China presented at the Disgusting Food Museum on November 7, 2018 in Malmo, Sweden. - The exhibit has 80 of the world's most disgusting foods where adventurous visitors get the opportunity to smell and taste some of these notorious foods.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Tuesday, STI down 1.08% at 3,032.08
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index down 32.99 points, or 1.08%, to 3,032.08, following Wall Street stocks' decline on Monday. Losers outnumbered gainers 97 to 24, with Metro gaining 7 cents, or 6.5%, to S$1.15, while UOB and Venture Corp fell 29 cents and 21 cents, respectively.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower, Nissan down over 6%
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday, with Nissan shares plummeting over 6% and Mitsubishi also declining. The Nikkei 225 index fell 1.08% to 21,585.97, while the Topix index dropped 0.97% to 1,621.70. The arrest of Nissan chairman Carlos Ghosn over financial misconduct allegations contributed to the decline.

site_title: Australian police arrest three over plan to stage 'mass' attack
summary: Australian police arrested three men, aged 30, 26, and 21, on Tuesday for allegedly planning a 'mass' attack in Melbourne, less than two weeks after a similar incident. The men were taken into custody after attempting to acquire a semi-automatic gun. The Joint Counter Terrorism Team, including federal and state police, and the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, carried out the arrests. The motive behind the alleged attack is still under investigation.

site_title: JD founder struggles to calm investors after slowdown, arrest
summary: JD.com's founder Richard Liu is struggling to reassure investors amid a slowdown in the company's growth and a global trade war. His arrest in the US has raised concerns, but Liu denied any wrongdoing. JD's ADRs slid 8.4% after a disappointing earnings report and lower-than-expected revenue, with annual active customers falling for the first time since listing. Liu plans to focus on new businesses and strategy, while letting his subordinates handle mature operations. The company faces increased competition from rivals Alibaba and Pinduoduo, and analysts predict margin pressure in the coming years.

site_title: Fishing nations fail in bid to cut quotas for depleted bigeye tuna
summary: Fishing nations failed to reach a consensus at the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) meeting in Dubrovnik, Croatia, to reduce quotas for the depleted bigeye tuna. Despite warnings from scientists that catch levels must be sharply reduced to prevent stock collapse, countries such as Brazil, Senegal, and Cape Verde were not brought under quotas due to commercial interests. The current 65,000-tonne catch limit was extended for a year, and a partial moratorium on fishing devices was maintained. Experts estimate that cutting the total catch to 50,000 tonnes per year could give bigeye a 70% probability of recovery by 2028.

site_title: DBS makes new appointments to boost transaction banking
summary: DBS Bank has appointed new leaders to its transaction banking team, including Sriram Muthukrishnan as group head of global transaction services trade product management and Jasmin Ng as group head of cash product management. Navinder Duggal, who was appointed in July, will oversee the bank's GTS-SME strategy in key markets. The moves aim to strengthen the bank's trade products and services, with a focus on growing its market share in the SME segment. DBS's global transaction services accounted for 35% of its institutional banking business income in 2017, with growth of 17% year on year.

site_title: Tradeshift is bidding for Finnish software maker Basware
summary: Tradeshift, a payment-technology startup, has made an offer to acquire Finnish software maker Basware to better compete with SAP and Oracle. The offer, backed by US and Chinese investors, may include a premium to Basware's average share price. Basware has confirmed it's evaluating the proposal, which comes after the company's shares surged 47% since Thursday. Tradeshift, valued at $1.1 billion, aims to create an "open business platform" to connect companies with suppliers and facilitate faster payments. The deal could be a strategic move to expand Tradeshift's offerings and compete with larger software giants.

site_title: Canada Post seeks holiday truce with striking workers
summary: Canada Post seeks a truce with striking workers to avoid a disastrous holiday season, but the union rejected the proposal, saying it would ask workers to return to work under the same conditions that produce the highest injury rate. The strike, now in its fifth week, has resulted in a delivery backlog of up to 30 days, with hundreds of trailers waiting to be unloaded. The Canadian government is under pressure from online retailers to step in and legislate an end to the walkout, which has impacted Canada Post's ability to deliver two-thirds of the nation's online shopping during the holiday rush.

site_title: Refinancing risk in Asia to 'remain low and manageable' over next 5 years: study
summary: A study by S&P Global Fixed Income Research suggests that refinancing risk in Asia-Pacific will remain low and manageable over the next 5 years due to the majority of maturing debt being in the investment-grade category. Approximately $1.2 trillion of Asia-Pacific debt will mature from 2018 to 2023, with 90% of it in investment-grade, and only $17 billion of debt rated "B-" or lower will mature during this period. Rising borrowing costs and capital market volatility are potential risks, but the study concludes that refinancing risk will remain low and manageable.

site_title: Asia: Tech losses drag stocks, Ghosn arrest hits Nissan, Mitsubishi
summary: Asian markets declined due to concerns over iPhone demand, with tech firms experiencing significant losses. Nissan and Mitsubishi plummeted after Carlos Ghosn's arrest for alleged financial misconduct. The US's production cut of iPhones sparked speculation about the device's sales performance. The sell-off follows a brief period of stability, with the tech sector leading the downturn.

site_title: One in 8 Singapore investors see volatility as risk to investment: poll
summary: Singapore investors see volatility as a risk to investment, with only about one in eight viewing it negatively. Despite global concerns, 40% of investors believe they would invest more in volatile markets. Singapore investors are most optimistic about the local equity market, with 60% expecting it to perform better in 2019. They are also bullish on China and the US markets, with 44% and 37% of investors respectively confident about their prospects. Overall, Singapore investors remain long-term investors, with 53% being "quite or very confident" about having enough money for a comfortable retirement.

site_title: Nissan shares plunge as Ghosn face ouster after arrest
summary: Nissan shares plummeted as chairman Carlos Ghosn faced ouster after his arrest for alleged financial misconduct. Ghosn, 64, was accused of under-reporting his income by around $61 million over five years and misusing company assets. His own successor, Nissan CEO Hiroto Saikawa, called his leadership a "dark side" of the Ghosn era, citing too much power and governance issues. Ghosn's removal is expected, with both Nissan and Mitsubishi proposing his removal as chairman, and Renault's board also meeting to discuss his fate.

site_title: Medical support services provider Medinex eyes all-placement Catalist IPO
summary: Medinex, a medical support services provider, is seeking a listing on the Catalist board of the Singapore Exchange to raise funds for expansion and possible acquisitions. The IPO will be an all-placement deal, comprising new shares and vendor shares sold by existing shareholders. Medinex plans to use the funds to expand its business, acquire human resources consulting services group Ark Leadership, and enhance its marketing and business development team. The company reported a net profit of S$1.06 million for half-year 2018, up from S$583,000 a year ago.

site_title: Malaysia: Markets closed on Tuesday for public holiday
summary: Malaysia's financial markets are closed on Tuesday, November 20, for a public holiday. Trading will resume on Wednesday, November 21. This is the only relevant information provided in the article.

site_title: Societe Generale fined US$1.3b for US sanctions violations
summary: Societe Generale, a French bank, has been fined US$1.3 billion by US officials for violating US sanctions on Cuba, Iran, and other countries. The bank engaged in over 2,500 Cuba-related transactions from 2004 to 2010, involving US$13 billion, and failed to disclose the matter to US authorities. The bank has agreed to a three-year probation period and has set aside funds to pay the fine. This is the second-largest fine on a financial institution for violating US sanctions.

site_title: World wine output rises 13% after disastrous year
summary: Global wine production rose 13% in 2018, rebounding from a disastrous year in 2017 marked by heatwaves, frosts, and hailstorms. This year's production was estimated at 279 million hectolitres, one of the highest since 2000. Italy was the world's top producer with 48.5 million hectolitres, followed by France and Spain. The US was the biggest global consumer, with a 3.4% increase in volume and 4.8% increase in value compared to 2016.

site_title: White House restores CNN journalist's credentials, with warning
summary: The White House has restored CNN journalist Jim Acosta's full media credentials after a contentious legal battle, but also warned that he may be ejected again if he fails to follow new rules. The new rules require journalists to ask a single question and yield the floor, with follow-up questions only taken at the discretion of the president or White House official. CNN dropped its lawsuit on Acosta's access, citing the restored credentials. The White House had previously ejected Acosta after a heated exchange with President Donald Trump.

site_title: With Ghosn gone, so is the glue that held the world's biggest car group together
summary: Carlos Ghosn's arrest in Japan has led to cracks in the automotive alliance he skillfully held together for nearly two decades. Nissan's CEO Hiroto Saikawa criticized the alliance, citing undervalued Japanese markets and biased product decisions. Renault officials demanded continuity, with President Emmanuel Macron remaining "extremely vigilant" on the alliance's stability. Ghosn's departure leaves no obvious person to fill his role, potentially jeopardizing integration and future mergers. Renault shares plummeted 8.4% after the news, while analysts warn of a "gulf" opening up between Renault and Nissan.

site_title: New Petrobras CEO rules out privatisation, wants non-core asset sales
summary: Brazil's new Petrobras CEO, Roberto Castello Branco, has ruled out privatizing the state-run company, but plans to sell non-core assets and focus on oil exploration and production. The appointment is part of President-elect Jair Bolsonaro's market-friendly selections, influenced by his adviser Paulo Guedes. Castello Branco's stance aims to stabilize the indebted company, which is Latin America's largest by market capitalization.

site_title: Crude futures rises slightly despite oversupply fears
summary: Crude oil futures rose slightly, settling up 3 cents at $66.79 a barrel, despite concerns over oversupply and global demand. A reported US oil inventory drawdown and potential EU sanctions on Iran supported prices. OPEC is pushing for 1-1.4 million barrel per day production cuts, but clear signals from producers are needed to support the market. US crude stockpiles have grown for eight straight weeks, and global demand is slowing due to a trade war between the US and China, with investors becoming bearish on crude prices.

site_title: Halcyon Agri implements sustainable natural rubber supply chain policy
summary: Halcyon Agri, the world's largest natural rubber supplier, has launched a sustainable natural rubber supply chain policy (SNRSCP) to minimize environmental impact. The policy covers seven areas, including working conditions, land acquisition, ecosystem protection, and good agricultural practices. The company aims to achieve zero-net deforestation and will implement integrated landscape management with environmental and social organizations. A Sustainability Commission will monitor policy implementation, with updates expected in Q1 2019.

site_title: 500 Startups surpasses Vietnam fund goal by raising US$14m
summary: 500 Startups, a venture capital investor, has exceeded its target for its Vietnam fund by raising US$14 million to back startups in the country. The fund, which was initially set to raise US$10 million, has secured backing from GS Home Shopping Inc., Humax Co., and NCORE Ventures. With a population of 100 million and a high mobile phone penetration, Vietnam is emerging as an attractive market for technology investors, with 500 Startups having invested in 36 companies in the country since 2017.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Hotel Properties Limited, Hyflux, SATS
summary: Hotel Properties Limited plans to buy a 740-acre site in Tuscany, Italy for S$35.4 million, using loans and internal resources. Hyflux sold its 50% stake in an Indonesian bottled water firm for S$32 million, resulting in a S$300,000 loss. SATS will build a central kitchen in Tianjin, China, and acquire stakes in two China joint ventures from Wilmar International.

images.alt_text: Water treatment firm Hyflux has sold its 50 per cent stake in a firm that sells bottled drinking water in Indonesia for S$32 million.

site_title: Saudi king backs son amid furore over Khashoggi murder
summary: Saudi King Salman reaffirmed his support for Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, amid international criticism over the murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi. The king praised the judiciary and public prosecution, but made no direct reference to Khashoggi's death. The CIA has reported that the crown prince ordered the assassination, but the public prosecutor exonerated him. The king's comments were seen as an effort to shore up support for the crown prince, who is facing intense global criticism.

site_title: Singapore at forefront in Asia for talent competitiveness
summary: Singapore has maintained its 13th position globally in the IMD World Talent Ranking 2018, ahead of Hong Kong and Malaysia. The country fared well in attracting highly skilled professionals and education outcomes, but ranked 60th in public education investment, investing only 2.9% of its GDP. Director Arturo Bris notes that Singapore's efficient education system is a key factor in its success, but also highlights the need for increased investment in public education to reduce inequality.

site_title: Europe: Stocks resume their slide a tech tumbles, Renault slumps
summary: European stocks ended at a three-week low, falling 0.7% as tech stocks plummeted 2% to a 20-month closing low due to concerns over Apple's iPhone demand. Renault shares sank 9.4% after CEO Carlos Ghosn's arrest in Japan on allegations of financial misconduct, raising questions about the future of the alliance with Nissan. The Stoxx 600 has lost its fourth consecutive day, and analysts have cut earnings estimates at the fastest pace since the Brexit vote selloff.

site_title: Commonwealth Bank of Australia CEO grilled over financial sector misconduct
summary: Commonwealth Bank of Australia CEO Matt Comyn testified before a public inquiry into financial sector misconduct, stating that senior staff felt powerless to stop thousands of breaches of anti-money laundering laws. Comyn acknowledged the bank's systemic complacency and expressed willingness to reform, including replacing bonuses for mortgage brokers with flat fees. However, he noted that unilateral action would be challenging and required cooperation from other major banks. The inquiry's final report is expected to recommend sweeping reforms, particularly around conflicted bonuses and incentives.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: US President Trump imposes a 50% copper import tariff, covering refined metal. This comes as investors weigh market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions, causing oil prices to rise over 2%. The US stock market edges down from records amid tariff threats. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer receives 9.8 times oversubscription. Creative Technology warns of potential revenue shortfall in H2, citing operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow considers increasing fees for a £10 billion upgrade.

site_title: Berlin imposes travel ban, arms freeze over Khashoggi killing
summary: Germany imposed a travel ban and arms freeze on 18 Saudis suspected of involvement in Jamal Khashoggi's killing, affecting the Schengen zone. The decision, coordinated with France and Britain, aims to push for a tougher line on Saudi Arabia. The EU's largest country, Germany, used its influence to secure support from other member states. The move follows the killing of Khashoggi, a journalist and critic of Saudi Arabia, in 2018.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Coffee with Claressa - Vincent Sim, leadership with a personal touch
summary: Karcher Singapore's General Manager, Vincent Sim, shared his management philosophy on the Money FM podcast "Coffee with Claressa". He discussed how his decision-making has benefited from embracing a 'personal touch' management style, allowing for more effective leadership. The conversation highlighted the importance of empathy and understanding in leadership, providing a unique perspective on corporate management.

images.alt_text: Karcher Singapore's GM Vincent Sim

site_title: May wins business support for draft Brexit deal
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May secured support from big business for her draft Brexit deal, with the Confederation of British Industry (CBI) backing the agreement as a "hard-won progress." May faces an uphill challenge to pass the deal through a skeptical parliament, but CBI chief Carolyn Fairbairn described it as a "step back from the cliff-edge" that offers a transitional period. May also promised to introduce streamlined immigration processes to attract skilled workers, while Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn vowed to vote against the deal and demand a general election if it fails.

site_title: US: Stocks sink amid tech sell-off; Nasdaq -3.0%
summary: US stocks plummeted on Monday, with the Nasdaq Composite Index falling 3.0% to 7,028.48, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 1.6% to 25,017.44. Tech shares led the decline, with Apple, Facebook, Amazon, Netflix, and Adobe all falling 5% or more. The decline follows a blowout third-quarter earnings period and concerns about US-China trade tensions and slowing US growth, with Goldman Sachs predicting a US recession is unlikely but growth will slow to 1.75% by the end of 2019.

site_title: In uncertain property market, try before you buy
summary: In uncertain property markets, some developers are adopting the "try before you buy" concept, allowing potential homeowners to rent and experience a property before making a purchase. This concept is seen as perfect for a risky time, allowing buyers to be sure they're making the right choice. Experts say it's essential to consider both personality and financial factors when buying a house, especially in uncertain times. The concept is being implemented in both second-home and urban condominium markets, with some developers offering free stays or charging a refundable fee for the experience.

site_title: Federal Reserve governor Randal Quarles poised to become FSB chair
summary: Federal Reserve Governor Randal Quarles is poised to become the new head of the Financial Stability Board (FSB), following Bank of England Governor Mark Carney's departure in December. Quarles, a pragmatist on regulation, is seen as a compromise to keep the US engaged in the FSB, which has been coordinating international rules since the global financial crisis. European regulators hope this appointment will ensure US commitment to the body, while Klaas Knot will become FSB vice chair.

site_title: It's time for a new act, Mr Trump
summary: President Donald Trump's populist and nationalist shtick has worked for his base, but his closest aides urge him to adopt a new act to avoid being divisive and more presidential. Despite winning the 2016 election, Trump lost support from traditional Republican voters, particularly white suburban and professional women, who find his shtick repulsive. His divisive rhetoric has also alienated minority groups and younger voters. To regain support, Trump needs to develop a new act that is less divisive and more inclusive, rather than relying on his old shtick.

site_title: Coal producer Golden Energy and Resources bids for Stanmore Coal
summary: Golden Energy and Resources is acquiring a 19.9% stake in Australia-listed Stanmore Coal for A$47.6 million in cash, with plans to transfer the interest to a 51% joint venture offering up to A$201.13 million for the remaining shares. The acquisition aims to diversify Gear's presence and product suite, and expand its geographical presence. Gear and Ascend Global Investment Fund will fund the joint venture's bid through subscriptions for additional shares. The deal is valued at up to A$249 million.

site_title: Ascott to boost presence with Ciputra alliance
summary: CapitaLand's serviced residence arm, The Ascott, has formed a strategic alliance with Indonesian property developer Ciputra Development Group. The partnership will boost Ascott's pipeline in Indonesia and China over the next 5 years, with the first property, Citadines Sudirman Jakarta, set to open in 2021. The alliance follows previous partnerships with Ciputra, including the acquisition of Ascott Sudirman Jakarta and Ascott Kuningan Jakarta. Ascott expects to expand its growth in Indonesia, driven by the country's increasing economic activities and infrastructure developments.

site_title: Air traffic controllers work to ease holiday rush
summary: Air traffic controllers are working to ease the holiday travel rush in the US, aiming to maximize airspace without overwhelming high-traffic routes. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has implemented a playbook to temporarily reclaim military airspace and offer it to airlines. With 54.3 million travelers expected, this is the highest total in over a decade, and traffic management specialists are advising drivers to avoid peak commute periods and usual choke points. The FAA is also working to balance demand with system capacity, and pilots are being guided by the bigger picture, with weather being the most persistent and disruptive unknown.

site_title: UK housing woes deepen as asking prices fall
summary: UK housing prices have fallen for the first time since 2011, with asking prices decreasing 0.2% to £302,023, according to Rightmove. The decline is attributed to uncertainty over the UK's divorce from the EU, which has led to buyers becoming more cautious and sellers lowering their asking prices. London saw the largest decline, with asking prices falling 2.4% annually to £614,271, while outer Zone 6 areas saw a 3.1% increase. The decline marks a weakening of the UK property market after a three-decade boom.

site_title: Bitcoin falls below US$5,000 for first time since 2017
summary: Bitcoin's value has fallen below US$5,000 for the first time since October 2017, according to data from Coinbase. The cryptocurrency lost 12.5% of its value from Friday evening to US$4,914.21 by Monday, amid a broad selloff in the opaque market. This decline has also affected other cryptocurrencies, such as ethereum and ripple.

site_title: Business climate worsens, but Singapore's prospects still beat China's, survey finds
summary: Singapore's business climate worsened in the third quarter, with negative readings on indicators such as sales net balance, profits net balance, and business prospects. However, the city-state still ranks top in business prospects for the next 12 months, beating out China and Vietnam. The survey attributed the improvement to easing global risk levels and a domestic labour market recovery. Despite this, companies are cautious about the near-term outlook due to trade tensions and a shrinking pie. A regression analysis projects 1.8-2.5% GDP growth for the fourth quarter.

site_title: Corporate governance at the crossroads
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has updated the Code of Corporate Governance for Singapore, introducing a more principle-based approach with a "comply or explain" framework. The revised Code aims to reduce boilerplate explanations and improve substance in corporate governance reports. However, some stakeholders are concerned that the new approach may lead to a regression in standards, particularly in areas such as director independence. The MAS has also introduced a two-tier voting system for long-serving independent directors, which aims to balance the power between controlling shareholders and minority shareholders.

site_title: OCBC rolls out annual review process for financial life goals
summary: OCBC Bank has launched an annual review process for its financial life goals program, which is the first of its kind in Singapore. The service is free for customers who have mapped out their financial goals using the Life Goals program and will send an SMS alert to review their portfolio once a year. This aims to cater to customers who are too busy or lack a dedicated relationship manager to review their portfolios regularly.

site_title: Japan's plan to allow more foreign workers sparks concerns
summary: Japan is introducing a bill to allow hundreds of thousands of "semi-skilled" foreign workers to enter the country in the coming years, marking a significant shift in the country's immigration policy. The plan aims to address Japan's labor shortage, which is expected to worsen due to a shrinking population and aging workforce. Critics argue that the plan lacks rigorous planning and integration strategies, while proponents see it as a necessary step to reverse the country's demographic decline.

site_title: E-wallet, crypto players show support for Payment Services Bill
summary: E-wallet and cryptocurrency players in Singapore have welcomed the new Payment Services Bill, which regulates cryptocurrency activities and places e-wallet players under tighter supervision. The bill was tabled for a first reading in Parliament, marking the first time cryptocurrency players will be expressly regulated. While some expressed reservations, the industry generally saw the new framework as a positive step, indicating a shift towards greater regulatory clarity and stability.

site_title: Stormy days ahead in US-China relations
summary: US-China relations are expected to remain tense despite a planned bilateral summit in Buenos Aires on December 1, with key differences remaining unresolved. The two nations have agreed to meet in Buenos Aires ahead of the summit, suggesting a potential trade accord may be within reach. However, fundamental issues such as the South China Sea and Taiwan remain a point of contention. The US and China will mark the 40th anniversary of diplomatic relations next month, which will be closely analyzed by commentators.

site_title: BHP to pay A$529m to Aussie taxman to resolve dispute over Singapore hub
summary: BHP has agreed to pay A$529 million in additional taxes to the Australian taxman to resolve a long-running dispute over its operations in Singapore. The dispute concerned the sales of Australian commodities to the miner's Singapore marketing business. The payment, which covers income from 2003 to 2018, is part of a settlement between the miner and the Australian tax authorities.

site_title: Sapphire Corp's consortium wins 1.4 billion yuan, 15-year public-private-partnership project in Chengdu
summary: Sapphire Corp's consortium, comprising Ranken Railway Construction Group Co Ltd, has won a 1.4 billion yuan, 15-year public-private-partnership project in Chengdu, China. The consortium will be involved in the investment, design, build, operate, and transfer works for the first phase of the Wuhou District "Liveable River Bank" project. This marks a significant win for Sapphire Corp, further expanding its presence in the Chinese infrastructure market.

site_title: A haven for money in the Middle East, Dubai is losing its shine
summary: Dubai, once a thriving trading hub, is losing its luster due to the US-led global tariff war and its impact on commerce with Iran. The city's iconic builders continue to construct new retail and office space, but uncertainty surrounds occupancy. Unlike previous boom-and-bust cycles, this slowdown is distinct. The US tariffs have led to a decline in trade, affecting Dubai's economy and reputation as a haven for international commerce. The city's future growth and appeal are now in question.

site_title: Region's VC, PE to double to US$70b by 2024: Bain report
summary: A report by Bain & Co predicts that Southeast Asia's venture capital and private equity market will double to $70 billion by 2024, driven by strong macroeconomic fundamentals and investment in emerging regional champions. The region is expected to produce at least 10 new unicorns by 2024, with technology companies attracting the majority of new capital, accounting for 40% of deal count in 2017. Investors are also showing interest in healthcare and education sectors, with Singapore remaining the region's investment hub but facing competition from Indonesia and Vietnam.

site_title: M&As can bring relief to Asia's crowded skies
summary: Asia's crowded skies may see relief through mergers and acquisitions. Overcapacity, low prices, and net losses among major airlines in India and Southeast Asia have raised concerns. Consolidation efforts, such as Indonesia's Garuda taking over Sriwijaya Air, and India's Jet Airways potentially being acquired by Tata and Singapore Airlines, could ease cut-throat competition and improve airline viability. Market forces, rather than government intervention, are seen as the best solution, with new owners taking a more sustainable approach to pricing. This could lead to higher fares and improved efficiency in the industry.

site_title: Home security systems become more sophisticated
summary: Home security systems have become increasingly sophisticated with the integration of wireless or cellular all-in-one systems, voice command capabilities, and roving robots. These systems enable homeowners to remotely monitor their properties and receive alerts when unusual activity is detected. Advanced camera systems with 360-degree vision and data analytics are being installed in high-end buildings, while smart access systems allow residents to control access to their buildings through their cellphones. The use of artificial intelligence and facial-recognition capabilities is also becoming more prevalent, offering enhanced security features for homeowners.

site_title: Branson gets behind push to design more efficient air conditioners
summary: Richard Branson has initiated the Global Cooling Prize, a $3 million competition to develop more efficient air conditioning technology. The prize aims to address the growing issue of air conditioners contributing to global warming, with an estimated 4.5 billion units worldwide by 2050. The competition seeks to develop cooling methods that are five times more efficient, with the goal of "literally helping save the world." The prize is open to startups and individuals, with the first round offering $200,000 to build prototypes of more efficient cooling methods.

site_title: Red lights flashing for cross-Channel truck pile-up with Brexit
summary: A no-deal Brexit poses significant risks to the UK-France border, particularly for heavy goods vehicles. The Channel's current smooth flow of 10,000 trucks daily could be severely disrupted, with potential doubling of transit times due to additional controls. This could lead to queues, traffic jams, and increased vulnerability to migrant incursions. The port of Dover, with limited land, is struggling to adapt to the potential chaos, while some companies are preparing for a no-deal scenario.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Two Singapore-listed companies received upgrades from analysts. BS Group Research maintained a "buy" call on CDL Hospitality Trusts, targeting S$1.85 with a 24% upside, citing a projected 3-5% RevPAR growth in the hospitality market. HB Research Institute upgraded Food Empire's rating to "buy" with a target price of S$0.66, following Q3 2018 results that beat expectations despite forex losses.

site_title: CIMB makes new management appointments
summary: CIMB Group announced new management appointments, effective January 1, 2019. Shahnaz Jammal will step down as CFO to become CEO of wholesale banking, while Khairulanwar Rifaie will succeed him as CFO. Omar Siddiq, former head of group wholesale banking, will become COO, and Effendy Shahul Hamid will lead the new group ventures and partnerships division. The changes aim to drive growth across businesses and geographies, with customers remaining the top priority.

site_title: Developments progressing well towards modernisation and prosperity
summary: Oman celebrated its 48th National Day on November 18, 2018, with a message of pride and gratitude to Sultan Qaboos bin Said for the country's achievements in various fields. The country has diversified its economy, reducing its reliance on oil, and aims to increase foreign investments and private sector participation. Oman's tourism sector is thriving, with the new Muscat International Airport and e-visas. The country has also strengthened its bilateral ties with Singapore, with the Sultanate welcoming Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean for an official visit.

site_title: Ensuring a bountiful harvest
summary: Asiatic Agricultural Industries, a Singapore-based SME, has contributed to food security and public health through its agrochemical products since 1972. The company has grown its distribution network to cover Southeast Asia, Africa, the Middle East, and India, and has established itself as a trusted supplier of crop protection and public health chemicals. Asiatic's success is attributed to its dedication to building long-term relationships with customers, embracing innovation, and partnering with local stakeholders to conduct efficacy trials. The company has also launched a mobile app, CropSolv, to provide real-time technical support to farmers.

site_title: New York's Grand Central Terminal sold for US$35m
summary: The New York Metropolitan Transportation Authority (MTA) has approved the purchase of Grand Central Terminal for US$35 million, a price that reflects a centuries-long lease agreement struck in the early 1990s. The agency will have an option to buy the terminal in 11 months, with the current rent being paid at US$2.4 million annually. The purchase is seen as a financially savvy move, especially considering the terminal's value in a real estate market known for being among the most expensive in the world.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Hotel Properties Ltd plans to buy a 740-acre site in Tuscany, Italy for 22.6 million euros, including a five-star hotel and chapel. Hyflux Ltd sold its 50% stake in a bottled water firm in Indonesia for S$32 million, resulting in a loss of S$300,000. Hyflux aims to use the sale proceeds to repay debts and channel funds for working capital. These transactions come as Hyflux continues its restructuring efforts.

site_title: Internet economy in South-east Asia to top US$240b by 2025: study
summary: The internet economy in South-east Asia is projected to reach $240 billion by 2025, surpassing the previous estimate of $200 billion, driven by lower internet costs and mobile phone adoption. The region's internet economy grew 37% in 2018, accelerating beyond the 32% CAGR recorded between 2015 and 2018. Indonesia is the fastest-growing market, with e-commerce expected to exceed $100 billion by 2025, accounting for 70% of the market.

site_title: Where birds sing, shrimp grow, developers circle
summary: In Hong Kong's northwest, a rare wetland ecosystem is threatened by developers. The 4,350-acre wetlands, home to endangered species, is a popular spot for birdwatchers and nature lovers, but land prices are high, making development more lucrative. Despite a recent proposal to include apartments for 6,500 people, environmental groups oppose the plan, citing the area's unique sensitivity and potential loss of wetlands. The area's protection is limited, and a 15-foot fence blocks mainland access, but poachers still visit. Conservation efforts, such as the Mai Po Nature Reserve, protect traditional shrimp farming ponds, but the area's future remains uncertain.

site_title: US$ bulls wary after biggest weekly drop in months
summary: The US dollar experienced its largest weekly drop in two months, falling nearly half a percent, due to dovish comments from US policymakers, including Federal Reserve officials, about a potential slowdown in global growth. The greenback steadied at 96.48 against a basket of rivals, after rising nearly 10% in 2018. Investors grew cautious about the near-term outlook for the dollar, with long US dollar positions swelling to nearly two-year highs despite the modest decline.

site_title: China begins anti-dumping probe into Aussie barley as tensions simmer
summary: China has launched an anti-dumping investigation into Australian barley imports, citing "lower than normal" prices that have affected its domestic industry. The one-year probe, which could be extended to May 2020, is seen as a sign of strained relations between China and Australia amid the trade war with the US. Despite Australia's assurances that it does not dump barley, the investigation may impact China's brewing industry and raise domestic beer prices, as China struggles to meet its demand for brewing-quality barley.

site_title: Fantastic Beasts 2 charms with US$62m debut
summary: Fantastic Beasts 2, "The Crimes of Grindelwald," earned a US$62 million debut in the US, dominating the weekend box office. The film's performance is slightly lower than its predecessor, but it has already earned US$191 million internationally. Despite mixed reviews, the movie appeals to Potterheads, and other films like "Instant Family" and "Widows" also performed well, with "The Grinch" taking second place.

site_title: Intense week of talks ahead of Brexit showdown summit
summary: European governments will debate future ties with the UK this week ahead of a Brexit showdown summit on Sunday, where Britain's divorce papers will be signed. Ministers from the 27 EU member states gather in Brussels to finalize a parallel political declaration outlining a roadmap for post-Brexit negotiations. London wants to secure a free trade agreement before the end of the 21-month transition period, while Brussels insists on maintaining its single market rules. The EU and UK are scrambling to finalize the agreement, with Prime Minister Theresa May set to meet EU Commission head Jean-Claude Juncker for last-minute talks.

site_title: Airbnb Q3 revenue stands at more than US$1b
summary: Airbnb reported Q3 revenue exceeding US$1 billion, marking its strongest quarter yet ahead of an anticipated IPO next year. The company cited growth in key overseas markets and suburban areas, with bookings increasing by 91% in Beijing, 79% in Mexico City, and 70% in Birmingham, England. Airbnb achieved its first full year of profitability in 2017 and is on track to be profitable this year. The company faces regulatory battles, particularly in Europe and the US, as cities try to limit its impact on housing stock and rental prices.

site_title: New tech regulation inevitable: Apple CEO
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook predicts new regulations on tech companies and social networks to protect personal data are "inevitable" and will likely be passed by the US Congress. Cook, who has previously advocated for self-regulation, now believes the industry's failure to protect user data following the Cambridge Analytica scandal means regulation is necessary. Cook also expressed support for improving gender diversity in the tech industry, stating that progress is expected over time.

site_title: Corporate America's debt boom looking more like bust for the economy
summary: Corporate America's debt boom appears to be unsustainable, with non-financial corporate debt reaching 45.6% of gross domestic product, near the highest in post-war record-keeping. Despite the Republican tax plan's incentives to boost economic growth, many companies are issuing debt for other reasons, such as to finance acquisitions or refinance existing debt. This debt boom may lead to economic instability, raising concerns about the long-term health of the US economy.

site_title: Clifton Partners picks up Tras St shophouse trio for S$21.2m
summary: Singapore property investment firm Clifton Partners has acquired three adjoining two-storey shophouses on Tras Street in the Tanjong Pagar Conservation Area for S$21.2 million. The property, linked to investor Stanley Quek, reflects a gross yield of nearly 3.5% based on current tenancies. This sale marks another conservation shophouse property being offloaded by Quek, following previous sales.

site_title: China's fight against smog makes palladium 2018's best metal
summary: Palladium prices have surged almost 9% this year, making it the best-performing major metal, driven by China's efforts to reduce smog emissions. The metal's use in pollution-control devices in cars has increased, with global production falling short of demand. Market forecasters project further price gains, with hedge funds betting on an extended rally. However, a threat to demand is the substitution of palladium with platinum, but this is unlikely to impact prices in the near term.

site_title: Traders slam crypto exchange for fiddling with contracts
summary: OKEx, a major cryptocurrency exchange, has faced backlash from traders after unilaterally forcing the early settlement of its Bitcoin Cash contracts, resulting in losses for some users. The move, which occurred without prior notice, has eroded confidence in the exchange and its ability to manage risk. Several traders have filed complaints and reduced their use of the platform, citing concerns over the exchange's credibility and lack of transparency. The incident highlights the risks of using unregulated virtual currency platforms and the need for regulation to promote a fair and healthy trading environment.

site_title: Arrest of Nissan's Ghosn rocks investor confidence in Renault
summary: Nissan Motor Co chairman Carlos Ghosn was arrested over suspected financial violations, causing investor confidence in Renault SA to dwindle. Renault's shares plummeted 15% in Paris trading, the largest decline since 2016, amid concerns about repercussions for the French-Japanese alliance. Ghosn, who played a pivotal role in cementing the alliance, is accused of making personal use of company assets and failing to report his full compensation. The French government has vowed to preserve Renault's stability and support its employees, while Nissan's board is set to meet to remove Ghosn and board member Greg Kelly.

site_title: Sea deepens partnership with Tencent, to sell games in region
summary: Sea's entertainment unit, Garena, has signed a 5-year agreement with Tencent Holdings to distribute and promote top Tencent games in Indonesia, Taiwan, Thailand, the Philippines, Malaysia, and Singapore. The partnership builds on a long-standing relationship between the two companies, which already publishes successful games like Arena of Valor and League of Legends in Sea's core markets. The deal grants Garena a right of first refusal to publish Tencent's games in the region, further solidifying their strategic partnership.

site_title: 2019 home prices could fall in some smaller Chinese cities: Fitch
summary: Fitch Ratings predicts that home prices in smaller Chinese cities could fall in 2019 due to a broad slowdown in the economy. Despite efforts by the government to curb speculation, investors are exploiting regulatory loopholes in smaller cities. Sales volumes may decline up to 10% in 2019, with lower-tier cities being the most affected. However, the government has considerable scope to ease policies to support the market, and prices are likely to remain stable but fall in some lower-tier cities.

site_title: Deloitte Legal partners new local firm Sabara Law
summary: Deloitte Legal has added Sabara Law to its network, expanding its capabilities in Singapore with a focus on data protection, financial services, and mergers and acquisitions. Managing director Yeoh Lian Chuan, with 24 years of experience, will work with Deloitte Legal International, providing full international legal services in South-east Asia. This move follows similar partnerships by PwC and EY, as the professional services firms aim to offer one-stop shop solutions to clients.

site_title: Hugo Boss's winning plan: more Meghan Markle, fewer suits
summary: Hugo Boss's sales surged after Meghan Markle's royal visit, with its US$595 lambskin pencil skirt selling out online. The company's CEO, Mark Langer, attributes the success to consumers finding inspiration online and wanting instant gratification. This marks a shift for Hugo Boss, which is traditionally known for its suits and sensible shirts. The episode highlights the company's need to adapt to changing consumer behavior and keep pace with online trends.

images.alt_text: Meghan Markle's forest-green outfit lit up Instagram when she graced Chichester with a royal visit. Within minutes, the US$595 lambskin pencil skirt from Hugo Boss AG sold out online.

site_title: China's Internet - the art of the state
summary: China has successfully harnessed the power of the internet to drive technological innovation, despite its authoritarian government. By censoring and controlling the flow of information, Chinese tech companies have thrived, creating a vibrant economy that rivals the US. The government demands stakes in companies and influence over management to keep tech in its place, making it useful to the state. This approach has allowed Chinese firms like Alibaba and Tencent to dominate industries, while US companies look to them for inspiration, highlighting the benefits of China's unique approach to technology and innovation.

site_title: Oman is open to all
summary: Oman is open to foreign investment, with its economic diversification efforts creating opportunities for growth. The country has shifted its focus away from oil since 2016, with the National Program for Enhancing Economic Diversification (tanfeedh) aiming to develop sectors like manufacturing, tourism, and mining. Oman's ninth five-year development plan, from 2016 to 2020, aims to enhance diversification and private sector engagement, making it an attractive destination for investors.

site_title: Toys 'R' Us Asia just wants to grow up
summary: Toys 'R' Us Asia is ramping up investments, including store and e-commerce growth, data analytics, and hiring, after its separation from the US-based Toys "R" Us Inc, which filed for bankruptcy protection last year. The company's new owners, including US-based financial institutions and funds, have taken a 21% stake in the business. CEO Andre Javes stated that there are no current plans for an initial public offering (IPO) despite the ownership changes, citing consistent growth and an "investment phase." The company has reported a 32.8% increase in post-tax profit for the year to Dec 31, 2017, and has over 500 stores across Asia.

site_title: STI down 0.6% after Apec summit divide
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) declined 18.53 points, or 0.6%, to close at 3,065.07 on Monday, November 19, 2018, following the APEC summit, where US and China trade tensions overshadowed potential breakthroughs. Local banks OCBC, UOB, and DBS dropped, while Best World International rose 3.3%. Analysts attributed the market's decline to uncertainty and rising external risks, including the US-China trade tensions and Fed rate normalisation.

site_title: RCEP pact should be sealed soon to avoid losing credibility
summary: ASEAN and its key trading partners aim to finalize the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) by the end of 2019, despite the agreement's failure to conclude last week. The pact, if sealed, would be the world's largest economic grouping, covering 40% of global trade and 45% of the world's population. India is seen as the main obstacle, with its protected economy and concerns over intellectual property rights and investor protection. Elections in India, Indonesia, Australia, and possibly Thailand are also putting pressure on the negotiations, with politicians wary of giving too much away.

site_title: Brexit deal breakthrough underwhelms UK
summary: The UK's draft EU exit deal appears to be in jeopardy, with Prime Minister Theresa May facing a critical week ahead of the scheduled withdrawal from the EU in late March. A YouGov study found that 42% of UK citizens oppose the deal, while 19% support it, with public opinion largely united against it. The deal's complexities, particularly the backstop contingency plan for Northern Ireland, pose significant challenges for May, who is facing a leadership challenge from within the Conservative Party and must navigate ratification in the House of Commons without a majority.

site_title: Noble seeks life as smaller, coal-trading business
summary: Noble Group Ltd, once Asia's top commodity trader, has suspended its shares from trading as it seeks to transform into an Asia-focused coal-trading business. The company obtained a US$3.5 billion debt restructuring deal, halving its debt in return for giving 70% ownership to creditors. Existing equity holders will retain 20% in the restructured firm. A new board is expected to be named by end-November, with shares listing in December. The company will have access to US$800 million in trade financing and hedging facilities, crucial for the industry.

site_title: Technology takes a walk on the wild side
summary: A year-end theatre show, "Ki," was performed by The Little Arts Academy in Singapore, featuring digital backdrops created by children aged 6-19 using digital art tools.
