site_title: Investing in driving change
summary: Several Singaporean companies have restructured their corporate social responsibility (CSR) initiatives to align with their core business and mission. Informatics Education, Deloitte & Touche LLP, and Prudential Assurance Company Singapore have made changes to focus on inclusive education opportunities, youth development, and financial literacy. Companies like Shell Companies in Singapore, ABR Holdings, and Ang Chin Moh Funeral Directors have also implemented CSR efforts that incorporate their business values and mission. These efforts aim to create a positive impact on the community and promote sustainability, with many companies believing that CSR is essential to their long-term success.

site_title: Dinner At Datai
summary: The Datai resort on Malaysia's Langkawi island is set to reopen after a $60 million refurbishment. To celebrate its grand opening, the resort is hosting a show-stopping dining event with Michelin-starred chefs Michel and Se´bastien Bras on December 19-20. The event will feature an eight-course cocktail dinner with signature dishes, and is priced around $284 for the dinner and $284 for the wine pairing. The resort's luxurious villas will offer a fitting end to the evening, allowing guests to relax in a natural rainforest setting.

site_title: Noble granted court sanctions for debt revamp schemes
summary: Noble Group's debt restructuring schemes have been granted court sanctions in England and Bermuda, allowing the company to proceed with its plan to restructure its debt. The schemes, which involve handing over 70% of equity to senior creditors, were approved by shareholders in August. Noble reported a third-quarter net loss of $99 million, with revenue down 17.4% and a 16% decline in its metals segment. The company's shares closed at 8.3 Singapore cents, down 0.5 cents. The restructuring is expected to be effective on November 26.

site_title: Ascendas-Singbridge 'mulling US$500m Reit IPO'
summary: Ascendas-Singbridge Group is considering a US$500 million real estate investment trust (Reit) IPO, backed by recently acquired US office properties. The firm, owned by Temasek Holdings and JTC Corp, bought a portfolio of 33 US office properties with tenants including Nike and Oracle. A possible IPO could take place as early as the first quarter, with details including size and timing still being deliberated. This would add to the US$3.1 billion of property trust listings in Singapore over the last three years.

site_title: Remembering Bugis
summary: A site-specific performance titled "Bitten: Return To Our Roots" will be held in Kampong Bugis, recalling the district's 1950s industrial pride. Dancers will perform at various locations, including the skeletal remains of the Kallang Gasworks, choreographed by Thong Pei Qin and Dr Nidya Shanthini Manokara. The performance combines verbatim storytelling and bharatanatyam dance and will run on Nov 24-25 and Dec 1-2.

site_title: SGX: No basis to suspend voluntary delistings amid consultation
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has rejected a suggestion by corporate governance advocate Mak Yuen Teen to suspend voluntary delistings until a proposed change in the rules comes into effect. The change, which would shift voting power to minority shareholders, is currently undergoing public consultation. One company, LTC Corp, was set to hold an extraordinary general meeting to vote on a voluntary delisting but was adjourned after shareholders sought a surprise adjournment, citing the proposed changes. Mak fears some companies may try to beat the deadline, and the SGX may consider a moratorium on delistings until the new rules are in place.

site_title: It's Europe that really won the Brexit brinkmanship
summary: The EU has emerged stronger from the Brexit brinkmanship, with the UK's exit deal signaling it will remain tethered to the bloc for the foreseeable future. The terms of the exit deal make clear that Britain will play by the EU's rules, effectively becoming a vassal state of Brussels. The EU has galvanized its 27 remaining governments, with polls showing support for the bloc at its highest in 35 years. The UK's failure to negotiate a mutually beneficial deal has left it isolated, with no other EU member state following its lead.

site_title: May risks facing 'no confidence' vote without EU deals
summary: The UK Parliament is likely to vote against Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit draft deal unless the EU provides compromises. Sterling plummeted 1.5% as fears of a no-deal Brexit mounted. The draft agreement proposes the UK to remain in the EU's single market and subject to EU laws until December 2020, with a new trade relationship to be negotiated. The "backstop" solution, which would keep the UK in the EU's customs union, has sparked opposition from Cabinet ministers and MPs, threatening May's leadership.

site_title: Now's not the time to celebrate Tencent earnings
summary: Tencent Holdings Ltd reported a 27% beat on analyst estimates in its third quarter, driven by the IPO of Meituan Dianping, which contributed 8.8 billion yuan to profit. However, challenges persist, including declining Meituan's share price and the suspension of new game licenses in China. Advertising revenue grew 80% year-over-year, mainly from WeChat, but management's restraint in promotions may hold back growth. The company's "others" category, including cloud and payments, saw a 69% revenue increase but contributes low margins. A sustained profit pickup is uncertain until Tencent's strategy gains momentum.

site_title: Drunk raccoons cause false rabies scare in West Virginia
summary: A false rabies scare in West Virginia was caused by drunk raccoons that had been feeding on fermented crab apples. The raccoons, named Dallas, were found staggering and disoriented by police, who realized they were intoxicated, not rabid. The animals were held in a "drunk tank" and released into the wild after sobering up. This incident is part of a growing trend of animals getting drunk due to human activities, such as people giving marijuana to pets or exposing them to vaping.

site_title: Cisco shines as new areas of business pay off
summary: Cisco Systems Inc. beat analyst estimates with a 7.7% increase in quarterly revenue to $13.07 billion, driven by growth in software and cybersecurity businesses. The company's application software businesses rose 18% to $1.42 billion, while its security business rose 11% to $651 million. Cisco's infrastructure platform unit revenue rose 9% to $7.64 billion, and the company expects second-quarter revenue growth of 5-7%. The company's shares rose 4% in extended trading, putting them on track for a near 16% gain for the year.

site_title: Emirates warns of tough six months ahead as profit drops
summary: Emirates' first-half profit dropped 86% to 226 million dirhams due to higher fuel costs and unfavorable currency moves, with revenue rising 10% to 48.9 billion dirhams. The airline faces a tough six months ahead, citing relentless downward pressure on yields and uncertain economic and political realities. Operating costs rose 13% with fuel costs up 42%, and the workforce shrunk by 1.4% due to natural attrition and slower recruitment. The airline's chairman warned of a challenging period ahead, echoing similar warnings from other airlines.

site_title: Fund managers place bets on Asia's oversold assets
summary: Fund managers are betting on Asia's oversold assets, particularly high-yielding dollar bonds, as global growth and trade concerns push markets into bear territory. Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan have declined 15.5% this year, while currencies from emerging markets have come under pressure. Despite negative factors, some fund managers see value in Chinese equities and dollar-denominated bonds, citing healthy current accounts and lower foreign debt levels in emerging markets. They are seeking alternatives to US equities, which have been the lone outperformers globally.

site_title: Govt 'can't be hands off about the property cycle'
summary: National Development Minister Lawrence Wong stated that the government cannot be hands-off about the property cycle, as it may lead to bubble development. If the authorities hadn't intervened, private home prices in Singapore were likely to increase by 10-15% this year. Wong's comments were made at the Redas anniversary dinner, citing the potential for significant price growth if the government hadn't imposed cooling measures in July.

site_title: KGI downgrades Accordia Golf Trust to 'hold' but sees limited downside risks for investors
summary: Broker KGI Securities downgrades Accordia Golf Trust (AGT) to "hold" with a revised target price of S$0.61 due to natural disasters, lack of re-rating catalysts, and a cautious macroeconomic outlook. The stock closed flat at S$0.49, with KGI expecting AGT's FY2019 dividend to fall but recover in subsequent years. Limited downside risks and potential acquisition opportunities are seen as positive for investors.

site_title: Rosmah charged with two additional counts of corruption in helping company win govt project
summary: Malaysia has charged Rosmah Mansor, the wife of former Prime Minister Najib Razak, with two additional counts of corruption involving bribes worth RM189 million (S$62.1 million) to secure a government project. Rosmah faces up to 20 years in jail and a fine of at least five times the amount. The charges follow a wide-ranging graft investigation launched by Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, who returned to power after a stunning election victory in May. Najib and Rosmah have pleaded not guilty to all charges.

site_title: The Return Of Polaroid
summary: Polaroid cameras, once considered a relic of the past, are experiencing a resurgence in popularity, driven by nostalgia and the unique qualities of instant photography. An exhibition at the National Museum of Singapore, "In An Instant: Polaroid At The Intersection Of Art And Technology," showcases the camera's history as a tool for cutting-edge artists, including Andy Warhol and Ansel Adams, who experimented with its technology. The show features over 220 photos and artifacts, highlighting Polaroid's impact on art, history, and technology, and runs until March 31, 2019.

images.alt_text: The Polaroid instant camera has been used by many popular artists such as Andy Warhol and Robert Rauschenberg to experiment with image production.
The exhibition at National Museum of Singapore.
Ellen Carey's 20 by 24 inch Polacolor composite artwork.
Maria Magdalena Campos- Pons' photo series on Cuban feminism and heritage.

site_title: Singapore cleaners to get an annual bonus of at least two weeks' pay from Jan 1
summary: Singapore cleaners will receive an annual bonus of at least two weeks' pay starting from January 1, 2020, under the country's progressive wage model. The bonus applies to resident cleaners who have worked at least a year in the same company and benefits over 40,000 cleaners. The move aims to uplift wages, encourage businesses to invest in training, and motivate cleaners to stay with their employers longer.

site_title: Using arts to bring everyone together
summary: Fifteen groups of students from special education schools partnered with mainstream schools and organizations to stage a 90-minute performance at Resorts World Theatre in Singapore, celebrating inclusivity and featuring over 500 differently abled performers. The event, titled "An Extra•Ordinary Celebration," was organized by Extra•Ordinary People, a charity aiming to promote inclusivity and break down stereotypes. The event was met with praise from Minister Ng Chee Meng, who emphasized the importance of inclusivity and values in action, and was hailed as a breakthrough in creating an inclusive society.

site_title: Bitcoin bulls wonder where's the bottom as slide accelerates
summary: Bitcoin's price plummeted 5.9% to $5,221, its biggest one-day loss in eight months, following its biggest one-day loss since August 2017. Bitcoin Cash's hard fork also contributed to the decline, with its price dropping 10%. Analysts predict a potential test of $2,500 for Bitcoin and warn of a prolonged downturn, citing technical measures such as the Directional Movement Index's largest negative reading since 2016. The plunge has raised concerns about the cryptocurrency's stability and suitability as an investment.

site_title: Sterling tumbles as PM May races to salvage Brexit deal
summary: Sterling tumbled 1.5% against the dollar and 1.8% against the euro after Brexit minister Dominic Raab and three other ministers resigned in protest against Prime Minister Theresa May's plan, sparking concerns about her leadership and a potential "no-deal" Brexit. The pound's drop, its second biggest this year, fueled a selloff in UK assets and sent investors to government debt. May showed little sign of backing down, but a leadership challenge is possible, with letters of no confidence in her submitted to party officials, and a hard Brexit now more likely than a negotiated departure.

site_title: Finland's new hope, in BT Weekend
summary: Finland, known for its inclusive education system and social support, is now making a name for itself in the startup scene despite its history of being risk-averse. The country's shift towards embracing startup culture is attributed to the decline of Nokia, a major contributor to Finland's "sick man of Europe" reputation. The nation is now building a social stock exchange to empower women and is investing in impact investing, marking a significant shift in its economic landscape.

site_title: Whole-of-society approach needed against truth decay
summary: A whole-of-society approach is needed to combat truth decay and the threat of fake news, which can compromise democratic functioning and erode trust in institutions. Deliberate falsehoods can be spread through coordinated efforts, technology, and targeted messages, posing a significant threat to societies. While legislation is crucial, it must balance competing interests and protect freedom of speech. A multi-stakeholder approach, enhancing media and information literacy, and bolstering data privacy are essential to defend against disinformation campaigns. Ultimately, it is people's discernment and critical thinking that can help repel falsehoods and preserve democratic values.

images.alt_text: A newsstand in midtown Manhattan which aims to educate the public about the dangers of fake news. The newsstand was set up by the Columbia Journalism Review.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower
summary: US stocks opened lower on Thursday, with the Dow Jones falling 0.08% to 25,061.48, the S&P 500 down 0.30% to 2,693.52, and the Nasdaq Composite 0.33% to 7,112.83. The decline was attributed to mixed results from retailers and a slide in growth stocks, including Facebook and Amazon.com. Despite hopes for a trade negotiation between the US and China, the mixed results offset the potential positive impact.

site_title: Opportunities for growth abound despite tensions
summary: Singapore's economy faces challenges from global geopolitical tensions, particularly with US-China trade relations. Despite this, opportunities for growth exist, such as becoming a global hub for advanced chip packaging. The country can capitalize on its existing deep relationship with China and leverage its strategic location to remain competitive. However, the shrinking of trading markets and downsizing of businesses are potential risks.

site_title: Walmart raises annual earnings estimate on higher quarterly revenue
summary: Walmart raised its annual earnings estimate after posting strong quarterly revenue growth, with total sales increasing 2.4% to $124.9 billion and comparable store sales rising 3.4%. The company attributed the growth to solid sales across all business lines and most regions. Walmart's earnings per share measure rose to $1.08, beating expectations, and the company raised its fiscal year 2019 earnings estimate by 10 cents to $4.75-$4.85. The company cited investments in e-commerce as key to its success in the competitive retail sector.

site_title: African swine fever spreads to more than half of China's provinces
summary: African swine fever has spread to more than half of China's provinces, with the situation described as "very serious" by the government. The disease has caused a spike in pork prices and has significant implications for China, the world's largest pig producer. Despite measures to contain it, the outbreak continues to spread, raising concerns about its impact on the global food supply.

site_title: US retail sales rebound on autos, building materials
summary: US retail sales rebounded 0.8% in October, driven by a surge in motor vehicle and building material sales, likely due to recovery efforts from Hurricane Florence. This rebounded from a 0.1% dip in September, and core retail sales rose 0.3%. Strong labor market and wage growth support consumer spending, which accounts for over two-thirds of US economic activity. The trend in retail sales suggests a solid growth path for the economy, despite slowing business investment and a weakening housing market.

site_title: Trump says Mueller is 'threatening' witnesses without citing any examples
summary: President Donald Trump accused Robert Mueller of "threatening" witnesses in the Russia probe investigation, but provided no examples. Trump's comments came a day after Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell blocked a bipartisan bill to protect Mueller's work. Despite the rhetoric, Trump isn't likely to seek Mueller's ouster or meddle in the probe, according to lawmakers. The move allows the investigation to continue, which has resulted in criminal charges against Russian hackers and Trump campaign associates.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 5.8 points to 1,694.21, with a two-billion lots volume worth RM1.9 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 563 to 285. The market's positive trend was not mentioned in the provided articles.

site_title: Saudi public prosecutor seeks death penalty in Khashoggi murder case
summary: Saudi Arabia's public prosecutor is seeking the death penalty for five out of 11 suspects charged in the murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi, who was killed in the country's Istanbul consulate on October 2 after a struggle. The killing, allegedly ordered by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, has strained Saudi ties with Western allies and sparked a global outcry. The prosecutor's request comes as Turkish officials accuse the prince of ordering the murder and US President Donald Trump suggests ultimate responsibility lies with him. The cases will be referred to court, with investigations ongoing.

site_title: Europe's hottest building markets need workers to return
summary: Europe's construction market, particularly in Eastern Europe, faces a severe labor shortage as workers migrate west in search of better pay. Despite an influx of foreign investment, many projects are struggling to find skilled workers to complete. In Bucharest, construction crews are having trouble finding a dozen workers to complete a high-rise building, highlighting the region's labor shortage. This shortage is expected to impact the construction industry's ability to meet demand, leading to potential delays and cost increases for projects.

site_title: Lawrence Wong, Redas chief give different takes on cooling measures
summary: National Development Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized that the government cannot take a hands-off approach to the property cycle, and instead, will intervene to prevent property bubbles from forming and minimize exuberance in the market. He cited the July cooling measures, which he believes would have led to a 10-15% increase in private home prices, followed by a sharp decline. Wong's approach aims for a steady and sustained property market where prices move in line with income growth or fundamentals.

images.alt_text: Sending a clear message at the 59th anniversary of the Real Estate Developers' Association of Singapore (Redas), National Development Minister Lawrence Wong stressed: "Let me be very clear that government cannot and will not take a hands-off attitude to the property cycle. So there should not be any surprise when we intervene in the market, because that is our approach and attitude."

site_title: Element AI forges partnerships with GIC, SGInnovate, SMU
summary: Element AI has forged partnerships with GIC, SGInnovate, and SMU, focusing on AI applications for large asset managers, expanding the deep tech talent pool in Singapore, and researching AI governance. The partnerships aim to leverage AI to address various challenges and create opportunities for startups to deploy and scale AI solutions. Element AI will work with GIC on North American research, while SMU will focus on Singaporean and Asean aspects, and the three parties will share information and approaches to deliver research papers.

site_title: UK politics instability raises British ad market uncertainty, JCDecaux says
summary: UK politics instability is raising uncertainty in the British ad market, according to JCDecaux co-CEO Jean-Charles Decaux. The recent Cabinet resignations, triggered by a draft EU divorce deal, have reinforced market doubts. Britain's ad market accounts for 10% of JCDecaux's total revenues, making it the company's third-largest market. The uncertainty is affecting JCDecaux's outdoor advertising business, particularly in London, where it manages the bus shelter advertising concession by Transport for London.

site_title: Top Chinese university warns students to avoid activism
summary: Peking University, one of China's top universities, has warned students to avoid associating with the labour-rights organization Jasic Workers Solidarity, citing "criminal activity". The warning comes amid a crackdown on the group, with at least a dozen activists and student supporters detained. The university accused two students of conspiring with Jasic Workers Solidarity and interfering with the arrest of a member. The move marks the latest attempt by authorities to suppress campus activism in China, where universities have historically been a hub for radical movements.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rise at open
summary: European stocks rose at the opening on Thursday, November 15, 2018, as the UK Cabinet backed British Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit deal despite a ministerial resignation. London's FTSE 100 index gained 0.4%, while the eurozone's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 added 0.3% and 0.6%, respectively.

site_title: Britain's work and pensions minister McVey quits over Brexit deal
summary: Britain's work and pensions minister Esther McVey quit Prime Minister Theresa May's Cabinet over a Brexit deal, citing it does not honor the 2016 referendum result. McVey joined Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab in resigning, citing £39 billion handed to the EU without return. The move thrusts the UK into a crisis, with May's premiership potentially at risk.

site_title: Germany eases diesel vehicle bans
summary: The German government has eased diesel vehicle bans in cities that only slightly exceed nitrogen dioxide limits. The new law lowers the threshold from 40 to 50 microgrammes per cubic metre, allowing older Euro 4 and 5 diesel vehicles emitting less than 270 milligrammes of nitrogen dioxide per kilometre to enter exclusion zones. Environmental groups, such as DUH, have criticized the changes, warning of a weakening of EU law and plans to sue the federal government. The move is seen as a compromise to avoid fines and preserve the car industry's interests.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.4 per cent up on Thursday
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.4% on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index gaining 11.34 points to 3,054.53. Gainers outnumbered losers 222 to 170, with Genting Singapore leading the gainers. Telco Singtel added 0.99% to S$3.05, while DBS Group fell 0.22%. The rally comes ahead of GDP data, with stocks maintaining a 5-day rally.

site_title: Malaysia charges former PM Najib's wife Rosmah with receiving bribes of RM189m
summary: Malaysia charges Rosmah Mansor, the wife of former Prime Minister Najib Razak, with receiving bribes of RM189 million for her involvement in a RM1.25 billion solar project in Sarawak. She pleaded not guilty to the two corruption charges. Prosecutors allege the payments were made by a company pitching for the project. This move marks a significant development in the ongoing corruption probe against Najib and his associates.

site_title: Sanli Environmental secures S$54.3m in contracts, order book stands at S$134.4m
summary: Sanli Environmental, a Catalist-listed environment engineering firm, secured S$54.3 million in contracts, boosting its order book to S$134.4 million. The contracts are for its EPC and O&M segments, with the most significant win being a sub-contract for Pulau Tekong's water reclamation plant. The orders are expected to contribute to its revenue for FY2019 and the next four years.

site_title: Ex-minister Mah Bow Tan joins Singapore fintech firm as investor, adviser
summary: Former Singapore minister Mah Bow Tan has joined HydraX, a fintech firm, as an adviser and director. This marks his second board seat in the private sector, alongside his roles as non-executive chairman of GYP Properties and chairman of GlobalCities Sustainable Investment Pte Ltd. The appointment highlights Mah Bow Tan's continued involvement in the financial sector after his tenure as minister for National Development from 1999 to 2011.

site_title: UK signals plan to leave EU emissions trading scheme after Brexit
summary: Britain is likely to leave the European Union's Emissions Trading System (ETS) after Brexit and establish its own equivalent system, according to UK government documents. The country will continue to meet its international commitments under the Paris Climate Agreement, including implementing a system of carbon pricing. Britain's exit from the ETS is expected to impact the price of EU carbon permits, which are currently in high demand due to the country's large industry and utility sectors.

site_title: Singapore, UK and Canada central banks issue joint report on cross-border payments
summary: The central banks of Canada, Britain, and Singapore have released a joint report on cross-border payments and settlements, providing a framework for assessing transactions and discussing alternative payment models. The report examines three models of cross-border payments, including two built on existing domestic interbank payments and one using wholesale central bank digital currency. The report concludes that the models could improve access, speed, and transparency of cross-border payments, but requires further work from industry and regulators.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust confirms Ixom purchase at A$777 million
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust has agreed to purchase Australian chemicals group Ixom for A$777 million, with the deal expected to be completed in Q1 2019 pending unit holder and regulatory approvals. The acquisition will grow Keppel Infrastructure Trust's portfolio to S$5.1 billion and enhance the stability of distributions for unit holders. Ixom, a mature and profitable business with a dominant market position, will be funded by debt and potentially equity-raised funds. The deal is seen as a logical fit with Keppel Infrastructure Trust's value proposition, providing stable and resilient cash flows driven by long-term customer relationships.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close sharply higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged 1.75% on Thursday, driven by hopes of eased trade tensions between China and the US. The Hang Seng Index closed at 26,103.34, with market heavyweight Tencent rising on better-than-expected earnings. The Shanghai Composite Index also rose 1.36%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 1.45%. The gains came despite US President Trump's recent threats to extend tariffs, which traders brushed off. The rally was seen as a positive sign for the market, with investors optimistic about a potential resolution to the trade tensions.

site_title: UK's May takes Brexit deal to rebellious MPs
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May is set to present her Brexit deal to parliament, despite opposition from many Conservative MPs. The draft withdrawal agreement, which includes a "backstop" plan to keep Britain in a customs union with the EU, has sparked concerns among Brexiteers and hardline unionists. European leaders have agreed to a rapid summit to sign off on the deal by November 25, but May faces an uphill battle to secure approval from parliament, which must approve the deal by March 29.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks jump on hopes of Trump-Kim summit; won gains
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 1% on Thursday, boosted by hopes of a second Trump-Kim summit next year. The Korean won and bond yields also increased. Shares of companies exposed to North Korea, such as Hyundai Elevator and Sungshin Cement, surged. The won was quoted at 1,129.2 per dollar, its highest since April. The market is expected to remain bullish despite the Kospi being down 16.2% this year.

site_title: Stormy Daniels' attorney Michael Avenatti arrested on suspicion of domestic violence
summary: Michael Avenatti, lawyer for adult film star Stormy Daniels, was arrested on suspicion of domestic violence in Los Angeles. Avenatti denied the allegations, calling them "completely bogus." He had previously represented Daniels in a lawsuit seeking to nullify a $130,000 "hush payment" deal with Donald Trump's fixer Michael Cohen. Avenatti's arrest comes after he was ordered to pay $4.85 million to an attorney who worked with him at his former law firm.

site_title: GrabPay wallets to allow instant remittance overseas from early 2019
summary: GrabPay wallets will allow instant overseas remittance starting early 2019, enabling both banked and unbanked users to send money securely to receivers in another country. The wallet-to-wallet remittance product will reduce payment friction for intra-Asean tourism and business travel, and pave the way for a multi-currency Asean travel wallet. The move aims to improve the user experience and reduce lost sums in the region's estimated $70 billion remittance market, currently dominated by unlicensed agents.

site_title: Clutch of small caps plunge as much as 93% in Hong Kong
summary: In Hong Kong, six small-cap stocks plummeted, with Sino Haijing Holdings Ltd experiencing a 93% drop. The sudden decline, totaling over $1.6 billion in losses, has sparked speculation that a large holder was forced to liquidate shares after a loan went sour. This is not the first instance of such volatility in Hong Kong, with critics calling for improved corporate governance oversight. The Hong Kong exchange operator declined to comment on individual companies, leaving traders to continue speculating about the cause of the sudden declines.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: China and Singapore agreed on collaborations for fintech innovations and cross-border supervision of derivative trades. Vietnam expressed surprise over US President Trump's tariff announcement and sought a lower rate. The Asian garment industry prepares for higher US tariffs, while Malaysia's agency plans to seize RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Meanwhile, Citigroup set a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for the MSCI's global equity index.

site_title: British junior minister quits May's government
summary: British junior minister Shailesh Vara has quit Prime Minister Theresa May's government, citing her draft Brexit deal as a "half-way house with no time limit" for the UK to become a sovereign nation. This resignation comes after May won backing from her senior ministers for the deal, but opponents continue to criticize it. Vara was the first member of May's government to resign since the deal's announcement.

site_title: China's impact investing is an expat project
summary: China's impact investing faces challenges due to a lack of ESG (environmental, social, and governance) reporting and data. Domestic share owners prioritize returns, while foreign investors see the potential for ESG to take hold. However, corporate governance remains a work in progress in China, and ESG is mainly a project for foreign investors. The Asian Corporate Governance Association's conference highlighted the need for reliable information and better data, but progress is slow, with the number of Chinese companies reporting on CSR plateauing since 2014.

site_title: Cleaners in Singapore must be paid an annual bonus of at least two weeks' pay from 2020
summary: Singapore will require cleaning firms to pay resident cleaners a minimum annual bonus of two weeks' pay, starting from January 1, 2020. This applies to Singaporean and permanent resident workers who have worked at least a year in the same company. The bonus aims to motivate cleaners to stay with their employers longer for better career progression and encourage businesses to raise productivity through training. The move is expected to benefit over 40,000 cleaners employed by more than 1,300 firms.

site_title: US state spending exceeds US$2t in fiscal 2018
summary: US state spending exceeded $2 trillion for the first time in fiscal 2018, growing 4.8% from the previous year, according to the National Association of State Budget Officers' report. Medicaid expenditures rose 7.3%, while transportation spending increased by 6.5%, representing 8% of total state expenditures. Elementary and secondary education expenditures remained the largest area of state general fund spending, with a 4.6% growth. States expect growth in revenue collections, but face long-term spending pressures from rising healthcare costs and pensions.

site_title: Chinese regulator orders detailed user data to fight online mobilisation
summary: China's Cyberspace Administration has ordered internet firms to provide detailed user data to combat online mobilization and dissenting opinions. Starting November 30, companies must log information including real names, usernames, and device types. The policy aims to crack down on social movements and online content deemed a cybersecurity risk, with companies already required to share information with the government on request. The move is part of China's tightening control over the internet under President Xi Jinping, amid a spate of protests and grassroots movements.

images.alt_text: China's cyber watchdog said on Thursday it will require detailed logs on users from internet firms as part of a new policy aimed at cracking down on dissenting opinion and online social movements.

site_title: Amazon's HQ2 in Virginia leaves a real estate firm poised to cash in
summary: Amazon has chosen Northern Virginia's National Landing region, along with New York City, for its second headquarters, dubbed HQ2. JBG Smith, a real estate firm led by Matt Kelly, has a significant stake in the area, having merged with Vornado Realty Trust in 2017. Amazon will lease 500,000 square feet of office space and buy land for an additional 4.1 million square feet. The deal is expected to boost JBG Smith's occupancy and rents, but may take 5-7 years to materialize. The decision validates Kelly's plan to revitalize the area, which has struggled with low occupancy rates.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open with gains on Thursday
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.81% on Thursday, driven by energy firms rebounding from recent losses and Tencent's earnings report beating expectations. The Hang Seng Index reached 25,862.18, while the Shanghai Composite Index remained nearly unchanged.

site_title: Australia shares erase losses on Sino-UStrade hopes; NZ flat
summary: Australian shares erased early losses to close almost flat on Thursday as investors took heart from signs that China and the US may de-escalate their trade dispute. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.06% to 5,736.0 after US government sources reported China's response to US demands for trade reform. Financial shares declined, but were offset by gains in the industrial and healthcare sectors, with healthcare stocks rising 0.2% and gold stocks jumping 1.7%. New Zealand's benchmark index closed nearly flat.

site_title: New private home sales in October dive by nearly 48% over September amid absence of new launches
summary: Singapore private home sales in October dropped 48% from September, with 487 units sold, according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority. This is a 36% decrease from the same period last year. The absence of major launches in October contributed to the decline.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed but traders on edge, pound holds ground
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Thursday as investors navigated headwinds including the China-US trade war, rising interest rates, and slowing global growth. Oil prices dropped, dragging energy firms down, despite Opec's promise to tighten output. The pound held ground despite concerns over Brexit. Analysts expect risk sentiment to remain low, and markets are uncertain about the outcome of the G-20 summit and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Scoot to relocate to Changi Airport's upgraded T1 from T2 in Q4 2019
summary: Scoot, a budget airline, plans to relocate its operations from Changi Airport's Terminal 2 to Terminal 1 in the last quarter of 2019. The move aims to enhance customer experience and facilitate growth plans, with projected double-digit annual growth over the next three years. The relocation is part of Changi Airport's upgrading works, which include refurbishment of the Departure hall and the addition of automated self-service machines. The move is expected to provide sufficient terminal capacity for Scoot's increased operations, ensuring a seamless transition for customers, employees, and service partners.

site_title: Blockchain-based firm MVL Foundation unveils cab booking app TADA Taxi
summary: MVL Foundation, a Singapore-based blockchain firm, launched TADA Taxi, a standalone cab booking app. The service allows commuters to book rides from registered taxi drivers. Premier, the first Singapore taxi company to partner MVL, has added 2,000 drivers to its fleet. TADA Taxi operates on a zero-commission model and aims to reach 5,000 drivers by the end of 2018. The launch comes after MVL received a Third-Party Taxi Booking Service Provider licence from the Land Transport Authority, aiming to support existing taxi drivers and generate revenue for drivers and riders.

site_title: Jetstar joins Scoot, SIA in ceasing pre-selection of travel insurance in online bookings
summary: Jetstar Asia Airways, Scoot Tigerair, and Singapore Airlines have stopped pre-selecting travel insurance for online bookings, following a recommendation from the Consumers Association of Singapore (Case). The airlines will now require consumers to actively select or reject travel insurance during the booking process, starting from October 2019. This change aims to increase transparency in ticket pricing and booking processes, and follows similar moves by Scoot and SIA earlier this year. The decision is in line with Case's efforts to promote ethical marketing and consumer protection.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon at 3,045.87, down 0.1% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading at 3,045.87, down 0.1% on the day, as the Straits Times Index rose 0.1% or 2.68 points. Gainers edged out losers 163 to 144, with 920.6 million shares changing hands. Genting Singapore led the gainers, rising 2.7% to 95 cents, while OCBC Bank fell 1.25% to S$11.00 and DBS traded lower by 0.52%.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close down as bank shares tumble
summary: Tokyo stocks fell on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index losing 0.20% or 42.86 points to close at 21,803.62, due to a drop in US bank shares amid regulation concerns. Worries about Brexit and oil prices also contributed to the decline. The broader Topix index was down 0.14%.

site_title: Singapore gets top accolade at Smart City Expo World Congress
summary: Singapore was named Smart City of 2018 at the Smart City Expo World Congress in Barcelona, beating seven other finalists including London, Melbourne, and Haifa. The city-state's smart urban solutions have improved services for citizens and enhanced the quality of life, according to the jury. Senior Minister of State Janil Puthucheary said Singapore's Smart Nation efforts aim to create a better lived experience for citizens and future generations. This is Singapore's second Smart City award, following previous winners New York and Dubai.

site_title: Singapore, China to collaborate on fintech, regulating derivative trades
summary: Singapore and China have agreed to collaborate on fintech innovations and cross-border supervision of futures exchanges and intermediaries through two cooperation agreements. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and the People's Bank of China signed an agreement to facilitate joint research and innovation projects in fintech, while a second agreement with the China Securities Regulatory Commission will enhance supervision of futures exchanges and intermediaries. Private-sector tie-ups also include Nets and UnionPay for mobile wallet connections and the Singapore Exchange and Bank of China for promoting a new bond index to international investors.

site_title: China's October home prices gather pace as smaller cities sustain growth
summary: China's new home prices rose 1.0% in October, the 42nd consecutive month of price increases, according to official data. The growth was driven by smaller cities, with 65 out of 70 cities reporting a monthly price increase. New home prices have risen 8.6% year-over-year, the fastest pace since July last year. The sector's resilience is attributed to regulatory loopholes and speculation, with local governments potentially reluctant to tighten curbs. However, signs of a slowdown in the property sector are emerging, including a 10-month low in real estate investment and falling home sales.

site_title: Silence please. South Korea hushes for crucial exam
summary: South Korea took extraordinary measures to minimize distractions during its national university entrance exam, which affects students' adult lives and social status. Nearly 595,000 students sat the 9-hour exam, with authorities restricting public offices, businesses, and airports to reduce disruptions. Electronics were forbidden, and students were only allowed to wear masks due to fine dust pollution. The results will be released on December 5, with President Moon Jae-in sending a good luck message to the students, urging them to believe in themselves and show their full competence.

site_title: Lion Air: a deadly crash and a whole lot of questions for Boeing
summary: Boeing faces scrutiny over its handling of an anti-stall system suspected in the fatal Lion Air Flight 610 crash in Indonesia, which killed 189 people on October 29. Investigators are examining whether the system's modifications, made without informing airlines and pilots, contributed to the crash. The system's incorrect readings could cause a plane to dive instead of climb, leading to a stall. Boeing has denied purposefully omitting critical information, but experts say the company may have underestimated the change.

site_title: Fund managers place bets in Asia's oversold assets, such as high-yield bonds
summary: Asian fund managers are betting on oversold assets, such as high-yield bonds and Chinese and Indian equities, amid a global economic slowdown and trade tensions. The region's equity markets have fallen 15.5% this year, while currencies from emerging markets have come under pressure. Fund managers see value in cheap dollar bonds in China and are seeking alternatives to US equities, which have been the lone outperformers globally. Some are focusing on mid-cap firms in emerging markets, such as Indonesia and India, and are optimistic about China's recovery due to policy measures and healthy current accounts.

site_title: Crypto platform KuCoin raises US$20m in Series A funding
summary: KuCoin, a Singapore-based cryptocurrency platform, has raised US$20 million in Series A funding led by IDG Capital, Matrix Partners, and Neo Global Capital. The platform, which has over 5 million registered users, aims to become a market leader in the blockchain industry. The partnership will focus on launching KuCoin's Platform 2.0, expanding globally, and investing in new cryptocurrency ventures. CEO Michael Gan believes that blockchain technology will one day function in everything, and the partnership will help achieve this vision by expanding the team and finding more valuable opportunities.

site_title: Tata Sons' chairman to pitch to board on plan to buy Jet Airways: report
summary: Tata Sons chairman N. Chandrasekaran is set to present a business viability plan to the board on acquiring cash-strapped Jet Airways. The proposed deal, which could transform Tata into India's dominant airline, involves a two-step transaction: a share swap between Tata SIA Airlines and Jet, followed by Singapore Airlines buying the Goyal family's stake in the combined entity. The deal could give the Goyal family a complete exit, and shares in Jet Airways rose 4% on the news. Etihad Airways, which has a 24% stake in Jet, is also expected to be a partner in the new company.

images.alt_text: Tata Sons chairman N. Chandrasekaran is expected to present to the board on Friday a business viability plan on a proposed acquisition of cash-strapped Jet Airways, the Times of India reported, citing people close to the development.

site_title: Tencent finally gives its battle-weary investors some relief
summary: Tencent Holdings surged 4.6% after reporting a 30% jump in quarterly profit, driven by a resurgent advertising business and one-time gains. The company's core gaming business remains under stress due to a Chinese clampdown on gaming licenses, but its WeChat social network, advertising, and cloud services are performing well. Revenue grew at its slowest pace in three years, and the stock has shed over $230 billion in market value since January. Despite this, analysts say investors are relieved that Tencent didn't perform worse, but long-term uncertainty persists.

site_title: Japan cyber security minister admits shunning PCs
summary: Japan's cyber security minister, Yoshitaka Sakurada, has sparked outrage after admitting he has never used a computer in his professional life. The 68-year-old deputy chief of the government's cyber security strategy office made the statement in parliament, leaving opposition lawmakers and online users incredulous. His comments have raised questions about his ability to oversee cyber security policies, with many joking that his lack of computer use might be the "strongest kind of security." Sakurada has been in office just over a month and has already faced criticism for other gaffes in parliament.

images.alt_text: A Japanese minister in charge of cyber security has provoked astonishment by admitting he has never used a computer in his professional life, and appearing confused by the concept of a USB drive.

site_title: Main points of the draft Brexit agreement
summary: The European Union has published a 585-page draft Brexit deal aimed at a smooth divorce by March and outlining a transition period. Key provisions include avoiding a hard border between Ireland and Northern Ireland, protecting citizens' rights, and settling Britain's last bill. The Irish issue was the main hurdle in 17 months of negotiations, but the deal is seen as a significant step towards avoiding a hard border and maintaining the peace process.

site_title: Broker's take: KGI downgrades Accordia Golf Trust to 'hold' on natural disasters, cautious macro outlook
summary: Broker KGI Securities downgraded Accordia Golf Trust's recommendation to 'hold' due to a series of natural disasters in Japan, lack of near-term rerating catalysts, and a cautious macro outlook. The revised target price is S$0.61 from S$0.70. KGI expects the trust's FY2019 dividend to fall to 4c, then recover to at least 5.2c, offering a 10.7% dividend yield. The trust's share price has been weak due to share sales by major shareholders, but KGI believes the decline has already been priced in, with limited downside risks.

site_title: CDW posts 31% fall in Q3 profit on fewer customer orders
summary: CDW Holding reported a 31% decline in Q3 profit to $900,000 due to lower revenue from fewer customer orders, down 21.5% to $23.5 million. The company attributed the drop to delayed orders for large LCD backlight units and the early termination of a key customer order. Despite higher revenue in its office automation and LCD parts segments, the company reported a net loss for the nine months ended September 30.

site_title: Marie Antoinette pendant sells for US$36m, shattering estimate
summary: A pearl and diamond pendant owned by Marie Antoinette sold for US$36 million at an auction in Geneva, shattering its estimated sale price of up to US$2 million. The 10-piece collection, unseen in public for two centuries, was sold by Sotheby's. The sale exceeded expectations and marked a significant milestone for the ill-fated queen's estate. The pendant is one of the most valuable items to be sold by Sotheby's in recent years.

site_title: Noble says debt revamp schemes granted court sanctions
summary: Noble Group's debt restructuring plans have been granted court sanctions, allowing the company's debt revamp to take effect on November 26. The English Court sanctioned the English scheme on Tuesday, while the Bermuda Court issued the order on Wednesday. The restructuring plan, approved by shareholders in August, involves handing over 70% of equity to senior creditors, 10% to management, and the rest to existing shareholders. The company's shares closed at 8.8 Singapore cents on Wednesday, down 0.1 Singapore cent.

site_title: Singapore-backed business accelerator to help Thai SMEs digitalise
summary: A Singapore-backed business accelerator, FinLab, has launched a three-month Smart Business Transformation Programme to help Thai SMEs digitalize. The program aims to address online sales and marketing, with a focus on social media and digital marketing. Despite 67% citing cost concerns and 44% worrying about complexity, the FinLab will provide workshops, mentoring, and meetings with tech solutions providers to participating businesses in the food, construction, logistics, and retail industries. The program is supported by United Overseas Bank (Thai) and the Digital Economy Promotion Agency of Thailand.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on November 15, 2018, due to a higher yen and falls on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 0.85% to 21,660.07, while the Topix index fell 0.64% to 1,630.82.

site_title: Theresa May is on the brink as Tories plot to kill her Brexit deal
summary: Theresa May faces a growing revolt within her own party as senior ministers and Conservative MPs consider voting against her Brexit deal, potentially forcing the UK out of the EU with no deal. At least two cabinet ministers are said to be considering quitting, while others, including Esther McVey and Andrea Leadsom, weigh their options. May's deal has been criticized by pro-Brexit Tories over the Irish border backstop, and euroskeptic MPs, including Jacob Rees-Mogg, are urging a vote of no confidence in May as their party leader and prime minister. The UK's EU withdrawal agreement is set to be debated in Parliament in the coming weeks.

site_title: Powell sees potential headwinds to US growth as Fed weighs rate policy
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell expressed concerns about potential headwinds to the US economy next year as the Fed considers raising interest rates. Despite a strong economy with low unemployment and inflation at its 2% target, Powell cited slowing growth abroad, fading fiscal stimulus, and the lagged effect of previous rate increases as potential challenges. The Fed has pursued a policy of gradualism with three interest-rate increases this year and plans for a fourth next month, amid criticism from President Donald Trump.

site_title: Malaysia shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Thursday, down 1.06 points to 1,687.35. The market saw 27.29 million lots traded worth RM11.05 million, with gainer-to-loser ratio 74-53. This follows a broader regional trend, with Europe's stocks down due to bank and healthcare sector drag, and US stocks edging down from records amid tariff threats.

site_title: UK's May defends Brexit deal in cabinet showdown
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May defended her draft Brexit deal before a divided cabinet, stating it delivered on the British people's vote to leave the EU. The deal includes a "backstop" that could keep the UK in a customs arrangement with the EU, sparking concerns among Brexit supporters and critics. May's government faces a no-confidence vote, and a Brexit summit is set for November 25. The pound's value dropped after the cabinet session, but recovered after Downing Street clarified May would give a press statement.

site_title: Sakae Q1 earnings fall 63.6% to S$75,000
summary: Sakae Holdings reported a 63.6% year-on-year decline in earnings to S$75,000 in Q1, with revenue falling 36.6% to S$10.4 million. The company attributed this to lower revenue and streamlined operations. Despite a negative operating cash flow of S$1.3 million, Sakae remains cautious and committed to managing costs. The sugar trade business is under investigation, and the company expects challenging operating conditions due to intense competition, labor shortages, and rising costs.

site_title: Energy drives US consumer prices to 9-month high in October
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.3% in October, the largest gain in nine months, driven by increases in petrol, electricity, and shelter costs. However, underlying price pressures remained tame, with the core CPI rising 0.2% and the annual gain slowing to 2.1%. The data calmed inflation fears, potentially limiting the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes, but worker pay failed to keep pace with inflation, resulting in a net loss of 0.1% for the month.

site_title: Singapore real estate continues to hold value for investors
summary: Singapore's real estate market continues to attract strong investor demand, particularly from foreign institutional investors. Over the past three years, foreign institutional investors have poured in S$5.3 billion, a significant increase from the S$1.1 billion between 2010 and 2015. The office market has rebounded, with Grade-A office rents rising 18% and capital values expected to increase by 16% in 2018. The hospitality sector is also poised for growth, with average hotel occupancy rates reaching 87% and room rates rising. Despite recent cooling measures, demand for residential homes remains strong, driven by HDB upgraders and those selling en bloc.

site_title: LTC Corp voluntary delisting resolution derailed by adjournment
summary: LTC Corp, a steel trading and property group, had a voluntary delisting resolution at its EGM on November 14, 2018, adjourned after shareholders voted to postpone the decision due to recent changes in delisting rules by the Singapore Exchange Regulatory Co. The proposed changes would shift voting power from offerors to minority shareholders. LTC is evaluating its options and will update shareholders in due course, with a 92.5 Singapore cents per-share exit offer previously proposed.

site_title: Energy Market Company offers portal to help Singapore firms procure electricity
summary: Singapore Exchange-backed Energy Market Company (EMC) has launched a portal to help businesses procure electricity. The PowerSelect online platform, which includes 11 electricity retailers, allows businesses with high electricity consumption to compete for contracts through live auctions or invitations to tender. A food and beverage firm, Sakae Holdings, saved over S$12,000 in electricity bills by using the portal. The platform aims to provide businesses with various procurement options and secure better electricity packages, while also saving time and effort in sourcing quotes and negotiating with retailers.

site_title: Stocks to watch: mm2, Noble, CDW, LTC Corp, Sakae, Hong Leong Asia
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several companies saw new developments affecting their shares on Thursday. mm2 Asia reported a 17.7% decline in net profit due to higher finance expenses. Hong Leong Asia saw a 36.4% decline in net profit due to the decline in the construction industry. Fragrance Group's net profit dived 47.5% due to a 20% decline in revenue.

site_title: mm2 posts 17.7% drop in Q2 earnings on higher finance expenses
summary: MAINBOARD-LISTED mm2 Asia saw its second-quarter net profit drop 17.7% to S$3.7 million, mainly due to higher finance expenses. Revenue more than doubled to S$64.9 million from S$31.4 million in the same quarter last year. After adjusting for the one-off interest, net profit would have risen 17.7% to S$5.3 million. The company's core business and event production and concert promotion business contributed to the revenue growth.

site_title: Europe: Stocks hit 2-week low as sell-off leaves few sectors unscathed
summary: European stocks hit a 2-week low, falling 0.6% as a broad-based sell-off affected oil, mining, technology, and banking sectors. Concerns about a global economic slowdown and Italy's budget crisis deepened, with Italian stocks and government bonds experiencing significant declines. The Stoxx 600, a pan-European index, ended near its lowest levels since October 31, while US stocks also fell amid worries about a US-EU trade deal.

site_title: US: Early Wall Street rally evaporates, sending stocks lower
summary: US stocks fell for the fourth consecutive session, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 losing 0.8% each, as an early rally lost momentum. Soft inflation numbers and downgraded analyst estimates on Apple and other tech stocks contributed to the decline. Fragile markets were also impacted by forceful remarks from a senior Democratic lawmaker and negative economic data from Japan and Germany. The close marked the longest losing streak in three months, with the Nasdaq falling 0.9%.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at Thursday's open; STI down 0.1% to 3,040.43
summary: Singapore stocks declined 0.1% to 3,040.43 at Thursday's open, following the S&P 500's overnight decline in the US. Gainers and losers were evenly matched, with 58 securities up and 55 down. Key movers included SingTel, up 0.3%, and Asti Holdings, up 3.7%. Active index stocks included DBS Group Holdings and OCBC Bank, both down. The decline was attributed to the US-EU trade tensions and the S&P 500's overnight drop.

site_title: SIA finding premium economy a tougher sell on new non-stop US flights
summary: Singapore Airlines is struggling to sell premium economy seats on its ultra-long non-stop US flights, with some markets being unfamiliar with the product offering more leg room and amenities than economy class. The airline is pricing premium economy seats very attractively, with fares as low as US$1,230.17 return from Singapore to New York. This is in line with economy class fares from rival airlines, and the airline's executive vice-president expects demand for premium economy to pick up as travelers appreciate the benefits of the product.

site_title: A US$343.8m Powerball jackpot after 25 years of using the same numbers
summary: Robert Bailey, a 67-year-old retired postal worker, won the largest Powerball jackpot in New York Lottery history, $343.8 million. He shared the prize with Lerynne West, a mother of three from Iowa, and initially kept his win a secret before claiming his prize at the Resorts World Casino in Queens. Bailey plans to give back to his community, donate to a veterans' organization, and invest in a house for his mother and travel. Despite his newfound wealth, he remains humble and has a routine, saying he will continue to play the same numbers that brought him luck.

site_title: Scores protest against new Amazon headquarters in Queens, New York
summary: Around 100 people protested in Queens, New York, against Amazon's new headquarters, citing concerns over $3 billion in tax breaks and incentives that could accelerate gentrification and push out ordinary families. Critics, including local officials, fear the impact on affordable housing and questioned the size of the incentives for a company led by billionaire Jeff Bezos. Protests and calls for renegotiation of the deal have been made, with some opposing a boycott of Amazon.

site_title: SGX inks pact with Bank of China, CFETS to promote their bond indices
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) signed a strategic cooperation agreement with Bank of China and China Foreign Exchange Trade System to promote the CFETS-BOC Traded Bond Index outside of China. The indices, jointly developed by CFETS and BOC, provide a price-level indicator of the China interbank bond market. The SGX is the first exchange to distribute the bond indices internationally, publishing them on its website. This partnership aims to increase accessibility to China's bond market for international investors.

site_title: Threat from ascendant Chinese phones hangs over Apple
summary: Apple faces concerns over stagnant iPhone sales, with suppliers issuing profit warnings. The company's plan to rely on services for growth is threatened by fierce competition from mid-priced Chinese phones. Average selling prices have risen, but analysts believe iPhone sales account for about two-thirds of Apple devices worldwide. The company's revenue growth from services depends on a growing base of device owners, which may not be possible with stagnant iPhone sales.

images.alt_text: A raft of profit warnings from Apple Inc suppliers this week has fueled investor concerns that iPhone sales, in terms of volume, have hit a wall that could spell trouble for the company's plans to make services its main pillar of growth.

site_title: US Democrat vows to halt easing of banking regulations
summary: US Representative Maxine Waters has vowed to halt the easing of banking regulations once her party takes power in the US House of Representatives in January. Waters, expected to lead the House Financial Services Committee, criticized the rollback of Dodd-Frank provisions and said the Fed must keep a "watchful eye" on financial institutions. This move could lead to stricter oversight and potentially impact financial firms, with shares already moving lower on Wall Street. Waters' comments signal a shift in oversight and could signal a reversal of the recent regulatory changes.

site_title: Digital currency for the freedom to quaff a pint
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore and International Monetary Fund (IMF) are exploring the potential of state-backed digital currencies to address financial bias and promote financial inclusion. IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde proposed that digital currencies could offer a solution to the trade-off between financial integrity and privacy, allowing users to maintain anonymity while still being subject to anti-money laundering controls. Lagarde argued that digital currencies could boost financial inclusion, especially in remote and marginalized regions, and provide a low-cost alternative to private payment providers, potentially reducing the risk of bank runs and promoting competition.

site_title: Collaboration key in making NZ and Singapore big players on the financial services stage
summary: New Zealand and Singapore are strengthening their collaboration in the financial services sector, driven by the need for advanced products and services to stay competitive. The two countries share similarities in their economies, values, and focus on regional economic integration. New Zealand's technology sector has seen rapid growth, and companies like 9 Spokes and Delta Insurance are establishing partnerships with Singaporean financial institutions to deliver innovative solutions. This collaboration is expected to bring positive outcomes and sustained growth to both countries and the wider region.

site_title: A culinary road trip in S Korea
summary: A culinary road trip in South Korea explores the country's exciting dining scene and diverse produce. Chef Ryu Tae Hwan embarks on a 3,000 km journey to discover artisanal producers, sampling prized matsutake mushrooms and medicinal herb-fed cattle. The article also features interviews with TWG Tea's Taha Bouqdib and Michelin-starred chefs at the Ritz-Carlton Osaka, highlighting South Korea's growing culinary reputation.

site_title: Crater bigger than Paris is discovered under Greenland ice
summary: A massive 31km-wide iron meteorite crater, larger than Paris, has been discovered beneath the Hiawatha Glacier in Greenland. The crater, dated to be 12,000 years old, is the first of its kind found on Greenland and among the 25 largest known on Earth. The impact would have had significant ripple effects in the region and potentially globally, affecting climate and ocean flow. Researchers plan to recover material from the glacier to learn more about the crater's timing and effects on life at the time, and its story is just beginning to be told.

site_title: UK business breathes sigh of relief at draft Brexit deal
summary: British businesses expressed relief as the UK cabinet backed a draft Brexit deal, despite numerous hurdles in Brussels and London. The deal's backing led to a pound rise to around US$1.3016. The Confederation of British Industry hailed the agreement as "progress." However, the UK economy has continued to shrink for the second month, posing a challenge to Labour leader Keir Starmer. The draft deal still faces significant challenges before a final agreement can be reached.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore Airlines' Q2 2019 earnings fell short of expectations, with a 1% decline in passenger yield and a 81% drop in net profit due to one-off losses at Virgin Australia. The airline downgraded its interim dividend and lowered FY2019 and FY2020 estimates by 31% and 23%, respectively. Despite cost management initiatives, the company needs more significant passenger yield improvement to post returns equal to or better than its cost of capital.

site_title: Apec summit: The Xi show by the sea shore
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping is taking centrestage at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) summit in Papua New Guinea, with the US President Donald Trump's decision to skip the event allowing Beijing to showcase its growing influence in the region. Xi will host a meeting with Pacific leaders, attend a traditional "sing sing" welcome, and stay at a luxurious hotel, surrounded by red flags and Chinese aid logos. Beijing has invested heavily in the Pacific, with $10.25 billion in trade and $3 billion in investment in 2017, and is seeking to expand its influence in the region.

site_title: US could lose in war with China or Russia, panel warns
summary: A bipartisan congressional panel warns the US is facing a national security crisis and could lose in a war against Russia or China due to diminishing military advantages and budget cuts. The panel, consisting of former top officials, found America's focus on counter-insurgency operations has eroded its capabilities in other warfighting areas. The US military could suffer unacceptably high casualties and loss of major capital assets in a conflict, and the commission recommends a 3-5% annual increase in the defence budget to meet the goals laid out in the National Defence Strategy.

site_title: SingHaiyi cancels bulk sale involving 34 condo units in California
summary: Singaporean property developer SingHaiyi Group has cancelled a bulk sale of 34 condominium units in California due to the buyer's failure to close the escrow for 31 units by November 13. The sale was valued at US$23.1 million. The company will receive US$1.3 million from the termination of the purchase agreement, which will be recognized as other income in its financial statements. This marks a reversal of a previous agreement made in September, where the buyer had received a non-refundable deposit of US$7.5 million.

site_title: ST Engg to raise debt for US$630m MRAS takeover
summary: ST Engineering plans to raise US$630 million in debt to finance its acquisition of General Electric's MRA Systems LLC (MRAS), a move aimed at scaling up its aerospace capabilities. The acquisition comes as the company embarks on a business rationalisation drive, with Q3 net profit rising 5.3% to S$134.6 million. The funding will be raised out of the US by VT Systems, the US headquarters of ST Engg, and will be used to finance the MRAS acquisition, which is expected to be completed by year-end.

site_title: A future-ready justice system for Singapore
summary: The Singapore government's proposed introduction of litigation scale costs may harm the country's status as a global litigation hub. The proposal, which pegs professional fees to the monetary amount in dispute, has sparked concerns among lawyers, who fear it will limit their ability to take on complex cases and stifle innovation in the legal field. Critics argue that the proposal will create a stratified industry, favoring established firms and Senior Counsel over up-and-coming lawyers, and may even lead to more litigation and decreased access to justice.

site_title: Qatar economy growing despite crisis: IMF
summary: Qatar's economy is growing despite a diplomatic rift with neighboring countries, with the IMF predicting a real GDP growth of 3% next year and stabilizing at 2.7% annually from 2020 to 2023. The country's gas exports, infrastructure projects, and hosting of the 2022 World Cup are driving growth. Qatar has significant fiscal and external buffers to absorb shocks from global trade tensions and the 2014-2016 decline in oil prices. The country plans to introduce VAT, and while the IMF warns of potential economic impact, Qatar's economy is expected to continue strengthening.

site_title: Oil rebounds from steep sell-off as Opec, partners discuss supply cut
summary: Oil prices rebounded 1% on Wednesday, recouping losses from the previous session, after reports that Opec and its partners discussed a proposal to cut output by up to 1.4 million barrels per day. This proposal, which was more than previously mentioned, led to a session high of $67.63. Brent crude settled at $66.12 a barrel, following a record 12-day losing streak. The potential output cut is seen as a positive sign for the market, which had been weighed down by market uncertainty and geopolitical tensions.

images.alt_text: Oil rose about 1 per cent on Wednesday, recouping some of the previous session's heavy sell-off, on growing prospects that the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and allied producers would cut output at a meeting next month to prop up prices.

site_title: Samsung unit faces potential criminal probe after breaking accounting rules
summary: Samsung Biologics, a unit of Samsung Group, faces a potential criminal investigation and delisting after intentionally violating accounting rules surrounding its 2016 initial public offering (IPO). The company was fined 8 billion won (S$9.7 million) for overstating the value of affiliate Samsung Bioepis. A criminal investigation has been launched, and stock trading of Samsung Biologics will be halted. The company's CEO may be dismissed, and delisting is also possible. This scandal threatens Samsung Group's corporate governance and may impact the company's succession plans.

site_title: BCA eyes 'live' demonstration projects in digital push
summary: The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) in Singapore has launched a plan to encourage the construction industry to go digital by 2020, with the goal of 40-60 sites implementing Integrated Digital Delivery (IDD) technologies. The first 12 demonstration projects, including the JTC Logistics Hub, have been identified, and training and digital platforms will be provided to develop skills such as virtual collaboration and data analytics. Early adopters have seen a 35-39% reduction in construction time, and the BCA aims to improve building quality, reduce costs, and create new jobs for Singaporeans.

site_title: Soybean trade goes haywire as major exporter turns to imports
summary: Argentina, the world's third-largest soybean producer, is increasing imports of US soybeans due to the US-China trade war. Weekly shipments to Argentina have reached their highest in 35 years, with over 249,000 tonnes of soybeans destined for the country. This is a significant shift, as Argentina typically processes its soybeans domestically before exporting. The surge in imports is driven by China's voracious appetite for soybeans and Argentina's changed tax structure, which is expected to quadruple exports. US oilseed supplies have become relatively cheap, signaling a surplus in the market.

site_title: RCEP conclusion delayed due to 'unique challenges': PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong confirmed that the finalization of the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) will not be completed by the end of 2018 as initially hoped. Negotiations have taken longer than usual due to unique challenges, including the first time many countries are working on a free trade agreement together. The countries will work towards completion by next year, with substantial progress made in the past year, including the conclusion of five more chapters and significant breakthroughs in "rules"-based chapters.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Asian companies report mixed earnings for Q3, with NAM Cheong turning profitable after a one-time gain, while THE Straits Trading Company saw increased earnings from its property portfolio. Fragrance Group's net profit declined 47.5% due to lower revenue, while Hong Leong Asia's profit fell 36.4% due to decline in construction industry and price competition. UnUsUaL Limited's earnings improved 30.4% year-on-year, despite a decline in earnings per share.

site_title: Shadow banking crisis is starting to hit India's consumers
summary: India's shadow banking industry, which accounts for nearly four out of every 10 consumer loans, is experiencing a funding crunch, leading to cautious credit extension and slowing sales for businesses, particularly in the festive season. Loan volumes have dropped to 10% of pre-default levels, threatening consumption and the economy. Economists predict a hit to growth, with some estimating a 0.1-0.2 percentage point hit, while others believe the crisis is temporary. The Reserve Bank of India's liquidity index shows a nearly trillion rupee shortfall, and interest rate increases have further exacerbated the issue.

site_title: STI falls for fourth straight session
summary: Singapore stocks fell for a fourth straight session, ending 0.3% lower at 3,043.19, due to external factors such as rising US interest rates, softer earnings season, and falling crude oil prices. Analysts attributed the decline to the disappointing earnings reports from large-cap companies, including Singapore Airlines. The decline weighed on the market, with CMC Markets analyst Margaret Yang stating that the recent earnings season has failed to deliver positive surprises.

site_title: Boeing studies need for 737 MAX software changes after crash
summary: The US Federal Aviation Administration and Boeing are evaluating the need for software or design changes to 737 MAX jets after the Lion Air crash in Indonesia, where all 189 people on board were killed. The crash raised concerns over the effectiveness of the anti-stall system, prompting questions about pilot preparation. Boeing shares fell 2.1% due to concerns about the safety of the newest 737 MAX version. The investigation is ongoing, with no immediate changes to the aircraft's design or software planned.

site_title: Fragrance plans hotels along Waterloo St, Hoe Chiang Rd
summary: Fragrance Group, a Singapore property developer, has announced plans to redevelop the 999-year leasehold Waterloo Apartments into a hotel, with a S$131.1 million collective sale. The company has also applied for a change of use for its Tower 15 at 15 Hoe Chiang Road, which will result in a S$210 million uplift in property value. The redevelopment plans are subject to URA approval and are expected to increase the hotel's fair value.

site_title: Marie Antoinette's jewels go on the block
summary: Marie Antoinette's 100-piece collection of royal jewels, including a diamond-set monogrammed ring and a pearl pendant valued at $1-2 million, went under the hammer at Sotheby's auction house in Geneva. The sale, described as "the sale of the 21st century," features pieces not seen in public for two centuries, and prices are expected to reach hundreds of thousands of dollars. The collection, once owned by the Italian royal House of Bourbon-Parma, includes 10 dazzling treasures that belonged to the ill-fated French queen.

site_title: SingHaiyi Group Ltd
summary: SingHaiyi Group Ltd, a Singapore-based property development and investment company, is a diversified firm with a strong track record in residential property development and a portfolio of commercial and retail assets in the US, Australia, and Asia. The company has access to unique investment opportunities due to its strategic partnerships and deep industry connections. With a focus on growth and expansion, SingHaiyi Group continues to navigate the global property market, driven by its established board and management team.

site_title: Hopper painting sells for record US$91.9m at Christie's
summary: Edward Hopper's 1929 painting "Chop Suey" sold for a record-breaking US$91.9 million at Christie's auction, surpassing the previous high of US$43.8 million after adjusting for inflation. The painting, one of 10 works from the estate of Barney Ebsworth, was estimated to go for US$70-100 million. The sale marked a significant achievement for Christie's, securing the prime 20th-century collection for the November auction season. The auction also featured notable works by Willem de Kooning and Jackson Pollock, with the de Kooning painting selling for US$68.9 million.

site_title: United Engineers net profit falls 16% in Q3
summary: United Engineers reported a net profit of S$7.7 million in Q3, down 16% from the same period last year. Earnings per share decreased to 1.2 Singapore cents from 1.4 Singapore cents in the same quarter last year.

site_title: Fintech sets path to financial inclusion: Modi
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi emphasized the importance of financial inclusion, stating that no emerging enterprise should be cut off from credit. Since the launch of India's Aadhaar biometric identification system in 2009, over 1.2 billion biometric identities have been created, leading to over 300 million new bank accounts opened in three years, making banking nearly universal. The government has also provided $90 billion in loans to small entrepreneurs, with 75% going to women, and has implemented a system to approve loans up to $150,000 without visiting a bank in just 59 minutes.
