Several Singaporean companies reported significant developments in their financial performances. CapitaLand acquired Shanghai's tallest twin towers for $2.54 billion. Oxley Holdings saw its first-quarter net profit drop 83% to $8.06 million, but launched the Kent Ridge Hill Residences for sale. Wilmar International's third-quarter net profit jumped 10.7% to $407.4 million. Boustead Singapore's second-quarter net profit fell 3% to $6.89 million. Metro Holdings swung into profit with a $12.81 million net profit for the second quarter. Golden Agri-Resources posted a net loss of $53.92 million for the third quarter.

site_title: US: Wall Street dives into the red, losses sparked by Apple fears
summary: US stocks plummeted, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 2.3% to 25,387.18, amid fears of weakening demand for Apple's iPhone. The tech-heavy Nasdaq sank 2.8% to 7,200.87, while Goldman Sachs fell 7.5%. Investors were spooked by slashed sales expectations and concerns about global economic growth. President Trump blamed congressional Democrats for the market downturn, despite no evidence. The losses compounded previous declines, with General Electric experiencing its lowest close in nearly a decade.

site_title: UK PM says working 'extremely hard' to save elusive Brexit deal
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May is working "extremely hard" to save a Brexit deal, with a deadline of November 30 to finalize terms that will maintain frictionless trade and avoid market panic. Despite recent talks with the EU, a breakthrough remains elusive, with the UK government facing pressure from its own party members over the proposed deal. The pound has dropped in value due to fears of a messy Brexit divorce. A deal must be reached by Wednesday to avoid an extraordinary EU summit and to give May time to get the agreement passed by Parliament before Brexit day on March 29.

site_title: Gold falls to one-month low on stronger US dollar
summary: Gold prices fell to a one-month low on Monday, dropping 0.5% to $1,202.80 per ounce, as the US dollar rose to 16-month highs. The Federal Reserve's hawkish interest rate policy and political uncertainty in Europe boosted the dollar. Gold has fallen about 12% since its peak in April due to investors' preference for the dollar amid the US-China trade war and rising US interest rates.

images.alt_text: Gold slid to its lowest level in a month on Monday as the dollar rose to 16-month highs, boosted by the Federal Reserve's hawkish interest rate policy and political uncertainty in Europe.

site_title: Kellogg becomes latest food company to look at slimming down
summary: Kellogg is seeking buyers for its cookies and fruit snacks businesses as part of a strategic plan to refocus on growing areas of the business. The move comes after the cereal maker's cereal segment is experiencing declining popularity. By selling these units, Kellogg aims to devote more resources to turning around the cereal business and appealing to consumers seeking healthier snack options. The company also plans to simplify its corporate structure, unifying its US morning foods, snacks, and frozen foods business into a single unit.

images.alt_text: Kellogg is looking for buyers of its cookies and fruit snacks businesses as the cereal maker seeks to refocus on the fast-growing parts of its business.

site_title: BT to introduce new subscription plans
summary: Business Times (BT) will introduce new subscription plans from December 1, with print copies sold at S$1.30 per copy, up 10 cents. The All-Digital + Print package and Print only package will cost S$32.90 per month, an increase from S$29.90. The All-Digital subscription package price will also decrease to S$32.90 per month. The new plans aim to provide better value to subscribers, following BT's 42-year history as Singapore's only financial daily.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Tuesday; STI down 1.2% to 3,031.88
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index dropping 36.27 points or 1.2% to 3,031.88. About 46.4 million shares changed hands, with Thai Beverage being the most actively traded counter, rising S$0.005 to S$0.655. Other notable movers included DBS and UOB, which fell 2% and 2.5% respectively. The market saw a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, but was influenced by US-EU trade tensions and new Trump threats.

site_title: Goldman Sachs tumbles on 1MDB scandal and 'fear of the unknown'
summary: Goldman Sachs' shares plummeted 7.5% on November 12, 2018, amid the 1MDB scandal, with investors concerned over the uncertainty and potential fines. The bank's reputation faces a crisis, with analysts attributing the decline to the "fear of the unknown" rather than the dollar amount of the potential payment. Goldman Sachs has cooperated with investigations, but the bank's ties to the scandal have raised questions about its culture and compliance.

images.alt_text: Goldman Sachs Group's reputation is facing one of its biggest crises of the decade - and now its shares are, too.

site_title: 'Exceptional' white truffle sold for 85,000 euros
summary: A rare 850g white truffle was sold for 85,000 euros (S$132,700) at an auction in Alba, Italy, for charity. The sale price is nearly 30 times this year's market price for smaller truffles, due to the truffle's exceptional size and rarity. The truffle's value is estimated at 100 euros per gramme, with the annual market price ranging from 250 to 350 euros for 100 grammes of smaller truffles.

site_title: Helping ASEAN ride the e-commerce wave
summary: ASEAN is set to streamline regional trade rules on e-commerce and lower operating barriers to entry for businesses, aiming to boost the regional e-commerce market to $88 billion by 2025. The agreement, finalized after nine rounds of negotiations, will facilitate cross-border commerce, foster trust and confidence, and deepen cooperation among member states. It will also promote digital connectivity, lower costs, and improve supply chains, making it easier for small and medium-sized enterprises to access a larger market. The agreement is expected to be signed at the 33rd ASEAN Summit and Related Summits.

site_title: Golden Agri-Resources sinks into the red with US$53.92m Q3 loss
summary: Golden Agri-Resources posted a net loss of US$53.92 million for the third quarter, reversing a net profit of US$43.68 million in the same period last year. Loss per share was 0.42 US cents, compared to earnings per share of 0.34 US cents in the previous year.

site_title: Robots are coming for Europe's jobs
summary: Robots are increasingly replacing jobs in Europe, particularly in emerging countries like Slovakia, Lithuania, and Slovenia. The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development reports that workers in these countries face a high risk of job automation, with median probabilities ranging from 62% to nearly 50%. While some jobs will become obsolete, others in more productive sectors will emerge, and robots will help fill job shortages in the region. The increased use of robots is also linked to a decline in total employment rates in the region, with jobs in agriculture and manufacturing declining by 4% and 2% respectively.

site_title: North Korea hiding missile bases, US researchers say
summary: US researchers have found that North Korea is operating at least 13 undeclared missile bases to hide mobile, nuclear-capable missiles, contradicting US President Donald Trump's claims of progress in denuclearization talks. The bases, located in underground facilities, are scattered across the country and designed to enable quick mobile missile launches. The discovery raises concerns that Trump may accept a "bad deal" in negotiations, and the US has delayed approval of humanitarian aid requests to North Korea due to stalled negotiations.

site_title: CapitaLand teams up with GIC to buy Shanghai's tallest twin towers for 12.8b yuan
summary: CapitaLand has partnered with GIC to acquire Shanghai's tallest twin towers for 12.8 billion yuan (S$2.54 billion). This marks CapitaLand's third Raffles City integrated development in Shanghai and its ninth in China, 10th globally. The investment is made through CapitaLand's investment fund, with a 50:50 joint venture formed with GIC.

site_title: Amnesty International strips Aung San Suu Kyi of highest honour
summary: Amnesty International has stripped Aung San Suu Kyi of its highest honour, the Ambassador of Conscience Award, due to her "indifference" to the atrocities committed by the Myanmar military against Rohingya Muslims. The move comes after Suu Kyi's government failed to speak up for the Rohingya and amid reports of human rights abuses and intimidation of campaigners. The decision is the latest in a string of awards Suu Kyi has lost since the military's crackdown on the Rohingya in 2017.

site_title: Europe: FTSE outperforms European peers as Brexit angst sinks sterling
summary: The FTSE 100 index outperformed European peers on Monday, losing 0.74% as Brexit-related fears weighed on sterling, boosting stocks with foreign revenues in dollars. European bourses fell, with Germany's DAX down 1.77% and Paris's CAC 40 0.93% lower. The pound sank 1% against the dollar amid Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit strategy under attack. Oil majors BP and Royal Dutch Shell rose, while AstraZeneca and Shire shares also gained.

site_title: Mandarin Gardens raises en bloc asking price to S$2.79b
summary: The owners of Mandarin Gardens condominium in Singapore have raised the en bloc asking price to S$2.79 billion, a 12.5% increase from the original S$2.48 billion. The increase is attributed to a discovery that the land on which the property sits was undervalued by over S$300 million. The move aims to reach the 80% resident approval required for an en bloc sale. If successful, owners could receive an average of S$2.8 million each.

site_title: Billionaire American families seek profit from Brexit chaos
summary: Billionaire American families, including the Van Tuyls and Stephens, are investing in London real estate, taking advantage of Brexit-induced opportunities. They join foreign investors from Israel and Asia who are also capitalizing on the market's volatility. Despite concerns of a recession and pound slump, the uncertainty has created opportunities for investors, with some predicting a smooth exit from the EU could boost the pound. The market has seen a significant shift, with 74% of London office real estate now owned by foreign investors, and the pound's weakness may be short-lived.

site_title: CapitaLand wins bid for prime Guangzhou site while expanding footprint
summary: CapitaLand wins a 4.7-hectare mixed-use site in Guangzhou, China for $175 million, expanding its footprint in the city. The site, located in Guangzhou Science City, will be developed into office, retail, and serviced residences, with a gross floor area of 142,107 sq m. The development is slated for completion by 2022, capitalizing on Guangzhou's booming office market and growing demand for innovation and tech companies. This acquisition strengthens CapitaLand's portfolio in the region, following recent divestments and investments in China.

site_title: A helping hand when disaster strikes
summary: ASEAN is committed to reducing and managing disasters in the region, having experienced over 1,600 natural disasters affecting 450 million people since 1967. The ASEAN Agreement on Disaster Management and Emergency Response (AADMER) has led to initiatives such as the ASEAN Coordinating Centre for Humanitarian Assistance (AHA Centre) and the ASEAN Joint Disaster Response Plan (AJDRP). The AHA Centre has facilitated cooperation and coordination among ASEAN Member States, deploying 29 members to a recent Central Sulawesi Earthquake mission. ASEAN has also implemented initiatives such as disaster risk financing, school safety, and humanitarian assistance coordination to boost community resilience and mitigate disaster impacts.

site_title: Stan Lee, Marvel legend and father of superheroes, dies at 95
summary: Stan Lee, the co-creator of iconic Marvel superheroes such as Spider-Man and The Hulk, has died at 95. Born on December 28, 1922, Lee rose through the ranks of the comics industry and became a publisher, leading the Marvel empire for decades. He collaborated with other authors and illustrators to create a vast universe of characters, inspiring millions with his imagination and entertainment value. Lee's legacy continues to be celebrated through his cameo roles in Marvel Cinematic Universe films, cementing his status as a superhero in his own right.

site_title: Queens neighbourhood wary of Amazon coming to town
summary: Residents of Long Island City, Queens, are concerned about the potential arrival of Amazon, which is reportedly planning to set up a second headquarters in the area. The neighborhood has already undergone significant gentrification, with new skyscrapers and luxury developments, leading to concerns about rising rents and displacement of long-term residents. Local business owners and officials are urging caution, citing concerns about infrastructure and the impact on the community, while city officials and the governor have expressed support for the move, promising investment and economic benefits.

site_title: US crude ends lower for record 11th consecutive session
summary: US crude prices fell for the 11th consecutive session, the longest streak on record, as President Donald Trump expressed hope that Saudi Arabia and Opec won't cut oil production. Trump's comments came after Saudi Arabia's energy minister stated that Opec was considering a 1 million barrel per day supply cut. US crude prices dropped 26 cents to settle at $59.93 a barrel, while Brent crude futures fell 6 cents to settle at $70.12 a barrel. The decline marked a reversal from an early session rally, and analysts attributed it to concerns over a slowdown in demand and a surge in global supply.

site_title: Air India ops director stopped from piloting flight after failing breath tests
summary: Air India operations director Arvind Kathpalia was stopped from piloting a flight to London after failing two breathalyzer tests, his second incident involving alcohol tests. Kathpalia, who is also on Air India's board, denies he had been drinking and claims the tests were related to internal feuding. He plans to contest the results, citing a culture of conflict at the airline. Kathpalia was previously suspended for three months in 2017 for refusing breathalyzer tests.

site_title: It's not the economy, stupid!
summary: US midterm elections have shown that economic growth is no longer a unifying force, contradicting the long-held notion that prosperity favors the incumbent party. Economic themes have persisted in presidential campaigns, with phrases like "It's the economy, stupid" coined by James Carville in 1992. However, the current election highlights the decline of economic unity, instead emphasizing divisive issues like race, religion, and ethnicity. This shift suggests that economic growth alone is no longer a reliable factor in American politics, marking a significant change in the country's election narratives.

site_title: Global consortium to bid for rail link in Thailand
summary: Billionaire Dhanin Chearavanont's CP Group has teamed up with Asian and European firms to bid for a 225 billion-baht (S$9.4 billion) high-speed rail link connecting three international airports in Thailand. The consortium aims to connect Bangkok's two international airports and Pattaya's U-Tapao International Airport. The winning bidder is due to be selected by January. This project is part of the military government's infrastructure agenda, and the outcome may be influenced by the upcoming general election in late February next year.

site_title: A firm commitment to deepen economic integration
summary: Singapore, as ASEAN chair in 2018, has pursued economic integration with five key areas of focus. At the 50th ASEAN Economic Ministers' Meeting, the 32nd ASEAN Free Trade Area Council Meeting, and the 21st ASEAN Investment Area Council Meeting, held in Singapore, key outcomes were reached. The meetings aimed to deliver tangible benefits to businesses and individuals, with a focus on economic deliverables. However, the article does not mention the specific outcomes or results of these meetings.

site_title: Yangon Stock Exchange opens up to the world
summary: The Yangon Stock Exchange (YSX) is set to announce new rules allowing overseas investors to trade, lifting restrictions on foreign participation in its economy. The new rules, expected to be released before the end of the year, will enable foreigners to buy shares in Myanmar companies listed on the YSX up to 35% threshold. This move comes after Myanmar amended its century-old Companies Act, allowing foreigners to engage in export and import, insurance, and other business activities. The new rules aim to promote investments and improve the country's growth potential, with foreign companies already showing interest in investing in the YSX.

site_title: E-wallets yet to take off in Singapore: Worldpay report
summary: A 2018 report by Worldpay found that e-wallets in Singapore constitute only 10% of online payments and 4% of offline purchases, with credit cards being the preferred method for both online and offline transactions. Despite Singapore's tech-savvy culture, e-wallets have yet to change payment habits, with cash remaining a top payment preference for offline purchases. The report projects that e-wallets will surpass credit cards as the top payment method for online purchases in the Asia-Pacific region by 2022.

site_title: Facebook courting startups and SMEs
summary: Facebook is investing in South-east Asian startups and small businesses through various initiatives, including digital literacy education and business training. The company plans to build a $1.4 billion data centre in Singapore, its first in Asia and 15th globally, which will support hundreds of jobs and enhance its presence in the region. Facebook also launched Startup Station, Singapore, a data innovation startup programme that will provide startups with mentorship, connections to investors, and access to the Regulatory Sandbox. The programme aims to empower startups to accelerate their businesses while maintaining people's trust and control over their data.

site_title: Germany's vehicle rebound may be stung by trade tensions, China's slowdown
summary: Germany's automotive industry is expected to rebound in the fourth quarter after a slowdown in economic growth due to updated emissions-test procedures and China's slowdown. Despite this, the strength of the rebound is uncertain due to trade tensions and slower growth in China, which accounts for 40% of global deliveries for Volkswagen AG. The German economy is expected to bounce back to 0.8% growth, with industrial production forecast to improve in October, according to UniCredit.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Sasseur Reit reported a 4.5% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) and distributable income to S$18.2 million for the third quarter, exceeding forecasts. Net property income rose 0.7% to S$29.08 million. The company's results were unaffected by the recent tariffs on copper imports, which are expected to cover refined metal.

site_title: National efforts vital to tackle climate issues
summary: A whole-of-nation effort is required to tackle climate change, with governments, businesses, and individuals working together to address the global challenge. The recent Special Report on Global Warming of 1.5°C by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change highlights the severe impacts of climate change if global warming exceeds 1.5°C. ASEAN countries have taken steps to address climate change, including the adoption of the Paris Agreement and national pledges to take climate action. However, more needs to be done to reach the 1.5°C goal, with South-east Asia particularly vulnerable to the impacts of climate change due to its long coastlines and heavily-populated low-lying areas.

site_title: Thai developers pouring billions into retail space
summary: Thai developers are investing billions of dollars in the retail space, with $4 billion in new projects in the pipeline, surpassing other Southeast Asian cities like Jakarta, Singapore, and Kuala Lumpur. The sector has grown 17% in August, with Bangkok expected to add more retail floor space than any city in the region this year. Despite political uncertainty and a decline in tourism, developers remain confident, citing opportunities in e-commerce and mixed-use projects. However, concerns about sustainability and a potential supply glut have raised questions about the long-term viability of Thailand's retail market.

site_title: ASEAN: Shining oasis of regional cooperation
summary: ASEAN has bucked the trend of global anti-globalization and isolationism, providing a safe haven for its member states and dialogue partners. The 33rd ASEAN Summit, hosted by Singapore, brings together 10 ASEAN leaders to discuss regional issues and review community-building efforts. ASEAN has revitalized its concept of "resilience" with new meanings, such as digital resilience and smart solutions for urbanization. The summit also welcomes back Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, who is expected to discuss the East Asia Economic Caucus and the Rohingya crisis. ASEAN remains a multilateral cooperation hub, with the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) aiming to deepen regional integration and connect trade partners without free trade agreements.

site_title: More work needed in regulations, industry to grab blockchain opportunities: panel
summary: Regulators and industry experts emphasize the need for better regulations to support blockchain growth. The technology offers opportunities in supply chain management, trade financing, and asset management. Experts agree that interoperability between blockchain systems is crucial, but standards over regulatory frameworks are preferred. The US, Singapore, and Switzerland are working towards interoperable frameworks that cross borders, aiming to promote safe and secure interflows. Despite the hype, blockchain has real-world applications, but its growth is hindered by regulatory environments that need to adapt.

site_title: Being agile helps power JustLogin's performance
summary: JustLogin, a cloud-based HR solutions firm, owes its success to being highly adaptable and responsive to its customers. Founded in 1999, the company initially struggled during the dotcom crisis but secured investment from OCBC bank, allowing it to capitalize on emerging trends. JustLogin's use of the Agile Methodology enables it to quickly respond to technological trends and market demands, resulting in a highly adaptable business model. The company's focus on product quality, motivated workforce, and employee welfare also contribute to its success, making it a forward-thinking company in the industry.

site_title: Businesses must do their part for greater Asean integration: PM Lee
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need for businesses to welcome competition in their home markets to access other Asean countries, citing the benefits of economic integration and openness. He noted that Asean's governments have reduced tariffs and created a business-friendly environment, but businesses must also play a key role in further regional integration. Lee highlighted the potential of Asean to become the world's fourth-largest economy by 2030, but warned that its success depends on member countries' commitment to deeper integration and openness.

site_title: China signals tougher measures to shore up yuan
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China, has signaled tougher measures to manage the yuan, dropping a phrase that emphasizes market forces' role in setting the exchange rate for the first time in five years. The yuan has weakened 9% over the past six months, prompting concerns of potential intervention to prevent it from reaching its weakest level in over a decade. Despite this, the PBOC reiterated that the market will play a fundamental role in its foreign-exchange system, and the nation will deepen currency market reforms.

site_title: GIC, CPF, Temasek among Asia's top 10 asset owners
summary: Singapore's Government Investment Corporation (GIC), Central Provident Fund, and Temasek Holdings are among the top 10 asset owners in Asia, with GIC ranking 12th with US$359 billion and Temasek ranking 19th with US$230 billion. The top 100 asset owners globally have US$55 trillion in discretionary funds, with Asia-Pacific accounting for 36% of the total. The largest asset owner globally is Japan's Government Pension Investment with US$1.44 trillion. Experts emphasize the importance of these asset owners taking their financial and social responsibilities seriously and evolving their investment models into sustainable arrangements.

site_title: Thomson Medical Group proposes to spin off property businesses
summary: Thomson Medical Group proposes to spin off its real estate business, comprising design, engineering, and hospitality operations, into its current subsidiary RSP Holdings. The distribution will be made to existing shareholders via capital reduction. This restructuring aims to simplify the company's operations and focus on its core medical business. The move is expected to be announced in the coming weeks.

images.alt_text: Main-board listed Thomson Medical Group unveiled a proposal before trading opened on Monday, to spin off its real estate business to existing shareholders via a distribution in specie by way of capital reduction.

site_title: S-E Asia's imminent Fintech boom needs a robust IT and data centre support infrastructure
summary: A fintech boom is imminent in Southeast Asia, driven by the increasing adoption of cashless payment options and e-wallets. Singapore, a hub for fintech firms, has taken proactive steps to position itself as a leader in the region. However, a robust IT and data centre support infrastructure is crucial to handle the projected hyper-scale growth trajectory, prioritizing speed, security, and scalability. Failure to invest in robust backend infrastructure could lead to system outages, data breaches, and financial losses, ultimately affecting the bottom line and reputation of fintech operators and associated banks.

site_title: Banks told to shed 'legacy stuff' for real innovation to happen
summary: Financial institutions in Singapore must adapt their culture to foster innovation, according to leaders from pioneering fintech firms. Culture is key to birthing innovative solutions, panelists agreed during the Singapore Fintech Festival. This shift is crucial for financial institutions to remain competitive in the age of disruption.

site_title: Halcyon Agri Q3 profit down 75.8%
summary: Halcyon Agri Corporation reported a 75.8% decline in its third-quarter net profit to US$1.73 million due to low rubber prices, higher finance costs, and increased use of banking facilities to support working capital requirements. The decline was attributed to the firm's reliance on the rubber industry, which has been impacted by low prices. This decrease in profit is expected to continue affecting the company's earnings.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: US President Trump has imposed a 50% copper import tariff, covering refined metal. This move is part of his ongoing trade policy. Markets reacted with oil prices rising over 2% as investors weighed the impact of tariffs and sanctions. In other news, NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, while Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss. Additionally, London's Heathrow Airport is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade.

site_title: Towards smart cities in ASEAN
summary: ASEAN aims to create smart cities to address urbanization and digitalization challenges. 90 million people are expected to urbanize by 2030, and the region's online population is growing rapidly. The ASEAN Smart Cities Network, launched during Singapore's 2018 chairmanship, brings together 26 pilot cities to develop action plans and share best practices. The network focuses on interoperability and integrated services, and aims to facilitate cooperation between cities and attract private sector finance. The initiative has already seen progress, with cities developing their own plans and networking with global partners. The goal is to create a region where technology benefits ordinary people, including individual farmers, hawkers, and handicraft makers, and where culture, language, and aesthetic skills are valued.

site_title: Cooperating to counter cyber threats
summary: Southeast Asian countries are working together to counter cyber threats, as the region's digital economy has the potential to add $1 trillion to its GDP over the next 10 years. Despite spending less than 0.06% of GDP on cyber security, ASEAN countries face significant threats from cyber terrorism, fraud, and identity theft. Singapore, a key player in the region, has been hit by a major cyber attack, and the country is investing in cyber defence, innovation, and partnerships to build a resilient digital community. ASEAN countries are establishing a regional cyber security centre and industry call for innovation to develop cutting-edge cyber security solutions.

site_title: Pagoda Street shophouses go on the market
summary: Singapore's historic Chinatown district is seeing a shift in the property market with two prime shophouses at Pagoda Street going on the market. The properties, located at 31 and 76 Pagoda Street, are a freehold and a 99-year leasehold, respectively. JLL is acting as the exclusive marketing agent, calling for offers to buy these unique conservation shophouses. The move is seen as a response to the growing demand for prime projects in Singapore, with a Q3 wave of condo launches expected to test the market's resilience.

site_title: CRYPTIC CROSSWORD
summary: A cryptic crossword puzzle was published on November 12, 2018. The puzzle consisted of 30 clues across and down, with answers ranging from 3 to 15 letters. The puzzle was created by the GTelegraph Group Limited in London, and its copyright is reserved by SPH Media. The solution to the puzzle was published, but the original clues remain cryptic, providing a challenge for solvers to decipher the answers.

site_title: US dollar hits 16-month high
summary: The US dollar reached a 16-month high on Monday as investors anticipated a Federal Reserve interest rate rise next month and concerns about European politics. The dollar surged due to robust US economic growth and fears about a no-deal Brexit and European economic instability. The euro slid 0.7% to its lowest since June 2017, while the British pound fell 1% to its weakest level since October. The dollar's rally is expected to continue, with analysts predicting further euro-selling pressure and a strengthening dollar going into the year-end.

site_title: Fostering unity and friendship among youth
summary: The Singapore-ASEAN Youth Fund, launched in 2007, supports projects fostering unity and friendship among ASEAN youth, increasing awareness of ASEAN culture, and promoting entrepreneurship, education, and the environment. The fund, renewed with a S$5 million top-up, has benefited approximately 200,000 youths across South-east Asia. Recent initiatives include the Puppet Arts for Change Workshop and Tour, the ASEAN e-sports and music festival "Hyperplay", and the ASEAN Youth Fellowship programme, showcasing the region's arts and culture. These efforts aim to strengthen people-to-people ties and promote understanding among ASEAN youth.

site_title: Leveraging infrastructure opportunities in South-east Asia
summary: Infrastructure Asia, a Singapore-based organization, aims to support Asia's economic and social growth through infrastructure development. Established by Enterprise Singapore and the Monetary Authority of Singapore, it seeks to connect industry players, multilateral development banks, and the public sector to facilitate information exchange and best practices in Asia. The organization identifies significant infrastructure opportunities in South-east Asia, requiring US$3.1 trillion in investment from 2016 to 2030, driven by population growth and urbanization. It will leverage its networks to connect companies and financial institutions with governments, and work to develop scalable yet customizable solutions for infrastructure projects.

site_title: Valuetronics reports 12.8% drop in Q2 net profit
summary: Valuetronics Holdings reported a 12.8% drop in Q2 net profit to HK$44.3 million due to lower revenue and a provision for flash flooding damages at its factory. Revenue decreased 1.3% to HK$716.2 million, with the consumer electronics segment falling 22%. The company is evaluating measures to mitigate tariff impact, including relocating product assembly out of China. Net profit for the half year fell 5.6% to HK$93.98 million.

site_title: A collective regional approach to fight terrorism threat
summary: Singapore proposes the 'Resilience, Response, and Recovery' framework to counter the evolving global terrorism threat, particularly from ISIS. The region faces a high threat due to returning fighters and social divisions exploited by terrorists. A collective regional approach is crucial to counter this threat, with initiatives such as the ASEAN Ministerial Meeting on Transnational Crime and the Special ASEAN Ministerial Meeting on the Rise of Radicalisation and Violent Extremism. Singapore emphasizes the importance of social cohesion, community resilience, and awareness of online radicalization to prevent terrorism.

site_title: Towards an inclusive, stable financial sector
summary: Singapore and the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) have pursued various initiatives to help ASEAN achieve its goal of economic integration. The ASEAN Economic Community (AEC) Blueprint 2025 aims to create a highly integrated and cohesive economy, with a focus on financial sector inclusivity and stability. Initiatives include infrastructure financing, financial integration, facilitating trade and investment, green finance, resilience against natural disasters, cyber threats, and financial stability. ASEAN is also leveraging digital solutions to advance financial inclusion, with the launch of the API Exchange platform.

site_title: China Everbright Water net profit up 18% in Q3
summary: China Everbright Water, a Singapore-listed company, reported a 18% increase in net profit to HK$144.3 million in Q3, driven by a 39% rise in revenue. Construction revenue rose by HK$227.76 million, while operation and finance income also increased. This growth is attributed to the company's expansion in the water management sector.

site_title: Raising yard capacity in downturn a tough call
summary: The offshore and marine (O&M) sector is recovering from a downturn, with global capex for upstream oil and gas projects expected to rebound along with oil prices. However, industry players, including Hyundai Heavy Industries, Keppel O&M, and Sembcorp Marine, have significantly downsized their operations, resulting in thousands of layoffs. To rebuild and re-group, these companies must focus on design, engineering, and project management competencies, which may have been degraded during the downturn. Sembcorp Marine, which has acquired engineering-focused outfits and developed its Tuas Boulevard Yard, is well-positioned to capitalize on the next upswing, while Keppel O&M's divestments and exit from certain regions raise questions about its ability to reap the full benefits of its LeTourneau acquisition.

site_title: Adapting for expansion into the regional market
summary: Select Group, a Singapore-based food and beverage operator, expects to make over 10% of its sales in neighboring South-east Asian markets next year. The company, which has a footprint in Kuala Lumpur, Jakarta, and Ho Chi Minh City, plans to expand into Penang and Melaka, Medan and Surabaya, and Hanoi, with entries into Thailand and the Philippines also planned. With a population of over 650 million, South-east Asia offers significant growth potential, according to managing director Vincent Tan, who attributes the region's receptiveness to new culinary concepts and lifestyle changes.

site_title: Neon Lights fest still dazzles despite downpour
summary: The Neon Lights festival in Singapore, now in its third edition, took place despite a downpour on Sunday, causing a one-hour delay in opening the grounds. The event featured an eclectic lineup, with varying vibes across the three days, including WOMAD, Glastonbury, Coachella, and Laneway. Despite a smaller turnout of 8,300, fans and bands adapted to the bad weather, and the festival's art component added a unique dimension. However, the lack of fresh headliners was a notable letdown, potentially limiting the event's appeal.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: City Developments Limited (CDL) reported Q3 results in-line with expectations, with profit after tax and minority interests increasing 10.4% year-on-year to S$161.8 million. Revenue jumped 17.7% to S$1.02 billion. Despite lower sales in Singapore, CDL's strong balance sheet, share buybacks, and diversification of income streams support a "buy" recommendation. ComfortDelGro's 9M profit was 6.6% lower than expected, but the company remains confident of growth in its public transport business and new acquisitions.

site_title: All eyes on RCEP pact to light the way for global trade
summary: The Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) is a proposed free trade agreement between 16 countries, including 10 ASEAN member states and six key partners, aiming to become the world's largest free trade area. Negotiations have been ongoing for five years, with leaders meeting at the 33rd ASEAN Summit in Singapore. The deal, seen as an alternative to the US-led Trans-Pacific Partnership, seeks to lower trade barriers, secure improved market access, and facilitate trade and investment among participating countries. If concluded, it is expected to recognize ASEAN centrality and promote economic integration and cooperation among the participating countries.

site_title: Asean on track to realise 2025 vision of free and open trade
summary: Asean has made significant progress towards its 2025 vision of free and open trade with the signing of three agreements, promoting economic integration and free trade within the bloc. The agreements were opened by Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing, emphasizing the need for continued progress towards the Asean Economic Community.

site_title: Vietnam becomes 7th country to ratify Trans-Pacific trade deal
summary: Vietnam's National Assembly unanimously ratified the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP), making it the 7th country to do so. The deal, which includes labor rights and conditions of work, is expected to benefit Vietnam's garment and seafood sectors, with tariffs on 43% of apparel exports to Canada set to be removed immediately and 100% after four years. The pact is seen as a great opportunity for Vietnam to modernize its labor laws and industrial relations system.

site_title: Spirit of sharing and helping in ASEAN
summary: Singapore launched the Initiative for ASEAN Integration (IAI) 18 years ago to narrow the development divide among ASEAN countries. The IAI aims to enhance ASEAN's competitiveness by providing vocational training and capacity-building programs in areas such as trade development, human resource development, and agriculture. Since its inception, Singapore has established IAI Training Centres in Cambodia, Laos, Myanmar, and Vietnam, offering over 1,900 programs to more than 39,000 government officials. The centers have been upgraded to become Singapore Cooperation Centres (SCCs), offering a more flexible platform for technical assistance and joint development programs with third countries and international organizations.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Turning challenges into opportunities
summary: Singapore's chairmanship of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) emphasizes the group's resolve to tackle challenges together, including the digital revolution, climate change, and terrorism. The theme "Resilience and Innovation" aims to turn these issues into opportunities, with concrete deliverables including the ASEAN Smart Cities Network, the ASEAN-Singapore Cybersecurity Centre of Excellence, and the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), which will be the world's largest trading bloc. ASEAN's efforts reflect its conviction that the group benefits its members by working together.

images.alt_text: Member states think regionally, not just nationally. Successive national governments have looked beyond their domestic concerns, and invested political capital in the ASEAN project for the last 50 years. This is why ASEAN has stood the test of time. Our determination to stay the course has borne fruit. Today, ASEAN is one of the more politically cohesive and economically vibrant regional groupings in the world.
ASEAN leaders at the opening ceremony of the 32nd ASEAN Summit held in Singapore in April 2018.

site_title: Asean Smart Cities Initiative will benefit region's big and small players
summary: The Asean summit will focus on the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) and the Asean Smart Cities initiative. Asean leaders are expected to adopt the Asean Smart Cities Framework, which defines a smart city and aims to harness digital technology to solve problems and create opportunities across the region. With 90 million more people expected to join the urban population within the next decade, the initiative seeks to address challenges such as resource competition, environmental issues, and security concerns.

site_title: Never a dull moment at Sunburst 2018
summary: Azariah Tan, a 26-year-old pianist with 15% hearing loss, performed at the Sunburst: The Business Times-CapitaLand Fundraising Concert, raising S$250,000 for the Muscular Dystrophy Association of Singapore and the SOTA Student Assistance Fund. The event, organized by The Business Times and CapitaLand Hope Foundation, featured various performers and was supported by major sponsors such as OCBC Bank and Standard Chartered Bank. Speaker of Parliament Tan Chuan-Jin was the guest of honor, and the concert was also attended by a 350-strong crowd at the SOTA concert hall.

site_title: Singapore, China deepen ties with upgraded FTA, other pacts
summary: Singapore and China deepened their bilateral ties with the signing of several agreements, including an upgraded free trade agreement (FTA) that provides Singapore businesses with easier entry into China's legal, maritime, and construction services sector. The agreements also include enhancements in investment protection, customs procedures, and trade facilitation, and will take effect after both countries ratify the protocol. The upgraded FTA is part of a three-year process that began in 2015 and marks a significant boost to Singapore-China economic collaboration.

site_title: Thousands rally to back Italy-France high-speed train project
summary: Thousands of people in Turin, Italy, rallied in support of a planned high-speed train line to Lyon, marking the first large-scale demonstration in favor of the TAV Lyon-Turin railway. The project faced opposition from environmental groups but has received significant public backing. The rally, attended by 30,000 to 40,000 people, demonstrates growing support for the project and its potential economic benefits.

site_title: Key to manufacturing success in ASEAN
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector is experiencing a resurgence, with a 3% year-on-year growth in August 2018 and an average expansion of 1% month-on-month over the past three months. The demand for "Made in Singapore" goods is rising, driven by the growing economy of ASEAN and the need for food safety and traceability. Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) can tap into government support, including the Singapore Economic Development Board's (EDB) Industry 4.0 transformation program, to accelerate their growth. International partnerships, such as DBS' e-commerce platform, are also being launched to support SMEs in scaling their businesses through digitalization.

site_title: Wilmar posts 10.7% jump in Q3 profit
summary: Wilmar International reported a 10.7% jump in Q3 profit to US$407.4 million, driven by better performance in tropical oils and oilseeds/grains businesses. Revenue rose 4.3% to US$11.6 billion, supported by higher sales volumes. Core net profit rose 35% to US$435 million. The company attributed the growth to favorable weather conditions, higher production yields, and stronger demand for downstream products.

site_title: ADMM-Plus: An ASEAN-led security forum
summary: ASEAN-led security forum, ADMM-Plus, held its fifth meeting in Singapore, bringing together defence ministers from 18 countries, including ASEAN member states and "Plus" countries from Australia, China, India, Japan, New Zealand, Russia, South Korea, and the US. The forum promotes multilateral cooperation on transnational security challenges and capacity building, and has become a keystone to the emerging regional security architecture. Key achievements include the adoption of a non-binding code for military encounters in the air and at sea, and a joint maritime exercise between the US and ASEAN. However, challenges remain, including ASEAN unity on key issues and limited capacity to respond collectively to challenges.

images.alt_text: Singapore Minister for Defence Ng Eng Hen (middle), hosting the ASEAN defence ministers to breakfast during the ADMM-Plus.

site_title: Blockchain could speed up homebuying, lower costs once hurdles are cleared
summary: Blockchain technology may speed up homebuying and lower closing costs in the US. Franklin County, Ohio, plans to migrate its 438,000 parcels onto a digital ledger in 2-3 years, reducing transfer times to hours or seconds and cutting costs of thousands of dollars. This effort could reshape the global real-estate market, with many governments exploring blockchain for property deeds. Lenders, agents, and insurers will be on the blockchain, potentially reducing transaction costs and shrinking the roles of title companies.

site_title: Global order under stress on WW1 anniversary
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron commemorated the 100th anniversary of the end of WW1 in Paris, warning that the world may be sleepwalking towards another deadly conflict due to rising nationalism and the erosion of the international order. Macron called for a "European army" to protect the continent against potential threats from Russia, China, and the US, which has been criticized by Donald Trump. Despite parallels with the early 20th century, the global order is under stress due to shifting power to Asia, particularly China, but memories of two world wars and the presence of nuclear weapons act as a restraint on major conflict.

site_title: Suu Kyi beckons investors to Myanmar despite troubles
summary: Myanmar's Aung San Suu Kyi urged foreign investors to invest in her country despite troubles, warning they won't exploit its resources at the cost of its people. The country's economy is forecast to grow at 7% next year, according to the World Bank. Suu Kyi's appeal comes as her country faces challenges, including human rights concerns and ethnic tensions. She emphasized the need for sustainable development and responsible investment practices.

site_title: SoftBank launches US$21b IPO of Japan mobile unit
summary: SoftBank is launching a US$21 billion initial public offering (IPO) of its Japanese mobile unit, SoftBank Corp, on December 19. The offering will see 1.6 billion shares listed at 1,500 yen (S$18) each, valuing the mobile unit at 7.18 trillion yen. The IPO is expected to be Japan's largest-ever, and will help SoftBank raise funds as it transitions into an investment firm, with CEO Masayoshi Son taking stakes in top tech companies.

site_title: Taking Asean forward
summary: The 33rd Asean Summit and Related Summits concluded in Singapore, marking the final milestone of the country's year-long chairmanship. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong chaired the summit, which focused on regional economic integration and future development. Asean is projected to become the world's fourth-largest economy by 2030, and the bloc will need to address present needs and drive future development over the next 50 years and beyond. The summit did not prioritize the Myanmar election, as Malaysia stated.

site_title: Indonesia urges more training for pilots after Lion Air crash
summary: Indonesian investigators have found that the crew of the Lion Air Boeing 737 MAX did not receive adequate training on handling a faulty sensor, which led to the plane's descent into the Java Sea. The incident has highlighted the need for more training on the aircraft's US-approved procedures to prevent over-reacting to sensor data loss. Indonesian regulators plan to tighten training requirements, and experts will examine cockpit voice recordings to determine if the crew had time to respond to the emergency.

site_title: E-payment war morphing from single to paired fighters
summary: The e-payment war in Singapore has shifted from single competitors to teams of unicorn and incumbent companies. Go-Jek partnered with DBS Bank, Grab with UOB Bank, and Razer with NETS, forming new alliances at the Singapore FinTech Festival. These partnerships aim to create a unified e-payments system for Singapore and the region, taking the competition to a new level. Industry observers see this as a significant development, marking a new stage in the e-payment fight. The tie-ups are expected to unlock deep tech innovation and drive growth in the sector.

site_title: Malaysia seeking 'full refund' from Goldman for 1MDB deals
summary: Malaysia is seeking a full refund of nearly $600 million in fees paid to Goldman Sachs for arranging 1MDB deals, citing the bank's "admitted culpability" in the scandal. Finance Minister Lim Guan Eng hopes to recover 30% of the total $4.5 billion lost through 1MDB, with Goldman's former banker Tim Leissner pleading guilty to withholding information on bribes. The government plans to pursue legal action and recover fees through interest-rate differential and asset tracing, with the help of international cooperation, including from Chinese authorities.

site_title: Macron, tech giants launch initiative to fix internet ills
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron and tech giants, including Microsoft, launched the "Paris call for trust and security in cyberspace" to regulate the internet and combat threats like cyber attacks, online censorship, and hate speech. The initiative, signed by European countries but excluding China and Russia, urges governments to strengthen protection against cyber threats and prevent trade secret theft. The move aims to promote global cooperation in the face of rising nationalism, with large US tech companies like Facebook and Google expected to sign up.

site_title: Sinarmas Land's Q3 profit falls 25.7%
summary: Sinarmas Land, an Indonesian property developer, reported a 25.7% drop in Q3 net profit to S$12.4 million, mainly due to lower revenue and higher finance costs. The company attributed the decline to a weakening Indonesian rupiah and escalating US-China trade tensions. For the 9-month period, net profit fell 49.7% to S$60.4 million, with revenue decreasing 23%. The company's executive director attributed the decline to a combination of factors, including interest rate hikes and weakening of the rupiah.

site_title: ASEAN: Towards a people-oriented, people-centred community
summary: ASEAN's ASEAN Socio-Cultural Community (ASCC) aims to improve the well-being and livelihood of its people, focusing on a people-oriented, people-centred approach. Key initiatives include developing a culture of prevention, enhancing education, promoting health and digital literacy, and fostering a culture of inclusivity. The ASEAN Enabling Masterplan 2025 prioritizes empowering persons with disabilities, while ASEAN also seeks to address issues like antimicrobial resistance and combating fake news. The community is guided by a set of core values, including digital literacy and cyber wellness, to promote responsible online behavior and critical consumption of information.

site_title: Pioneering electric plane needs US$200m for final push
summary: A US$200 million investment is needed to bring the Eviation Aircraft Ltd's "Alice" electric plane to market, with a planned price tag of $3 million to $5 million. The nine-passenger, 650-mile range plane could compete in the commuter market, offering lower running costs compared to traditional turboprop models. The company aims to begin production in 2.5 years, with a Paris Air Show prototype flight planned in June.

site_title: Meet the robot who trades bonds better than you can
summary: AllianceBernstein's virtual assistant Abbie has been upgraded to suggest bonds based on pricing, ease of trading, and risk. Abbie 2.0 can scan millions of data points to identify potential trades and communicate with other chatbots, targeting US high yield and investment grade bonds initially. The upgraded version mines data pools to make suggestions, reducing reliance on human input. Abbie already supports 60% of AllianceBernstein's fixed income trades and aims to increase efficiency in bond trading, where liquidity is a growing concern.

site_title: Singapore's fintech drive arcs towards financial inclusion
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is pushing for better access to technology services and credit for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) through the fintech drive. To achieve this, MAS has set out the world's first set of principles for responsible use of data in financial services, aiming to prevent technology from creating fault lines that hurt financial inclusion. The regulator also plans to facilitate financial institutions' credit assessment of SMEs using trusted government data and create a cross-border innovation platform for SMEs.

site_title: Smarter transportation critical for Emerging Asia's growth
summary: Emerging Asia's economies are expected to grow at an annual average of 5.2% from 2019 to 2023, with China and India projected to expand at 6.1% and 7.3% respectively. South-east Asian countries, including Indonesia, the Philippines, and Vietnam, are also expected to see growth rates of 5.3%, 6.6%, and 6.5% respectively. However, traffic congestion is a critical issue hindering growth, and dealing with it is crucial for sustaining growth, according to the OECD Development Centre.

site_title: Canada's Avison Young buys UK's GVA
summary: Canada's Avison Young has acquired UK-based GVA, its largest deal yet, combining the operations of 1,500 employees in 15 offices across the UK, Ireland, and Poland. Avison Young's CEO, Mark Rose, expects the deal to boost revenues to C$1 billion, more than doubling its previous C$650 million. The acquisition will expand Avison Young's global presence and entry into Europe, allowing for further growth and expansion.

site_title: Theresa May stares into Brexit abyss as domestic opposition mounts
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit strategy faces mounting opposition from all sides, increasing the risk of a "no-deal" Brexit. Negotiators are still haggling over a border plan between Northern Ireland and Ireland, and May's compromise plan is being criticized by Brexiteers, pro-Europeans, and her own ministers. Economists predict a one-in-four chance of a failed deal, and the EU's chief Brexit negotiator is waiting for a signal from May that she has secured enough parliamentary votes. If the deal is rejected, the UK faces an uncertain future, including the possibility of a new referendum.

site_title: ShopBack looks to scale up in Australia
summary: ShopBack, a Singapore-based cashback firm, has expanded into the Australian market, garnering over 120,000 users and 700 merchants since May this year. The company aims to capitalize on Australia's high internet penetration rate and growing e-commerce sector. ShopBack's chief commercial officer Candice Ong notes that the Australian market offers "tremendous opportunities" for the firm, which is well-versed in app development. To further establish its presence, ShopBack has been hiring aggressively and onboarding new merchants, including e-commerce giant Amazon and supermarket chain Woolworths.

site_title: Delfi posts stronger profits in Q3
summary: Delfi, a chocolate maker, reported a 19% jump in net profit to US$4 million in Q3, driven by 17% year-over-year revenue growth due to higher own brand sales and expanding markets in Indonesia and the Philippines. CEO John Chuang attributed the growth to strong fundamentals in the priority markets and actions taken over the past two years.

site_title: In China's Himalayas, a wine 'flying above the clouds'
summary: China's wine industry has gained international recognition with the debut of Ao Yun, a US$300 bottle of wine made at the foot of the Himalayas in Yunnan province. French luxury giant Moet Hennessy partnered with local farmers to create the wine, which has received positive reviews for its smooth, full-bodied blend of Cabernet Sauvignon and Cabernet Franc. The company's efforts aim to prove China can produce high-quality wine, despite a history of inconsistent quality, and capitalize on the country's growing wine market, expected to reach nearly US$91 billion by 2023.

images.alt_text: The vineyards are situated in the middle of the Mekong, Yangtze and Salween rivers, a unique location which boasts moderate temperatures all year round.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: US President Trump has announced a 50% copper import tariff, affecting refined metal. Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weigh market outlook and trade tensions. European stocks declined due to bank and healthcare sector losses, with US-EU tariffs in focus. US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss for the second half. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade.

site_title: 51 states pledge support for global cybersecurity rules
summary: Fifty-one countries, including all EU members, have pledged support for a Paris Call for Trust and Security in Cyberspace, aiming to set standards for cyberweapons and internet use. The agreement seeks to avoid a war in cyberspace, which would be catastrophic. China, Russia, and the US did not sign, reflecting resistance to setting standards. The pledge was signed by 93 civil society groups and 218 companies, with French President Emmanuel Macron set to present the text at the Internet Governance Forum in Paris.

site_title: Delhi homeless to be given masks as smog worsens: official
summary: New Delhi's homeless will receive cotton masks to cope with extreme pollution, but experts say they offer little protection against deadly smog particles. The city's pollution levels are 30 times above safe limits, posing a significant threat to the poor and homeless. Despite measures to curb smog, such as reducing traffic and banning firecrackers, the situation remains dire. The city government has distributed 10,000 masks, but experts recommend medically approved masks for effective protection.

site_title: World's biggest firms plan to get down with WeWork effect
summary: The world's largest employers plan to adopt flexible office spaces similar to WeWork's model, with 55% expecting non-traditional space to account for at least 20% of total space by 2021. This shift challenges traditional landlords, who have focused on long-term leases. Companies like Citigroup and Deutsche Bank are already placing teams in co-working spaces to improve recruitment and productivity. Shorter leases and employee well-being initiatives are driving the change, with WeWork's amenities and global network attracting big businesses.

site_title: Nestle raises stake in food allergy drug developer Aimmune
summary: Nestle's health science unit is investing $98 million to increase its stake in Aimmune Therapeutics Inc, a developer of food allergy treatments, to approximately 19%. The investment extends a two-year strategic collaboration to develop therapies for food allergies by another two years.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower as Apple drags
summary: US stocks opened lower on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 29.97 points, or 0.12%, to 25,959.33, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also dropping. The decline was attributed to a slide in Apple Inc after weak forecasts from its suppliers and losses in tobacco companies, despite a rebound in oil prices.

site_title: SAP to buy customer sentiment tracker Qualtrics for US$8b
summary: SAP has agreed to acquire customer sentiment tracker Qualtrics for $8 billion, its largest acquisition since buying Concur in 2014. The deal will expand SAP's customer relationship management capabilities and provide real-time insights into customer behavior. Qualtrics CEO Ryan Smith will remain in the job and the company will retain its dual headquarters. The acquisition is expected to boost SAP's revenue growth, with the company predicting double-digit growth and outpacing competitors like Salesforce and Oracle.

site_title: Saudi, UAE energy giants team up for gas push
summary: Saudi Arabia's Aramco and the UAE's ADNOC signed a cooperation deal to bolster gas production and revenue. The agreement aims to increase cooperation in exploring investment opportunities and swapping knowledge to tap into natural gas and LNG markets. The move follows UAE's plans to become self-sufficient in natural gas and later a net exporter, with the goal of producing 1 billion cubic feet of gas daily by 2030. The deal is seen as a step towards greater energy security and long-term economic prosperity for both nations.

site_title: Boustead Singapore Q2 FY19 profit down 3%
summary: Boustead Singapore's Q2 FY19 net profit fell 3% to S$6.89 million, driven by a S$2.11 million loss from associated and joint venture companies. Revenue rose 13% to S$118.36 million, while earnings per share remained unchanged. The company declared a one-cent-per-share dividend, payable Dec 7. The six-month net profit surged 90% to S$19.09 million.

site_title: Asian markets close mixed, STI slips 0.3%
summary: Asian markets closed mixed, with the STI slipping 0.3% due to weak local market sentiment. The decline was attributed to lacklustre corporate earnings and concerns over trade and growth prospects amid rising uncertainties. The Federal Reserve's decision to continue raising interest rates also dampened post-US mid-term rallies in Asia.

site_title: Volkswagen capable of building 50 million electric vehicles - CEO
summary: Volkswagen CEO Herbert Diess announced that the company is prepared to produce 50 million electric vehicles, with its electric vehicle platform and battery procurement plans in place. This milestone comes after Volkswagen sold 10.7 million vehicles in 2017. The company has already procured batteries for 50 million vehicles, positioning itself to meet this ambitious production target.

site_title: Jawala Inc voluntarily suspends trading of its shares
summary: Jawala Inc has voluntarily suspended trading of its shares due to the suspension of its subsidiary's main bank accounts in Malaysia, effective Nov 5. The company requires more time to seek clarification from authorities and regulators. Despite this, operations of the subsidiary continue as normal, utilizing unaffected bank accounts to facilitate payments. Jawala will make announcements when material updates are available and request for trading to resume in due course.

site_title: Metro in the black in Q2 FY19
summary: Metro Holdings reported a net profit of S$12.81 million for the second quarter of FY19, reversing a net loss of S$13.75 million in the same period last year. Revenue increased 53% to S$46.33 million, driven by higher venue sales from its retail business and property rights sales. The company's profit before tax improved to S$14.42 million, driven by the recognition of profit from a joint venture project and improved associate profit contributions.

site_title: Oxley Holdings posts lower net profit for Q1 FY19
summary: Oxley Holdings reported a 83% year-on-year decline in Q1 FY19 net profit to S$8.06 million, due to lower revenue from UK and Singapore projects. Revenue fell 45% to S$170.3 million. The company launched Kent Ridge Hill Residences for sale, with 116 out of 250 units sold, and 80% of buyers were Singaporeans. The counter closed at 30.5 Singapore cents, down half a cent, on Monday.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: MAS sets out FEAT Principles to guide responsible use of AI and data analytics in finance. Go-Jek partners DBS for regional payments, while Grab ties up with UOB for financial services. Consumers may soon use Razer Pay at Nets terminals. Businesses in Asean must accept more competition at home for access to regional markets, said PM Lee. E-wallets have yet to change payment habits in Singapore, according to a Worldpay report. Singapore shares ended lower on Monday, with the Straits Times Index down 0.3%.

site_title: Centurion Corp reports Q3 profit of S$7.32m
summary: Centurion Corp reported a 21% year-over-year increase in Q3 net profit to S$7.32 million, reversing a loss of S$1.48 million in the same quarter last year. Revenue decreased 12% to S$28.27 million due to the expiry of a lease on Westlite Tuas in Singapore.

site_title: China, Singapore deepen bilateral relations with slew of agreements signed
summary: China and Singapore signed several agreements to deepen their bilateral relations, including an upgraded free trade agreement that provides Singapore businesses with easier market access into China's legal, maritime, and construction services sector. The agreements, signed during PRC Premier Li Keqiang's official visit to Singapore, also include enhancements in investment protection, customs procedures, and trade facilitation. The agreements aim to promote closer economic collaboration and an open and rules-based market trading system between the two countries.

site_title: SoftBank seeks Deutsche's advice on Saudi power investments-sources
summary: SoftBank has hired Deutsche Bank to advise on its power investment plans in Saudi Arabia, including a potential minority stake in Saudi Electricity. The Japanese firm is planning to invest in a 200-gigawatt solar power plant in the kingdom by 2030. SoftBank's CEO Masayoshi Son has defended the firm's ties with Saudi Arabia despite global outcry over the murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi. The move comes as Saudi Arabia seeks to transform its economy and reduce its dependence on oil.

site_title: Cosco Shipping Q3 profit down on absence of profit from discontinued operations
summary: Cosco Shipping International reported a 91% year-on-year decline in Q3 net profit to S$2.12 million, due to the absence of profit from discontinued operations. Revenue jumped 6 times to S$42.15 million, driven by newly acquired logistics businesses. The company aims to expand its logistics network in South and Southeast Asia through acquisitions and investments, and reported an improvement in the international dry bulk shipping market. Its stock closed at 35.5 Singapore cents, down half a cent.

site_title: EU's Juncker signals US car-tariffs truce may not last long
summary: European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker signals that a US trade truce on car tariffs may not last until year-end, citing the Trump administration's lack of interest in reducing industrial tariffs. The truce was reached in July, with the US agreeing to hold off on new duties while both sides work towards reducing barriers on industrial goods. The EU remains prepared to seek an agreement to reduce tariffs, but is focused on regulatory cooperation rather than tariff reductions. The US could impose 25% car tariffs on national-security grounds if an investigation is completed by early next year.

site_title: Straco Corp reports flat net profit for Q3
summary: Straco Corp reported a flat net profit of S$21.42 million for the third quarter, with revenue rising 5.2% to S$48.49 million. Operating profit increased 0.9% to S$31.83 million, driven by higher revenues from Shanghai Ocean Aquarium and Underwater World Xiamen, but offset by staff costs and exchange losses. The company's shares closed one cent lower at 69 Singapore cents.

site_title: French fashion giant Jean Paul Gaultier goes fur-free
summary: French fashion designer Jean Paul Gaultier has announced he is going fur-free, joining a growing list of designers to ban fur from their collections. In a TV interview, Gaultier described methods used to kill animals as "absolutely deplorable" and opted for alternative materials. Animal rights groups, including PETA, hailed the decision as a sign of the times, while French fur-makers expressed disappointment. Gaultier's move follows similar announcements from brands like Armani and Versace, and is seen as a step towards a more compassionate fashion industry.

site_title: Italy's budget tussle raises debt concerns: ECB's de Guindos
summary: Italy's budget crisis is raising concerns about the sustainability of its public debt, with the European Central Bank's Vice President Luis de Guindos stating that the government's breach of EU rules is the cause of the rise in yield. The ECB will not intervene to lower borrowing costs, and the market reaction has triggered concerns about banks holding large amounts of Italian debt. De Guindos also highlighted risks from a potential US downturn and global tensions, warning that these could trigger a domino effect and spill over to euro area financial markets.

site_title: Wilmar's Q3 net profit jumps 11%
summary: Wilmar International's net profit for the third quarter jumped 11% to US$407.4 million, driven by better performance in tropical oils and oilseeds, grains, and higher affiliate results. Core net profit rose 35% to US$435 million, and revenue increased 4.3% to US$11.6 billion. The company expects its operations to continue well in the coming quarter due to better processing margins.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets jump at open
summary: European stocks jumped at the open on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 index rising 1.0% to 7,176.92 points. Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris' CAC 40 also gained 0.5% each. The rally was driven by rallying oil prices and a sliding pound, boosting exporters.

site_title: Marie Antoinette's exquisite jewels go under the hammer
summary: Marie Antoinette's exquisite jewels, including a pearl and diamond pendant valued at $1-2 million, are set to go under the hammer in Geneva, marking one of the most significant royal jewelry auctions in history. The collection, once secretly whisked away from Paris in 1791, features over 100 lots, 10 of which belonged to the ill-fated queen. The jewels have been privately owned by the Italian royal House of Bourbon-Parma and are expected to fetch millions at the sale, which also includes pieces from other European royal families.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 11.95 points to 1,696.14. Volume reached 1.633 billion lots worth RM1.321 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 452 to 294.

site_title: China Everbright Water net profit up 18% in Q3
summary: China Everbright Water posted a 18% increase in net profit to HK$144.3 million in Q3, driven by a 39% rise in revenue. Construction revenue rose HK$227.76 million, while operation revenue increased HK$54 million. Earnings per share was HK$0.054, up from HK$0.047 last year. The company's 9-month net profit rose 36% to HK$515 million, with revenue increasing 42% to HK$3.4 billion.

site_title: Diageo sells Seagram's VO to Sazerac in US$550 million deal
summary: Diageo sells its US whiskey brand Seagram's VO to Sazerac Co. for $550 million, focusing on premium labels. The deal will help Diageo develop faster-growing premium drinks in its US portfolio. The proceeds will be returned to investors through a share repurchase, generating an exceptional gain on disposal of about $110 million. The sale includes 19 brands, including Myers's rum, Popov vodka, and Yukon Jack whiskey, as the company shifts its focus to higher-end labels.

site_title: Singapore shares end lower on Monday
summary: Singapore shares closed lower on Monday, with the Straits Times Index down 9.82 points or 0.3% to 3,068.15. Losers outnumbered gainers 236 to 145, with Genting Singapore and Rex International among the most actively traded stocks. Financials like DBS, OCBC, and UOB also fell, with Singtel shares down 1.6% at S$3.05. The decline came despite a 5-day rally, as investors focus on the upcoming GDP data.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close up on Monday
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index increasing 0.12% to 25,633.18, the Shanghai Composite Index rising 1.22% to 2,630.52, and the Shenzhen Composite Index adding 2.53% to 1,361.74. The gains were seen as a cautious response to Asian markets opening the week, with US-EU trade tensions and tariff threats also in focus.

site_title: UK's Labour Party: If PM May's deal fails, we want an election
summary: The UK's Labour Party has stated that if Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit deal fails, they will push for a national election and possibly another referendum. Labour spokesman Keir Starmer said if the deal is voted down, a general election would be called, and if that doesn't happen, all options, including a public vote, would remain on the table. Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn also expressed support for another referendum, saying it's time to bring people together.

site_title: WHO maps dangerous misuse of antibiotics
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has warned that antibiotic consumption is dangerously high in some countries, while shortages in others are leading to the misuse of antibiotics, driving the emergence of deadly superbug infections. The 2015 data from 65 countries shows significant differences in consumption rates, with some countries using over 64 defined daily doses per 1,000 inhabitants per day, while others use as few as four. Overuse and misuse of antibiotics are the leading causes of antimicrobial resistance, and the WHO urges governments and big pharma to create new antibiotics to fight ultra-resistant supergerms.

site_title: First US LNG cargo since 10 per cent tariff enacted arrives in China: data
summary: The first US liquefied natural gas (LNG) cargo since a 10% tariff was imposed on US imports arrived in China on November 11, 2018. The cargo, shipped from the Sabine Pass terminal, was diverted to China's Zhejiang Ningbo LNG terminal after Chinese companies largely diverted US shipments to other countries. The shipment is now discharging, despite rising gas storage levels in North Asia and a warmer-than-expected winter.

site_title: How one family built US$8b startup far from Silicon Valley
summary: Ryan and Jared Smith, brothers and co-founders of Qualtrics International Inc., are selling their $8 billion startup to SAP SE after resisting venture capital funding for over a decade. The brothers, who started the company in their parents' basement in Utah, will retain control and run the business as an entity within SAP's cloud business group. Qualtrics' experience management approach has boosted revenue eight-fold over the past seven years, and the brothers will receive approximately $7 billion for their shares. The sale is seen as a testament to the company's ability to grow without relying on outsized funding.

site_title: CapitaLand lands bid for site in Guangzhou for 882m yuan
summary: CapitaLand secures a 75% stake in a 4.7-hectare mixed-use site in Guangzhou, China, for 882 million yuan (S$175.2 million). The site, located in Huangpu District, will be developed into a 142,107 sq m property, with 70% dedicated to investment assets and 30% to low-density strata offices. The project is slated for completion by 2022, further diversifying CapitaLand's portfolio in the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area.

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei index inches up on bargain-hunting, weak yen
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index rose 0.09% to close at 22,269.88, driven by bargain-hunting and a weak yen, as investors awaited fresh trading direction after US elections. The broader Topix index fell 0.06%. The move comes despite US President Trump's recent tariff threats, which initially sparked market volatility.

site_title: Trade war, Russia and tech: What to know as grains world meets
summary: The global grain market is facing significant challenges, including the US-China trade war, droughts, and Russia's expanding wheat dominance. The annual Global Grain conference in Geneva will focus on the winners and losers in the trade war, and how rival shippers can close the gap when Russia's exports slow. The conference will also explore the use of blockchain technology to modernize trading and crop movement, particularly in the US-China soybean market. The event is expected to discuss the impact of the trade war on prices, the potential for US farmers to switch to other crops, and the role of Ukraine in the corn-export market.

site_title: Takeda sets vote date, aims to close US$62b Shire deal on Jan 8
summary: Takeda Pharmaceutical aims to close its US$62 billion acquisition of Shire on January 8, following a vote by shareholders on December 5. The deal, the largest-ever overseas acquisition by a Japanese company, has secured approval from regulators in the US, Japan, China, and Brazil. However, some investors are concerned about the enlarged company's debt burden, with Takeda securing a US$30.9 billion bridge loan to finance the acquisition. The company is seeking two-thirds support from shareholders for the deal, which will propel Takeda into the top 10 rankings of global drugmakers by sales.

site_title: Energy stocks boost Australian shares; NZ also rises
summary: Australia's benchmark share index rose 0.3% to a three-week high, driven by energy stocks, which jumped after Saudi Arabia announced a 0.5 million barrel per day oil supply cut. Energy stocks, including Beach Energy Ltd, Whitehaven Coal Ltd, and Oil Search Ltd, rose between 1.8% and 3.3%. Metals and mining stocks also gained, while Aussie healthcare stocks climbed for a fourth straight session. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.3% to finish at a record high.

site_title: Vietnam's banking, fintech sector have strong growth potential: Moody's
summary: Vietnam's banking and fintech sectors have strong growth potential, according to Moody's. The rating agency changed its outlook on the country's banking system to "stable" from "positive" due to the sector's slow digital transformation. The banks' pace of transformation lags behind peers in the region, which have addressed issues from the 2011-2012 credit bust. Moody's notes that the sector's growth potential is driven by the need for banks to adopt digital technologies and improve transparency and corporate governance.
