summary: Battery maker GP Industries reported a 3.8% decline in Q2 net profit to S$6.9 million, due to higher distribution and finance costs, and lower other operating income. The decline was mainly attributed to a decrease in gain on disposal of property, plant, and equipment and government grant. On a per-share basis, earnings came in at 1.41 Singapore cents, down from 1.47 cents last year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks hit as trade optimism fades
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted over 2% on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index falling 2.08% to 25,934.39, amid fading trade optimism. US President Donald Trump's top economics advisor expressed skepticism about a quick resolution to the China-US trade row. The Shanghai Composite Index also declined 0.41% to 2,665.43, while the Shenzhen Composite Index remained largely unchanged. The decline was attributed to profit-taking after last week's rally and ongoing concerns over the US-China trade tensions.

site_title: Ozone layer recovering at 1-3 per cent per decade - UN
summary: The ozone layer is recovering at a rate of 1-3% per decade, reversing years of depletion caused by harmful chemicals. A UN study found long-term decreases in ozone-depleting substances and the ongoing recovery of stratospheric ozone. The Antarctic ozone hole is expected to close by the 2060s, returning to 1980 levels. However, production and emissions of CFC-11 from eastern Asia have increased, potentially delaying the recovery of mid-latitude and polar ozone-depleting chemicals by 7 and 20 years, respectively.

site_title: Iranians feeling US sanctions 'in their bones'
summary: Iranians are feeling the effects of US sanctions, which have been in place for nearly 40 years, as a daily reality. The latest round of sanctions targeting Iran's oil and financial sectors has caused economic turmoil, with many Iranians struggling to acquire basic needs. Despite the sanctions, some Iranians express defiance and anger, while others acknowledge the country's economic problems run deeper than US pressure. Many believe the government is unable to address the issue, with some calling for the resignation of the current leadership.

site_title: Prince Charles acknowledges UK role in horror of slave trade
summary: Prince Charles acknowledged the UK's role in the slave trade, calling it an "appalling atrocity" that left a "stain on the history of our world." In Ghana, where African slaves were held before being shipped across the Atlantic, Charles acknowledged the "profound injustice" and the "unimaginable suffering" caused by the slave trade. Britain abolished the trans-Atlantic slave trade in 1807, but the full abolition of slavery did not follow until another generation. Charles emphasized the need to remember the "abject horror of slavery" and ensure its legacy is never forgotten.

images.alt_text: Prince Charles acknowledged Britain's role in the slave trade on Monday calling it an appalling atrocity that had "left an indelible stain on the history of our world".

site_title: Boustead Projects' Q2 profit down on higher expenses, share loss
summary: Boustead Projects reported a net profit of S$8 million for its Q2, down 16% from S$9.5 million in the same period last year due to higher overhead expenses and share loss. Revenue rose 21% to S$60.6 million, with a higher gross profit. The company's net asset value per share was S$0.865, and its order book backlog stood at S$212 million. Managing director Thomas Chu expressed cautious optimism about capitalizing on a steady pipeline of opportunities in 2019, with plans to invest in smart and eco-sustainable building capabilities and secure strategic partnerships.

site_title: Singapore shares end lower on Monday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index closed 55.77 points lower, or 1.79%, at 3,060.62 on Monday. About 1.3 billion securities worth S$939 million changed hands, with losers outnumbering gainers 287 to 127. Capital World Ltd led the gainers, rising 1.4 cents or 32.6% to S$0.057 after 32.8 million shares traded. The market saw a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, but was weighed down by Sunpower Group and Geo Energy Resources' trading halts.

site_title: M1 CEO Karen Kooi to retire on Dec 6; replacement unveiled
summary: M1 CEO Karen Kooi will retire on Dec 6, after 9 years in the role, and will remain an adviser to the board until Feb 28, 2019. She will be replaced by Manjot Singh Mann, 53, who previously led Hutchison Telecommunications in Indonesia and Lebara Mobile in Britain. Mann has no prior experience as a director of a listed company but has embedded innovation and digital strategies into his previous operations, according to M1 chairman Danny Teoh.

site_title: Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust DPU up 0.6% in Q4
summary: Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust (FLT) reported a 0.6% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.78 Singapore cents in its fiscal fourth quarter, driven by revenue growth of 43.2% to A$60.4 million and a 52.6% rise in net property income to A$49.3 million. The Reit's portfolio occupancy was 99.6% as of September 30, with a weighted average lease expiry of 6.87 years. FLT's full-year DPU rose 2.6% to 7.19 Singapore cents, with distributable income increasing 16.6% to A$118.3 million.

site_title: China Sunsine net profit up 85% in Q3
summary: China Sunsine Chemical Holdings posted a net profit of RMB 143.4 million (S$28.6 million) in Q3, up 85% from the same period last year, driven by a 22% revenue increase. The company attributed the rise in revenue to higher sales volume and average selling price. Despite a decline in ASP, the group maintained a good profit margin level due to its core competences and investments in environmental protection and safety. China Sunsine remains cautiously optimistic about its performance in the next 12 months.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore retained its 2018 growth forecast of 2.5-3.5% despite trade war risks. DBS lowered its mortgage loan growth forecast to S$2.5 billion. MAS and Bank Indonesia established a US$10 billion bilateral financial arrangement. Great Eastern is discussing contributing RM2 billion to Malaysia's new health insurance plan. The Singapore Exchange signed MOUs with two industry bodies to strengthen partnerships in China. The Straits Times Index closed 1.79% lower on Monday, ending at 3,060.62.

site_title: Japan's Subaru recalls more cars, slashes guidance as cheating issue widens
summary: Subaru recalls 100,000 vehicles in Japan due to inspection cheating, including its popular Impreza sedan. The company expects to incur 6.5 billion yen in costs, pushing its operating profit to 220 billion yen in the year to March 2019. This is a significant drop from its previous forecast of 300 billion yen. Subaru's shares fell 5% to a four-year low, citing a series of recalls and quality-linked issues. The company has struggled with compliance at its plants, and shares have shed almost 20% this year.

site_title: AngloGold Asset Streamlining to Start With Mali Mine Sale
summary: AngloGold Ashanti Ltd. is considering selling its Sadiola mine in Mali as part of a plan to streamline its assets and focus on high-quality, core mines. The company, the world's third-largest gold producer, aims to sell non-core assets to reduce costs and concentrate on mines with "critical mass and good geology". AngloGold has already secured a new credit facility and reduced its net debt, and has no plans to exit its Mponeng mine in South Africa, which has a remaining exploitable deposit until 2036.

site_title: Australian regulators call for more powers to police retirement funds sector
summary: Australian financial regulators, APRA and ASIC, have called for increased powers to police the retirement funds sector, citing widespread misconduct such as fee gouging and breaching best interests. The regulators rejected criticism of their actions, but acknowledged the need for improvements. They proposed strengthening APRA's powers and introducing more regulatory intervention to manage conflicts of interest in vertically integrated firms, which could impact major lenders and retirement savings managers. A government-mandated inquiry is expected to recommend far-reaching reforms to address these issues.

site_title: China's Sinopec, CNPC speed up oil, gas drilling to boost output
summary: China's state-owned oil and gas companies, Sinopec and CNPC, are accelerating drilling and exploration in western regions to boost domestic output. The companies aim to increase production from major tight and shale oil and gas formations. Despite having large domestic reserves, China remains the world's largest importer of crude oil. Sinopec plans to tap 66 new natural gas wells and install 23 gas drilling stations, while CNPC's drilling cycle at the Mahu field in Xinjiang has decreased by 40% from last year. This move is part of a government call to safeguard China's energy security.

site_title: China services sector grows at slowest pace in 13 months as orders dry up: poll
summary: China's services sector experienced its slowest growth in 13 months in October, with new orders drying up and business confidence at a three-month low. The Caixin/Markit services purchasing managers' index (PMI) fell to 50.8, the lowest since September 2017. The slowdown is concerning for policymakers, who are trying to offset rising pressure on exports from the US trade row and manufacturing slowdown at home. China's economic growth is expected to slow further, with the nation's financial services sector particularly hard-hit.

site_title: Asean firms bullish on outlook despite trade war: HSBC report
summary: Southeast Asian firms have the most bullish trade outlook in the world, despite expecting protectionism to rise, according to a HSBC report. 86% of Asean firms are positive about foreign trade prospects, with 3/4 believing governments are becoming more protectionist. The US-China trade war may indirectly impact the Asean bloc, but tariffs could create opportunities in electronics, textiles, and automobiles, with countries like Thailand and Malaysia potentially shifting assembly.

site_title: UK meat retailer Crawshaw appoints EY execs as administrators
summary: UK meat retailer Crawshaw Group has appointed Ernst & Young LLP executives as joint administrators due to insufficient cash for restructuring. The company has closed 35 stores, cut 354 jobs, and will continue to operate 19 stores. Administration offers creditor protection, with the administrators aiming to sell the business and assets. This move follows a decline in shares by 80% this year and a significant drop in like-for-like sales, attributed to competition from online shopping and Brexit-induced cost increases.

site_title: Liane Moriarty's Hollywood angst: it's complicated
summary: Australian author Liane Moriarty has achieved significant success in Hollywood after her novel "Big Little Lies" debuted at No. 1 on The New York Times best-seller list. Her latest novel, "Nine Perfect Strangers," has catapulted her to stratospheric fame, with a TV series adaptation starring Nicole Kidman. Moriarty, 51, has found it challenging to navigate the Hollywood experience, feeling like an outsider. Despite this, she has gained confidence from readers who have praised her work, allowing her to take pride in her writing. Moriarty's success has also led to her speaking publicly about her experiences and advocating for gender equality.

site_title: Golden memories? Graf 'rarely looks back' at Grand Slam
summary: Steffi Graf, a 1988 Golden Slam winner, says she rarely looks back at her record-breaking tennis career. Despite Serena Williams continuing her quest to match Graf's all-time record for Grand Slam singles titles, Graf is unconcerned about whether her records are matched or broken. Graf attributes her focus on her life after tennis, including her marriage and retirement, for her lack of concern about records. Graf believes Williams has the determination and talent to achieve the record, but Graf herself is prioritizing her life over tennis achievements.

site_title: Europe: Stocks open steady
summary: European equities remained steady at the open, with the Stoxx Europe 600 Index down 0.1%. Optimism over a possible US-China trade pact began to fade, with BHP Billiton and Ashtead Group declining 0.7% and 3.5%, respectively. Investors weigh corporate earnings and prepare for the Fed policy meeting and US midterm elections, citing concerns about an economic slowdown.

images.alt_text: European equities were little changed at the open and industrials fell as the optimism from a possible trade pact began to dissipate.

site_title: Export orders to US at China's Canton Fair down by one-third
summary: Export orders to the US at China's Canton Fair dropped 30.3% from a year earlier, with overall deals falling 1% to 206.5 billion yuan. Orders to Australia and Canada fell 8.9% and 7.3%, respectively. However, outbound orders to Japan, Asean countries, BRICS, and South Korea rose, with Japan seeing a 74.4% increase. Exhibitors expressed pessimism about export outlook due to rising costs and trade friction with the US.

site_title: Australia extends 'backpacker visas' to ease farm worker shortage
summary: Australia has extended its "backpacker visas" to allow young travelers to stay longer in the country to address a farm labor shortage. The change allows travelers to remain in Australia for up to three years if they spend at least six months doing agricultural work. This move aims to alleviate labor shortages, particularly in rural Queensland, and follows a broader effort to curb immigration. The extension affects travelers who have previously held one-year "Working Holiday Maker" visas, which can now be extended to a third year under the new rules.

site_title: Sri Lanka crisis scares tourists in fresh hit to economy
summary: Sri Lanka's political crisis, sparked by a dispute between two prime ministers, is deterring tourists and threatening the economy. The crisis has led to cancellations of hotel bookings, with deluxe hotels reporting a significant decline in new bookings over the past 10 days. The tourism industry is a cornerstone of the economy, generating $3.2 billion in revenue last year, and a prolonged crisis could undermine foreign investor confidence and make it challenging for the government to pay its debts. The crisis has also raised doubts over foreign aid and a $1.5 billion Japanese-funded light rail project.

site_title: UAE amps up oil and gas output as Iran sanctions hit
summary: The UAE has announced the discovery of new oil and gas resources, aiming for full self-sufficiency as US sanctions on Iran take effect. ADNOC, the state-run oil company, has discovered 15 trillion cubic feet of gas and 1 billion barrels of oil, with plans to boost output to 4 million barrels per day by 2020 and 5 million barrels per day by 2030. The UAE, OPEC's fourth-largest producer, currently produces 3.5 million barrels per day, and the move is seen as a response to the US sanctions targeting Iranian oil buyers.

site_title: PODCAST: Is it worth enjoying higher interest rates with OCBC 360 and UOB One following latest tweaks? (Money Hacks, Ep 25)
summary: Local banks OCBC and UOB introduced higher bonus interest rates for their customers. OCBC's 360 account offers up to 3.2% interest on the first $70,000, while UOB One customers can earn up to 2.44% interest on the first $75,000 with specific spending and salary criteria. DBS Bank's Multiplier account also offers up to 3.5% interest on the first $50,000 with salary and transaction requirements. These moves aim to encourage customers to save more with the latest tweaks.

site_title: Booksellers hit Amazon with strike
summary: More than 250 antiquarian book dealers in 24 countries are pulling 1 million books off an Amazon-owned site, AbeBooks, for a week in protest against the site's ban on sellers from several nations, including South Korea, Hungary, and Russia. The impromptu strike, called Banned Booksellers Week, is a rare action against Amazon, which relies on third-party sellers for its merchandise and revenue. The protest follows emails sent by AbeBooks to affected sellers in October, stating it would no longer "support" them.

site_title: Fee for EU citizens staying in UK puts slavery survivors at risk - campaigners
summary: Britain's proposed fee for EU citizens staying in the UK after Brexit could put slavery survivors at risk of being trafficked again. The Home Office plans to charge around £65 for adults and £33 for children. However, immigration minister Caroline Nokes stated that survivors of modern slavery would not be exempt unless they are in local authority care. Campaigners warn that this could lead to a return of trafficking. The UK is set to leave the EU in March 2019.

site_title: Barclays fares worst in Europe bank stress tests as Brexit looms
summary: Barclays, the UK's largest bank, performed the worst in Europe's stress test, with a key measure of financial health falling sharply in the most adverse scenario, highlighting the vulnerability of UK lenders to weak growth, credit losses, and Brexit. Fellow British lender Lloyds Banking Group also underperformed, with German lenders such as Deutsche Bank and Italian counterparts performing better. The test assumes years of negative economic growth, weak bank profitability, and a rise in government bond yields, underscoring the need for banks to add capital and adjust shareholder payouts.

site_title: Polluted Delhi air akin to death sentence, say doctors
summary: Delhi's air pollution reached emergency levels, exceeding 35 times the World Health Organization's safe limit, with PM2.5 levels soaring to 908 in the Anand Vihar suburb. Doctors warn that the polluted air is akin to a "death sentence" for patients, particularly children and those with respiratory ailments. Exposure to toxic air kills hundreds of thousands of children annually, and Delhi's smog has devastating effects on children's health, with one child's first breath equivalent to smoking 20-25 cigarettes. Despite repeated emergencies, official efforts to combat pollution remain ineffective, with state governments refusing to address the root causes of the crisis.

site_title: Aussie airline aborts veterans-first boarding plan before takeoff
summary: Virgin Australia scrapped its plan to allow military veterans to board flights first, following widespread criticism as "tokenism." Prominent figures, including politicians and veterans, denounced the idea, calling it "embarrassing" and "faux-American bollocks." Virgin CEO John Borghetti cited the response and vowed to consult with community groups to determine a better way to honor veterans. Critics argued that the gesture would have been more meaningful if it focused on supporting those less fortunate, rather than just recognizing military service.

site_title: China to create stock venue in Shanghai for high-tech companies
summary: China is set to establish a new trading venue in Shanghai, aimed at facilitating funding for high-tech companies. The Shanghai Stock Exchange will also launch a pilot program for a registration-based system of initial public offerings. The move is part of China's efforts to keep promising companies from going public in Hong Kong or the US. The new market, which may have lower thresholds and waived requirements, could open as early as next year, according to officials. This expansion is part of President Xi Jinping's push to boost China's economy.

site_title: SoftBank's Saudi ties in focus as CEO Son makes first appearance since journalist murder
summary: Japan's SoftBank Group Corp CEO Masayoshi Son will face questions about his company's reliance on Saudi Arabia, following the murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi. Son will present earnings results and address concerns over SoftBank's telecoms business ahead of its massive IPO. Despite Saudi Arabia's significant investment in SoftBank's Vision Fund, the company's ties to the kingdom are seen as a risk amid global outrage. SoftBank's shares have fallen 30% in recent weeks due to concerns over the IPO and broader market downturn.

site_title: Capital World signs MOU for capital injection from Bursa-listed firm
summary: Capital World, an integrated property developer, signed a non-binding MOU with PRG Holdings, a Bursa-listed investment holding company, to inject capital into the company. PRG will subscribe for new shares, potentially holding up to 29.9% of Capital World's enlarged issued share capital. The investment terms are subject to further negotiations and regulatory approvals. The deal aims to generate business synergies between the parties.

site_title: SingPost to offer more parcel delivery options with new logistics platform
summary: SingPost launches a new regional logistics platform, integrating partner courier services, parcel lockers, and collection points across South-east Asia, offering consumers more delivery options and the ability to reroute packages. The platform, called the Last Mile Platform, will allow retailers to offer customers the option to receive purchases through any delivery node in the network. Discussions with retail and logistics partners are at an advanced stage, with no launch date announced.

site_title: SGX to ink MOUs with two industry bodies to strengthen partnerships in China
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) will sign memoranda of understanding (MOUs) with the Zhejiang (S) Entrepreneurs Association and the China Futures Association to strengthen partnerships in China. The MOUs aim to foster collaboration in developing Singapore capital market opportunities for Chinese companies and promote financial market education and research. This move follows a 10th anniversary of the SGX's Beijing Representative Office and highlights the exchange's commitment to facilitating Chinese companies' international expansion.

site_title: MAS, Bank Indonesia set up US$10b bilateral financial arrangement
summary: MAS and Bank Indonesia have established a $10 billion bilateral financial arrangement, allowing the two central banks to access foreign currency liquidity from each other to preserve monetary and financial stability. The arrangement, signed by BI governor Perry Warjiyo and MAS managing director Ravi Menon, includes a new local currency bilateral swap agreement and an enhanced bilateral repo agreement. The move aims to instil confidence in investors and reflects the strengthened bilateral monetary and financial cooperation between Singapore and Indonesia. The arrangement will be in place for one year.

site_title: Australian shares pulled lower by healthcare, energy; NZ falls
summary: Australian shares fell 0.5% to 5818.1, weighed down by healthcare and energy stocks, while New Zealand shares dropped 0.6% to 8778.78. Healthcare stocks declined 2.2% due to a stronger Australian dollar, with Cochlear falling 3.8% after a patent infringement lawsuit award. Energy stocks fell for the third session, driven by lower oil prices. Financial stocks recovered slightly, with Australia and New Zealand Banking Group and Westpac Banking Corp ending 0.2% and 0.6% higher, respectively.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall on trade war concerns, Fed rate hike fears
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index fell nearly 1% on Monday due to concerns over the Sino-US trade war and potential US Federal Reserve rate hikes. The US job growth rebounded sharply in October, indicating further labour market tightening, which could prompt interest rate increases in December. The White House's top economic adviser stated that a trade deal between the US and China is unlikely, adding to market uncertainty. The won fell, while bond yields edged higher, as investors became risk-averse.

site_title: Indonesia's Q3 GDP growth slows as exports fade
summary: Indonesia's economic growth slowed in Q3 to 5.17% from a year earlier, missing expectations of 5.15%. The country's export contribution to GDP was negatively impacted by imports, and household consumption weakened. The slowdown is attributed to global challenges, including a trade war between the US and China. Indonesia's central bank has raised interest rates to slow capital outflows, but higher borrowing costs may slow medium-term consumption. The government's official growth target for 2018 is 5.4%, but it now seems more likely to be 5.14%.

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei index down more than 1.5%
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index fell 1.55% on Monday, closing at 21,898.99, amid profit-taking and caution ahead of US mid-term elections. The index had surged 5.0% last week following positive US-China trade talks. Investors also remained cautious about corporate earnings reports and worsening business confidence indicators. Trading was thin, and the dollar fetched 113.27 yen in Asian trade.

site_title: Sri Lanka speaker won't accept Rajapaksa as PM until he proves a majority
summary: Sri Lanka's speaker of parliament has refused to accept former president Mahinda Rajapaksa as prime minister until he proves he commands a majority in parliament. President Maithripala Sirisena appointed Rajapaksa after firing sitting Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe, sparking a political crisis. Wickremesinghe has vowed to remain prime minister until parliament votes him out, denouncing his dismissal as unconstitutional.

site_title: Chinese chipmaker's ambitions hit hurdle with US indictment
summary: Chinese state-backed semiconductor maker Fujian Jinhua Integrated Circuit Co Ltd, touted as a national leader in the tech industry, has hit a hurdle with a US indictment. The company aimed to drive local chip production and reduce reliance on US imports. However, the indictment, which is not specified in the article, has halted its ambitions. The company had previously highlighted its high-skilled global workforce and local production, but the US indictment now casts a shadow over its plans for a self-sufficient chip industry.

site_title: Japan invests in service industry, reshaping its legendary hospitality
summary: Japan is shifting its focus to the services sector, driven by a shrinking workforce and labor shortages. The country is investing heavily in automation, with self-checkout systems and software being implemented in various industries, including retail and transportation. This move is expected to increase productivity but may erode Japan's legendary hospitality, known as omotenashi, which prioritizes face-to-face interaction with customers. Companies are finding ways to balance efficiency with human touch, with some arguing that machines can help maintain customer service standards.

site_title: Kuroda concedes BOJ's easy policy hurting banks, but rules out rate hike
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that the central bank will maintain its easy policy, focusing on addressing the fallout of prolonged ultra-low rates on financial institutions. He ruled out a near-term interest rate hike, citing the need to keep monetary conditions loose to stimulate the economy without destabilizing the banking system. Kuroda emphasized the importance of making the BOJ's stimulus programme sustainable, and dismissed the possibility of deploying another huge stimulus programme if the economy deteriorates.

site_title: Australia's ANZ cuts top officials' pay by 20% amid inquiry panel scrutiny
summary: Australia and New Zealand Banking Group (ANZ) has cut top officials' pay by 20% amid scrutiny from a financial sector inquiry. The bank's non-executive directors and chairman will see their base fees reduced for fiscal 2019. This move comes after a royal commission found widespread wrongdoing by Australia's major banks, leading to a weaker retail banking environment. ANZ's shares rose 1.3% following the announcement, outperforming the benchmark. The bank had previously reduced staff variable pay by A$124 million in 2018, but left CEO remuneration unchanged.

site_title: Xi pledges to 'step up' opening China's markets as criticism grows
summary: President Xi Jinping pledged to "step up" efforts to open China's markets, aiming to stimulate domestic consumption of imports and lower tariffs. He also vowed to ease customs clearance procedures and implement harsh punishments for intellectual property infringements. The move comes amid growing foreign criticism of China's alleged backtracking on reform pledges. Xi's address at the import fair in Shanghai aims to foster a world-class business environment, but the initiative is seen as a response to US trade tensions and growing concerns over China's economic practices.

site_title: Malaysia shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 4.80 points to 1,718.67 on Monday, with gains beating losses 136 to 64. Volume reached 92.17 million lots worth RM85.31 million.

site_title: Emirates seeks Rolls-Royce A380 engine deal, nothing finalised
summary: Emirates is nearing a deal with Rolls-Royce to power its A380 superjumbos, but a final agreement has not been reached. The airline is seeking a lifeline order for up to 36 aircraft, despite previous reports of a deal being finalized. Emirates is reportedly unhappy with the performance of Rolls-Royce Trent 900 engines, which have led to penalties. The deal comes as Rolls-Royce faces delays and reliability issues with its 787 and A330neo engines, and engine manufacturer Engine Alliance shows little interest in reviving output for Emirates' A380 fleet.

site_title: Remixpoint to start crypto payments for Tokyo Limousines, say sources
summary: Remixpoint Inc is launching a trial service allowing passengers to pay for Tokyo Limousines rides with Bitcoin, Bitcoin Cash, and Ethereum. The service, starting this month, will cover rides between Tokyo's 23 wards and either Haneda or Narita airports. Remixpoint, which operates BITPoint, a licensed cryptocurrency exchange, aims to move cryptocurrencies beyond financial speculation and into commerce. If successful, the service may be expanded to regular taxi rides.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks open with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index sinking 1.65% to 26,050.34. The decline was attributed to dashed hopes for a China-US trade deal, following comments from Donald Trump's economics adviser. The Shanghai Composite Index also fell 0.41%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index declined 0.27%. The losses followed a rally at the end of last week.

site_title: DBS chief flags steeper drop in mortgage loans growth this year
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest mortgage provider, has revised its mortgage loan growth forecast for 2018, now expecting new mortgage bookings to end at S$2.5 billion, down S$1.5 billion from its previous estimate. The bank now anticipates mid-single-digit loan growth for the year, with stable asset quality but moderate deterioration in SME portfolios due to rising interest rates. DBS expects a 12.2-12.3% return-on-equity (ROE) this year and 13% next year.

site_title: Australia's property slump casts doubt on household spending
summary: Australia's falling house prices are raising concerns about household spending, with retail sales growth sharply declining in the third quarter. As home values increase, households prioritize saving over spending, but when prices drop, saving becomes the priority. The Reserve Bank of Australia is set to keep the cash rate unchanged at a record-low 1.5% due to record household debt and stagnant incomes, making it difficult to absorb higher borrowing costs. This uncertainty has Governor Philip Lowe warning about consumption and highlights the potential risks to the economy.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Monday; STI falls 0.9% to 3,087.96
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.9% to 3,087.96 on Monday, with the Straits Times Index down 28.43 points. About 58 million shares changed hands, with losers outnumbering gainers 103 to 50. DBS, OCBC, and UOB shares were down 1.4%, 0.4%, and 1.3% respectively, following the bank's 76% increase in net profit.

site_title: Britain's freezing renters to get relief at landlords' expense
summary: Britain's energy-efficient home requirements for landlords will take effect next year, affecting around 290,000 properties. Landlords of F or G-rated homes must upgrade to at least E-rated properties, which may cost them approximately 1,200 pounds per property. The upgrades are expected to save tenants 180 pounds per year, while also reducing carbon emissions and potentially increasing property values.

site_title: Hong Kong housing may be headed for a correction
summary: Hong Kong's housing market may be headed for a correction, with signs of a downturn spreading after the city's first interest-rate increases in 12 years and escalating trade tensions. Home prices have fallen 13% during previous downturns, compared to a 3% decline this time around. Mortgage applications plummeted 56% in September, luxury sales dropped, and agents are taking a holiday. Price cuts are also common, with some properties selling for 17-28% less than their original asking price. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is assessing the market, but experts warn of a potential downward cycle.

site_title: Polluted Delhi air akin to death sentence, say doctors
summary: Doctors in New Delhi describe the city's air as akin to a "death sentence" due to high pollution levels, killing over one million Indians annually. Delhi's air is the worst among major cities globally, according to the World Health Organization. Every November, hospitals fill with patients struggling to breathe amidst a grey haze, affecting the city's 20 million residents. The pollution has severe consequences, as seen in the case of Yogesh Kumar, who underwent life-saving surgery to remove a diseased lung after being exposed to the polluted air.

site_title: ComfortDelGro buying Australia's Buslink for A$191m in its largest acquisition Down Under
summary: ComfortDelGro, a Singaporean company, is acquiring Australia's Buslink for A$190.9 million, its largest acquisition in Australia. The deal provides immediate access to the Northern Territory and Queensland, and enables the company to grow its existing bus operations. ComfortDelGro will operate in six states, with a fleet of over 4,200 vehicles. The acquisition is part of the company's strategy to expand into new avenues of growth and leverage technology and artificial intelligence.

site_title: Kuroda says aware BOJ's easy policy hurting banks, warns of global risks
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that the central bank is aware of the potential risks of prolonged ultra-loose monetary policy on financial institutions and the country's banking system. Despite subdued inflation, Kuroda emphasized the need to maintain the massive stimulus program while monitoring its effects. He warned of global risks, including Sino-US trade frictions and rising protectionism, which could impact Japan's economy. Kuroda urged financial institutions to take action as necessary to mitigate risks, while the BOJ will scrutinize developments and consider adjusting its policy framework if needed.

site_title: Israel announces new oil and gas exploration round in eastern Med
summary: Israel's energy ministry announced a new oil and gas exploration round in the eastern Mediterranean, tendering 19 blocks to companies. The move aims to boost the country's energy sector, following a disappointing bidding round last year. Conditions in the global energy market have improved, with companies more willing to invest. The exploration licenses will be for three years, with options to extend up to four more years, and will benefit from more comprehensive geological studies. This is Israel's fifth oil and gas exploration round since discovering large reserves off its Mediterranean coast in 2009.

site_title: Asia: Stocks slump on trade concerns; pound jumps
summary: Asian stocks fell on Monday due to concerns over trade tensions with China, with the pound jumping on news of progress in Brexit negotiations. Japan's Topix index dropped 0.6%, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index fell 1.7%. US equity-index futures lost 0.2% amid tempered optimism on a trade breakthrough. The yuan pared losses after China announced further tariff cuts, while the pound strengthened to US$1.2988. Investors await the US midterm elections and Brexit developments.

site_title: Federal International (2000) warns of Q3 loss
summary: Federal International (2000) reported a net loss in Q3 due to weak demand in the oil and gas sector, resulting in lower sales from its trading business segment. The company expects to release its earnings results by November 14. Its shares closed down 2% at S$0.24 on Friday.

site_title: KTL Global plans S$940,000 share placement with Hong Kong's Changsheng Investment Development
summary: KTL Global Limited plans to issue S$940,000 worth of new shares to Changsheng Investment Development Limited at S$0.02 apiece, representing 14.89% of the company's enlarged share capital. The estimated net proceeds of S$885,000 will be used for business expansion, investments, and working capital. The new shares are issued pursuant to the general mandate given by the shareholders at the 2017 annual general meeting.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday afternoon at 3,058.13, down 1.9% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Monday afternoon at 3,058.13, down 1.9% from the previous day. The Straits Times Index dropped 58.26 points, with about 973 million shares changing hands. Losers outnumbered gainers 243 to 100, while Jiutian Chemical was the most actively traded stock, rising 0.001 to 0.025.

site_title: Hot stock: Venture shares down 10% after posting 27.5% fall in Q3 profit
summary: Venture Corp, a Singapore-listed electronics manufacturing services provider, saw its shares decline 9.9% in early trading after posting a 27.5% fall in Q3 profit to S$80.8 million. Revenue also fell 27.4% to S$770.4 million due to customer transitions to new products and M&A activities. Analysts, including RHB Research Institute and DBS Group Research, maintained "buy" calls on the stock, citing a potential V-shaped recovery in Q4 and new customer acquisitions.

site_title: Great Eastern says RM2b contribution to Malaysia's new health insurance plan among options still being discussed
summary: Great Eastern Holdings (GEH) is in discussions with Malaysian authorities to enable its unit, Great Eastern Life Assurance (Malaysia) Berhad (GELM), to meet foreign ownership requirements in Malaysia. Options include a contribution to a special insurance development trust fund, potentially in the form of a B40 Health Protection Fund. GEH believes the contribution, initially reported as RM2 billion, will not significantly impact earnings. The Malaysian government may be reviewing the foreign ownership rule to roll back previous reforms.

site_title: The Rhine, a lifeline of Germany, is crippled by drought
summary: The Rhine River, a vital lifeline for Germany's commerce, is facing severe drought, with record-low water levels causing disruptions to shipping and freight transport. The Rhine's water level has dropped to just 10 inches, forcing ships to reduce cargo or stop navigating the river altogether. The drought, exacerbated by climate change, has resulted in significant losses for farmers, with estimated losses of several billion dollars. The German chemical giant BASF has also been affected, decreasing production due to low water levels. The situation is expected to worsen, with experts warning that low water events will become more frequent and the Rhine fleet will become bigger and heavier.

site_title: Trump, Democrats in frenzied final push ahead of US elections
summary: US President Donald Trump and his Democratic rivals made final pushes ahead of the contentious midterm elections, with voter turnout seen as key. Trump campaigned for Republican candidates, while former President Barack Obama appealed to an endangered Senate Democrat in Indiana. Democrats are favored to win control of the House, but face a tough Senate battle. The economy has favored the incumbent, but Trump's divisive presidency has driven both supporters and foes to high levels of emotion.

site_title: Manulife US Reit DPU up 33.6% to 1.51 US cents for Q3
summary: MANULIFE US Reit reported a 33.6% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.51 US cents for Q3, up from 1.13 US cents in the previous year. Q3 income available for distribution jumped 64.9% to US$19.3 million, while gross revenue rose 75.3% to US$40.4 million.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday, extending losses on Wall Street ahead of US mid-term elections. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 1.25% to 21,966.40, and the Topix index fell 0.97% to 1,642.59. Investors took profits as the US mid-term elections approach, with US-EU trade talks also in focus.

site_title: Singapore-based digital wealth startup WeInvest expands to UAE
summary: Singapore-based digital wealth startup WeInvest is expanding into the UAE, with its office located in the Dubai International Financial Centre. The expansion follows WeInvest's previous entries into Hong Kong, Indonesia, Malaysia, and Thailand. The company aims to serve the Middle East market, where wealth penetration is low, and is looking to collaborate with top financial institutions in the region. WeInvest's co-founder, Bhaskar Prabhakara, notes that the UAE presents a timely opportunity for business growth, following the region's recent digital revolution.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, Venture Corp, Great Eastern, Manulife US Reit, Chip Eng Seng, Pacc Offshore Services
summary: DBS Group Holdings reported a 76% increase in third-quarter net profit to S$1.41 billion, while Venture Corporation's net profit fell 27.5% to S$80.8 million. Great Eastern Holdings is in discussions with Malaysian authorities to satisfy foreign ownership requirements for its insurance unit. Manulife US Reit's distribution per unit expanded 33.6% to 1.51 US cents, and Chip Eng Seng Corporation's net profit rose 8% to S$14.28 million. PACC Offshore Services Holdings posted a net loss of US$5.3 million, while Challenger Technologies reported a 44% increase in net profit to S$4.5 million.

site_title: Italy storms kill at least 30
summary: Italy's recent storms have claimed at least 30 lives, with 12 reported in the island of Sicily, including nine from a single family. The floods, coupled with violent winds and strong rain, have caused widespread destruction, including the destruction of 100,000 hectares of pine forest. Italian authorities are investigating whether homes built near rivers complied with safety norms. The country's civil protection agency has described the weather as "one of the most complex meteorological situations of the past 50 to 60 years."

site_title: Khashoggi probe will exonerate leader: Saudi Prince Alwaleed
summary: Saudi Arabian billionaire Prince Alwaleed bin Talal claims an official investigation into Jamal Khashoggi's death will exonerate Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman. Khashoggi, a Washington Post columnist critical of the Saudi government, was killed after entering the Saudi consulate in Istanbul in October. Prince Alwaleed, who was detained last year, said his detention was "forgiven and forgotten" and that the crown prince will be "100% vindicated." The prince urged Saudi Arabia to release the investigation findings, which he believes will clear the crown prince's name.

site_title: Singapore assessing 2019 forecasts as trade war risks loom: Heng Swee Keat
summary: Singapore's finance minister, Heng Swee Keat, has expressed concerns over the country's economic growth projections for next year due to the ongoing trade war between the US and China. Despite retaining its 2.5-3.5% growth forecast for this year, Heng warned that any trade tension affecting globalisation will have far-reaching consequences for all economies, including Singapore's. He emphasized the need for the country to review its forecasts as uncertainty increases.

site_title: Australia's Westpac FY profit flat as legal costs, refunds mount
summary: Westpac Banking Corp reported flat cash earnings for the year ended Sept 30, missing expectations, due to increased customer refunds and legal costs. The bank's cash earnings came in at A$8.07 billion, lower than the A$8.18 billion average estimate from six analysts. Westpac had previously flagged a A$235 million reduction in annual cash earnings due to provisions for customer refunds and litigation. The bank's net interest income rose 4% to A$16.34 billion, while net interest margin increased 2 basis points to 2.11%.

site_title: One dead in plane crash near Ottawa
summary: A small passenger plane crashed into a field near Ottawa, Ontario, killing one person. The incident occurred early Sunday around 30km west of Ottawa, with the pilot of the Cessna aircraft, who was flying alone, pronounced dead at the scene. The second plane, a turboprop Piper PA-42, was rerouted to Ottawa's international airport and landed safely, with neither the pilot nor his one passenger injured. The incident is under investigation, with police still unknown of the exact circumstances of the accident.

site_title: Indonesia extends search for jet crash victims, 2nd black box
summary: Indonesian authorities have extended the search for victims and a black box from the Lion Air passenger jet crash by three days, citing the need to recover more remains and the cockpit voice recorder. As of Sunday, 105 body bags had been recovered, with 14 victims identified, and 69 hours of flight data recorder data have been downloaded. The second black box is believed to be around 50 meters from the main search area, with divers homing in on ping signals. The investigation into the crash of the Boeing 737 MAX is ongoing, with preliminary findings expected within 30 days.

site_title: Pompeo says he will meet North Korea's number two in New York
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo announced a meeting with North Korea's number two, Kim Yong Chol, in New York to discuss denuclearization and a potential second summit between US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. Pompeo expressed confidence in making progress, despite North Korea's warning that it will revive its nuclear program unless US sanctions are lifted. The meeting comes just days before US midterm elections and amid ongoing tensions between the two nations.

site_title: South African minister in leaked sex video rejects calls to quit
summary: South African Home Affairs Minister Malusi Gigaba has refused to resign following a leaked private sex video and allegations of lying under oath. The country's ombudswoman has recommended disciplinary action against Gigaba for "telling an untruth under oath and before a court of law." Gigaba claims the video was leaked to embarrass him and the African National Congress, and he will meet President Cyril Ramaphosa to discuss the matter. The minister's defiance has sparked controversy, with many calling for his resignation.

site_title: Indonesia investigates Lion Air after first Boeing Max crash
summary: Indonesian authorities are conducting a special audit of Lion Air, following the crash of a Boeing 737 Max 8 jet into the Java Sea on October 29, resulting in the loss of 189 lives. The review will examine standard operating procedures, flight crew qualifications, and coordination with industry stakeholders. The investigation comes after President Joko Widodo emphasized passenger safety, and corrective steps will be taken based on the review. The audit is being coordinated with international organizations such as the European Union and the International Civil Aviation Organization.

site_title: Global smartphone sales down for fourth straight quarter
summary: Global smartphone sales declined by 6% in the third quarter, with 355 million handsets delivered, marking a fourth consecutive quarter of decline. The market is considered in a recession, with factors including carrier subsidies, replacement rates, and a lack of innovative design contributing to the slump. Despite this, research firms IDC and Strategy Analytics predict the market will recover in 2019, driven by the introduction of 5G devices and a large refresh cycle of existing devices.

site_title: World leaders to mark WWI in France amid warnings about nationalism
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron is commemorating the 100th anniversary of the end of World War I in France, with around 70 world leaders expected to attend a ceremony at the Arc de Triomphe in Paris. Macron is using the event to issue a warning against nationalism, citing its spread globally, while also visiting war-hit areas in northern and eastern France. The commemorations come as Macron seeks to position himself as a champion of centrist politics and multilateralism ahead of European parliamentary elections in May.

site_title: Money FM podcast: The Hot Seat: October Market Wrap: David Kuo, CEO, the Motley Fool Singapore
summary: David Kuo, CEO of the Motley Fool Singapore, shares his October market wrap, highlighting key winners and losers on the STI. Notable events include a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks ahead of GDP data and US stocks edging down from records amid tariff threats. Key losers include banks and healthcare companies in Europe, while mining and healthcare shares were boosted. Overall, Kuo notes that the market is cautiously optimistic despite uncertainty over US-EU trade talks.

site_title: DBS Q3 profit up 76% on higher loan income, lower allowances
summary: DBS Group Holdings reported a 76% increase in third-quarter net profit to S$1.41 billion, driven by higher loan income and lower allowances for losses. This missed market forecasts by 2.1%, but was the last of Singapore's Big Three banks to report results. Allowances for credits and other losses fell 71% to S$236 million. DBS shares traded down 2.6% to S$24.03.

site_title: Trump's trade war edgy for Republicans in US midterm elections
summary: US President Donald Trump's trade war with China has created a rift among Republicans in the country's midterm elections. Nationwide polls show a majority of Americans oppose the tariffs, fearing they will hurt consumers and jobs. In Iowa, a key battleground state, two-thirds of voters think tariffs have hurt the economy, and 70% of independent voters oppose them, giving Democrats an advantage. The tariffs have also affected agricultural states, with losses projected to reach $1 to $2 billion and 7,000 to 12,300 jobs.

site_title: IPO activity disappoints in 2018 as big plans get iced
summary: IPO activity in Singapore is expected to be its worst year since 2015, with 13 companies raising S$715 million in gross proceeds from initial public offerings this year. Despite a blockbuster 2017, the market has been sluggish due to factors such as the US-China trade war and market volatility. Analysts predict a better outlook for 2019, but deal sizes are shrinking, and local issue managers are giving more attention to smaller companies. Several companies, including Reebonz and KBS Realty Advisors, have pushed their IPO timelines to 2019.

site_title: Skin cancer deaths rates soar, mostly for men: study
summary: Men's skin cancer death rates have soared in wealthy nations since 1985, with mortality rates among women rising more slowly or even declining in some countries. Men are less likely to protect themselves from the sun, and more than 90% of melanoma cancers are caused by UV radiation. In 8 of 18 countries examined, men's skin cancer death rates increased by at least 50% over three decades. The nations with the biggest rise in skin cancer deaths were not necessarily those with the highest mortality rates, highlighting the need for public health awareness campaigns.

site_title: Data leak affects thousands of wealthy Moscow residents
summary: Thousands of wealthy Moscow residents who subscribed to Akado Telecom have had their personal data, including names, home addresses, and mobile numbers, leaked online. The data was uploaded to the RIPE NCC database by Akado Telecom, a subsidiary of billionaire Viktor Vekselberg's company. Russian authorities are investigating the incident, which is a high-profile data leak following similar incidents involving military intelligence agents. Companies that breach Russia's data protection laws face fines of up to $1,038. Akado Telecom has launched an internal investigation but did not confirm whether it knew the data was leaked.

site_title: Mindset raises over S$375,000 for mental health
summary: The Mindset Challenge & Carnival 2018 raised over S$375,000 for the Mindset Learning Hub in Singapore, supporting mental health initiatives. The event featured a 33-floor climb, with over 280 participants and 30 mental health persons-in-recovery taking part. The Mindset Learning Hub provides job training and placement opportunities for mental health individuals, with over 150 clients placed in jobs since 2011. The event also raised awareness and reduced social stigma, with a guest-of-honour and local celebrities supporting the cause.

site_title: Consumer companies try price hikes as US wages climb
summary: Consumer goods companies in the US are increasing prices on everyday products and groceries, driven by a strong economy and low wages. After two years of competition from discount supermarkets and online retailers, companies like Walmart and Target are now raising prices to offset costs. Despite a 190% tariff on imported goods, US shoemaker New Balance remains reliant on China.

site_title: Earnings, US mid-terms to dominate markets this week
summary: Asian markets received a boost from positive US earnings reports and US-China trade developments, but the focus shifts to the US mid-term elections on November 6. Polls suggest the Democrats will win a majority in the House of Representatives but the Republicans will retain control of the Senate, potentially leading to increased legislative gridlock. Emerging market currencies are expected to be sensitive to the outcome, while the equity market may not be significantly affected.

site_title: Plenty to keep investors occupied as focus fixed on earnings, mid-terms
summary: US stocks experienced a sharp sell-off last week, despite a rally earlier in the month, as investors digest a new Federal Reserve policy statement and the mid-term election results. Analysts anticipate a prolonged economic conflict between the US and China, with rising interest rates and tariffs on metals and goods contributing to volatility. Despite a strong jobs report, investors remain cautious, with many sectors, including tech giants, reporting slowing growth. The Dow Jones Industrial Average surged back into positive territory for the year, but strategists predict more swings in the near term, with potential losses unlikely to reach "bear market" proportions.

images.alt_text: US stocks rose sharply last week, but hopes that the rally marked the end of autumn volatility were dashed by last Friday's sell-off.

site_title: A broader measure of merit
summary: Singapore's meritocracy concept should be tweaked to tackle new challenges, balancing power accessibility with social policies. Experts argue that education system tweaks are good steps, but more is needed to ensure equality and fairness. Meritocracy should enhance diversity and include character-building, valuing diverse skills and talents. Scholars emphasize the need for a broader definition of merit, recognizing individual starting points and compensating for disadvantages. To achieve true equality, education institutions and corporations should re-evaluate their assessment methods, focusing on soft skills and competency assessments.

site_title: Did you hear that 2018 has been a terrible year for winemakers? Don't believe it
summary: Despite a challenging harvest season due to heavy rains, some Virginia winemakers are refusing to surrender. Barboursville Vineyards winemaker Luca Paschina declared an "Octagon vintage" for his flagship red blend, made from grapes grown despite 75 days of persistent rain. Paschina attributes his success to a warm August and the hard work of his team, who controlled vine vigor and discarded grapes showing signs of rot. Other winemakers, including those in Bordeaux and Europe, are also adopting resilient viticulture practices to cope with the unpredictability of the weather.

site_title: Demand for small flats edging up: OrangeTee study
summary: Demand for small flats, particularly those below 500 sq ft and 500-800 sq ft, has been increasing in Singapore, driven by affordability and attractive yields. According to an OrangeTee & Tie study, new sales of units under 500 sq ft reached a four-year high in 2018, with 1,199 units sold, while resale volumes also rose to a 10-year record of 670 units. The trend is expected to continue, with reduced supply due to government measures to increase average unit size.

site_title: Gold price could see more downside
summary: Gold prices have experienced a slight reprieve after a four-month decline, rebounding from a 20-month low of US$1,160 per ounce in August 2018. However, weekly charts indicate potential further downside in the mid to near term. The gold price currently trades around US$1,220 per ounce, but experts warn of potential losses ahead.

site_title: North Korea warns of returning to nuclear policy
summary: North Korea has warned the US it will "seriously" consider returning to its nuclear policy if Washington does not end economic sanctions. The impoverished regime had pursued a "byungjin" policy, developing nuclear capabilities alongside the economy. This policy was abandoned in 2018, but the country is now reconsidering it due to ongoing sanctions. The US has maintained tough economic sanctions against North Korea, leading to the warning. The move could potentially escalate tensions between the two nations.

site_title: Saudis host WWE wrestlers in shadow of Khashoggi's murder
summary: WWE held its Crown Jewel event in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, despite global calls to boycott due to the murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi. WWE wrestlers, including Shane McMahon and AJ Styles, clashed in the ring, while Hulk Hogan hosted the event. The company cited its contractual obligations to the General Sports Authority and stated it had operated in the Middle East for nearly 20 years. The event took place amidst growing international pressure on Saudi Arabia over the murder, with Turkish President Recep Tayip Erdogan linking it to "the highest levels" of the Saudi government.

site_title: Aung San Suu Kyi's NLD party slapped down in by-elections
summary: Aung San Suu Kyi's National League for Democracy (NLD) party lost in six out of six constituencies in a recent by-election in Myanmar, showing uneven support for her government amid controversies. The NLD won all seats in the 2015 general election, ending decades of military rule. The by-election results come as Suu Kyi faces criticism over her handling of the Rohingya crisis and other issues. The NLD's defeat suggests a loss of public trust in the government.

site_title: Owning your own home doesn't make you rich. Owning somebody else's does
summary: Wealth inequality in the US is concentrated among business owners and landlords, with those groups holding about four times the wealth of the average American. Renters, on the other hand, have about an eighth of the average wealth. The study found that this polarization has increased since 1962, with the widest gaps between business owners/landlords and their customers/tenants in the US and Austria. The findings highlight the importance of considering the use of wealth, not just its distribution, in understanding wealth inequality.

site_title: Oil rally faces tidal wave of supply
summary: The oil market faces a significant test with a surge in global supply and concerns over economic weakness sapping demand worldwide. Despite hopes that US sanctions on Iran would lead to a supply crunch, the world's three largest producers - Russia, Saudi Arabia, and the US - have indicated record or near-record production levels. The US will allow waivers to keep importing Iranian oil, further easing supply concerns. As a result, oil futures have plummeted, with US crude futures falling below $65 a barrel, and investors are now expecting oversupply, pushing demand forecasts lower.

site_title: 10 years on, TWG sips on global ambitions
summary: TWG Tea, a Singaporean luxury tea brand, has achieved global ambitions within 10 years of its founding in 2008. The company, which distributes fine tea leaves from every tea-producing country to 42 countries, was saved from financial struggles in 2011 by an initial investment of S$31.4 million by OSIM International. Under the guidance of CEO Taha Bouqdib, TWG Tea has expanded to 70 tea salons and boutiques in 19 countries, and has set its sights on becoming a travel destination in major cities worldwide.

site_title: Positive start for sales of three private residences
summary: City Developments Limited sold 160 out of 240 units for Whistler Grand condominium, with 91% of buyers being Singaporeans, mostly first-time home buyers. Another developer, Roxy Pacific, sold 40 out of 70 units for Arena Residences, while 27 units were sold at Belgravia Green. Prices for Whistler Grand ranged from S$608,000 to S$1.788 million, and for Arena Residences from S$1,750 to S$1,850 psf. The average selling price for Whistler Grand is S$1,380 per square foot.

site_title: GE hands former CEO John Flannery US$10m exit package after 14-month stint
summary: General Electric (GE) has agreed to pay former CEO John Flannery an exit package worth over $10 million after his 14-month tenure. The package includes $4.25 million in severance, $3.75 million in vested equity awards, $21.9 million in pension benefits, and $2.16 million in deferred compensation. Flannery, 57, stepped down amid the company's significant market loss and troubles in its power business, with a total loss of over $100 billion in market value.

site_title: Dollar up as White House denies report of US-China deal
summary: The US dollar rose against the yen and euro on Friday, driven by concerns over a potential US-China trade deal. White House economic adviser Larry Kudlow denied a report that President Trump had asked officials to draft a trade plan, saying Trump "could pull the trigger" on additional tariffs on Chinese imports. The dollar index hit a 16-month high, while the offshore yuan fell to a 6-month low. Investors' views that the US is better equipped to weather a trade war also boosted demand for the dollar.

site_title: Exxon, Chevron surprise Wall Street as higher output lifts Q3 results
summary: Exxon and Chevron delivered their strongest third-quarter results in four years, with Exxon's oil and natural gas output surpassing expectations for the first time in 10 quarters. Earnings climbed 57% for Exxon and doubled to $4 billion for Chevron, driven by record production and higher crude prices. The companies' strong performance has lifted Wall Street, with Exxon shares rising and Chevron jumping the most in three years. Both companies have cut debt and seen cash flow from operations surge, with Exxon continuing to focus on expanding its presence in the US Permian Basin.

site_title: Wall St's back to doing business as usual with Saudi Arabia
summary: Wall Street is re-engaging with Saudi Arabia despite the 2018 murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi, with bankers citing the kingdom's vast oil reserves and lucrative investment opportunities as outweighing the risks. The Khashoggi killing has led to a slight increase in borrowing costs, but bankers expect this to stabilize as the world's attention shifts. Saudi Arabia's sovereign wealth fund and government have borrowed billions from Western banks, and bankers are optimistic that business will resume as usual when fundraising for the Aramco-Sabic deal begins next year.

images.alt_text: Saudi Aramco (above) is preparing to acquire a 70 per cent stake in Saudi Basic Industries Corp for about US$70 billion next year. Bankers say borrowing costs for the deal may now be slightly higher.

site_title: BA owner still likes Norwegian, sees Qatar Air leaving Oneworld
summary: IAG CEO Willie Walsh expressed interest in buying Norwegian Air Shuttle, despite two rejected bids, citing its attractive European network. He also stated that Qatar Airways, IAG's biggest investor, may quit the Oneworld Alliance amid tensions with other members, with Qatar's CEO Akbar Al Baker previously warning of a possible exit. IAG is boosting growth plans through 2023 to boost profit by an average of 11% annually, including investing 500 million euros and expanding its fleet by 130 aircraft.

site_title: Trade war, spy claims cloud horizon for China airshow
summary: China's largest aerospace meeting, Airshow China, is set to take place in Zhuhai, with trade frictions with the US and accusations of industrial espionage casting a cloud over the event. Suppliers expect few major announcements or deals due to China's slowing economy and booming jet demand. The biennial event is traditionally a platform for Beijing to showcase its aviation prowess, but this year's focus may be on diplomacy rather than deal-making. Analysts anticipate a more subdued atmosphere, with a focus on building relationships rather than securing large contracts.

images.alt_text: The biennial Airshow China is traditionally an event for Beijing to parade its growing aviation prowess in front of aerospace executives, diplomats and arms buyers from over 40 countries.

site_title: Grab seizes big deals ahead of Go-Jek's arrival
summary: Grab, a South-east Asian ride-hailing giant, has announced partnerships with Mastercard and Booking.com to expand its services beyond ride-hailing. The partnerships, announced in October, will see Mastercard issue prepaid cards integrated with Grab's mobile wallet, and Booking.com's 28 million accommodation options integrated into the Grab app. The move aims to position Grab as a Super App, with a range of services including payments, accommodation booking, and travel services. The partnerships also underscore Grab's efforts to compete with Go-Jek, set to launch in Singapore.

site_title: UK promotes global airline carbon market after Brexit
summary: The UK is urging the European Union to support a global airline carbon market, which would likely supersede the EU's own trading program after Brexit. Aviation minister Liz Sugg argues that a global scheme is needed to tackle climate change, as the industry is too large to be covered by regional rules. The UK is proposing a market that would place a price on emissions above 2020 levels, but the EU has expressed concerns about the effectiveness of the plan and potential opposition from the US.

site_title: Actor Alec Baldwin charged over New York parking spot fight
summary: Actor Alec Baldwin, 60, was charged with misdemeanor assault and harassment after a fight over a New York parking spot. According to police, Baldwin "assaulted someone for a parking spot they were both going for." He was arrested and released from a New York police station, meeting dozens of photographers and camera crews.

site_title: Coal-dependent Poland shifts towards wind energy ahead of climate meeting
summary: Poland is shifting towards wind energy ahead of the COP24 World Climate Conference, where the country aims to meet EU goals for renewable energy. The right-wing government's 2016 legislation restricted onshore wind energy, but recent changes have eased some restrictions. Poland plans to add 1 gigawatt of wind energy capacity through an auction and public subsidies, aiming to boost its renewable energy mix to at least 15% by 2020. Despite challenges, Poland's wind energy sector is expected to get a boost, with two more auctions planned to add 2 gigawatts of capacity.

site_title: UK and EU close to Brexit agreement over Irish border, says report
summary: The UK and EU are close to a Brexit agreement, with Prime Minister Theresa May securing concessions from Brussels to avoid a hard Irish border. The EU will write an "all-UK" customs union into the divorce deal, allowing for temporary customs union with the EU while maintaining regulatory checks in factories and shops. This could pave the way for a future free trade agreement. The deal still needs to secure support from May's slim parliamentary majority and may face opposition from hardline Brexiteers.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report covers the tanker and dry bulk market for the week of November 4, 2018. Key points include: tanker rates firming in the Middle East Gulf, West Africa to China basis rates increasing, and Suezmax rates rising. Dry bulk rates also increased, with Capesize rates steadying after a disappointing week. Period fixing remained scarce, and freight rates for the Caribbean and Atlantic were lower. The transpacific peak season is expected to drive demand, with China trade tariffs set to increase to 25% on January 1.

site_title: UK, German banks struggle in EU 'stress tests'
summary: British and German banks suffered the largest potential financial hits in the latest EU stress tests, with Lloyds, Barclays, and Royal Bank of Scotland in Britain, and Deutsche Bank and German regional lenders, at risk due to factors like Brexit and Italy's debt issues. However, the tests showed that Europe's banks are in better shape, with higher capital cushions and reduced non-performing loans, thanks to clean-up measures since the 2008 crisis. The European Central Bank's results will inform discussions on whether to require banks to build up their capital cushions to guard against potential losses.

site_title: Two dead, multiple wounded in US yoga studio shooting: police
summary: A gunman killed two people and injured several others at a yoga studio in Tallahassee, Florida, on Friday. The shooter took his own life after responding to police. Five people were transported to a nearby hospital, with two later dying from their wounds. One victim was pistol-whipped, and multiple others fought back, showcasing their courage. The shooting appeared to be the act of a single person with no further threat to the community.

site_title: BlackRock sick of excuses for corporate boards lacking women
summary: BlackRock is criticizing companies with fewer than two women on their boards, saying excuses for the lack of diversity are unconvincing. The asset manager sent letters to Russell 1000 companies, asking for explanations, but found responses such as "there aren't any qualified women" and "we don't need a woman director." BlackRock believes a wide pipeline of female directors exists and urges companies to look beyond traditional sources. The firm's research shows that more diverse boards lead to better results.

site_title: Full occupancy for Mapletree Logistics Trust's redevelopment project in China
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust has achieved full occupancy for the first phase of its redevelopment project in China, Mapletree Ouluo Logistics Park (MOLP). The project secured strong pre-commitments from existing and new tenants, including leading third-party logistics providers. Phase 1, located near Shanghai Pudong International Airport, is part of a two-phase development with Phase 2 set for completion in March 2020. Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry, Chan Chun Sing, attended the event.

site_title: Despite crackdown, 'junk news' still flourishes on social media
summary: Researchers at the Oxford Internet Institute found that "junk news" is spreading at a greater rate on social media ahead of the 2018 US midterm elections, with less than 5% of sources being from public agencies, experts, or political candidates. Despite efforts by Facebook and Twitter to root out misinformation, the study suggests that "tweaks" may not be enough to make a significant impact. The researchers believe that the style of producing "junk news" may have a Russian origin and has spread to include mainstream conservative communities.

site_title: Citic Envirotech on lookout for promising SMEs
summary: Citic Envirotech Ltd (CEL) is investing S$30 million in promising SMEs via its accelerator program over four years. The company has already taken a 20% stake in Century Water Systems & Technologies for S$1.73 million. CEL aims to help Century sell its membranes in China, where the company currently generates 90% of its business. The investment is part of the company's efforts to diversify risks and enter new markets, including the US and Europe. CEL's CEO, Hao Weibao, expects growth in the industrial wastewater treatment market to outpace that of municipal wastewater treatment in China.

site_title: Diver dies in search for Indonesia jet crash dead
summary: A diver, Syachrul Anto, 48, died while recovering body parts from the wreckage of the Lion Air plane in the Java Sea, where 189 people died in a crash. He was a volunteer with the Search and Rescue Agency. The incident occurred on Friday, and Anto's death brings the total number of fatalities in the search and recovery efforts to at least one.

site_title: US top court rejects Trump administration bid to halt climate trial
summary: The US Supreme Court rejected a bid by the Trump administration to halt a climate change trial. Young activists sued the government for ignoring climate change, and the trial was set to begin on October 29 in Eugene, Oregon. The court temporarily put the case on hold while deciding how to proceed, but ultimately rejected the administration's request to block the trial. The trial will now proceed, examining US climate change policy.

site_title: US allows eight importers to keep buying Iran oil for now
summary: The US has temporarily allowed eight importers to continue buying Iranian oil as sanctions are set to be re-imposed on Monday. The eight countries, which include China, India, South Korea, and Turkey, will be allowed to reduce their oil imports, with some stopping imports entirely. The US aims to force Iran to curb its nuclear, missile, and regional activities. The decision is part of President Trump's "maximum pressure" policy, and the US expects global oil supplies to exceed demand next year, making it easier for countries to cut Iranian oil imports to zero.

site_title: Berkshire profit doubles as Buffett's insurers weather storms
summary: Berkshire Hathaway's insurers saw a 90% decline in catastrophe costs in the third quarter, driving a doubling of operating profit to $6.88 billion. The company's insurance division capitalized on trends in railroad and electronic components, while the railroad reported a 34% profit increase. Berkshire's cash reserves remain substantial at $103.6 billion, allowing Chairman Warren Buffett to repurchase $928 million in stock. Net income more than quadrupled, thanks to a new accounting rule.

site_title: Hiap Hoe buys Aloft Perth hotel and office building for A$100m
summary: Hiap Hoe has acquired the 224-room Aloft Perth hotel and office building in Australia for A$100 million. The acquisition, made through a sale and purchase deal with BGC (Australia) affiliate BAAC Pty Ltd, does not require shareholder approval. The company views the property as a prime investment opportunity with high occupancy levels and a diverse mix of blue-chip tenants.

site_title: US has political blind spot for right-wing threat: analysts
summary: US law enforcement has been criticized for its handling of right-wing extremism, with experts claiming a "political blind spot" that prioritizes Islamic extremism. Despite a surge in violent acts by white nationalists, neo-Nazis, and anti-Semites, the government has failed to allocate resources equally to address the issue. Since 2009, significant right-wing shootings and bombings have increased, with some analysts attributing this to a conscious reluctance to criticize right-wing extremists, particularly from Republicans. Experts call for the government to treat far-right extremism as a singular nationwide threat, allocating resources accordingly.

site_title: Myanmar by-election rare local test for Aung San Suu Kyi
summary: Myanmar's Aung San Suu Kyi's party, the National League for Democracy (NLD), is facing a rare local test with a by-election in Yangon, marking more than halfway through her time in office. The NLD swept to power in 2015, but Suu Kyi's tenure has been marred by controversy, including her handling of the Rohingya crisis and stalled peace talks. The by-election is seen as a key indicator of support for the NLD and Suu Kyi's leadership, despite criticism from the international community.

site_title: Best week since Dec 2016 for European shares as trade hopes fuel rally
summary: European shares had their best week since December 2016, rising 3.4% on Friday, fueled by hopes of a trade deal between the US and China. US President Donald Trump's comments sparked optimism, with the pan-European STOXX 600 reaching its highest since October 10. However, analysts at UBS warned that their base case was for the trade dispute to worsen before improving. Despite this, the rally continued, marking a third day of gains.

site_title: US: Wall St snaps three-day rally as Apple falls, trade optimism fades
summary: US stocks snapped a three-day rally on Friday as Apple's 6.6% drop in shares dragged down the S&P 500, with the technology sector falling 1.9%. The decline was attributed to a disappointing forecast from Apple and comments from White House economic adviser Larry Kudlow that dampened optimism over US-China trade talks. Despite the losses, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq still posted their biggest weekly percentage gains since May, with the Dow rising 2.4% for the week.

site_title: US securities regulator subpoenas Tesla on Model 3 production estimates
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has subpoenaed Tesla over its 2017 production estimates for the Model 3, a vehicle the company failed to meet on time. The SEC is also investigating whether Tesla misled investors about its business, including CEO Elon Musk's statements about taking the company private. Tesla has denied any wrongdoing and stated that it disclosed production bottlenecks, while the company also revealed it received regulatory credits that contributed to nearly half of its third-quarter net profit.

site_title: Fierce winds raze forests in storm-hit Italy
summary: Fierce winds and rains in Italy have killed at least 20 people and razed thousands of hectares of forest in the north, with 160,000 people left without electricity. Trees in the Dolomites range were reduced to matchsticks, and several towns were cut off due to landslides. The region's governor described the damage as "like after an earthquake" and warned of further wind and rain throughout the weekend. Italy's civil protection agency has described the weather as one of the most complex in the past 50-60 years, with Venice experiencing near-record flooding.

site_title: Chinese stocks sending scary signal about the economy
summary: China's consumer stocks have been experiencing a slowdown, with the Shenzhen CSI 300 Consumer Staples Index sliding 22% in October, its worst month since the 2008 global financial crisis. The decline is attributed to a slowdown in retail sales and concerns about consumer spending habits.
