Authorities are taking steps to shore up spending, including proposals to halve the tax on car purchases and personal income-tax cuts. While some analysts predict a short-term cyclical consumption momentum slowdown, others warn of a longer-term structural decline, and investors are advised to tilt towards materials and energy companies.

site_title: Twitter deletes over 10,000 accounts that sought to discourage US voting
summary: Twitter deleted over 10,000 automated accounts posting misleading messages discouraging US voting, mainly targeting Democrats, in a joint effort with the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee. The removals, which occurred in late September and early October, represent an early win for the party's anti-disinformation campaign. The Democratic National Committee uses publicly available tools to identify and report malicious automated accounts, and Twitter removed the flagged accounts after being alerted by the party.

site_title: Lion Air jet's final plunge may have reached 600 miles per hour
summary: A Lion Air jet crashed into the Java Sea shortly after taking off from Jakarta, Indonesia, with 189 people on board. Preliminary flight-tracking data suggests the plane may have reached speeds of 600 miles per hour before slamming into the sea, with estimates ranging from 540 to 633 mph. Experts analyzed data from the plane's radio transmissions, concluding the high-speed descent was consistent with the plane being pointed sharply downward and accelerating. The investigation is ongoing, with the recovered flight-data recorder expected to provide more information on the plane's speed and trajectory.

site_title: Goldman says 1MDB dealings may still result in penalties
summary: Goldman Sachs has stated that government probes into its dealings with the Malaysian sovereign wealth fund 1MDB may result in "significant fines, penalties, and other sanctions." The bank is cooperating with the US Department of Justice and other regulators. US prosecutors have filed criminal charges against two former Goldman bankers and a Malaysian financier over alleged theft of billions of dollars from 1MDB. The alleged graft involving 1MDB occurred between 2009 and 2014, with an estimated $4.5 billion misappropriated.

site_title: Making a name through ethical practices
summary: Providend, a fee-only advisory firm, was set up in 2001 with a focus on ethical practices. Despite initial skepticism, the firm grew to manage around S$283 million and partnered with NTUC Enterprise Co-operative to form MoneyOwl. Providend's insurance portal, DIYInsurance, was launched in 2014 and successfully expanded services to the retail public, achieving exponential growth and changing consumer behavior. The portal advocated term insurance over expensive whole life plans, and its average policy size was around S$2,000 annually, offering a sum assured of about S$1.5 million.

site_title: China Everbright bags jobs worth 1.05b yuan from Shandong govt
summary: China Everbright Water has secured contracts worth approximately 1.05 billion yuan (S$208.03 million) from Shandong government authorities to upgrade three existing waste water treatment plants in Zibo City, Shandong province. The projects, valued at 855 million yuan, 109 million yuan, and 83 million yuan, will increase treatment capacities and improve water quality. The 30-year concession period is expected to boost operational efficiency and economic benefits for the company, solidifying its position in the local market.

site_title: Uber seeks OK to resume self-driving tests in Pennsylvania
summary: Uber has asked Pennsylvania for permission to resume self-driving car testing on public roads, over seven months after suspending testing following a deadly crash in Arizona. The company has improved its autonomous vehicle software, enabling automatic braking at all times and stricter safety monitoring. Uber has also implemented new processes, including real-time third-party monitoring of safety drivers and improved training. The state's Department of Transportation has received the application and will review it before issuing an authorization letter, which is required for Uber to resume testing in Pittsburgh.

site_title: Sembcorp's Q3 profit dips 12%; firm secures 25-year solar deal
summary: Sembcorp Industries' third-quarter net profit dropped 12% to S$82.3 million due to losses in the marine business, mainly caused by weak volumes and a sale of a semi-submersible. Despite a 36% increase in turnover to S$3.02 billion, primarily driven by higher revenue from marine and utilities businesses, the company's marine segment suffered a net loss of S$18 million.

site_title: Developers tee off amid mass closure of US golf courses
summary: US developers are capitalizing on the mass closure of golf courses, with many converting the land into housing developments, public parks, and agricultural businesses. The closures, which accelerated after the 2008 economic recession, are attributed to an oversupply of new facilities and decreased interest in golf among millennials. About 205 US golf courses closed last year, reducing the total to approximately 14,800. Developers see selling or redeveloping the land as a lucrative exit strategy, with Las Vegas being a hotspot for redevelopment due to its abundance of golf courses and lack of regulations governing the process.

site_title: Trump says 'I think we'll make a deal with China' on trade
summary: US President Donald Trump stated that he will likely make a deal with China on trade, despite warnings from his top economic adviser that progress has been slow. Trump said China wants to make a deal and that it will be "very fair" for the US, but also warned that he may impose more tariffs if a deal is not reached. The two countries are currently negotiating changes to China's policies on intellectual property, technology transfers, and industrial subsidies. Trump will discuss trade with Chinese President Xi Jinping at the G20 leaders' summit in Buenos Aires, Argentina, at the end of November.

site_title: Trump and Xi upbeat on trade after phone call
summary: US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping expressed optimism about resolving their trade dispute after a phone call, with Trump planning to meet Xi at the G-20 summit in Argentina. Despite this, the US Justice Department announced actions against Chinese firms accused of unfair practices. Investors cheered the resumption of dialogue, with shares in Asia hitting three-week highs. Trump wants to reach a trade agreement with China at the G-20 meeting, but intellectual property theft remains a sticking point. The two leaders hope to promote a steady and healthy relationship, with Xi willing to meet Trump in Argentina.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Keppel Corporation's indirect subsidiary Ibeworth has converted 49% of its Vietnamese dong convertible bonds into shares of housing developer Nam Long Investment Corporation (NLG), increasing its stake to 10% of issued shares. This follows the conversion of 5% of pre-conversion shares. The move is part of Ibeworth's strategy to acquire NLG shares.

site_title: Oil drops 1% as US allows Iran sanctions waivers
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo announced a temporary waiver of Iran-related sanctions on eight jurisdictions, including India, Iraq, and South Korea, allowing top buyers to keep importing Iranian oil after economic penalties come into effect on Monday. Oil prices fell 1% and notched a weekly loss of over 6% as investors worried about oversupply. Brent crude futures settled at $72.83 a barrel, while US crude declined 55 cents to end the session at $63.14 per barrel, a 0.86% loss.

site_title: Goldman Sachs stung by US probe into 1MDB
summary: The US Department of Justice has implicated at least three senior Goldman Sachs bankers in a multiyear corruption probe involving bribery and money laundering of hundreds of millions of dollars in Malaysia. Andrea Vella, a Goldman Sachs Asia banker, was placed on leave pending review, while two other bankers were charged with wrongdoing. The probe, which has spanned continents, is the first direct blow to Goldman Sachs, raising concerns about potential further charges against other bank employees.

site_title: Positive news on US-China trade ties boosts Asian markets
summary: US President Donald Trump revealed positive talks with Chinese President Xi Jinping, boosting Asian markets. Key Asian indices ended the day in positive territory, with the Hang Seng jumping 4.21% and South Korea's Kospi and mainland China's Shanghai Composite gaining 3.5% and 2.7%, respectively. The positive news on US-China trade ties helped Singapore's Straits Times Index rise 1.8% and other Asian markets to close with modest gains, despite some declines.

site_title: Audi A8 review: A smart start
summary: The Audi A8, a luxury limousine, boasts cutting-edge technology, including a Level 3 autonomous driving system, but its capabilities are currently limited by regulatory approvals. The vehicle features a range of innovative features, including wireless charging, voice commands, and a customizable interface. The A8 also boasts a smooth ride, adaptive air suspension, and a powerful 3.0-litre V6 turbocharged engine. However, its ride quality can be bumpy, and the vehicle's price tag is S$417,479. Audi expects to introduce AI Active Suspension technology in 2019 to improve ride quality.

site_title: Chongqing-Singapore financial links get boost with over 10 MOUs inked
summary: Over 10 memoranda of understanding (MOUs) were signed during the inaugural China (Chongqing)-Singapore Connectivity Initiative Financial Summit, aiming to enhance regional connectivity under China's Belt and Road Initiative and the Chongqing Connectivity Initiative Southern Transport Corridor. Agreements include fintech collaborations between Singapore and Chongqing authorities, as well as rail-sea transport links between China and South-east Asia. The summit marks progress in the China-Singapore Demonstration Initiative on Strategic Connectivity, with 51 cross-border financing deals worth US$4.2 billion completed as of August this year.

site_title: Japan aims to open door wider to blue-collar workers
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's cabinet approved a revised law to create two new visa categories for foreigners in sectors with labor shortages. This move aims to address labor shortages in Japan, a policy shift in the country's immigration-shy stance. The new visa categories are expected to open the door to more overseas blue-collar workers, a move seen as a response to Japan's demographic challenges. The policy shift comes amidst the US's focus on immigration during the Congressional mid-term elections.

site_title: The future of fund management? It's vinyl
summary: Active fund management will survive, but its relevance will decrease, with the industry shifting towards a 30% market share over the next 7-10 years. Active management will occupy a niche, leveraging human skills such as contextualization, innovation, and people skills that are difficult for AI to replicate. The industry must focus on service innovation, hyper-customization of asset allocations, and personalized client experiences to remain competitive, rather than just relying on product development and marketing.

site_title: Venture Corp's Q3 net profit down 27.5%
summary: Venture Corp, a Singapore-based electronics manufacturing services provider, reported a 27.5% decrease in Q3 net profit to S$80.8 million, missing street estimates. Revenue fell 27.4% to S$770.4 million due to customers transitioning to new products and M&A activities. The company expects revenue to improve sequentially in the next quarter, driven by new product introductions and expanded partnerships. Despite concerns over trade tariffs, Venture Corp maintains its long-term resilience due to its diversified portfolio and strong supply chain management.

site_title: Cash or carry?
summary: The article discusses the long-standing investment strategy of taking the cash on the dollar trade and carrying a short trade in gold. Historically, when the US dollar index rises, gold price falls, and vice versa. However, with the US dollar index reaching a recent peak, the gold price has rallied. Investors are now faced with the dilemma of whether to take the cash and back the continued rise in the US dollar or to carry a short trade in gold. This poses a challenge to the traditional relationship trade, and investors must reassess their investment strategy.

site_title: Singtel, StarHub scale back electricity efforts
summary: Singapore's two major telcos, Singtel and StarHub, have scaled back their efforts in the newly liberalised Open Electricity Market (OEM). Singtel's SingNet unit, which was awarded a retail electricity licence, is in talks with potential partners, while StarHub has exited its partnership with Sunseap Group and is no longer reselling power. M1 remains the only telco participating in the OEM, offering product bundling for households. Analysts attribute the pullback to low margins and limited market size, but predict the Singapore electricity market will be fully liberalised by mid-2024, offering opportunities for telcos to explore further.

site_title: Upgrade to China-Singapore free-trade deal likely to be inked this month: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing expects the upgrade of the China-Singapore free-trade deal to be signed in Singapore this month. The enhanced pact will provide greater trade facilitation, investment protection, and cooperation in areas like e-commerce and the environment. It is expected to boost investments, employment, and people's living standards. The signing of the deal sends a positive message about maintaining and strengthening free trade, according to Chan. Chinese Premier Li Keqiang's visit to Singapore in mid-November is seen as a key moment for the agreement's completion.

site_title: Investors bristle as Apple's iPhone data goes the way of its headphone jacks
summary: Apple has stopped reporting unit sales data for its iPhone, iPad, and Mac products, citing that it's less relevant to its business strength as customers bundle products with paid services. The move has led to a 7% decline in shares in after-hours trading, but Apple will now provide cost-of-sales data for its total product businesses and services, giving investors a gross margin for both. This change will help evaluate Apple's lucrative hardware business and subscription-based services, such as Apple Music and iCloud storage.

site_title: Reits
summary: US President Trump's 50% copper import tariff is expected to cover refined metal, potentially affecting the global market. In the real estate sector, prices of Good Class Bungalows in Singapore are being scrutinized, while the Q3 condo launch wave may test demand for prime projects above S$3,000 per square foot. US mortgage rates have risen after five straight weeks of declines, and Manhattan rents have hit a record, with more increases anticipated. Additionally, Goldman Sachs has acquired 262 billion won hotel and retail assets in Seoul, and UK homebuyer demand has rebounded to a six-month high.

site_title: Singapore still second easiest place to do business: World Bank
summary: Singapore has retained its No 2 spot on the World Bank's rankings for ease of doing business, with a score of 85.24. The country improved in starting a business and enforcing contracts, but fell behind in resolving insolvency, getting credit, and trading across borders. Globally, 314 business reforms were implemented in 128 economies over the past year, with China and Malaysia making significant improvements. Singapore has held the No 2 spot for three consecutive years, behind New Zealand.

site_title: Equities fare well in lead-up to economic slowdown: Fidelity head
summary: Fidelity's Genevieve Cua says investors shouldn't exit equities despite a possible US recession, citing a flattening yield curve as a sign of economic weakness. Historically, equities perform well in the lead-up to a slowdown. The yield curve is currently 29 basis points apart, down from 134 basis points in 2016. Cua expects one more rate hike this year and one to two next year. Meanwhile, emerging markets are experiencing a correction, with the MSCI Emerging Markets index down 16% year-to-date. The Institute of International Finance notes that large equity outflows in October could signal a buying opportunity.

site_title: Malaysia targets biggest budget deficit since 2013
summary: Malaysia's government has set a budget deficit target of 3.7% of GDP, the highest in five years, to plug a shortfall from the scrapping of the consumption tax. The government aims to raise taxes and draw more income from the state oil company to achieve this target. This decision comes in the first budget since Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad took office in May.

site_title: Best in class: Fundamentals of education-sector investing
summary: The education sector is a non-discretionary service, driven by parents' desire to improve their children's educational outcomes, particularly in emerging markets with significant demand-supply gaps. Companies in this sector must analyze employment conditions, economic trends, and the demand for specialized skills to predict growth. Assessing the quality of services offered, revenue models, and scalability are also crucial. Understanding the regulatory environment, ESG issues, and the company's response to these factors is essential for sustainable business models. By conducting thorough sector analysis, investors can identify opportunities and mitigate risks in the education industry.

site_title: NTUC, Providend tie up to offer low-cost advisory
summary: MoneyOwl, a joint venture between NTUC Enterprise and Providend, offers low-cost financial advisory services in Singapore. The firm provides comprehensive financial planning, including protection, investment, and wills, with a 50% rebate on insurance product commissions. MoneyOwl's first service is insurance, offering term life, endowment, and critical illness plans, and will expand to whole life policies and low-cost portfolio services over the next six to nine months. The firm aims to deliver conflict-free and comprehensive financial advice, empowering clients to pursue their goals.

site_title: Why we tend to remember the bad more than the good
summary: Research suggests that humans are wired to remember negative experiences more than positive ones, with studies indicating this phenomenon may have evolutionary roots. According to Laura Carstensen, a psychology professor at Stanford University, this attention to negative events has adaptive value, allowing individuals to learn from difficult situations and apply that knowledge in the future. Additionally, Carstensen's research shows that this tendency is more pronounced among younger people, who have longer futures and need to collect information to manage those futures, whereas older individuals are better at living in the present and focusing on positive experiences.

site_title: The case of the disappearing General Manager
summary: Hotel general managers, once known for their personal interactions with guests, are now largely absent from the front lines due to consolidation and corporate pressures. Large hotel chains backed by REITs and private equity have streamlined operations, reducing individuality and face-to-face interactions. This shift has led to a decline in personalized service, with guests increasingly relying on online reviews and anonymous complaints. The loss of human connection is expected to have significant consequences for the hospitality industry and its employees.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng Q3 net profit up 8%
summary: Chip Eng Seng Corporation reported a 8% year-on-year increase in third-quarter net profit to S$14.28 million. Revenue jumped 50% to S$320.1 million, driven by a 76% surge in property development revenue. Earnings per share rose to 2.29 Singapore cents, up from 2.12 cents in the prior quarter.

site_title: The Scandinavian key to workplace happiness
summary: Scandinavian workplaces are renowned for prioritizing work-life balance, diversity, and inclusion, contributing to the region's high levels of happiness. Trust is the key factor, with flexible working hours and delegation of authority allowing employees to manage their priorities. The concept of "fika" provides a daily break for socializing and relaxation. Scandinavian companies like Telenor Group also emphasize diversity and inclusion, with initiatives such as six months of maternity leave and women's networks to support career growth. By adopting a people-centered approach, Scandinavian workplaces can create a culture that fosters happiness and productivity.

site_title: China's developers bracing for major shakeout
summary: China's property developers are bracing for a major shakeout as the government considers banning pre-sales to curb corporate debt. Smaller players are scrambling to sell assets to raise cash, while larger firms are driving consolidation through mergers and acquisitions. The industry is facing a perfect storm of debt, declining stocks, and looming bond maturities, with some analysts predicting that up to half of developers could go out of business if the pre-sales ban is implemented nationwide. This shakeout is expected to speed up the consolidation wave, with the "survival of the fittest" principle likely to prevail.

site_title: UIC posts 36% drop in Q3 earnings to S$59.3m
summary: UIC, a Singaporean property group, reported a 36% drop in Q3 earnings to S$59.3 million, largely due to lower sales recognition from trading properties. Revenue declined 63% to S$151.9 million in the same period.

site_title: US trade gap hits 7-month high amid expanding tariff war
summary: The US trade deficit widened to a seven-month high in September, reaching $54 billion, amid an escalating tariff war with China. Imports and exports both rose 1.5%, with exports increasing to $212.6 billion and imports to $266.6 billion. The trade gap with China widened to $40.2 billion. Meanwhile, the US economy added 250,000 jobs in October, with unemployment holding steady at 3.7%, and average hourly earnings rising 0.2% to 3.1% above the year-ago level.

site_title: US trade gap hits seven-month high amid expanding tariff war
summary: The US trade deficit widened to a seven-month high in September, reaching $54 billion, amid an escalating tariff war with China. Imports and exports both rose 1.5%, with the merchandise gap with China hitting a record. The trade deficit has been a significant drag on the US economy, with President Trump threatening more action. Exports rose to $212.6 billion, but American soybean exports fell 29% due to Chinese retaliatory levies. The stronger US dollar also poses a challenge for exports.

site_title: French court approves buyer of YuuZoo Networks unit
summary: A French court has approved the buyer of YuuZoo Networks' unit, YuuLog France, following a judicial recovery process. The proposal presented by a potential buyer is deemed the most promising for employees and creditors. The process is expected to be completed by November 19. The company has already fully impaired its investment in YuuLog France, with financial commitments totaling 1.5 million euros. The outcome is not expected to have a significant impact on the company's earnings per share and net asset value per share for the current financial year.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng Q3 profit up 8.4%
summary: Chip Eng Seng Corporation reported a 8.4% increase in Q3 net profit to S$14.28 million, driven by 50% revenue growth, largely due to property development sales. Revenue from property developments rose 76% to S$257.31 million. Earnings per share increased to 2.29 Singapore cents. The company's construction business saw a decline in total construction order book to S$440.7 million. Chip Eng Seng's property developments, such as Park Colonial and Grandeur Park Residences, are nearing completion, with 96.7% and 65.1% sales respectively.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: China Aviation Oil (CAO) reported a Q3 profit of US$18.9 million, 17% below estimates, with a 12% year-on-year decline and 35% quarter-on-quarter drop. Gross profit rose 156% year-on-year due to trading profits, but working capital requirements increased financing costs. Analysts downgraded CAO's target price to S$1.50 from S$1.50, citing declining profit growth. Meanwhile, Yongnam Holdings secured S$53.4 million worth of contracts, which could lead to a profit turnaround in FY19F, maintaining an "Add" call.

site_title: Pretty big (tennis) shoes for Shenzhen to fill
summary: The Women's Tennis Association (WTA) Finals has concluded its five-year stint in Singapore, marking the end of an era for the Lion City. The tournament, which began in 2014, featured top players like Serena Williams, Maria Sharapova, and Venus Williams, and drew over half a million fans to the Sports Hub. Elina Svitolina won the championship in a thrilling match against Sloane Stephens, bringing an end to the event's time in Singapore. The WTA Finals will now relocate to Shenzhen, China, for the next 10 years, leaving behind a legacy of memorable matches and experiences.

site_title: SGX imposes fine, education programme on UOBKH trader for misconduct
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has imposed a fine of S$15,000 and S$10,000 on UOBKH trader Seow Jin Yuan Reymond for misconduct. The trader admitted to four charges, including pre-arranged trades and acting as principal without informing a customer. The Disciplinary Committee also required him to attend an education programme. The misconduct occurred in March and April 2017, involving trades in GSH Corporation shares. The penalties were imposed following a hearing on September 6, 2018.

site_title: US payrolls rise more than forecast as wage gains hit 3.1%
summary: US job market shows resilience with 250,000 new payrolls, beating forecasts, and a 3.1% wage gain, the largest since 2009. The unemployment rate remains at 3.7%, and the median estimate predicted a 200,000 increase. The figures support President Trump ahead of midterm elections and may lead to further interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. Despite a boost from tax cuts, investors remain cautious due to the ongoing US-China trade war and potential risks to capital investment.

site_title: US home prices cool as sales slump in pricey western cities
summary: US home prices rose 4.8% to a median price of $266,900 in the third quarter, slower than the 5.3% annual increase in the same period last year. Higher mortgage rates contributed to the slowdown in sales, marking a shift in the market. The National Association of Realtors attributed the decline to decreased affordability.

site_title: Power, despair and facts in between
summary: The New Economy Forum (NEF) in Singapore aims to tackle pressing global issues such as inequality, climate change, and trade liberalization through data-driven solutions. The forum, hosted by Bloomberg, will bring together 400 global CEOs and government officials, including Chinese Vice-President Wang Qishan and former US Secretary of State Henry Kissinger, to hammer out solutions in areas like gender parity and artificial intelligence principles. The event represents a shift in economic growth, focusing on emerging economies, and aims to set up secretariats to implement the solutions, driven by pragmatism and a sense of urgency to solve problems.

site_title: POSH posts net loss of US$5.3m in Q3
summary: PACC Offshore Services Holdings (POSH) reported a net loss of US$5.3 million in Q3, narrowing by 8.6% from the same period last year. The loss was primarily due to a share of results from joint ventures, which recorded a US$0.8 million loss compared to a US$16 million profit in Q3 FY2017.

site_title: Arbitration proceeds, injunctions commenced against Sunvic unit
summary: Arbitration proceedings and injunctions have commenced against Sunvic Chemical's subsidiary Taixing Jurong Chemical, with Taixing Sunke Chemicals claiming 404 million yuan (S$80.5 million) owed for acrylic acid and acrylate esters provided. Taixing Sunke has also obtained an injunction to freeze Taixing Jurong's assets, pending the arbitration outcome. Sunvic Chemical is engaging in discussions to resolve the matter, but will make further announcements if there are developments.

site_title: M&C Q3 profit before tax falls 36%
summary: MILLENNIUM & Copthorne Hotels (M&C) reported a 36% decline in profit before tax for the third quarter, falling to £34 million, due to lower hotel revenue and increased operating costs. Hotel revenue dropped 2.2% and total revenue declined 2.3% in the same period. The company cited challenging trading conditions, including supply growth and rising labor costs, and plans to address these issues through product innovation and cost control.

site_title: Singapore's manufacturing growth slows further in October
summary: Singapore's manufacturing growth slowed for the second consecutive month in October, with a Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) of 51.9, the lowest level since August 2017. The sector continued to grow for the 26th consecutive month, but saw slower growth in new orders, exports, and factory output. The electronics sector PMI declined to 50.5, its lowest reading since November 2016, attributed to trade tensions between the US and China. Economists predict a lacklustre manufacturing growth for the fourth quarter of 2018.

site_title: SLNG mulls fifth tank as LNG trade turns more liquid
summary: Singapore LNG Corp plans to explore the demand for a fifth storage tank at its Jurong Island terminal amid surging LNG trading activity, mainly driven by China's high demand. The move comes as the company owns and operates four storage tanks with a total capacity of 800,000 cubic meters. Wood Mackenzie director Nicholas Browne expects a further liquidity boost from new supplies, benefiting terminals that can import and export LNG, particularly in Asia.

images.alt_text: SLNG now owns and operates four storage tanks with total capacity of 800,000 cubic metres. Its terminal on Jurong Island is the first open-access, multi-user facility of its kind in Singapore, designed to back a developing LNG trading hub here.

site_title: SLNG to sound market for fifth storage tank
summary: Singapore LNG Corp plans to explore the market for a fifth storage tank at its Jurong Island terminal, driven by increasing LNG trading activity and China's growing demand for the cleaner-burning fuel. The company will issue a non-binding expression of interest to gauge market demand, with the goal of determining whether to construct the additional tank. SLNG currently operates four storage tanks with a total capacity of 800,000 cubic meters.

site_title: Hyflux applies for super priority for rescue financing
summary: Hyflux has applied to the Singapore High Court for super priority rescue financing, seeking more time to put its restructuring plan to a creditors' vote by April. The proposal involves a consortium between Salim Group and Medco Group's SM Investments, which will provide a S$400 million equity injection and loans in exchange for a 60% stake in Hyflux and management continuity. The deal is subject to creditor and regulatory approval.

site_title: SingPost's Q2 profit falls 12.9%, weighed down by one-off item
summary: SingPost reported a 12.9% decline in Q2 net profit to S$25.1 million, impacted by a fair value loss of S$2.9 million. Excluding this, underlying net profit rose 0.4%. Revenue increased 2.2% to S$368.7 million, driven by higher post and parcel, and property segments. Operating expenses declined 0.4%. The company's eCommerce segment saw operating losses widen to S$11.2 million, primarily due to US pricing pressures.

site_title: US: Stocks lifted by jobs data but Apple shares fall
summary: US stocks rose 0.7% to 25,561.72 after strong jobs data, with the Dow and S&P 500 gaining 0.5% each. The Nasdaq Composite Index edged up 0.2% despite Apple's 4.9% drop due to lower-than-expected iPhone sales and disappointing fourth-quarter sales outlook. US unemployment remained steady at 3.7%, while wages rose 3.1% above the year-ago level, boosting investor sentiment. A report on US-China trade negotiations also lifted market expectations.

site_title: 'National Jealousy Day': Finland goes public with citizens' taxes
summary: Finland releases its citizens' taxable income publicly on November 1, sparking a national discussion about income inequality and tax transparency. The practice, known as "National Jealousy Day," has been in place since the 19th century and is seen as a way to promote transparency and accountability. While some argue it invades privacy, others believe it helps reduce inequality and encourages employers to pay their employees more. The data release also shines a light on the country's wealthiest citizens, including tech entrepreneurs and celebrities.

site_title: Financial, infrastructure links get boost with over 10 MOUs inked at first Chongqing-Singapore financial summit
summary: Over 500 business leaders and government officials attended the first Chongqing-Singapore financial summit, resulting in over 10 memoranda of understanding (MOUs) signed. The agreements aim to enhance regional connectivity under China's Belt and Road Initiative and the Chongqing Connectivity Initiative Southern Transport Corridor. Collaborations include fintech development, microfinance, and inclusive finance in China's western region, with potential benefits for trade and investment between the two regions.

site_title: Search teams recover chairs, wheels from Lion Air crash site
summary: Search teams in Indonesia have recovered chairs and wheels from the wreckage site of the Lion Air crash, which killed 189 people. The Boeing-737 MAX 8 jet plummeted into the Java Sea shortly after takeoff, raising concerns about mechanical faults. Authorities have analyzed black box data, which may explain the cause of the crash, and dozens of body bags containing remains have been recovered. The search continues, with hopes that more victims can be found in the bulk of the wreckage.

site_title: SGX imposes fine, education programme on UOB Kay Hian trader
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has imposed a fine of S$25,000 and required UOB Kay Hian trading representative Seow Jin Yuan Reymond to attend an education programme for violating exchange rules. The Disciplinary Committee found Reymond guilty of contravening rules in March and April 2017, including pre-arranged trades and acting as principal without informing customers. Reymond admitted to all four charges and the SGX will consider the second and third charges for sentencing purposes.

site_title: PACC Offshore Services posts Q3 net loss of US$5.3m
summary: PACC Offshore Services Holdings (POSH) reported a Q3 net loss of US$5.3 million, narrowing 8% from the same period last year. Revenue increased 52% to US$79.7 million, driven by higher contributions from its Offshore Accommodation (OA) segment. The OA segment's revenue doubled to US$46.2 million, with a gross profit of US$14 million. However, the Transportation & Installation segment saw a decline, and the Offshore Supply Vessel (OSV) segment's gross loss increased to US$1 million. The company expects charter rates for OA shallow water segment to continue firming up, but OSV charter rates remain under pressure due to oversupply.

site_title: NetLink NBN Trust to pay H1 DPU of 2.44¢
summary: NetLink NBN Trust posted a 43.9% increase in Q2 net profit to S$18.7 million, exceeding forecast, with a DPU of 2.44 Singapore cents. Revenue rose 39.9% year-over-year, driven by growth in fibre business and joint-build projects with Singtel. The trust's earnings per unit increased to 0.48 Singapore cents, and net asset value remained stable at 79.2 Singapore cents per unit. The manager expects the trust to meet FY2019's projected residential and non-residential fibre connections, despite potential revenue hit from lower installation revenues.

site_title: Singapore shares jump 1.8% on Friday
summary: Singapore shares rose 1.8% on Friday, closing at 3,116.39, with the Straits Times Index gaining 55.54 points. About 2.56 billion shares worth S$1.55 billion were traded at an average unit price of S$0.60. Gainers outnumbered losers 309 to 130, with Genting Singapore and Thomson Medical Group being the most actively traded stocks.

site_title: Challenger Tech Q3 net profit up 44%
summary: Challenger Technologies reported a 44% increase in net profit to S$4.5 million for Q3, driven by improved trade show and corporate sales, as well as cost-control efforts. Revenue rose 6% to S$82.5 million, mainly due to higher contributions from IT products and services. Earnings per share increased to 1.31 Singapore cents. The company remains cautious about the retail business environment and will continue cost-management measures while exploring business opportunities with strategic partners.

site_title: NetLink NBN Trust announces H1 DPU of 2.44 Singapore cents
summary: NetLink NBN Trust announced a distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.44 Singapore cents for the first half-year, beating forecast by 5.2%. The trust's net profit rose 43.9% to S$18.7 million, driven by higher diversion revenue and ducts and manholes service revenue. Residential connections grew 2% to 1.24 million, while non-residential connections rose 1.6% to 45,514. The trust's full-year DPU is expected to be 4.88 cents, 5.2% higher than forecast.

site_title: China Everbright Water bags 1.05b yuan water treatment contracts with Shandong government
summary: China Everbright Water has secured 1.05 billion yuan (S$208.03 million) in contracts with the Shandong government for three waste water treatment projects in Zibo City. The company will invest and operate the projects under a BOOT or BOT model, with a 30-year concession period. The projects will upgrade existing plants to meet national Grade 1A water standards, with improved treatment capacities and reduced discharge indicators. The contracts are expected to boost operational efficiency and economic benefits, solidifying Everbright Water's position in the local market.

site_title: SPH unit to subscribe for 30% stake in sgCarMart Financial Services
summary: SPH unit Quotz subscribed for 1.5 million shares of sgCarMart Financial Services, a 30% stake, for S$1.5 million. The remaining 70% is held by T Financial and five other parties. The transaction won't affect SPH's net tangible assets or earnings per share.

site_title: New Toys 'R' Us owners mull physical stores next year
summary: Hedge funds Solus Alternative Asset Management and Angelo Gordon plan to relaunch Toys 'R' Us as a standalone operation next year, with plans to open brick-and-mortar locations. They will initially partner with Kroger Co to create pop-up sections in 600 stores, selling toys from brands like Imaginarium and Journey Girls. The relaunch faces challenges, including the loss of intellectual property rights and a significant number of job losses, with former workers protesting the decision.

site_title: UIC Q3 net profit down 36% on lower sales
summary: UIC, a Singapore property group, reported a 36% decline in net profit to S$59.3 million in Q3, primarily due to lower sales recognition from trading properties. Revenue fell 63% to S$151.9 million, with S$11.7 million from trading properties, a 96% decrease from last year. Despite this, revenue from property investments and hotel operations rose, while information technology operations increased. The company expects office rentals to remain well-supported, but retail rentals to remain soft.

site_title: In controversial shift, Japan aims to open door wider for foreign blue-collar workers
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's cabinet approved a draft legislation to open the door to more overseas blue-collar workers in sectors with labor shortages, amid an ageing and shrinking population. The revised law would create two new visa categories for foreigners, with a focus on skills and Japanese language ability. The move is seen as a shift in immigration policy, despite the government's claims it's not. The bill is expected to be adopted by parliament, despite opposition from some parties and concerns about crime and wages.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks jump most in 7 years; won sees best day in 21 months
summary: Seoul's stocks jumped 3.53% on Friday, marking their best day in almost seven years, driven by expectations of progress in Sino-US trade negotiations. The won saw its best day in 21 months, rising 1.47% against the dollar. Large-cap firms, including Samsung Electronics and LG Chem, rose 4.7% and 5.6%, respectively. Analysts attributed the rally to reduced global uncertainties and hopes of a potential trade agreement between the US and China ahead of the US midterm election.

site_title: Australia shares turn up as report spurs Sino-US trade deal hopes; NZ slips
summary: Australian shares rose 0.14% on Friday, driven by a report suggesting US President Donald Trump is taking steps to resolve a trade dispute with China, boosting risk appetite. Materials stocks, especially miners, dominated the gains, with the metals and mining index climbing 1.3%. China is Australia's biggest trade partner and a major buyer of its commodities. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.09% as airline operator Air New Zealand Ltd declined 0.8%.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 6.95 points to 1,713.87 on Friday, driven by gains in the stock market. The index saw a volume of 3.1 billion lots worth RM2.5 billion, with 744 gainers beating 204 losers.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Sembcorp Industries signed a 25-year deal for one of Singapore's largest rooftop solar farms. Over 500 business leaders attended the Chongqing-Singapore financial summit, with multiple Memoranda of Understanding (MOUs) inked. Singapore sovereign wealth fund GIC appointed two new board directors, including Lawrence Wong. China Everbright Water secured 1.05 billion yuan (S$208.03 million) in water treatment contracts. Shangri-La Asia sold an S$825 million seven-year bond at 4.50% and Singapore shares jumped 1.8% on Friday.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon at 3,090.85, up 1% on the day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading at 3,090.85, up 1% on Friday, with 1.07 billion shares changing hands worth S$631.1 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 215 to 138, led by Genting Singapore's 5.06% rise. Other notable gains came from DBS Group and UOB, adding 1.8% and 1.7% respectively.

site_title: China urged to move 'beyond reform rhetoric' at trade expo
summary: European ambassadors and foreign business groups are urging China to introduce concrete market reforms at the upcoming Shanghai trade fair, citing a lack of action on promises made in the past. China's President Xi Jinping has raised expectations, but trading partners remain skeptical, citing preferential treatment, joint venture requirements, and intellectual property violations. The EU Chamber of Commerce calls for China to "move beyond rhetoric" and address the "reform deficit" to ease tensions with major trading partners.

site_title: Trump said to ask cabinet to draft possible trade deal with Xi
summary: US President Donald Trump has asked his cabinet to draft a possible trade deal with Chinese President Xi Jinping ahead of the Group of 20 nations summit in Argentina. The push for a deal comes after a telephone call between Trump and Xi, during which they discussed trade and North Korea. Trump's request for a deal signals a potential ceasefire in the escalating trade conflict, which has seen the US impose tariffs on $250 billion in trade with China. The draft deal is expected to focus on narrowing the trade deficit and intellectual property theft.

site_title: Venture Corp Q3 net profit falls 27.5%, misses street estimates
summary: Venture Corp reported a 27.5% decline in Q3 net profit to S$80.8 million, missing street estimates. Revenue fell 27.4% to S$770.4 million due to customer transitions to new products and M&A activities. The company expects revenue to improve sequentially in the next quarter driven by new product introductions and strategic alliances. However, it remains cautious about macroeconomic risks, particularly from a major escalation of the trade war. Despite this, Venture Corp maintains its long-term resilience and stability through its broad-based portfolio of technology domains and supply chain management.

site_title: EU commerce chamber urges China to go beyond rhetoric at import fair
summary: The European Chamber of Commerce in China's Shanghai chapter urges China to move beyond rhetoric and implement promised reforms, citing a trade deficit and raised expectations following President Xi Jinping's speech at the World Economic Forum. The China International Import Expo, starting November 5, is seen as an opportunity for China to demonstrate its willingness to open its economy. The chamber expects clear timelines for reforms, but notes that the expo may not resolve the country's structural reform deficit.

site_title: A phone call and hint of trade deal send Asia shares shooting up
summary: Asian stocks surged, with the MSCI Asia Pacific Index rising 2.3% as US President Donald Trump said his Chinese counterpart wanted to make a deal to end the escalating trade war. The news led to gains in Hong Kong, Shanghai, Japan, South Korea, and Singapore. Tech companies in the MSCI Asia Pacific Index rose 3.5%, while Chinese President Xi Jinping pledged a better environment for domestic private companies. The rally was also boosted by a report that the US will allow eight countries to continue buying Iranian oil after sanctions are reimposed.

site_title: Shangri-La Asia sells S$825m 7-year bonds at 4.50%
summary: SHANGRI-LA Asia sold S$825 million 7-year bonds at 4.50% in a deal that saw over S$1 billion in orderbooks from 51 accounts, led by DBS Bank and United Overseas Bank. The bonds, guaranteed by the issuer, were priced lower than initial guidance, making it the largest senior dated bullet bond from an unrated corporate issuer in Singapore's debt capital markets in 20 years. Investors, familiar with the issuer, drove demand for the bonds, making it an attractive asset for banks and other investors.

site_title: Jho Low denies wrongdoing after US charges over 1MDB
summary: Malaysian financier Jho Low denies wrongdoing after the US Justice Department unveiled criminal charges against him and two ex-Goldman Sachs bankers, accusing them of laundering billions of dollars from state fund 1MDB and bribing officials. Low, who was an associate of former Malaysian leader Najib Razak, maintains his innocence, stating he had no formal position at 1MDB and was presumed innocent until proven guilty. The US charges are the first over the huge 1MDB scandal, which has spawned investigations worldwide, with Low currently believed to be in China.

site_title: China-Singapore FTA upgrade likely to be signed this month: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore and China are set to sign an upgraded free trade agreement (FTA) later this month, a deal three years in the making. The enhanced pact will provide greater trade facilitation and investment protection, covering areas such as legal and financial services, e-commerce, and the environment. The signing is seen as a positive message to the international community, promoting free trade. The upgraded FTA is expected to boost investments, create employment opportunities, and improve living standards, with imported goods becoming cheaper due to simplified customs procedures.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Friday; STI rises 0.8% to 3,085.93
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.8% to 3,085.93 on its last trading day of the week, driven by gains in stocks like OCBC Bank and CityDev. The index saw 48.2 million shares change hands, with Genting Singapore being the most actively traded counter. The rally in Singapore mirrored a similar trend in Tokyo stocks, which rose 0.39% and in US stocks, which rose for a third consecutive session on Thursday amid positive corporate earnings reports and hopes for US-China trade talks resolution.

site_title: Asia: Markets surge as Trump tweet lifts trade hopes
summary: Asian markets surged on Friday after US President Donald Trump's tweet hailing positive talks with Chinese President Xi Jinping lifted trade hopes. Hong Kong and Shanghai led the gains, with Hong Kong rising over 2% and Shanghai jumping over 1%. The yuan also recovered, jumping almost 1% to 6.9151 per dollar. Trump's tweet sparked optimism, with dealers hoping for a breakthrough in the trade row. Markets were also boosted by a report that British Prime Minister Theresa May had reached a post-Brexit deal with Brussels, securing access to the EU for Britain's finance sector.

site_title: The Cambodian textile factory that craves 'normal' working conditions
summary: A Cambodian textile factory, Pactics Group Ltd, is credited for offering "normal" working conditions, including childcare, work in environmentally-friendly buildings, and benefits such as health insurance and free medicines. President Piet Holten credits these benefits for attracting and retaining employees, despite the factory's slim profit margins. However, workers' rights advocate Khun Tharo argues that wages should still be increased to match the minimum wage, as workers are struggling to save money and live decently. The factory's approach is seen as a rare example of a successful model in a sector plagued by exploitation and abuse.

site_title: Sembcorp inks 25-year deal for one of Singapore's largest rooftop solar farms
summary: Sembcorp Industries has signed a 25-year deal to install, own, and operate solar panels on two facilities in Singapore, creating one of the largest rooftop solar farms in the city-state. The 6.2 megawatt peak solar farm will produce 7,435 megawatt hours of power annually, equivalent to powering 1,500 four-room HDB flats for a year and avoiding 3 million kilograms of carbon dioxide emissions. The deal expands Sembcorp's solar portfolio to over 115 megawatts peak and supports Singapore's goal of achieving 350 megawatts peak of solar power capacity by 2020.

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei jumps more than 2.5%
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index rose 2.56% on Friday, closing at 22,243.66, driven by hopes of a potential breakthrough on the US-China trade dispute. The broader Topix index also increased 1.64%. The surge follows recent US President Trump's threats to extend tariffs on Chinese imports, which traders have largely brushed off. The market gains come despite ongoing US-EU trade talks and ongoing economic uncertainty.

site_title: Chinese stocks are sending a scary signal about the economy
summary: China's consumer spending, a key driver of the economy, is showing signs of slowing down, sending a scary signal about the country's economic health. Retail sales growth has been slowing, with official data and company reports, such as Kweichow Moutai Co's weakest profit expansion in almost three years, fueling investor alarm. Authorities are taking steps to shore up spending, including tax cuts and stimulus measures, but analysts remain cautious on the prospects for spending during key holiday periods, including Singles' Day and the lunar new year holidays.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks build on rally at Friday's open
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged over 2% on Friday, following a Wall Street rally and boosted by trade talk hopes. The Hang Seng Index rose 2.22% to 25,980.44, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased by 1.65% and 1.96% respectively. The gains came amid upbeat comments from US President Donald Trump, supporting trade talks.

site_title: Trump, Xi eye G-20 talks after 'very good' phone call
summary: US President Donald Trump and Chinese leader Xi Jinping had a "very good" phone call, discussing trade and other issues. Trump said trade talks were "moving along nicely" and meetings were planned at the G-20 summit in Buenos Aires. Xi emphasized the importance of good relations with Trump and expressed hope for a mutually acceptable solution to China-US economic and trade issues. The two leaders also discussed North Korea, with Xi noting positive changes on the Korean peninsula and calling for further denuclearization efforts.

site_title: Investors bristle as Apple's iPhone data goes the way of its headphone jacks
summary: Apple has stopped reporting unit sales data for its iPhone, iPad, and Mac products, a move that has sent shares down about 7% in after-hours trading. The decision, which analysts say is a sign of the company's shift towards bundled products and services, will instead provide cost-of-sales data for both its total product businesses and services. This change gives investors more transparency into Apple's gross margin, particularly for its lucrative services business, which reached $10 billion in its fiscal fourth quarter. However, the lack of margin mix information within services remains a concern.

site_title: Stakes are high for Mahathir in first budget back as Malaysian PM
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad is facing a tough balancing act in his government's first budget, which may include a higher deficit target, higher debt, and slower economic growth. Economists expect a 3.2% deficit this year and next, and credit-default swaps have risen due to concerns over the A3 rating. Mahathir needs to find more revenue and control debt without angering voters and stalling the economy with higher taxes and spending cuts. The budget will be delivered by Finance Minister Lim Guan Eng on Friday.

site_title: Trump threatens to shoot migrants who throw stones at US military
summary: President Donald Trump warned US soldiers deployed to the Mexican border could shoot migrants who throw stones at them, calling it "viciously and violently" behavior. He made the statement after a group of migrants threw rocks at Mexican police while attempting to cross the border illegally. Trump said the military will "fight back" against such actions, escalating tensions at the border.

site_title: Malaysia shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.68 points to 1,709.60 on Friday, with a trading volume of 48.81 million lots worth RM20.81 million. Gainers outpaced losers 116 to 48, as the market opened higher.

site_title: SingPost Q2 profit down 12.9% to S$25.1m as one-off item weighs
summary: SingPost's Q2 net profit fell 12.9% to S$25.1m due to a one-off fair value loss of S$2.9m from warrants. Excluding this, underlying net profit rose 0.4% to S$28.1m. Operating profit increased 33.5% to S$40m, driven by a 5.1% rise in post and parcel profit. The company's eCommerce segment saw operating losses widen to S$11.2m, while its logistics business posted an operating profit.

site_title: Japanese maker of train in deadly Taiwan crash finds design flaw
summary: A Japanese train manufacturer, Nippon Sharyo, has discovered a design flaw in the wiring of its automatic train protection system, which failed to alert the central control system that the speed-control system had been turned off. The flaw was found in 19 train sets built for Taiwan, including the one that derailed in October, killing 18 people and injuring 187. The company has not determined whether to fix the wiring, which is up to the Taiwan rail authority. The discovery led to a 17% drop in Nippon Sharyo's shares.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembcorp, SingPost, Moya Asia, Yongnam, Hock Liang Seng, Mapletree Logistics Trust
summary: Sembcorp Industries posted an 11.6% drop in net profit to S$82.33 million for the third fiscal quarter due to a challenging marine division environment. Singapore Post saw its net profit dip 12.9% to S$25.1 million, while Moya Asia reported a 25% jump in net profit to S$6.9 million. Yongnam Holdings secured four Singapore-based contracts worth S$53.4 million, and Hock Lian Seng posted a 55.7% increase in net profit to S$10.4 million. Mapletree Logistics Trust acquired a warehouse in Vietnam for approximately S$43 million.

site_title: Home-sales platform paves way for paperless transactions
summary: Singapore's home-sales platform Showsuite has launched the country's first fully digitalised sales-booking platform, saving developers and property agents from using thousands of sheets of paper. The platform uses 3D and virtual reality technology to enable digital transactions, reducing waiting time and environmental impact. Park Colonial and Roxy-Pacific are among the first to adopt the platform, with over 100 sales made since its launch in August. This move aims to improve productivity and streamline processes, aligning with the Real Estate Industry Transformation Map's objectives.

site_title: Keppel Land unit converts 49% of developer Nam Long convertible bonds
summary: Keppel Land's indirect subsidiary Ibeworth has converted 49% of its $29.5 million convertible bonds into shares of housing developer Nam Long Investment Corporation (NLG), increasing Keppel's stake to around 10% of NLG's issued shares. This move follows the conversion of 500 billion Vietnamese dong (S$29.5 million) bonds into shares at a price of 18,142 dong per share. The conversion is part of Ibeworth's strategy to acquire a larger stake in NLG.

site_title: Netanyahu hails Brazil leader's plan to move embassy to Jerusalem
summary: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu praised Brazilian President-elect Jair Bolsonaro for planning to move his country's embassy to Jerusalem, a move that would make Brazil the second country after the US to do so. Bolsonaro tweeted about the plan, stating he would transfer the embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem. The move is seen as a significant step, with Brazil's embassy transfer being the largest since the US in 2018.

site_title: US accuses China, Taiwan firms with stealing secrets from chip giant Micron
summary: US Attorney General Jeff Sessions accused Beijing of backing a scheme by Chinese and Taiwan companies to steal $8.75 billion worth of trade secrets from semiconductor giant Micron. Criminal charges were filed against Chinese state-owned Fujian Jinhua Integrated Circuit and Taiwan's United Microelectronics Corporation (UMC) for conspiring to steal Micron's advanced designs. The charges are part of a series of cases targeting China's alleged ongoing economic espionage program, posing a major threat to Micron's global market share.

site_title: Hiap Hoe buys Aloft Perth hotel and office building for A$100m
summary: HIAP Hoe has acquired the 224-room Aloft Perth hotel and office building in Western Australia for A$100 million (S$99.2 million). The deal was reached at a willing-buyer, willing-seller basis and will be funded by a mix of internal resources and debt. The acquisition is expected to increase Hiap Hoe's recurrent income streams, with the property boasting high occupancy levels and a diverse mix of bluechip tenants. The completion of the sale is subject to regulatory approvals and agreements.

site_title: Food For The Heart
summary: Three local wellness food makers, Cedele, EGA Juice Clinic, and Craft & Culture, are committed to improving customer health. Cedele, founded by Yeap Cheng Guat in 1997, offers healthy breads and salads with no additives or preservatives. EGA Juice Clinic, co-founded by Sumit Nanda and Dr. Ratheesh, promotes preventive healthcare through detox diets and natural supplements. Craft & Culture, founded by Winnie Ong and Lai Zhiwei, produces fermented drinks like kombucha and kefir. These businesses prioritize customer health and satisfaction, with a focus on longevity and sustainability.

site_title: Google workers walk out in global protest over harassment
summary: Thousands of Google employees worldwide participated in a coordinated walkout on November 1, 2018, to protest the company's handling of sexual harassment. The protest, called the "Google Walkout For Real Change," aimed to bring about meaningful action to ensure employee safety. The walkout followed allegations of misconduct against senior executives and the company's lack of action in addressing the issue. CEO Sundar Pichai apologized for past actions and stated that Google is committed to providing a safe and inclusive workplace.

site_title: Study of cellphone risks finds link, with a few caveats, to cancer in rats
summary: A federal agency has released the final results of a 30-million-dollar study on cellphone risks, finding a link between radio waves and brain cancer in male rats. The study, which involved 3,000 rodents, found a 2-3% risk of malignant gliomas in male rats exposed to radiation, compared to none in a control group. However, experts caution that the exposure levels were far greater than what humans encounter and the study examined outdated cellphone technology. The findings have implications for current cellphone users, but the risk is considered relatively modest and the study's results are not directly comparable to human exposure.

site_title: Destination Hotels
summary: Five hotels worth seeking out include Ett Hem in Stockholm, Sweden, offering Nordic chic with unique rooms; Setouchi Aonagi in Japan, a minimalist retreat with Tadao Ando's signature design; Bella Vista Spa and Marina in Japan, a luxe resort with panoramic views; Casa San Agustin in Colombia, a colonial home-turned-urban-retreat; and Qasr Al Sarab in Abu Dhabi, a luxurious desert resort with rustic Arabian charm. Each hotel offers a distinct travel experience, from elegant contemporary homes to minimalist comforts and stunning natural scenery.

site_title: Skeletons unearthed in giant UK train line excavation
summary: Archaeologists have unearthed the first 1,200 skeletons from a 40,000-person burial site in St James Gardens, London, as part of the HS2 high-speed rail project. The site, a former cemetery between 1788 and 1853, has revealed well-preserved graves, including an intact wooden coffin with a skeleton having a twisted spine and full set of teeth. The excavation, one of Britain's largest, will help researchers understand life and death during Britain's industrialization, with discoveries including evidence of tuberculosis, traumatic injuries, and early dentistry.

site_title: US charges 2 ex-Goldman Sachs bankers in Malaysia's 1MDB scandal
summary: The US Justice Department has charged two former Goldman Sachs bankers, Ng Chong Hwa and Tim Leissner, with conspiracy to commit bribery and money laundering in the 1MDB scandal. Leissner, who has already pleaded guilty, was charged alongside Ng, who was arrested in Malaysia. The men allegedly conspired to launder billions of dollars from 1MDB, a Malaysian sovereign wealth fund, and bribed officials in Malaysia and Abu Dhabi. Goldman Sachs was not charged, but was referred to as "financial institution #1" in the indictment, and is cooperating with the probe.

site_title: Europe: Strong earnings from ING, BT help shares to two-week high
summary: European shares reached a two-week high on Thursday, driven by strong earnings from Dutch bank ING and UK telecoms group BT, which offset a disappointing update from Credit Suisse. The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.2% and Germany's DAX declined 0.1%. Miner, bank, and retail stocks led the gains, while airlines and travel companies outperformed due to weaker fuel prices. The sector's rally was led by Lufthansa and Air France, while shares in Getinge and TGS fell after disappointing earnings reports.

site_title: Drunk Japan Airlines pilot was 'almost 10 times over limit'
summary: A Japan Airlines pilot was arrested for being drunk before a flight, with a blood alcohol level almost 10 times the legal limit for pilots. The incident occurred on Sunday, just a day after another Japanese carrier reported a hung-over pilot causing multiple delays. The co-pilot passed an in-house breath test but raised suspicions among a bus driver. The pilot's arrest is the latest in a series of incidents involving pilots being drunk on the job.

site_title: US Democrats favoured to take House, Republicans to hold Senate
summary: US midterm elections are underway, with Democrats favored to take control of the House of Representatives and Republicans clinging to the Senate. President Trump is intensifying his campaign efforts, focusing on immigration and anti-Trump rhetoric. The outcome of the Senate will depend on a handful of closely watched races, including Arizona, Florida, and North Dakota. Democrats need a net gain of 23 seats to take control of the House and are predicting victory in the Senate, although FiveThirtyEight.com gives them a 15% chance of winning the Senate.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, extending rallies in New York, as investors watched corporate earnings reports and awaited US jobs data. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.39% or 83.95 points to 21,771.60, while the Topix index gained 0.23% or 3.17 points to 1,635.76. The rally comes amid US-EU trade talks and despite Trump's tariff threats, with stocks in Europe also rising due to mining and healthcare gains.

site_title: DHL Express names Christopher Ong as its new Singapore MD
summary: DHL Express has appointed Christopher Ong as its new managing director for DHL Express Singapore, replacing Frank-Uwe Ungerer. Ong, a Singaporean, will report to Ken Lee, CEO, DHL Express, Asia-Pacific. This appointment comes after Ungerer's tenure ended on January 1, 2016.

site_title: Sembcorp Industries Q3 earnings fall 11.6% to S$82.33m
summary: Sembcorp Industries reported a 11.6% drop in net profit to S$82.33 million for the third fiscal quarter, mainly due to a net loss from its marine division. The division's turnover rose 60.2% to S$1.17 billion, but a loss from the sale of a rig and low business volume impacted earnings. The utilities division saw a 26.7% rise in turnover to S$1.78 billion, while the urban development unit saw a 1.4% net profit drop. The company expects its utilities business to deliver better performance in 2018, but its marine business remains expected to be "relatively low" for the immediate quarters.

site_title: Apple delivers strong profits, but shares slip on outlook
summary: Apple delivered a 32% increase in net profit to $14.13 billion in its recently ended quarter, driven by growing sales of digital content and services. Revenue rose 20% to $62.9 billion, but shares fell 4.2% to $212.85 due to disappointing iPhone sales of 46.9 million and lower-than-expected holiday forecasts. Despite this, Apple reported strong revenue growth and set a record for its September quarter, with services and Mac sales on the rise. The company forecasts $89-93 billion in revenue for the current quarter.

site_title: Germans vent VW fury in mass 'dieselgate'
summary: German consumer groups have filed the country's first class-action suit against Volkswagen over the emissions cheating scandal, known as "dieselgate." The suit, filed by consumer association VZBV, accuses Volkswagen of deliberately harming clients by installing software to make cars appear less polluting than they really were. The lawsuit, which started on November 1, 2018, could benefit an estimated two million VW owners in Germany, with the suit initially representing 10 disgruntled drivers.

site_title: B2B startups 'are where the opportunities lie'
summary: Singapore-based venture capitalists emphasize B2B startups as the investment opportunity of choice, citing the crowded B2C market. Jason Edwards and Cindy Teoh-Cavefors from Qualgro and Golden Equator Capital, respectively, suggest that B2B companies have clearer paths to profitability, but face challenges in securing recurring deals. They predict that the next unicorn in South-east Asia will come from Singapore's insurtech sector, and that B2B startups can capitalize on the region's growth by targeting enterprises.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Mind Your Business - Helping SMEs on their digital transformation journeys
summary: The Money FM podcast "Mind Your Business" discussed Singapore's efforts to become a leading digital economy, focusing on the digital transformation journeys of local SMEs. Gerald Leo, director of commercial partners and SME group at Microsoft Singapore, emphasized the need for SMEs to go digital to seize growth opportunities. The conversation highlighted the challenges and opportunities faced by SMEs in the digital landscape, with a focus on their potential to drive economic growth in Singapore.

site_title: OCBC's all for digital transformation, but is not keen on separate digital bank
summary: OCBC Bank, Singapore's second-largest bank, is prioritizing digital transformation within its existing operations, rather than creating a separate digital bank. CEO Samuel Tsien stated that the bank does not intend to create a digital bank outside of the conventional bank to pursue a digital strategy. Instead, OCBC will focus on a digital transformation throughout the bank, driving costs down and increasing efficiency. The bank aims to reach 60% of digital consumers in its core markets and 70% of small and medium enterprise (SME) digital consumers.

site_title: Australia's October home prices slide, weakest since 2012
summary: Australian home prices slid 0.5% in October, marking the 13th consecutive month of decline, with a 3.5% annual fall, the weakest since 2012. The decline was driven by tightening credit conditions, with regulators clamping down on risky lending and scandals in the industry. Sydney saw the largest drop, 7.4% on the year, while Melbourne's annual drop was 4.7%. The slowdown is attributed to the impact of credit availability on housing demand, with the combined capital cities' values falling 0.6% in the month and 4.6% for the year.

site_title: US: Stocks gain for third straight day; Dow +1.1%
summary: US stocks advanced for the third consecutive day, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 1.1% to 25,380.74. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also gained 1.1% and 1.8%, respectively. The positive momentum was driven by new optimism over US-China trade relations, with US President Donald Trump reporting that talks were "moving along nicely." Some companies, such as Amazon and Caterpillar, saw significant gains, while Alphabet fell due to a global employee protest over sexual misconduct claims.

site_title: Brazil: Stocks close at record high after Bolsonaro win
summary: Brazil's stocks closed at a record high, gaining 3.9% in the week after Jair Bolsonaro's election as president. The Sao Paulo stock exchange's Ibovespa index reached 88,419 points, its first record. Bolsonaro's economic plan, focused on austerity and privatisations, is expected to boost the market. The Brazilian real strengthened to 3.69 to the dollar, driven by optimism over the new administration's reforms, including pension system overhaul. Bolsonaro takes office on January 1, with markets eagerly awaiting the implementation of austerity measures.

site_title: ISR Capital issues clarification on chairman's comments in Mandarin
summary: ISR Capital's trading halt was lifted after executive chairman Chen Tong clarified comments made during an extraordinary general meeting, where shareholders approved a proposed acquisition of a 60% stake in Tantalum Holding. Chen initially stated the acquisition would achieve certain milestones within three years, but later clarified that it didn't mean the project or company would be profitable in three years. The acquisition aims to renew an exploration licence in Madagascar.

site_title: A Year Of Comebacks
summary: The 29th Singapore International Film Festival (SGIFF) is set to take place from November 28 to December 9, 2018. The festival features a lineup of films, including the return of directors Stanley Kwan, Royston Tan, and Rithy Panh, who have been out of the spotlight for some time. Kwan's film "First Night Nerves" and Tan's "15" will have their Southeast Asian premieres, while Panh will receive an honorary award for his documentary work. Other notable attendees include Joan Chen, Daniel Dae Kim, and Carlos Reygadas. The festival also launches the SGIFF Film Fund to support Southeast Asian filmmakers.

site_title: Oil prices drop as wave of supply meets global economic gloom
summary: Oil prices dropped 3% on Thursday, with US crude futures hitting their lowest levels since April, due to a surge in global supply and concerns over a possible slowdown in global growth amid the US-China trade dispute. US crude prices fell 17% below their highs in early October, with Brent crude futures settling down 2.9% at $72.89 a barrel. The US Energy Department reported record US crude output in August, while Opec production also increased, overwhelming concerns about a loss of Iranian barrels.

site_title: StarHub to cease cable services; customers to switch to fibre networks
summary: StarHub, a Singaporean pay-television and broadband provider, will cease its cable services by June 30, 2019, and transition customers to fibre networks. The move is expected to save costs and potentially increase value in the long run. Customers will not incur additional costs for switching to fibre subscriptions, and promotions such as discounted subscriptions and free wireless routers will be offered. Analysts believe that many of StarHub's cable subscribers are late adopters of new technology and will likely switch to fibre services, benefiting the company's overall value per subscriber.

site_title: Google workers walk out to protest harassment, inequality
summary: Google employees and contractors worldwide staged walkouts to protest harassment and inequality, with thousands more expected to follow. The organizers called for changes to Google's human resources practices, pay-equity data, and the addition of an employee representative to the board of directors. Google CEO Sundar Pichai acknowledged the feedback and promised to address it, but the company's shares were unaffected. The walkouts follow a New York Times report on Google's handling of a 2014 sexual harassment allegation against former executive Andy Rubin.

site_title: US indicts Jho Low and ex-Goldman banker
summary: US authorities have indicted Malaysian financier Jho Low and former Goldman Sachs banker Ng Chong Hwa on charges of conspiracy to launder billions of dollars in illegal proceeds from Malaysia's 1MDB wealth fund. Tim Leissner, a former Goldman Sachs banker, has pleaded guilty to laundering money and violating foreign bribery laws, forfeiting $43.7 million. Low remains at large, while Ng was arrested in Malaysia. This is the first time individuals have been charged in the US in relation to the 1MDB scandal, with prosecutors seeking to hold those responsible under the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act.

site_title: Ascott Reit Q3 DPU increases 7.7%
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (Ascott Reit) reported a 7.7% increase in distribution per unit to 1.82 Singapore cents in Q3, driven by revenue from two acquisitions and higher revenue from existing properties. Gross revenue rose 6% to S$134.5 million, while gross profit increased 9.2% to S$64.2 million. The company has a debt headroom of S$810 million, allowing it to pursue accretive acquisitions and reallocate investments into higher-yielding properties.

site_title: Europe: Businesses demand urgent Brexit deal after meeting UK's May
summary: European business leaders, including the European Round Table of Industrialists, urge British Prime Minister Theresa May to find a Brexit deal with the EU as soon as possible due to uncertainty damaging investment and growth. The group expressed concern over a no-deal Brexit, which would harm both the UK and EU economies. The meeting came as May seeks to reassure businesses that Britain remains a good investment destination despite stalled Brexit talks. The EU27 economies would be affected, and the UK's economy has already shrunk for the second month.

site_title: US mid-term elections: All bets are off
summary: US mid-term elections are expected to be highly unpredictable, with most journalists and pollsters hedging their bets due to the tight margins and uncertainty. A six-in-seven chance of a Democratic House and a Republican Senate has been suggested by Nate Silver, while others predict the Democrats may take control of both chambers. The outcome will have significant implications, with a Democratic victory potentially allowing the party to set the legislative agenda, while a Republican win could embolden President Trump and lead to a more centrist Democratic candidate in the 2020 presidential election.

site_title: Use business as a force for good
summary: Singapore's government-backed agencies, GIC and MAS, have invested in tobacco companies like British American Tobacco, contradicting public perceptions of the government's stance on smoking. However, this investment highlights the independence of these agencies and their focus on returns rather than commercial interests. The author suggests that these agencies can use their influence to push tobacco companies towards safer alternatives, creating a "win-win" situation for investors and the public. This could involve moving companies away from cigarette sales and into safer products that have withstood rigorous scientific testing.

site_title: Asian markets build on previous gains
summary: Asian markets continued their upward trend, with Singapore's Straits Times Index rising 1.4% to close at 3,060.85 points, driven by gains from Jardine Cycle & Carriage, OCBC Bank, and DBS. Analysts warn that volatility remains high due to US interest rate concerns and trade tensions, with the US mid-term elections looming. Key indices, such as the Hang Seng and ASX 200, also posted gains, while Tokyo's Nikkei fell 1.1% due to the communications sector's decline.

site_title: ABBA's Back
summary: ABBA's stage show "Mama Mia!" is returning to Singapore at the Sands Theatre at Marina Bay Sands from November 3-18. The musical, which premiered in 1999, has been seen by 60 million people and grossed over $2 billion at the box office worldwide. Praised for its feel-good plot, nostalgic appeal, and feminist overtones, the show features ABBA's hit songs like "Super Trouper" and "Dancing Queen." Tickets are available from S$58.

site_title: Netflix will release 3 prestige movies in theatres first
summary: Netflix will release three prestige movies in theatres first, followed by streaming, in an attempt to win Oscars and woo Hollywood talent. The films, including Roma and The Ballad of Buster Scruggs, will have a limited 1-3 week exclusive theatrical run in the US and overseas, before becoming available on the streaming service. The move is a departure from Netflix's previous policy of releasing movies immediately on streaming.

site_title: Working with top VC managers key to unicorn investing: report
summary: A systematic, diversified approach to investing with top-quartile venture capital managers can help overcome the challenges and risks of investing in unicorns, according to a report by UBS. The report found that even with a high probability of success, the combined probability of success for eight business-critical events for a startup is only 17%.
