Investing in experienced managers, or "unicorn catchers", such as SV Angels, Sequoia Capital, and DST Global, can mitigate risk and deliver high-potential portfolios. UBS Asset Management, which has adopted a systematic approach, has exposure to 30% of the world's unicorn companies and invested in top-performing venture capital managers.

site_title: Vibrant swings to S$88.7m loss on full writedown of Blackgold unit
summary: Vibrant Group reported a net loss of S$88.7 million for the year ended Apr 30, reversing from a profit of S$3.4 million in the previous year. The loss was attributed to a full impairment of its Blackgold unit, which included a writedown of S$63.2 million. Group revenue shrank 5% to S$175.5 million, and the net asset value per share fell to 30.12 cents. The company has decided to focus on its steady growth pipeline and is evaluating a restructuring of its business and strategy.

site_title: Powerful brand names honoured with awards at dinner gala
summary: The 17th annual Singapore Prestige Brand Awards (SPBA) honored powerful brand names at a dinner gala, recognizing their contributions to the Singapore brand. Toast Box was named Overall Winner of the Established Brands category, while B9 Dental Centre won the Promising Brands category. The event also recognized the Management Development Institute of Singapore and Novu as Overall Winners in their respective categories. Minister Ong Ye Kung emphasized the importance of strong brand names in driving successful companies in Singapore, citing their ability to build trust and confidence globally.

images.alt_text: More than 500 business leaders were at the 17th Singapore Prestige Brand Awards dinner on Thursday. Honours were presented in categories for Established, Promising, Heritage and Regional Brands.

site_title: Saumur Champigny, not always appreciated
summary: Cabernet franc wines from the Loire Valley, particularly those from the Saumur region, have struggled to gain widespread popularity despite their merits. A recent tasting of three entry-level wines from the Château Yvonne, Thierry Germain, and Antoine Sanzay producers revealed their unique characteristics, including herbal notes that are a natural part of the cabernet franc identity. While some may find these wines unappealing, they are recommended to try again with different food or in a different season to potentially change their opinion.

site_title: SIA to expand non-stop flights to Seattle
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) will launch non-stop flights to Seattle on September 3, 2019, becoming its fourth non-stop US destination. The airline will initially operate three flights per week, increasing to four times per week in October. The flights will be operated on Airbus A350-900 aircraft, taking approximately 14-16 hours. This expansion is part of SIA's commitment to grow its US operations and provide faster connectivity to North America from key markets in South-east Asia, South Asia, and Australasia.

site_title: Merkel's departure to leave a vacuum in Germany and European Union
summary: Germany is entering a period of uncertainty as Angela Merkel's departure as Chancellor looms, with her term set to end in 2021. The country's stock index has declined 16% since 2018, reflecting concerns over Merkel's potential resignation. Merkel's government coalition has seen a decline in support, potentially leading to a shift in German politics. The EU also faces challenges, including negotiating a Brexit deal and addressing rising populism in other European countries. Merkel's supporters want her to remain Chancellor for three more years, citing the need for stability in the face of global economic uncertainty.

site_title: DesignSingapore Council moves to EDB to help local firms expand overseas
summary: Singapore's DesignSingapore Council, a national agency for design, will transfer to the Economic Development Board (EDB) on April 1, 2019. The move aims to help local companies tap design to expand overseas, driven by rapid technological advancements and growing customer sophistication. The council has encouraged small and medium-sized enterprises to adopt design, leading to productivity growth and business improvements. The transfer will give the council greater autonomy and flexibility to develop partnerships and explore new opportunities. The council's work will continue to support the adoption of design as a strategic tool for businesses and government.

site_title: Best Brew
summary: Nespresso has released its limited edition Explorations collection, featuring four unique single estate and single origin coffees selected by experts. This year's Festive collection also celebrates French culture with three variations. The Explorations coffees include India Mylemoney, Nicaragua Las Marias, Galapagos Santa Cruz, and República Dominicana Valle Del Cibao, considered the best of 2018. The Festive collection is available in Nespresso boutiques and online until a limited time.

site_title: Beijing likely to rely more on fiscal stimulus measures: economists
summary: China's government is expected to rely more on fiscal stimulus to boost the economy due to the central bank's limitations in addressing the slowdown. Policy makers are considering tax cuts, infrastructure spending, and resuming fiscal spending to support economic growth. A 2% cut in the VAT rate could lead to a 0.4% reduction in economic growth, with a wider budget deficit expected in 2019. The People's Bank of China may further lower the reserve requirement ratio to supply cash and reduce banks' costs.

site_title: China's Oct manufacturing takes hit from trade war
summary: China's manufacturing sector experienced a slowdown in October, with the official PMI reading at 50.2, its weakest in two years. The Caixin/Markit PMI edged up slightly to 50.1. Production, business confidence, and new export orders all fell month-on-month, signaling difficulties ahead. The trade war with the US continues to impact demand, and investors are diversifying investments outside China. Economists expect a worse growth slowdown in spring 2019, with potential stimulus measures from the Chinese government to mitigate the impact.

site_title: Aesop's Christmas
summary: Aesop has collaborated with Dutch designer Iris van Herpen to create the "Atlas of Attraction" gift kits for the Christmas season. The kits, priced at S$75, feature Aesop's signature skincare and bodycare items, packaged in reusable amenity cases with customised van Herpen couture patterns. This marks the first time Aesop has offered a home kit, which includes the Istros Aromatique Room Spray, Post-Poo Drops, and Aesop Mouthwash. The kits are available at all Aesop stores and at aesop.com.

site_title: OCBC's Q3 profit jumps 12% to record S$1.25b as repricing kicks in
summary: OCBC Bank reported a 12% jump in Q3 net profit to a record S$1.25 billion, driven by higher margins from repricing loans at higher interest rates. The bank's banking operations saw a 23% increase in net profit, while non-interest income remained stable. OCBC's assets under management for its private bank, Bank of Singapore, rose to US$105 billion. The bank's CEO, Samuel Tsien, noted that trade tension may impact results next year, but the bank's performance has not been affected so far.

site_title: Keto Krunch
summary: BenBanter, a Singapore-based snack brand, offers low-carb, sugar-free, and oil-free products, inspired by the 1800s diet of Will Banting. The brand, owned by entrepreneur Mark Myerson, aims to transform health through diet and lifestyle changes. Its initial range includes power bars, crackers, granola, and chocolate mousse, available online at benbanter.com. Myerson claims to have transformed his own health through a low-carb lifestyle, linking diet to disease prevention.

site_title: FLT buys Dutch freehold logistics property for 25.36m euros
summary: FLT, a Singaporean real estate investment trust, acquired a 31,013 sq m logistics property in the Netherlands for 25.36 million euros (S$39.88 million). The property is fully leased to FrieslandCampina, a Dutch dairy company, and has a 14.9-year lease. The acquisition is expected to increase FLT's footprint in the Dutch logistics sector and is accretive to its distribution per unit. FLT's portfolio value is expected to rise to A$2.9 billion, with 83 properties totaling 2 million sq m.

site_title: Chef plays it safe, but hints of brilliance are there
summary: Chef Aitor Jeronimo Orive has opened his first solo restaurant, Basque Kitchen by Aitor, in Singapore. The restaurant serves traditional Basque cuisine with a twist, incorporating Japanese elements. The menu features dishes such as raw oysters with jelly and anchovy, and oxtail "bomba" rice with confit quail egg yolk. While the food shows flashes of brilliance, it is considered too safe and generic, with some dishes blurring the lines between Basque and Japanese cuisine. The restaurant's rating is 6.5, indicating a good to very good dining experience.

site_title: Former ComfortDelGro CEO Kua Hong Pak dies, aged 74
summary: Former ComfortDelGro Corp CEO Kua Hong Pak, 74, died after a long battle with cancer. He led the transport giant for 14 years, growing its revenue and profit, and is survived by his wife and daughter. Under his tenure, ComfortDelGro's revenue doubled and its profit nearly tripled. He was remembered by colleagues as a dedicated and hands-on leader who prioritized his staff's well-being, never having to retrench anyone during his 14 years at the helm.

site_title: Whoa. Workout leggings that cost US$320?
summary: US company BT has released $320 workout leggings, which are sold out and priced similarly to luxury items. This is not an isolated incident, as the company has previously sold expensive exercise equipment such as $365 foam rollers and $1,000 yoga mats. The leggings' high price may be due to their high-end materials and design, but it has also raised concerns about the commodification of exercise and the pursuit of profit over accessibility.

site_title: GIC is world's third most influential and powerful asset owner
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC has risen to become the world's third most influential and powerful asset owner, surpassing two large US pension funds. GIC's Chief Investment Officer Lim Chow Kiat led the fund's ascent to 3rd in the 2018 CIO Power 100 list, up from 10th in 2017 and 11th in 2016. This achievement solidifies GIC's position as a significant player in global investments.

images.alt_text: "This award is a recognition of the work of all at GIC," says Mr Lim, who was appointed the sovereign wealth fund's CEO on Jan 1, 2017.

site_title: That Lofty Feeling
summary: A couple, Sharon Foo and Ronald Huang, purchased a compact apartment in Bukit Timah, Singapore, with a high ceiling that made it feel like a penthouse. The 123 sq m apartment, with three bedrooms and a basement, was designed by architect Tan Sok Tuan to maximize the space. The high ceiling was utilized to create a loft in the master bedroom, guest room, and additional storage space. The couple, who met recently, incorporated their individual styles into the design, with Sharon preferring blue accents and Ronald having his own private space. The apartment's unique layout and high ceiling have created a calming atmosphere, allowing the couple to enjoy their home despite their busy schedules.

images.alt_text: The double volume living room.
The couple's bedroom with steps leading to a loft.
A colourful painting adds vibrancy to the home.
A seamless connection between the indoor living area and the outdoor dining area.
A loft that has been converted into a walk-in wardrobe.
The loft area which overlooks the living and dining areas.

site_title: DBS, Agrocorp launch blockchain platform for commodity trades
summary: DBS Bank, in collaboration with Distributed Ledger Technologies and Agrocorp International, has launched a blockchain platform for commodity trades. The platform enables real-time transactions, updates, and transparency, reducing the time and cost associated with physical documents and payments. The platform currently connects 4,500 Australian farmers to global end-customers and aims to expand to other origin markets such as Canada, Myanmar, and Ukraine. The initiative is expected to revolutionize the supply chain, making it faster, more efficient, and more transparent.

site_title: Future of customer service and retention rests on cloud
summary: The future of customer service and retention relies heavily on cloud computing, which enables businesses to connect every part of the enterprise and make customers the center of decision-making. By integrating customer data across various channels and business silos, businesses can provide personalized, seamless, and predictive experiences. Cloud applications facilitate this integration, allowing for a single point of view on customer data and enabling real-time engagement and feedback. Companies such as Zalora, Killem Pest, and Jetstar are already experiencing the benefits of cloud-based customer-centricity, including increased customer loyalty and revenue.

site_title: Why we fail at grading workers, in BT Weekend
summary: A current system of grading and ranking employees is widely criticized as ineffective and demotivating. Companies like GSK have shifted away from traditional performance appraisals, instead using data and analytics to evaluate employee performance. This approach allows for more objective and personalized feedback. Experts argue that this method can lead to increased employee satisfaction and engagement, but caution against blind emulation of Scandinavian workplace happiness models, as they may not be suitable for all regions.

site_title: Euro, emerging markets rebound as investors return to risk
summary: The euro rebounded to a 2½-month high, rising to US$1.1389, as investors returned to risk-taking after a month of caution. The dollar index fell 0.5% to 96.642, while the Australian, New Zealand, Swedish, and Norwegian currencies also surged. Emerging markets, including the offshore Chinese yuan, also rebounded versus the dollar. Analysts attribute the shift to hopes of Chinese fiscal stimulus and improved investor sentiment, but some warn that the US economy's performance could undermine the dollar's gains.

site_title: Tran Uyen Phuong
summary: Tan Hiep Phuong, deputy CEO of Vietnam's largest private beverage company, Tan Hiep Phat Beverage Group, shares her story of building the $1 billion empire with her parents. Born into a family business, Phuong joined immediately after university and has been instrumental in its success, including launching her second book, "Competing with Giants," which details the company's rise to prominence. With a strong work ethic and dedication to her job, Phuong credits her father's lessons, such as speaking up and gaining trust, for her success.

site_title: Consumer insights and trends seminar open for registration
summary: A Nielsen survey found that consumers in emerging countries are more receptive to innovation and disruption than those in developed countries, despite larger marketing budgets in developed countries. Singapore consumers are highly wired, owning an average of 3.7 connected devices. The Outlook 2019 Seminar for small and medium-sized enterprises will focus on consumer trends, economic outlook, and geopolitical developments, featuring speakers from various fields, including business and academia.

site_title: Seeing Stars
summary: Michelin-starred chefs from Ritz Carlton's Asia Pacific properties are touring four food capitals, starting in Singapore, for a month-long Stellar Dining series. The inaugural event features a six-hands collaboration of Chinese cuisine, with three Michelin-starred chefs preparing special dim sum creations. The event, priced at S$258 per person, runs from Nov 1-3 at The Ritz-Carlton, Millennia Singapore. The series also includes innovative desserts and cocktails at the Colony restaurant and Chihuly Lounge, with Executive Pastry Chef Richard Long and mixologist Oscar Mena participating.

site_title: One black box recovered from crashed Indonesia jet
summary: Indonesia's National Transportation Safety Committee announced the recovery of one black box from the crashed Lion Air jet, a Boeing-737 MAX 8 that killed 189 people on October 29, 2018. The device is believed to be a flight data recorder or cockpit voice recorder, and its recovery is critical to determining the cause of the crash. The search for the plane's fuselage continues, with divers and helicopters working to locate the wreckage in the Java Sea. Authorities have ruled out finding survivors, and forensic specialists have identified the first victim, a 24-year-old woman, whose remains were cremated and returned to her hometown.

site_title: 78 Shenton Way being sold to PGIM Real Estate
summary: US-based PGIM Real Estate has entered into a deal to buy 78 Shenton Way in Singapore for nearly S$1,900 per square foot on net lettable area (NLA), translating to around S$680 million. The property, comprising two office towers, has a balance lease term of about 64 years. The sale involves a complex structure, with PGIM Real Estate potentially agreeing to make a further payment if redevelopment schemes proposed by the seller, Alpha Investment Partners, are approved by the planning authority.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Independent financial advisers can no longer hedge their bets when giving opinions
summary: Independent Financial Advisers (IFAs) in Singapore are now required to give clear, understandable advice to minority shareholders, without conditional recommendations. A recent study examined the cases of Wheelock Properties and Vard Holdings, which received conflicting advice from their IFAs. The Securities Industries Council (SIC) amended its 2014 Practice Note in February last year, setting new guidelines for IFA advice in takeover transactions. The revised guidelines aim to ensure that IFAs properly serve minority shareholders, who ultimately receive the advice.

site_title: Digital connectivity will enhance trade processes across Asean
summary: Asean has implemented the Asean Single Window (ASW) to streamline customs procedures and enhance trade processes across member economies. Established in 2005, the ASW requires 10 National Single Windows in each Asean member country, allowing for a single submission of import and export data. The initiative aims to improve efficiency, reduce costs, and increase transparency in trade transactions. Currently, five Asean members, including Singapore, Malaysia, and Vietnam, are operational, with efforts underway to expand the system to other members.

site_title: Girls' Getaway
summary: A "Girls' Getaway" retreat, Sucimurni Retreat, Women's Edition, is offered at the Tanjong Jara Resort in Terengganu, Malaysia. The 2-day retreat (Nov 17-19) features wellness activities, including sound healing, yoga, and massage, as well as batik-making and Malay cooking. Prices start from S$333++. The event aims to promote the Malay concept of Sucimurni, emphasizing purity of spirit, health, and well-being.

site_title: Sears turning out to be wrong kind of anchor for Reit
summary: Seritage Growth Properties, a real estate investment trust (Reit) spun off from Sears Holdings, is facing significant financial challenges due to its close ties to the struggling retailer. Sears' bankruptcy could lead to a substantial decrease in Seritage's cash flow, with estimates suggesting a quarterly loss of $133 million. The Reit's cash reserves are limited, with $580 million in cash and $400 million in financing available, but its cash will likely be depleted within a year. Seritage's valuation is also at risk, with some analysts estimating its true value to be significantly lower than its current stock price.

site_title: Self-Made Art
summary: Ashidiq Ghazali, a renowned creative director, is now exploring self-made art. His abstract geometrical paintings are on display at Telok Ayer Arts Club in Singapore until November 14. Ghazali, who has worked with top agencies and won Cannes Lion, is inspired by his love of art, advertising, and music-making. This marks a new creative outlet for the 1990s rap duo member and deejay. The exhibit is free admission at 2 McCallum Street.

site_title: Keeping In Character
summary: An interactive theatre show, "The Ghost In Your Head," is set to premiere at Singapore Writers Festival, featuring characters from classic literature, including Miss Havisham, Mary Shelley, and Eileen Chang. The production, presented by Global Cultural Alliance, will recreate scenes from these novels, including a wedding breakfast and mahjong game. The show runs on November 8 at 7pm and 9:30pm at The Arts House.

site_title: Sterling rises on news UK, EU close to financial services deal
summary: The UK and EU are close to a Brexit deal on financial services, with British firms to have access to EU markets as long as financial regulation remains broadly aligned with Europe. This news led to a 1% surge in sterling against the US dollar and euro, and a 1% increase in the euro against the greenback. The agreement is seen as a significant step forward in the Brexit process, providing stability for UK businesses and potentially mitigating the economic impact of the UK's departure from the EU.

site_title: Drawing From The Past
summary: Singapore Design Archives, a history tour by Justin Zhuang, showcases the city's transformation from a fishing village to a modern city through its architecture, graphic design, and everyday objects, including restaurant menus. The archives, located at National Design Centre, feature a collection of materials, including books, ephemera, and objects, that provide insight into Singapore's design history and the ways in which design shapes the city's environment. The archives aim to make design more visible and appreciated by the public.

site_title: Cha-cha in a wheelchair - with faster beats
summary: Julie Chong, a determined Latin-ballroom dancer, will perform at a charity concert on November 8 to raise funds for muscular dystrophy and other causes. Chong, who uses a wheelchair, has been dancing since 2004 and finds high-tempo dances like cha-cha and samba most enjoyable. Despite having brittle bones, a rare condition, she aims to promote inclusiveness and showcase her talent, hoping the audience will see a "great show put up with a lot of heart."

site_title: Weird And Wonderful
summary: A new exhibition at the ArtScience Museum in Singapore celebrates the life and work of Nobel Prize-winning physicist Richard Feynman, marking the centenary of his birth. The show, titled "All Possible Paths: Richard Feynman's Curious Life," features personal items, documents, photographs, and artworks showcasing Feynman's passions, achievements, and contributions to quantum mechanics. The exhibition runs from November 1, 2018, to March 3, 2019, offering a unique glimpse into Feynman's colorful character and legacy.

site_title: Deutsche Boerse launches EEX Asia in Singapore
summary: Deutsche Boerse has launched EEX Asia in Singapore, revamping its Asian business to grow in the world's fastest-growing commodity markets. The exchange, a subsidiary of German-based EEX, will offer futures contracts on freight and seaborne commodities such as fuel oil and iron ore. The launch is part of Deutsche Boerse's global ambitions to become a leading commodities exchange, following the acquisition of US power and natural gas bourse Nodal Exchange in 2017. EEX Asia will initially focus on expanding its freight offerings, putting it in competition with the Baltic Exchange.

site_title: Brexit's demographic challenge
summary: A re-run of the 2016 Brexit referendum, held in March 2019, would likely result in a Remain majority, with the pro-Brexit bloc shrinking and the Remain bloc growing due to demographic changes. The death of over 1.4 million elderly voters and the arrival of 2.2 million young eligible voters would drastically narrow the gap between Leave and Remain voters. In a re-run, Remain would win by a margin of 369,501, compared to the actual 2016 majority of 1,269,501.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Manulife US Reit's distribution per unit (DPU) may be cut by 30% due to uncertainty over US tax reforms, but the potential cut is only 15% in the worst-case scenario. The Reit has measures to mitigate this risk. Meanwhile, CDL Hospitality Trust (CDLHT) reported a 1.3% year-on-year increase in Singapore hotel revenue per available room, driven by strong growth in leisure travelers. The company remains optimistic on its 2019 outlook and guides for the industry's RevPAR growth at 3-5%. CDLHT is considered a top pick for hospitality Reits due to its liquid proxy and high dividend yields.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: China Aviation Oil (CAO) reported a US$18.93 million profit for the third fiscal quarter, down 7.99% from the year-ago period. Revenue increased 21.24% to US$6.33 billion, driven by higher oil prices. Riverstone Holdings saw a 6.5% year-on-year drop in net income to RM32.1 million, while Moya Asia reported a 25% jump in net profit to S$6.9 million. Hock Lian Seng's net profit rose 55.7% to S$10.4 million, driven by higher revenue from the Changi Airport project.

site_title: SGX adds 10 more leveraged exposure products
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) is introducing 10 new leveraged exposure products (DLCs) linked to major stocks such as Singapore banks and Hong Kong-listed companies. The DLCs, which offer a 5x leverage, will be available on November 7, bringing the total to 38 DLCs. The new products provide investors with exposure to 10 single stocks, including DBS, OCBC, and Singtel, with lower entry barriers and potentially amplified returns.

site_title: The Real Deal
summary: Erdem Moralioglu, the Turkish-English fashion designer, is known for his sophisticated and ethereal designs that embody femininity and permanence. He creates his own fabrics and textiles, inspired by his love of women and his late mother, who was his inspiration. This season's collection is influenced by 1930s showgirl Adele Astaire, featuring floral frocks, tulle, and velvet numbers. Moralioglu's designs are a multi-faceted take on femininity, with contrasts and intellectual depth, and he is respected for his exquisite skirts and dresses. His success is driven by his obsessive mindset and strong work ethic, making him a rising star in the fashion world.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: US President Trump announced a 50% copper import tariff, covering refined metal. Oil prices rose over 2% amid market concerns and ongoing tariff threats. In the US, stocks edged down from records, while in Europe, stocks declined due to bank and healthcare sector issues, with US-EU tariffs in focus. Additionally, NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription, and Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall in the second half. London's Heathrow airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade.

site_title: AllianzGI to start new Asian private credit team based in Singapore
summary: Allianz Global Investors (AllianzGI) is launching an Asian private credit team based in Singapore, expanding its global private debt platforms. The team, led by Sumit Bhandari, will target mid-cap companies in Asia with senior secured debt and mezzanine financing strategies. The move is seen as an opportunity to tap into the region's growing private debt markets, which AllianzGI believes are "attractive fundamentals." The team's investment is expected to begin shortly, with Allianz as an initial investor.

site_title: China Calling
summary: Singapore chefs are seeking opportunities in China due to the country's growing demand for innovative dining experiences. Mainland Chinese investors are investing in new restaurant concepts and luring big names to their cities. Shanghai, Beijing, and Guangzhou are hubs for culinary innovation, with affluent customers willing to pay for unique meals. Recognizable Singaporean chefs, including Jereme Leung, Johnston Teo, Edward Voon, and Andre Chiang, are adapting their culinary styles to cater to Chinese tastes. They emphasize the importance of teamwork, understanding local tastes and eating habits, and reinventing oneself to stay relevant in the competitive Chinese market.

site_title: US home prices cool as sales slump in pricey western cities
summary: US home prices rose 4.8% to a median of $266,900 in the third quarter, but sales slowed due to higher mortgage rates and affordability issues. The West saw the biggest decline in home sales, with a 7.9% drop, while single-family home prices increased in 166 of 178 metropolitan areas. The inventory of home listings remains historically low, with a shortage of low- to mid-priced homes driving up prices in the high-end market.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims fall; productivity slows in Q3
summary: US weekly jobless claims fell to 214,000 for the week ended Oct 27, the lowest level since November 1969, as labor market conditions tightened further. Worker productivity slowed in Q3 to a 2.2% annualized rate, while hourly compensation jumped 3.5% due to rising employment costs. The number of people receiving benefits declined to 1.63 million, the lowest level since July 1973. Economists expect October's employment report to show a rebound in job growth, but tempered by Hurricane Michael's impact.

site_title: US indicts 1MDB's Low and ex-Goldman banker
summary: US authorities indicted Malaysian financier Low Taek Jho and former Goldman Sachs banker Ng Chong Hwa on charges of laundering billions of dollars in illegal proceeds from 1MDB. Tim Leissner, a former Goldman Sachs banker, pleaded guilty to laundering money and violating foreign bribery laws. Low remains at large, while Ng was arrested in Malaysia on a provisional arrest warrant.

site_title: Global Invacom pushes ahead with Tactilis acquisition despite dissent
summary: Global Invacom Group is pushing ahead with its proposed US$200 million acquisition of Tactilis, despite three dissenting directors on its board. The acquisition, valued at 200 million, is seen as a game-changer for Global Invacom, citing Tactilis' sophisticated technology and pipeline of customers. The deal, which includes a potential additional US$50 million payment if Tactilis meets a net profit target, has been met with skepticism due to Tactilis' losses and similar technology already available in the market.

site_title: Christopher Ong appointed new Singapore MD for DHL Express
summary: DHL Express has appointed Christopher Ong as managing director for DHL Express Singapore, effective immediately. Ong, a Singaporean, replaces Frank-Uwe Ungerer and brings 10 years of experience with Temasek Holdings and previous roles in Vietnam, Malaysia, and Brunei. He is expected to drive the B2C e-commerce and digitalisation agenda in Singapore, leveraging his business acumen and regional experience.

site_title: Yongnam secures 4 contracts worth S$53.4m
summary: Yongnam Holdings secured four Singapore-based contracts worth S$53.4 million. The contracts include a regional headquarters for AAC Optics Solutions, structural steelwork for a 51-storey integrated development, a nine-storey light industrial and commercial building, and a seven-storey Health Campus. These projects are expected to be completed by the first and second quarters of 2019, and are expected to positively impact the group's financial performance for the year ending Dec 31, 2018.

site_title: SingPost unit to dispose of stake in indirect associated company
summary: SingPost announced it will sell nearly 20 million shares in Indo Trans Logistics Corporation for S$38.3 million to Su Misura, resulting in no direct or indirect ownership. The sale does not significantly impact SingPost's net profits or earnings per share for the 2019 financial year.

site_title: Bank of England trims growth outlook, holds rates as Brexit looms
summary: The Bank of England trimmed its growth forecasts to 1.3% for 2018, citing slowing global economic growth, and maintained interest rates at 0.75% as Brexit approaches. The central bank also downgraded its 2019 growth forecast to 1.7% and warned that monetary policy could alter "in either direction" after Britain leaves the EU. The decision was made despite a post-Brexit financial services deal, and the forecasts are based on a smooth transition period, but markets remain uncertain about a chaotic no-deal Brexit.

site_title: Singapore firms show resurgent interest in Vietnam
summary: Singapore firms are showing renewed interest in Vietnam, driven by the country's rising middle class, business-friendly policies, and potential gains from the US-China trade tensions. The country's 6.8% growth last year and stable currency have made it an attractive destination for foreign direct investment. Vietnam's move up the value chain, skilled labor, and free-trade agreements have also made it an ideal location for manufacturers and tech companies. With support from Singapore's Enterprise Singapore, the number of Singapore firms expanding in Vietnam is increasing, with companies such as Standard Chartered, Doki Dokichose, and Ademco setting up operations in the country.

images.alt_text: Vietnam clocked 6.8 per cent growth last year, making it one of the fastest-growing economies. Its currency has been stable, and new laws and a crackdown on graft have improved the business environment.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher as strong earnings lift mood
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday, November 1, 2018, as strong earnings reports lifted risk sentiment. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.10%, the S&P 500 gained 0.22%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.30%. These gains followed a brutal October and came despite concerns about US-EU trade tensions. The positive earnings reports helped boost investor mood, leaving the market on a positive note.

site_title: Abbott wins FDA approval of much-anticipated insulin-monitor app
summary: Abbott Laboratories has received FDA approval for its FreeStyle LibreLink diabetes-monitoring app, allowing users to track glucose levels on their iPhones. The app is compatible with Abbott's FreeStyle Libre glucose sensors, which have become top-selling medical devices in the US. The approval marks a significant step for Abbott, with the company's diabetes unit experiencing a 37.4% sales increase in the third quarter. The app is free to download and enables users to view real-time glucose levels, assess their glucose history, and track changes.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust to acquire Vietnam warehouse for S$43m
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust is acquiring a warehouse in Vietnam's Southern key economic region for approximately S$43 million. The property, valued at 730 billion Vietnamese dong, will be leased to Unilever Vietnam for 10 years. The acquisition is expected to generate an initial net property income yield of 8.3% and be accretive at the distribution level. It will be funded by debt and completed by 4QFY18/19, with the trust's aggregate leverage ratio expected to increase to approximately 38.9%.

site_title: Encana to buy shale oil producer Newfield for US$5.5b
summary: Canada's Encana Corp agreed to purchase US shale producer Newfield Exploration Inc for US$5.5 billion, its largest-ever deal. The acquisition gives Encana positions in the Stack and Scoop shale fields in Oklahoma and the Bakken region of North Dakota, creating North America's second-largest shale explorer. The deal signals a shift for North American oil producers, reversing years of building pure-play drillers focused on single shale regions. Encana aims to expand its growth outside western Canada, where pipeline constraints have pressured crude prices, and promises significant investor benefits, including a 25% dividend increase.

site_title: Local biometrics startup Touché expands to the Middle East
summary: Touché, a Singaporean biometrics startup, has expanded to the Middle East with a letter of intent with Mashreq Bank in the UAE. The startup's fingerprint-based payment and loyalty management system will be offered to the bank's merchant clients, with potential pilot clients identified for delivery by Q1 2019. Touché plans a US$10 million raise to grow the team and expand markets, and has already partnered with SEED Group and OCBC Bank in the region.

site_title: US factory gauge slumps to six-month low amid trade war
summary: A US manufacturing gauge fell to a six-month low due to declining orders and hiring amid escalating trade tensions with China. The Institute for Supply Management reported the data, which may worsen concerns about President Trump's trade war with China. This follows reports of manufacturing slowdowns in other Asia-Pacific economies. The data contrasts with a positive stock market reaction after Trump's conversation with Chinese President Xi Jinping on trade.

site_title: Asia rice: Thailand eyes deals with Philippines, China; India demand tepid
summary: Thailand's rice export prices dropped this week due to a weaker baht, with benchmark 5% broken rice prices quoted at $380-$400 per tonne, a 4-5% decrease from last week. The country expects new deals with the Philippines and China before the end of the year, while India's rice export prices remained flat at 21-month lows. Thailand aims to meet its 11 million tonne rice export target before the end of the year.

site_title: Pfizer is weighing sale of $2 billion-women's health portfolio
summary: Pfizer is reviewing options to sell its $2 billion women's health portfolio, which includes menopause treatments such as Premarin, Prempro, and Premphase. The company is working with financial advisers to gauge interest from potential buyers, including private equity firms and rival pharmaceutical companies. The sale could fetch around $2 billion, and no final decision has been reached, with the possibility of retaining the assets. Pfizer declined to comment on speculation, citing that no decision has been made.

site_title: Carl Icahn sues Dell over plans to go public
summary: Activist investor Carl Icahn sued Dell Technologies over its plans to go public by buying back its tracking stock. Icahn, who owns 9.3% of Dell, alleges that the deal undervalues the tracking stock and is a "conflicted transaction" benefiting controlling stockholders at the expense of DVMT stockholders. Icahn claims the deal is a threat to force DVMT stockholders to vote in favor of the merger or face an unknown IPO conversion. Dell has not commented on the lawsuit.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 2.35 points to 1,706.92 on Thursday, closing lower. Volume was 2.2 billion lots worth RM1.7 billion. Gainers beat losers 434 to 364.

site_title: Chasen secures contract worth 50m yuan in Guangdong
summary: Chasen Holdings secured a 50 million yuan (S$9.9 million) contract to provide move-in and warehouse management services for an OLED display panel manufacturing plant in Guangdong, China. The Generation-8.5 OLED plant is the first and most advanced of its kind in China. Chasen's subsidiary will offer the services for seven months from October 2018 to April 2019, with the project expected to positively impact Chasen's financial results for its current year.

site_title: Dragon Group International to delist; Asti Holdings to make exit offer
summary: Dragon Group International, a subsidiary of Asti Holdings, will delist from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) due to rejection of a request for an extension of time to meet financial exit criteria. As the controlling shareholder, Asti Holdings must now make a cash exit offer to Dragon Group International's shareholders. Trading in Dragon Group International's securities has remained suspended since May 10, pending the completion of the exit offer.

site_title: Singapore shares end higher on Thursday
summary: Singapore shares ended higher on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index rising 1.4% to 3,060.85. About 2.33 billion shares changed hands, with OCBC, DBS, and UOB closing 3.8%, 2.1%, and 1.1% higher respectively. Gainers outnumbered losers 226 to 175, with Genting Singapore being the most actively traded stock.

site_title: Hock Lian Seng's 9-month net profit up 55.7%
summary: Hock Lian Seng, a civil engineering and construction firm, reported a 55.7% increase in its 9-month net profit to S$10.4 million, driven by higher revenue from the civil engineering segment. Revenue rose 77% to S$151.7 million, primarily from the Changi Airport project and property development. Earnings per share increased to 2.04 Singapore cents. The company's order book for ongoing projects was approximately S$675 million. Hock Lian Seng plans to continue tendering for infrastructure projects and explore other business opportunities to enhance shareholder value.

site_title: Sri Lanka's president to reconvene parliament on Nov 5, says new PM
summary: Sri Lanka's President Maithripala Sirisena plans to reconvene parliament on November 5, a move that could help resolve the country's ongoing political crisis. The decision comes after the dismissal of Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe and the appointment of Mahinda Rajapaksa as the new prime minister. The return of Rajapaksa has sparked concerns over fresh political and ethnic division, while Wickremesinghe has demanded the opportunity to prove his parliamentary majority. The move aims to alleviate uncertainty and prevent attempts by claimants to lure lawmakers with money and ministerial positions.

site_title: Lawrence Wong and Seck Wai Kwong join GIC board
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC has appointed two new board directors, Lawrence Wong, Minister for National Development and Second Minister for Finance, and Seck Wai Kwong, CEO of Asia-Pacific at State Street Bank and Trust Company. Wong joins the board on November 1, while Seck takes his position on November 9. Their expertise in economics and global investment markets is expected to enhance the fund's performance and risk profile. The appointments reflect GIC's commitment to strengthening its leadership and strategic direction.

site_title: Moya Asia reports 25% jump in Q3 profit, revenue stays flat
summary: Moya Asia reported a 25% jump in net profit after tax to S$6.9 million in Q3 2018, driven by a significant increase in "other gains" to S$8.3 million. Revenue remained flat at S$48.3 million. The company's managing director attributed the growth to improved distribution infrastructure and a rising trend in production. Moya Asia plans to expand its water treatment business in Indonesia through a two-pronged strategy of organic growth and mergers and acquisitions.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: OCBC Bank's digital transformation is yielding results, with customers increasing digital transactions and costs decreasing. StarHub plans to move services to fibre networks by July next year. The DesignSingapore Council will transfer to the Economic Development Board to drive business innovation and growth abroad. FLT acquired a Dutch freehold logistics property for €25.36m. Singapore shares ended higher on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index up 1.4% to 3,060.85. Globally, Vietnam was surprised by a US tariff announcement, while Malaysia is seizing assets from Daim Zainuddin, and China's GDP growth is expected to slow.

images.alt_text: The bank does not believe in focusing on digital banking, but believes in a digital transformation throughout the bank.

site_title: Riverstone Q3 profit slips on higher marketing expenses
summary: Riverstone Holdings reported a 6.5% year-on-year decline in net income to RM32.1 million for the third quarter, due to higher marketing expenses. The company's gross profit fell 9.2% and cost of sales increased 20.6%. Revenue rose 27.5% year-on-year to RM239.5 million. CEO Wong Teek Son expects an uptick in US healthcare glove orders after the US Pharmacopeia announces guidelines for stricter hygiene standards, set to come into effect in December 2019.

site_title: Thailand rate hike expected despite lower Oct inflation: Citi
summary: Thailand's central bank may hike interest rates despite lower October inflation, which came in at 1.23% year-on-year, below the consensus estimate of 1.3%. Core inflation was also lower at 0.75% year-on-year. Citi analyst Nalin Chutchotitham suggests a 25 bp rate hike at the upcoming Nov 14 meeting, citing policy normalization despite the lower inflation.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks slip on persistent trade concerns, won gains
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index fell 0.26% on November 1, 2018, amid persistent trade concerns between the US and China. The won rose against the dollar, while bond yields increased. Despite US President Trump's optimistic remark on trade, analysts expect limited impact on investor sentiment. Data showed factory activity expanded at a slower pace and exports beat estimates, but October headline inflation picked up. The won was quoted at 1,138.1 per dollar, while the KOSPI index is down 17.7% this year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares post second day of strong gains
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 1.75% on Thursday, driven by a solid lead from Wall Street and Beijing's pledge of support for the Chinese economy. The Hang Seng Index climbed to 25,416.00, while the Shanghai Composite Index edged up 0.13%. The rally follows a 1.60% gain on Wednesday.

site_title: Breaking down to build up
summary: Cisco CEO Chuck Robbins says it's the most exciting time ever for technology-driven organizations, as technology now drives strategy in every organization. After taking over in 2015, Robbins transformed Cisco's business model, shifting from hardware-centric to software-defined services, and successfully navigated disruptions like cloud computing and software-defined networks. He emphasizes the importance of staying focused on customer needs, embracing change, and being open to shifts in business models. Robbins believes that organizations must innovate differently using technology to deliver better customer and employee experiences and drive competitive differentiation. He highlights Cisco's efforts to change lives through education, housing initiatives, and socially responsible practices.

site_title: 2019's hottest Singapore jobs are analytics, data-driven roles
summary: Singapore's job market is expected to see stable growth in 2019, with top jobs in demand being analytical and data-driven. Key roles include data scientists, product management, UX designers, and cybersecurity professionals. Job movers can expect pay increments of 5-15% in 2019, with larger hikes for those with specialized skillsets in IT, digital, and financial services. Employers are also seeking HR professionals with experience in HR technologies and talent acquisition professionals for the technology sector. Competition is expected to intensify for specialists with international experience and niche skillsets.

site_title: Credit Suisse Q3 profit jumps 74%, lags estimates
summary: Credit Suisse reported a 74% year-on-year jump in Q3 net profit to 424 million Swiss francs, but missed estimates by 5 million francs. Operating expenses fell 2% more than a 2% decline in net revenues. The bank expects Wealth Management-related businesses to benefit from client-led growth in the final quarter.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse on Thursday posted a 74 per cent year-on-year jump in third-quarter net profit as operating expenses fell faster than a 2 per cent decline in net revenues.

site_title: US new home sales fall in October, missing projections
summary: US new home sales fell 8.9% in October to a 544,000 annualized pace, missing projections. Rising borrowing costs and elevated prices kept buyers out of the market, with single-family home sales declining across all four regions. The median sales price dropped 3.1% to $309,700, the lowest since February 2017. The supply of homes rose to 7.4 months, indicating improving supply, despite a cooling housing market.

site_title: UK house-price growth drops below 2% for first time since 2013
summary: The UK house-price growth has dropped below 2% for the first time since 2013, according to Nationwide Building Society. Average house prices rose 1.6% in October compared to the previous year, with the report citing stretched affordability and Brexit uncertainty as key factors. The Bank of England has signaled limited interest-rate increases, and Nationwide forecasts a 1% price rise this year, indicating a weakening housing market. This marks a significant slowdown in the market, which had experienced decades of booming prices.

site_title: Gearing up to fire off a second engine
summary: Expand Construction chief Von Lee Yong Miang emphasizes the importance of sustainability in infrastructure, likening his company to an aircraft carrier that needs to constantly expand and improve. He aims to build a second engine to boost the company's growth, despite not being in the shipbuilding trade.

site_title: Shell profits soar to four-year high
summary: Royal Dutch Shell's third-quarter profits rose to a four-year high, driven by 60% growth in cash generation from operations to $12.1 billion. Net income attributable to shareholders increased 39% to $5.624 billion, boosted by stronger oil and gas prices and trading operations. The company also launched a $25 billion share buyback program, completing its first tranche of $2 billion. Despite a 2% decline in oil and gas production, Shell's debt ratio decreased to 23.1% and the company remains confident in its future cash generation and profit growth outlook.

site_title: Go-Jek to enter Singapore this week, in challenge to Grab
summary: Go-Jek, a ride-hailing company, plans to launch a preliminary version of its app in Singapore on Thursday, entering the market in a challenge to arch-rival Grab. The move comes after Grab acquired Uber's Southeast Asian business, leading to complaints from users and drivers. Go-Jek's CEO, Nadiem Makarim, aims to introduce consumer- and driver-friendly policies, while Grab CEO Anthony Tan expects the competition to push the company to innovate. This is a significant milestone for Go-Jek, which has expanded from its home country of Indonesia and is valued at around $5 billion.

site_title: More choices, greater gains?
summary: Singapore's liberalization of previously sheltered markets has sparked debate over its effectiveness. The opening up of markets for goods such as public bus services, electricity, and hawker centers has led to increased efficiency and choice for consumers. However, the transition has also been marred by controversy, particularly in the hawker center sector, where privately operated centers have imposed onerous demands on hawkers. Experts argue that government involvement remains crucial in providing public goods and services, such as comprehensive route networks and grid reliability. Despite challenges, the liberalization of bus services and electricity retail has yielded positive results, with consumers enjoying lower bills and higher service levels.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.1% on Wednesday, closing at 3,094.48, with gains outnumbering losses 225 to 146. Ezion led the gainers, rising 40.48% to S$0.059, followed by Rex International's 7.35% gain to S$0.073. The rally came ahead of GDP data, with investors brushing off new Trump threats to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: SoftBank sets indicative IPO price at Y1,500 a share, unchanged from initial estimate
summary: SoftBank Corp has set an indicative price of 1,500 yen per share for its IPO, worth 2.4 trillion yen (S$29 billion), unchanged from the initial estimate. The deal aims to provide funds for debt repayment and investments in innovations. The final offer price will be determined on Dec 10 after a book-building process. The IPO is seen as a way for SoftBank to rebrand itself as a tech-driven growth company, despite concerns over demand and a mature image in Japan's domestic telecoms business.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open with losses on Tuesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened with losses on Tuesday, following a previous day's healthy gains. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.12% to 26,345.37, while the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.39% to 2,585.83. The news comes after US President Donald Trump announced he would ramp up trade tensions with China next year if no deal is reached.

site_title: Logitech ends negotiations to acquire Plantronics
summary: Logitech International SA has ended negotiations to acquire Plantronics Inc, a US maker of Bluetooth earpieces and gaming headsets, after discussions were terminated by Logitech's board. The talks, which began last week, aimed to conclude a potential deal but ultimately failed to progress. Plantronics offered no immediate comment on the decision.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand dollars find tenuous support ahead of trade test
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars found support on Monday as Asian markets steadied on hopes for progress on Sino-US tariffs at the upcoming G-20 meeting. The Australian dollar edged up to US$0.7242, while the kiwi hovered at US$0.6785. The currencies remain volatile ahead of the meeting, with a potential deal potentially lifting the Aussie to US$0.7400 in the short term. However, a lack of progress would be bearish for the currencies, particularly as concerns over the Chinese economy weigh on iron ore and coal prices.

site_title: Casino firm Landing says chairman back after assisting China probe
summary: Landing International Development Ltd chairman Yang Zhihui has resumed duties after assisting a China investigation, according to the company. Yang was absent since August 23, causing shares to plummet over 30% after Landing reported his unavailability. The company stated that its business and operations remained steady during his absence. Yang's involvement with Macau junket operators has raised concerns, particularly in relation to Landing's US$1.5 billion casino project in the Philippines, which was halted by authorities. The company did not provide details on the investigation.

site_title: About 100 Rohingya fleeing by boat sent back to Myanmar
summary: Nearly 100 Rohingya Muslims fleeing Myanmar were forced back to the country's Rakhine state after being detained at sea en route to Malaysia. The group, mostly under 18, was returned to camps in central Rakhine, where over 120,000 people have been confined since 2012. This is the third vessel seized and returned in two weeks, raising fears of a fresh refugee boat crisis. The Rohingya have been seeking safety and rights in Malaysia, but a repatriation deal has stalled due to their refusal to return until their safety is secured.

site_title: Noble's restructuring hangs in the balance amid investigations
summary: Singapore regulators launched a tripartite probe into Noble Group, a commodity firm, for suspected breaches of securities laws and accounting practices. The probe may derail Noble's hard-fought debt rescue plan, which includes a restructuring and listing on the Singapore Exchange. The company has stated it will cooperate with the investigation, but analysts express uncertainty over the timeline and potential consequences. Shareholders and creditors had previously approved the restructuring plan, but the probe may raise fresh concerns. The outcome of the investigation is unclear, and stakeholders may face uncertainty and potential losses.

site_title: CapBridge's 1exchange gets MAS nod to operate as one of Singapore's first private securities exchanges
summary: CapBridge's 1exchange has received approval from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) to operate as a regulated private securities exchange. This makes 1exchange one of Singapore's first private securities exchanges. The exchange aims to provide liquidity for private companies prior to an exit event, offering companies more control, flexibility, and lower costs compared to a public listing. CapBridge will offer an integrated suite of private capital services, enhancing capital flow for growth companies and improving liquidity options for private investors.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower after Trump's tariff threat
summary: US stocks opened lower on Tuesday after President Donald Trump threatened additional tariffs on Chinese goods, dampening hopes of resolving the ongoing trade spat at the upcoming G20 Summit. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.34%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.36%, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.57%. The market decline follows recent record highs, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite ongoing trade tensions.

site_title: Vietnam's Bamboo Airways books maiden flight
summary: Bamboo Airways, Vietnam's fifth carrier, is set to launch its maiden domestic flight on December 29, connecting Hanoi with Quy Nhon, with plans to expand to 40-50 planes by the end of 2019. The airline aims to rival market leader VietJet Aviation JSC and operate international flights to South Korea and Japan in the second quarter. Bamboo has secured a business licence and is awaiting an air operator's certificate, which it expects to receive soon. The airline has leased aircraft and signed deals with Airbus and Boeing to purchase planes, sparking skepticism about its rapid expansion plans.

site_title: Heavy rains lash Sydney, prompting chaos
summary: Heavy rains in Sydney, Australia, caused widespread chaos on November 27, 2018, with over a month's worth of rain falling in just a few hours. Flights were cancelled, railway lines closed, and motorists stranded on flooded roads. At least 3,500 people lost power, and emergency services received at least six flood rescue requests. Residents were advised to use caution and avoid driving into flooded roads, which can be deadly. The rain was expected to slow but continue throughout the day, highlighting Australia's vulnerability to extreme weather.

site_title: Race to stand out on London's skyline
summary: Architect Norman Foster's studio has submitted a formal planning application for the 305m-tall Tulip, a glass tower inspired by the Gherkin, to be built in London. Construction could begin in 2020, with a proposed opening in 2025. The tower will feature viewing platforms, restaurants, and a bar, as well as an interactive exhibition on London's history. The project aims to revitalize the city's skyline and comes as an optimistic statement about London's future amidst Brexit uncertainty.

site_title: The dearth of engineers
summary: Singapore faces a shortage of engineers, with the ratio of males to females in the field being about three to one. The country is trying to attract more women and graduates into the profession through higher salaries and a structured career path. Despite this, many engineering graduates opt for careers in other sectors, citing factors such as limited job prospects, unattractive pay, and the perception of the profession as unglamorous. The government is also exploring ways to hire foreign engineers to supplement the local talent pool, with companies such as Surbana Jurong Consultants attracting talent with major infrastructure projects.

site_title: Vietnam has big plans for its bond market
summary: Vietnam aims to increase its bond market size to 45% of GDP by 2025 and 65% by 2030, with a roadmap to modernize the market and improve its infrastructure. The market currently stands at 20% of GDP, with government bonds dominating the market. However, gaps in disclosure requirements, regulation, liquidity, and secondary trading need to be addressed. The market faces challenges such as a limited institutional investor base, inadequate disclosure requirements, and deficiencies in the offering and issuance process for corporate bonds. Reforms are underway, including new laws and amendments to improve the bond market and broader financial market.

site_title: One Home for All
summary: A Singaporean businessman, Michael Mun, has built a unique two-story house with a concrete bridge connecting it to another house on the same plot, allowing his family to live in close proximity while maintaining their individuality. Designed by Chan Loo Siang of Inte Architects, the houses share a seamless flow and incorporate cross-ventilation and natural light. The design features a dark grey and light grey concrete finish, with the second house having a Japanese touch. The large windows and glass lift facilitate easy communication between family members, while the houses offer ample space for the family to grow.

site_title: CapBridge-backed 1exchange gets go-ahead to operate private securities exchange
summary: CapBridge-backed 1exchange has received approval from the Monetary Authority of Singapore to operate a regulated private securities exchange. This makes it one of the first private exchanges in Singapore, designed to facilitate liquidity for private companies before an exit event. The exchange will offer companies more control, flexibility, and lower costs compared to public listings, while also providing alternative growth options for investors.

site_title: South Korean workers in nationwide strike over labour policies
summary: Tens of thousands of South Korean workers, including those in the auto industry, launched a half-day strike nationwide, accusing the government of rolling back pro-labour policies amid economic woes. The strike, led by the Korean Confederation of Trade Unions, aims to protest the government's move to increase flexibility in the maximum 52-hour work week and demands the implementation of the promised minimum wage increase to 10,000 won by 2020. The strike, involving around 160,000 workers, has affected major cities, including Seoul, with protesters wearing red headbands and chanting slogans.

site_title: Entrepreneurial Zen
summary: Silicon Valley remains the world's top startup hub, according to Zendesk's Mikkel Svane, who attributes its success to the region's favorable environment and favorable weather. Svane, a frequent traveler to Zendesk's 15 offices worldwide, emphasizes the importance of time management, stating that excessive travel can be detrimental to productivity. Despite his busy schedule, Svane believes Silicon Valley's unique combination of talent, resources, and climate continues to attract entrepreneurs and drive innovation.

site_title: Singapore non-oil exports grow for 5th quarter in a row in Q3, posts 8% jump
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) grew 8% in Q3, marking the fifth consecutive quarter of growth. Total trade rose 14.7% in the third quarter, with services trade up 3.0%. Enterprise Singapore revised its 2018 forecasts to 9.0-9.5% for trade and 5.5-6.0% for NODX, citing improved oil prices and higher base effects. However, the agency expects 2019 growth to be between zero and 2.0% due to easing growth in key trade partners.

site_title: Tycoon Mistry plans US$1b share offer amid rare asset sales
summary: India's Shapoorji Pallonji Group, owned by billionaire Pallonji Mistry, plans to raise $1 billion by selling 30% of its solar unit, Sterling & Wilson Pvt. The funds will be raised through a pre-listing stake sale and public offering, with part of the proceeds used to reduce debt. The group also plans to sell its water purification unit, Eureka Forbes Ltd, and commercial real estate, with the goal of raising $30 billion by March 2019. The move aims to tap the market at a time when debt funding is scarce and to capitalize on India's infrastructure spending plans.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close down; Nissan plunges over 5%
summary: Tokyo stocks dropped on Tuesday, with Nissan shares plummeting over 5% and Mitsubishi also falling. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 1.09% to close at 21,583.12. The arrest of Nissan chairman Carlos Ghosn over allegations of financial misconduct was cited as a major factor. The broader Topix index also declined 0.73%.

site_title: SATS moves to target fast-casual restaurants, aviation sector in China
summary: SATS, a Singapore-based ground-handling and in-flight catering service provider, is expanding its operations in China by building a central kitchen in Tianjin. The move aims to target fast-casual restaurants and the aviation sector, with construction expected to be completed within two years. SATS will acquire full control of a joint venture with commodities firm Wilmar International, while Wilmar will acquire full control of another joint venture. The investments are subject to regulatory approvals and will be funded through internal resources.

site_title: Britain's Brexit minister Raab quits
summary: Britain's Brexit minister Dominic Raab resigned on November 15, 2018, in protest against Prime Minister Theresa May's draft EU divorce deal, citing concerns over the integrity of the UK and the potential for an indefinite backstop arrangement. Raab stated that the arrangement would severely prejudice the UK's future negotiations with the EU. His resignation came after a five-hour Cabinet meeting where senior ministers were divided over the proposals.

site_title: Oil price now controlled by just three men
summary: Three men - US President Donald Trump, Russian President Vladimir Putin, and Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Mohammed Bin Salman - are now in control of the global oil market, potentially determining oil prices in 2019 and beyond. Despite OPEC's struggles to find common purpose, the US, Russia, and Saudi Arabia dominate global supply, producing more oil than the 15 OPEC members. The trio can increase production, but their decisions may not align, leading to a potential glut in the oil market.

site_title: Cheers as Mars InSight spacecraft lands on Red Planet
summary: The NASA InSight spacecraft successfully landed on Mars on November 26, 2018, marking the eighth successful landing on the planet in NASA's history. The $993 million spacecraft, designed to study quakes and tremors on Mars, touched down on the Martian surface after a nearly seven-year journey. Initial communications indicated the vehicle was in good shape, with some minor issues, but the French seismometer and other instruments are ready to begin studying the planet's interior.

images.alt_text: Cheers and applause erupted at Nasa's Jet Propulsion Laboratory on Monday as a waist-high unmanned lander, called InSight, touched down on Mars, capping a nearly seven-year journey from design to launch to landing.

site_title: Indonesia posts larger-than-expected trade deficit in October
summary: Indonesia posted a larger-than-expected trade deficit of $1.82 billion in October, driven by a 23.66% surge in imports to $17.62 billion and a 3.59% increase in exports to $15.80 billion. The deficit was higher than the expected $170 million surplus in September. This marks the country's struggle to address increasing imports and support the rupiah, which has lost 8% of its value against the dollar this year.

site_title: US: Dollar, yields slide on Fed official rate talk
summary: The US dollar weakened and Treasury yields slid on Friday after a top Federal Reserve official, Richard Clarida, said US interest rates were near a neutral rate, indicating a possible dovish stance by the Fed. The S&P 500 ended positive despite a seesaw session, boosted by optimism over US-China trade ties. Oil prices steadied but posted losses for the sixth straight week, while sterling volatility increased due to uncertainty over Britain's exit from the EU.

site_title: Latest profit misses trigger flurry of downgrades for Singapore stocks
summary: Singapore stocks saw a flurry of downgrades following September-quarter corporate earnings, with telcos getting the worst revisions. Banks were the only consistent performers, while electronics, property, and consumer sectors posted disappointing or mixed results. Venture Corp, Golden Agri-Resources, Singtel, and Hutchison Port Holdings Trust suffered the biggest cuts in consensus earnings. Analysts trimmed forecasts for electronics manufacturer Hi-P International and Valuetronics due to trade tensions. Despite this, banks remain a prime pick, with analysts favoring stocks with defensive earnings and strong cash flow/balance sheet themes.

site_title: Strength in a sari
summary: Bangladeshi entrepreneur Durreen Shahnaz, founder of the world's first social stock exchange, Impact Investment Exchange (IIX), aims to take impact investing from the margins to the mainstream. Born in Bangladesh during the Liberation War, Shahnaz defied societal norms and pursued higher education in the US, where she developed a passion for creating inclusive markets. She joined Morgan Stanley as the first Bangladeshi woman on Wall Street, and later worked at Grameen Bank, where she saw the potential of microfinance to empower women. Shahnaz's vision led to the creation of the world's first social stock exchange, which has issued a US$8 million Women's Livelihood Bond, and plans to issue more bonds to fund sustainable development projects. She hopes to tap US$1 billion in private sector capital to benefit 100 million people by 2020, and launch more Women's Health Bonds to address gaps in women's health services.

site_title: North Korea 'tests high-tech new weapon': report
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un supervised the successful testing of a "high-tech" new weapon, according to the country's state media. The test was seen as a significant development, potentially undermining recent diplomatic efforts between North Korea and the US. The test's specifics were not disclosed, but its success casts doubt on the future of the denuclearization process, which has stalled due to disagreements over the meaning of a vague agreement signed by Trump and Kim in June.

site_title: Commodities are sending a distressing signal
summary: Commodity prices, particularly oil and copper, are sending a distressing signal of a global economic slowdown. The price of crude oil has collapsed by over 25% since its four-year high in October, and copper prices are also falling, suggesting weakening demand and supply chain issues. Weakening demand is evident in the contraction of Japan and Germany's economies, and monetary policy divergence between countries, including the US and Europe, is contributing to the decline. Investors are advised to reallocate assets to high-grade fixed income securities as a precaution against a slowing economy.

site_title: Australia's bank chiefs to face the music as misconduct inquiry wraps up
summary: Australia's top bank CEOs, Matt Comyn of Commonwealth Bank and Mike Wilkins of AMP, will testify at a public inquiry into financial-sector misconduct starting in two weeks. The inquiry, led by retired High Court judge Kenneth Hayne, has heard of widespread wrongdoing, including fee-gouging and bribery. The CEOs' appearances come after the firms admitted to misconduct and promised to repair trust with the community. The inquiry's final report, due in February, may recommend charges, penalties, and sweeping reforms to the financial sector, including separating consumer and shareholder interests.

site_title: Air India operations director stopped from piloting flight after failing breath tests
summary: Air India operations director Arvind Kathpalia was stopped from piloting a flight to London after failing two breathalyzer tests, marking the second time he has been in trouble over alcohol tests. Kathpalia denies drinking and claims the tests were related to internal feuding within the airline. He was suspended for three months in 2017 for allegedly refusing breathalyzer tests. Kathpalia contests the results and claims he is being targeted due to his role in the merger of Air India and Indian Airlines.

site_title: Fintech jigsaw pieces falling into place
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is pushing for the use of artificial intelligence (AI) in the financial sector to increase efficiency, reduce risks, and promote financial inclusion. MAS managing director Ravi Menon believes that AI can help banks manage risks better and speed up approval processes for credit applications. The authority is also working with Asean to spur financial innovation and inclusion, with plans to standardize QR codes for e-payments and open up the interbank payment rails to fintech operators. MAS expects to use data analytics and AI to detect suspicious transactions and monitor possible collusive activities in the stock market.

site_title: Singapore condo resale prices slip for 3rd month with 0.4% drop in October: SRX
summary: Singapore condo resale prices declined for the third consecutive month in October with a 0.4% drop, following the latest property cooling measures. This marks a reversal from the 12-month run to new highs before August. Despite a 3.7% increase in resale units sold in October, the market remains lacklustre, with a 53% decrease in volume compared to last year. The gap between buyer and seller expectations continues to widen, leading to slower sales and property viewings, especially during the year-end holiday season.

site_title: Trade tensions continue to depress Asian markets
summary: Asian markets ended a choppy week lower, following US markets as investors turned their attention to the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes and the ongoing trade war. Despite relief over the midterm elections, sentiments remained pessimistic due to the US President's trade war agenda and its support from both political parties. Markets declined in Hong Kong, China, Japan, Australia, and Malaysia, with the Straits Times Index falling 0.49% to end at 3,077.97.

site_title: Startups: Finland's ray of light
summary: Finland has transformed into a hotbed for startups in the last decade, despite its risk-conservative nature. The country's growing public support, welfare state, and strong government support have enabled startups to thrive. Key factors include the decline of Nokia's mobile phone business, which inspired engineers to start their own companies, and the rise of Slush, a student-run startup and tech event. The government's initiatives, such as Business Finland, have funded around 800 startups annually, providing grants and loans to support early-stage companies. Finland's comprehensive welfare system, including universal healthcare and free education, has also made it easier for young people to take risks and pursue entrepreneurial ventures.

images.alt_text: FINLAND'S RAY OF LIGHT: How the small, risk-conservative nation became a hotbed for startups.
NEW HOPE FOR FINLAND: How the small, risk-conservative nation became a hotbed for startups.
Maria 01, a startup and venture capital club housing more than 90 startups occupying 10,000 sq m of space in a former hospital in Helsinki.
Startup Sauna, a co-working space for startups at Aalto University in Finland.
Slush, a worldwide startup and tech event originating in Finland, was held for the third time this year in Singapore.

site_title: MAS files police report against author of 'baseless and defamatory' 1MDB-related article
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has filed a police report against the author of an article published on the States Times Review website, accusing the piece of being "baseless and defamatory" regarding 1MDB-related allegations. The article claimed Malaysia had signed unfair agreements with Singapore in exchange for laundering funds for 1Malaysia Development Berhad. MAS stated the article ignored their actions against Singapore-based banks and bankers in the 1MDB case, and made false allegations about Singapore reopening its investigations.

site_title: Myth of China's forced technology transfer
summary: China's technology transfer requirements, a major point of contention in US-China trade, are not as coercive as claimed. While Chinese authorities require foreign companies to share technology with local partners, this is a standard practice that helps secure better deals and access to the Chinese market. The transferred technology is factored into foreign direct investment (FDI) and reflects in companies' continued profitability. China's technological capabilities have grown significantly, making the need for forced technology transfer less pressing. In reality, recorded royalties payments from China to foreign companies have skyrocketed, indicating that technology transfer is becoming increasingly voluntary.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday due to lingering concerns over global economic growth. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.55% and the Topix index dropped 0.50%. China's flagging growth and recent factory gate inflation wobble weighed on global equities and commodities. Investors were also watching corporate earnings reports and July-September GDP figures. Automakers, such as Honda and Toyota, and China-related shares, including Komatsu and Fanuc, declined. The dollar traded at 113.86 yen, while oil prices slid.

site_title: PM Lee, Mahathir reaffirm strong ties between Singapore and Malaysia
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad reaffirmed the strong ties between the two nations, noting their extensive economic interdependence and geographical proximity. They emphasized the importance of their bilateral relationship, which is strengthened by cultural and historical bonds. The two leaders also highlighted their mutual interest in each other's development and success, with Lee noting that Singapore and Malaysia are each other's second-largest trading partners.

site_title: China Oct loan data disappoints, signals further slowing
summary: China's credit growth slowed sharply in October, with banks extending 697 billion yuan in net new yuan loans, less than expected. This signals further weakening in the economy, with total social financing and money supply growth hitting record lows. The slowdown is attributed to companies' reluctance to make fresh investments due to uncertainties about demand, and US tariffs on Chinese goods. This marks a tightening of credit conditions in China, despite recent easing in monetary policy.

site_title: UK house price indicator drops to six-year low
summary: UK house prices have dropped to a six-year low, according to the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS). The indicator fell to -10 in October, its lowest since 2012, with the sharpest declines in London and southeast England. Direct measures of house prices show the weakest growth in over five years, with sales volumes flat or negative across the UK. The decline is attributed to uncertainty about the economic outlook due to Brexit negotiations, with higher purchase taxes on expensive homes also contributing to the slowdown.

site_title: AMTD sees S'pore as regional gateway
summary: Hong Kong-based financial services firm AMTD Group sees Singapore as a key regional gateway to tap into the Asean market and expand its business. AMTD aims to leverage its role as a grand sponsor of the Singapore FinTech Festival to connect with players in the country and region. The company's chairman, Calvin Choi, believes that Singapore and Hong Kong can benefit from each other, with AMTD looking to help Singaporean and Asean companies tap opportunities in the Greater Bay Area, while also expanding its own business into the region.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower on profit-taking
